reasoning: This is a walking gait pattern performed over distance at a recovery pace. Primary joint actions are cyclic hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane producing forward progression. Secondary actions include pelvic/trunk axial rotation and contralateral arm swing at the shoulder (sagittal/transverse), and frontal-plane hip stabilization during single-leg support. Propulsion and support are produced primarily by the glutes, hamstrings and triceps surae, with quadriceps and tibialis anterior controlling swing and foot placement. Core and hip abductors (gluteus medius) provide balance and frontal-plane stability throughout the single-leg stance phases.
notes: Recovery-paced walking is a pure locomotion pattern. On uneven terrain, with a load, or with asymmetric carrying variations, add CARRY and/or ANTI_ROTATION. Emphasis during analysis: single-leg support mechanics and frontal-plane hip stability (gluteus medius) for injury prevention.

reasoning: Running is a repetitive locomotor gait task. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane with cyclical hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension producing stance push-off and swing-phase limb advancement. Shoulder flexion/extension and trunk axial rotation occur as secondary, coordinated arm-trunk movements to balance momentum. Muscles of the posterior chain and plantarflexors generate propulsion while hip flexors and dorsiflexors control swing; core and hip abductors stabilize the pelvis during single-leg support.

notes: Classification assumes typical forward running gait. Variations (sprint vs jog, incline/decline, barefoot vs shod) alter muscle demands and joint loading. Single-leg stance phase increases demand on hip abductors and core stability; no external load so CARRY/ANTI_ROTATION not included.

reasoning: Running is a locomotion pattern characterized by repetitive single-leg support and flight phases. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: hip cyclic flexion (swing) and powerful extension (push-off), knee flexion (swing) and extension (stance/push-off), and ankle dorsiflexion (swing/landing) and plantarflexion (push-off). Arm swing produces reciprocal shoulder flexion/extension and contributes to transverse-plane counter-rotation for balance. Stabilization demands include frontal- and transverse-plane control of the pelvis and trunk (glute medius, obliques, erector spinae) during single-leg stance and absorption of ground reaction forces at the ankle/knee/hip. In a 'final push' intensity increases demand for greater hip and ankle power and elastic rebound from the plantarflexors and Achilles complex.
notes: Intensity/technique variations change emphasis: sprinting shifts toward greater hip/ankle power and sagittal-plane force production; fatigue or poor mechanics increases frontal/transverse stabilization demands (hip abductors, obliques). No external load or asymmetric loading—classifies cleanly as LOCOMOTION.

reasoning: Running is a cyclical locomotor pattern: primary joint actions are repetitive sagittal-plane hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension producing forward propulsion and stride. Arm swing produces sagittal plane shoulder flexion/extension to counterbalance lower-limb motion. The trunk undergoes transverse-plane rotation and requires isometric anti-rotational control to transfer force and stabilize the pelvis over a single stance limb. Primary movers (glutes, hamstrings, quads, plantarflexors) generate propulsion; core and hip abductors/obliques control trunk/pelvic alignment and resist rotation during stance.
notes: Endurance-focused locomotion. Variations (sprinting, uphill, interval work) change force/ROM demands and increase concentric power or eccentric loading. Footstrike, cadence and surface alter muscle timing and joint loading.

reasoning: Walking is a repetitive gait/locomotion pattern driven primarily by cyclical hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane with accompanying pelvic rotation in the transverse plane and frontal-plane hip stabilization. Primary joint actions are hip extension during push-off and hip flexion during swing, knee flexion during swing and extension during stance, and ankle plantarflexion at push-off with dorsiflexion during swing. Glute medius and other hip abductors provide frontal-plane single-leg stabilization. The trunk and core act isometrically to maintain posture and transfer energy; arm swing produces small shoulder sagittal-plane motion for counterbalance. extension during stance, flexion during swing

reasoning: A long-distance run is a sustained locomotion pattern composed of repeated gait cycles (stance and swing). exercise: 30 sec static hold with 70 lb sand duffel

reasoning: Primary joint demands are isometric loading of the shoulder complex and forearms with the body suspended from the hands. The exercise is primarily a vertical pull pattern performed isometrically: the shoulder girdle performs active scapular depression and partial retraction to hold the body, the glenohumeral joints are in end-range flexion/overhead position under load, and the elbows are held in full extension. Grip variation (pronated/supinated/neutral) changes forearm and elbow loading but does not change the primary PULL classification.

reasoning: The advanced kettlebell windmill is primarily a single‑arm loaded hip hinge with simultaneous controlled spinal rotation and lateral flexion. Primary joint actions: the hips perform a hinge (hip flexion) as the torso folds toward the femur while the spine undergoes contralateral rotation and ipsilateral lateral flexion to reach toward the foot. The shoulder is held in an overhead abducted/externally rotated lock (isometric) and the elbow is typically extended. Muscles producing the hinge are the gluteus maximus and hamstrings; trunk rotation and lateral flexion are produced by the external/internal obliques, erector spinae and quadratus lumborum; the overhead arm is stabilized by the deltoids, rotator cuff, trapezius and serratus anterior. Because the load is unilateral and the torso must resist unwanted collapse/rotation while moving, the pattern includes both ROTATION (active trunk rotation/lateral flexion) and ANTI_ROTATION (isometric resisting of secondary rotational torque) in addition to the HINGE.
notes: Advanced unilateral loaded pattern combining hip hinge and thoracic/trunk rotation with high demand on shoulder stability and anti‑rotational core control. Requires thoracic mobility, hamstring length and robust rotator cuff/shoulder stability. Variations/progressions: reduce ROM, use lighter weight, or perform strict RDL + separate anti‑rotation hold before full windmill.

reasoning: Primary action is a unilateral vertical push (overhead shoulder elevation) produced by shoulder elevation and elbow extension in the sagittal plane. The cable/resistance is applied unilaterally and alternated, creating a rotational torque about the spine that requires isometric anti-rotation from the core and hip stabilizers. reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal push performed unilaterally/alternating from a supine (floor) position. Because the press is performed one arm at a time, an external rotational moment is applied to the trunk that must be resisted isometrically, so anti-rotation core control is a key secondary demand. Scapular movement is limited by the floor (reduced protraction/retraction range), so serratus anterior and rotator cuff act to stabilize the scapula and glenohumeral joint while obliques and contralateral lats resist transverse-plane rotation; hips/glutes and legs provide isometric lower-body stabilization.

Variations (dumbbell, kettlebell, bodyweight single-arm push-up from knees) maintain the same primary patterns.

Primary movers are the posterior chain producing extension, while traps/deltoids and elbow flexors contribute to the upward pull. reasoning: Primary movement is elbow extension in the sagittal plane against band resistance — a single-joint, elbow-dominant pushing action. The triceps (long, lateral, medial heads) produce concentric extension while the anconeus assists. The shoulder and scapulothoracic apparatus are held quasi-isometric to fix proximal position (rotator cuff, anterior deltoid, pecs, scapular retractors/protractors) and the core/spine works isometrically to maintain torso posture. Performed supine with elbows moving toward/away from the head places the movement within a horizontal push context, but the primary joint action remains elbow extension.
notes: Variation notes: performed supine/bench = horizontal PUSH context; standing/leaning variants may increase shoulder/scapular stabilization demand. Single-arm band skull crushers add anti-rotation/carry-style core demand and should include ANTI_ROTATION in movements if unilateral/asymmetric loading is used.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are transverse-plane shoulder horizontal abduction (pulling the band toward the face) combined with shoulder external rotation and scapulothoracic retraction (scapular adduction). Elbow flexion occurs secondarily to draw the hand toward the face. The movement is a horizontal pulling pattern that emphasizes posterior shoulder and scapular stabilizer activation for shoulder health. Core and thoracic extensors provide isometric trunk stabilization while the scapular retractors (middle trapezius, rhomboids) and external rotators (infraspinatus, teres minor, posterior deltoid) produce the primary movement.

joint_actions.action: horizontal abduction (transverse pull) and external rotation

notes: Light band face-pulls are a shoulder-health/horizontal-pull accessory emphasizing scapular retraction and external rotation. Variations (single-arm or heavier bands) may add anti-rotation or greater elbow demand. Cue thoracic extension and scapular squeeze; avoid excessive load that substitutes with lumbar extension or anterior shoulder elevation.

reasoning: Primary movement is large-range glenohumeral elevation/forward flexion (moving the arms overhead) and extension/horizontal abduction as the band is carried behind the body — mechanically similar to an unloaded vertical push through the shoulder. There is also substantial transverse-plane humeral rotation and horizontal sweep of the arms, and continuous scapulothoracic upward rotation for overhead travel, so a rotation/transverse-plane component is included. The elbows remain mostly extended and the thoracic spine/shoulder girdle must extend and mobilize to allow the arc. Stabilization demands are primarily rotator‑cuff activity to center the humeral head, serratus anterior and trapezius for scapular control, and anterior shoulder/pectoral tissues are stretched under eccentric control.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: extension / horizontal abduction (bringing arms behind body)
external rotation/internal rotation (humeral rotation through arc)

notes: Mobility drill rather than a loaded push; classification as PUSH is based on primary shoulder elevation mechanics (vertical push analogue). Variations: narrower grip or bent elbows reduce required glenohumeral ROM; using a dowel versus band changes resistance/tension but not primary movement pattern. Caution with shoulder pathology — perform with controlled range and scapular control.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal pulling action of the shoulder complex: scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction) and glenohumeral horizontal abduction with concurrent external rotation as the band is drawn toward the face. The elbows flex to bring the hands inward. The spine remains relatively neutral and acts isometrically to stabilize the torso. Thus the dominant pattern is a horizontal PULL emphasizing posterior shoulder and upper-back musculature and scapular control.
notes: Anchor height and hand position alter emphasis: higher anchor/rope flare increases external rotation and posterior deltoid activation; elbows kept high emphasize posterior delts, elbows lower emphasize mid-traps/rhomboids. Single-arm or asymmetric variations introduce anti-rotation demands on the core.

reasoning: Primary joint action occurs at the glenohumeral joint: the arms travel through shoulder flexion/abduction to elevation and then into extension/horizontal abduction as the band is moved from front to back — with concurrent glenohumeral external rotation. Scapulothoracic motion (upward rotation, posterior tilt, some retraction) accompanies humeral elevation. The action is performed against band tension (a pulling vector) so primary pattern is a pull-type shoulder movement; because the humerus externally rotates through the arc, include ROTATION. Stabilization requires isometric elbow extension and thoracic control (postural/extension) while scapular stabilizers control the scapular rhythm.
primary_muscles: Rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor, supraspinatus, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: flexion / elevation then extension / horizontal abduction

notes: Primarily a shoulder mobility/drill rather than a strength push/pull — resistance band changes load direction. Variations (wide/narrow grip, passive vs active) alter the degree of glenohumeral rotation and scapular demand. Caution with limited shoulder ROM or pathology; maintain thoracic extension to facilitate scapular upward rotation.

reasoning: The exercise is a loaded gait-like lateral/diagonal stepping pattern performed with a miniband around the lower limbs. The primary moving joint is the hip performing repeated abduction/adduction in the frontal plane (stepping laterally/diagonally) with maintenance of a partial squat posture (hip and knee flexion) in the sagittal plane. Hip external rotation is often present as the band biases the femur laterally. The band creates resistance to stepping so the gluteus medius/minimus (hip abductors) produce concentric abduction on the working step and eccentrically control adduction on the return. The partial squat posture means quadriceps and gluteus maximus act isometrically to maintain knee/hip flexion while the core and lateral trunk musculature stabilize the spine and resist unwanted rotation. Because it is a stepping/walking pattern under load, it primarily maps to LOCOMOTION; the sustained low stance is a secondary SQUAT demand for knee/hip flexion stability.
notes: Band placement (ankle vs just above knees) changes hip abductor torque and degree of knee/hip flexion demand. Can be performed laterally, forward/backward (monster-walk), or with varying band tension to emphasize abduction control or general warm-up activation.

exercise: Band face-pull (pause at full external rotation)
reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal/face pull of the shoulder complex: active glenohumeral horizontal abduction (pulling the hands toward the face) with pronounced glenohumeral external rotation and scapular retraction. The band-resisted pull places the action in the transverse plane and emphasizes scapular adduction (retraction) and posterior shoulder external rotators. Elbow flexion is present but secondary. Trunk and hips act isometrically to stabilize the torso while the shoulder complex and scapulothoracic joint produce the movement.
notes: Pausing at full external rotation increases demand on the posterior rotator cuff and scapular retractors. Maintain neutral spine and avoid excessive thoracic extension or shoulder elevation; use a band tension that allows controlled external rotation without compensatory scapular shrug.

reasoning: Primary joint actions occur at the shoulder and scapulothoracic joint: horizontal posterior pull (shoulder horizontal abduction/transverse plane) combined with external rotation of the glenohumeral joint. Elbow flexion is present but secondary. Scapular retraction (adduction) and slight upward rotation occur to allow shoulder external rotation and posterior shoulder activation. Muscles producing the movement include posterior deltoid and rotator cuff external rotators (infraspinatus, teres minor) driving external rotation, and middle/lower trapezius and rhomboids producing scapular retraction. Core and thoracic posture are isometrically maintained to keep an upright torso during the band pull. As a warm-up mobility exercise, loads are low and emphasis is on scapular mechanics and rotator cuff activation rather than maximal force production.
notes: Typically performed as a horizontal pull focused on scapular retraction and external rotation; keep load light for warm-up. Cue high elbow/rope to optimize external rotation and lower trap activation. Avoid heavy loads that convert the movement into a stronger elbow-dominant row.

reasoning: Primary motion occurs at the glenohumeral joint as the arms move from front to overhead and behind the torso (shoulder flexion into extension/horizontal abduction) with concurrent humeral rotation. Scapulothoracic joints undergo upward rotation, posterior tilt and protraction/retraction to allow the path of the band/stick. Thoracic spine extension/mobility is also engaged to permit the posterior travel. Because the arms move posteriorly against band tension and the action includes humeral/scapular rotation, the pattern is best represented as a pulling/scapular-control action plus rotational/multi-planar shoulder motion. Stabilization demands include isometric activation of rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids) to guide the humeral head and control scapular position through the range.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (infraspinatus, supraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
notes: Grip width and band tension alter the demand and plane emphasis (wider grip increases humeral rotation requirement). Single-arm or asymmetric variations add anti-rotation/core demands. Use caution with existing shoulder impingement or instability; thoracic mobility limitations will change movement quality.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane producing upward movement of the bar; the biceps also contributes to forearm supination (transverse plane) with a supinated grip. The shoulder and scapula act primarily as isometric stabilizers to keep the upper arm close to the torso and maintain elbow joint position; the trunk and core provide isometric stabilization to prevent excessive torso lean or momentum. Therefore the dominant movement pattern is an upper-body pull (isolated elbow flexion) with secondary supination and stabilization demands.
notes: Variation notes: preacher or incline variations change shoulder involvement; hammer grip (dumbbell) reduces supination and emphasizes brachioradialis/brachialis. Using body swing/cheat curls introduces trunk extension and reduces isolation, recruiting additional patterns (e.g., whole-body momentum). Unilateral or offset loading can add ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: Primary visible joint action is forward reaching/pressing at the shoulder (glenohumeral flexion) as the barbell is moved away from the body — mechanically similar to a sagittal-plane push. The core (rectus abdominis, obliques, transverse abdominis) must resist spinal extension throughout the roll-out (anti‑extension isometric control of the lumbar spine), so substantial isometric trunk stabilization is required. Elbows remain extended and act as a rigid link; scapular and shoulder stabilizers (serratus anterior, lats, lower traps) control the shoulder girdle. The exercise is therefore a combined sagittal-plane pushing action at the shoulders with primary anti‑extension/anti‑collapse core stabilization.

joint_actions.action: stable / minimal movement (kneeling) or limited posterior chain engagement

notes: Commonly performed kneeling (less hip demand) or standing (greater shoulder/core challenge). Primary training effect is anti‑extension core strength; classify as a shoulder‑driven push with high demand for trunk anti‑extension. Progressions: standing rollouts, barbell with plates/wheels. Caution for lumbar hyperextension in inexperienced lifters — regress to plank variations or partial rollouts if needed.

exercise: Barbell Curls Lying Against An Incline
reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane — the movement is an isolation elbow flexion (curl) performed while the torso is supported on an incline bench. The incline places the shoulder into relative extension at the start, lengthening the long head of the biceps and reducing shoulder contribution, so the elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis) produce the movement. Forearm supination assists during concentric curling. The bench and scapular musculature provide isometric stabilization of the shoulder and trunk to prevent substitution or torso momentum.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (held in slight extension at start, minimal sagittal movement)

notes: Incline position emphasizes the long head of the biceps by pre-stretching it and reduces shoulder momentum/cheating. Using a barbell limits independent supination compared with dumbbells. Keep torso and scapula stable on the bench to maintain isolation of elbow flexors.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip extension in the sagittal plane as the pelvis is driven upward against a load on the hips. The knees remain largely fixed in a flexed position (isometric) while the hip extensors produce the movement. The trunk/core and erector spinae act isometrically to maintain a neutral spine and transfer load.
notes: Variation: single-leg or asymmetric loading introduces anti-rotation demands. Foot position (closer/further) alters hamstring vs glute emphasis. Ensure neutral lumbar spine and avoid excessive spinal extension at top.

reasoning: Primary movement is forward translation of the hands/shoulder complex in the sagittal plane (shoulder flexion/horizontal 'press' away from the body) while the trunk resists anterior collapse. The shoulders move into flexion and the elbows remain extended (isometric), while the anterior core (rectus abdominis and obliques) eccentrically controls spinal extension/lengthening and then concentrically helps return to start — functionally an anti-extension core demand. Secondary stabilizers include serratus anterior and scapular stabilizers to maintain scapular protraction/stability, triceps to maintain elbow extension, and posterior chain/hip musculature to keep pelvis aligned. Because the primary visible joint action is a forward pressing motion of the shoulder girdle, this is classified as a PUSH pattern with heavy anti-extension core demand.

joint_actions.action: flexion (hands/arms move anteriorly away from body)
anti-extension / controlled spinal extension (eccentric control) and isometric stabilization

notes: Functionally an anti-extension core exercise; progressed variation (standing rollout) raises demand. Caution for lumbar hyperextension — maintain thoracic mobility and braced core. Some practitioners may list this primarily as a core/anti-extension pattern rather than a PUSH; chosen classification emphasizes the shoulder-driven forward push action.

reasoning: Primary movement is elevation of the humerus at the glenohumeral joint (a shoulder raise). Depending on the exact variation this is executed as shoulder flexion (front/inclined front raise, sagittal plane) or shoulder abduction/scaption (lateral/inclined lateral raise, frontal/scapular plane). The deltoids (anterior and/or lateral heads) concentrically produce the humeral elevation while the rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint. The scapular stabilizers (trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids) act isometrically to control scapular position. The elbows are typically held slightly flexed and act isometrically; the torso is fixed against the incline bench requiring isometric core and posterior chain stabilization.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
notes: Exercise name is ambiguous: if performed as a prone/incline reverse fly (horizontal abduction) it would emphasize posterior deltoid and be classified as a horizontal abduction shoulder raise but would still map to a shoulder-elevation/raise pattern (PUSH). Single-arm or asymmetric variations introduce anti-rotation demands; standing/moving variants could add stabilization or carry elements.

reasoning: Primary movement is a controlled horizontal push pattern: the hands/bar move anteriorly and posteriorly in the sagittal plane while the trunk resists spinal extension. Primary joint action at the shoulder is active/controlled flexion as the arms reach forward; the elbows remain largely extended/isometric. The lumbar spine undergoes an extension moment that the anterior core resists (anti-extension), so the rectus abdominis and obliques act isometrically/eccentrically to prevent spinal collapse. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower traps) and the triceps/shoulder musculature provide stability through the motion. Hip and knee remain relatively fixed/isometric to maintain body alignment.
notes: This is primarily an anti-extension core exercise implemented through a horizontal push mechanic. Variations (kneeling, standing, wheel vs barbell) change leverage and demand; performing from a bench reduces ROM compared with standing rollouts. Caution with lumbar hyperextension—progress ROM gradually and maintain braced core. If performed with significant unilateral bias or asymmetric loading, include ANTI_ROTATION as an additional pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane with the knees and hips held in a flexed, stabilized position. The action is produced primarily by the plantarflexor group—soleus (dominant in seated position) and gastrocnemius (reduced contribution due to knee flexion)—with smaller contributors (plantaris, tibialis posterior) and isometric stabilization from the trunk and upper extremities to hold the load. There is negligible hip or knee angular displacement (no hinge, squat, lunge, push, pull, carry, or rotation pattern).
notes: Seated position biases the soleus (knee flexion shortens gastrocnemius); standing calf raises (knee extended) shift emphasis toward gastrocnemius. Barbell across the thighs functions similarly to a seated calf machine; load position requires upper-body/trunk isometric support but does not create carry or anti-rotation demands unless performed asymmetrically.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: bilateral shoulder elevation of a load from shoulder height to overhead. Primary joint actions are concentric shoulder flexion (with some abduction/plane-blending as the bar travels slightly anterior) and elbow extension in the sagittal plane. The scapulothoracic articulation produces upward rotation and posterior tilt to allow full overhead range. The spine, hips and lower limbs act isometrically to stabilize the trunk against extension/translation and to provide a stable base. Muscles producing the movement are primarily the deltoids (anterior and medial), triceps brachii for elbow extension, with assistance from clavicular pectoralis major; scapular upward rotation and stabilization are provided by serratus anterior and upper trapezius while the rotator cuff centers the humeral head. Core and lower-limb musculature produce isometric anti-extension/positional stability.

joint_actions.action: anti-extension / isometric stabilization (thoracic extension to allow overhead position)

notes: If performed as a push-press or push-jerk, include HINGE or LUNGE/PLYO (hip/knee drive). Single-arm or asymmetrical variations introduce ANTI_ROTATION demands. Seated variations reduce lower-limb stabilization requirements but keep PUSH as primary pattern. Overhead mobility and scapular upward rotation are common limitations.

reasoning: Primary movement is scapulothoracic elevation (shoulder-girdle elevation) in the frontal plane — the scapulae are elevated by concentric action of the upper trapezius and levator scapulae while the arms hold the load. There is minimal shoulder joint flexion/extension or elbow motion; the arms remain extended (isometric) to transmit load to the scapulae. Trunk and lower limb muscles act isometrically to stabilize posture. Because the primary action is a vertical/shoulder-girdle pulling action (shrug), this maps to the PULL pattern.
notes: Bar behind-the-back position alters shoulder/scapular mechanics compared with front-bar shrugs — increased demand on scapular upward rotation and potential for reduced shoulder mobility or impingement in some lifters. Maintain neutral spine, avoid excessive thoracic extension; grip width and bar position (low on hips vs high) change ROM and perceived load. Not a hinge, squat, or carry movement.

reasoning: Primary joint action is scapulothoracic elevation/upward rotation of the shoulder girdle in the frontal plane (shrugging the shoulders). This is produced mainly by the upper trapezius and levator scapulae with assistance/stabilization from the middle trapezius and rhomboids; the elbows remain extended and forearms/wrists act isometrically to hold the bar. The movement is an upward pull of the scapulae rather than hip/knee/ankle movement, so it classifies as a PULL pattern (scapular elevation subtype). Core and thoracic posture are isometrically stabilized to maintain trunk position and prevent excessive cervical extension.
notes: Shrugs are an isolated scapular elevation exercise; variations include dumbbell shrugs, behind-the-back shrugs, and loaded carries that could introduce CARRY or ANTI_ROTATION if combined with walking or asymmetric loading. Avoid excessive cervical extension and use controlled scapular motion.

reasoning: Primary movement is lateral flexion of the lumbar/thoracolumbar spine in the frontal plane (side bend). The spine performs active lateral flexion toward the loaded side with contralateral lateral spinal musculature controlling the return. Hips, knees and ankles remain essentially isometric to maintain upright stance; the shoulder girdle/scapulae and upper back act isometrically to support and position the barbell. Therefore the dominant movement pattern is a trunk rotational/lateral-flexion pattern (classified under ROTATION).
notes: If the bar is held asymmetrically (single-arm or off-center), include ANTI_ROTATION as the core resists rotation; heavy axial loading in lateral flexion can increase lumbar shear—use controlled ROM and light-to-moderate load. Alternative implements (dumbbell, plate) produce similar trunk lateral flexion mechanics.

reasoning: Barbell step-ups are a unilateral vertical step that primarily require single-leg hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane to raise the body onto an elevated surface. The concentric phase is driven by knee extension and hip extension on the working limb; the contralateral limb provides balance and assists during transition. Stabilization demands include frontal-plane pelvic control to prevent hip drop and sagittal-plane trunk stiffness to support the loaded bar. There is an eccentric control phase on descent (hip/knee flexion).
notes: Variation details: higher step increases hip extension demand; barbell placement (back vs front) changes trunk lean and spinal loading. Asymmetric loading (single-arm) introduces ANTI_ROTATION demands. Alternating or continuous step-ups increase conditioning/locomotion overlap.

reasoning: Primary movement is quadrupedal locomotion: alternating hip and knee flexion/extension to advance the body in the sagittal plane while maintaining a low, braced trunk. Concurrently the upper extremities produce horizontal pulling actions on the sled (scapular retraction/protraction and elbow flexion/extension) to overcome load resistance. Core and spinal musculature act isometrically to maintain trunk neutrality and transfer force between lower and upper limbs. Shoulders and scapular stabilizers control repeated protraction/retraction and resist rotational/transverse forces from an uneven load or asymmetric drag.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension and horizontal pull (repeated protraction/retraction of the contacting limb)

notes: If the sled is pushed instead of pulled (or load is carried on the back), classification would shift (PUSH or CARRY). Asymmetric drag or uneven surface increases anti-rotation demands. Load magnitude and dragging hand/rope position will change relative upper vs lower contribution.

reasoning: This is primarily a thoracic (spinal) rotation mobility drill performed in the transverse plane. The primary joint action is rotation of the thoracic spine. Secondary joint actions commonly include shoulder horizontal abduction/extension and shoulder external rotation (to reach/grab the thumb), plus elbow flexion for the thumb-grab. The pelvis/hips are generally held isometrically to localize motion to the thoracic spine and the scapulothoracic region must be controlled by scapular stabilizers. Therefore the dominant movement pattern is ROTATION (thoracic rotation) with shoulder and scapular movement as secondary motions.
notes: Commonly performed supine/standing/half-kneeling; goal is thoracic rotation and shoulder mobility. Emphasize thoracic movement and limit compensatory lumbar rotation. Modify or avoid if acute shoulder pain/instability.

reasoning: Primary task is walking while holding a front-loaded object in a bilateral 'bear hug'—this is a loaded carry combined with locomotion. Primary joint actions occur in the lower limbs (cyclical hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane) producing forward progression. Upper body actions are primarily isometric: shoulders and elbows maintain a flexed/adducted hold on the load and the trunk musculature resists flexion and rotation to keep posture stable. Stabilization demands include anti-flexion (preventing trunk collapse forward) and anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion during single-leg stance phases of gait.

joint_actions.action: flexion and horizontal adduction (static, arms wrapped around load)

notes: If load is asymmetric or the carry is performed unilaterally (single-arm bear hug) include ANTI_ROTATION. Heavier anterior loads increase trunk extensor and abdominal demand; slow/loaded variations increase isometric core and scapular stabilizer recruitment.

reasoning: Battling ropes are driven primarily by repetitive shoulder flexion/extension (producing vertical/diagonal waves) with force transmitted through the hands to the rope. Primary joint actions occur at the shoulder (alternating/reciprocal flexion and extension in the sagittal/vertical plane) and the scapulothoracic joint (protraction/retraction in the transverse plane). The spine and core act isometrically to resist rotation and lateral flexion produced by alternating arm actions (anti-rotation demand). The lower limbs commonly adopt a semi-squat/isometric stance (hip and knee flexion) to provide a stable base but do not produce the primary movement. Muscles producing the wave motion are anterior and posterior deltoids, trapezius/rhomboids and rotator cuff for scapular control; core (obliques, rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, erector spinae) resists rotational torque. Grip/forearm muscles maintain tension on the rope, and hips/quads/glutes act isometrically to stabilize posture.

joint_actions.action: isometric to mild flexion/extension depending on technique
anti-rotation (isometric stabilization to resist transverse plane torque)
isometric flexion (semi-squat stance) for base of support
isometric flexion (semi-squat stance) for base of support

notes: Variations change emphasis: double-arm slams increase symmetric vertical shoulder power (more pure PUSH/vertical power), alternating waves increase anti-rotation and unilateral shoulder endurance. If performed with strong trunk rotation (side-to-side waves), ROTATION may be added; if performed explosively from hips/legs (slam with hip drive), consider secondary HINGE contribution. Stance (standing vs. lunge) alters stabilization demands.

reasoning: This is an isometric anterior load hold where the lifter secures a sandbag to the chest (bear-hug) and resists trunk collapse and rotation. Primary joint actions are isometric shoulder flexion/horizontal adduction and elbow flexion to clamp the load to the torso; the spine and hips produce isometric anti-flexion and anti-rotation torque to maintain an upright posture. Because the load is carried anteriorly and held against the body, it functions as a static carry pattern; even when symmetric, core must resist rotational perturbation and sagittal flexion, so ANTI_ROTATION (and anti-flexion) stabilization is a relevant secondary pattern.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion and horizontal adduction (clamping the load)
isometric anti-flexion and anti-rotation (maintain upright torso)
isometric stabilization (neutral stance, resists trunk collapse)

notes: If performed while marching/walking, classify additionally as LOCOMOTION (bear-hug march) and ANTI_ROTATION importance increases. An asymmetric or single-arm bear-hug increases anti-rotation demand. Very heavy loads increase spinal extension demand and recruit more posterior chain for postural support.

reasoning: The bear-hug hold is an anterior-loaded isometric carry: the arms are held flexed/adducted around an object or chest while the torso is braced. Primary joint actions are isometric shoulder flexion/horizontal adduction and elbow flexion to maintain the hug; the spine, hips and lower limbs provide isometric postural support to resist trunk collapse/extension. Because the load is held anteriorly and the task is a static loaded hold (no primary rotation), the dominant pattern is CARRY (anterior-loaded hold).
notes: Static anterior-loaded hold classified as a carry. If performed while marching, add LOCOMOTION (and potential increased ANTI_ROTATION demand if gait is asymmetric). Asymmetric or single-arm variations would introduce significant anti-rotation requirements.

reasoning: This is primarily an anterior loaded isometric hold: the load is clamped to the chest (bear-hug) so the body functions as a carrier of load rather than producing a large dynamic joint movement. Primary joint demands are isometric shoulder horizontal adduction/arm flexion to keep the object secured and isometric trunk bracing to resist flexion and any rotational moments. Lower limbs produce isometric hip/knee/ankle extension to support the vertical load. Because the load creates anterior flexion and can introduce rotational moments (especially if grip or load is slightly asymmetric), the core must produce anti-rotation and anti-flexion torque while the upper limbs maintain adduction/hold — therefore classify as CARRY with an ANTI_ROTATION stabilization demand.
notes: This classification treats the static bear-hug hold as a carry-style isometric load. If the exercise transitions to walking/marching, the CARRY demand increases and ANTI_ROTATION becomes more prominent; strongly asymmetric loading or single-arm variations should raise the anti-rotation priority. Primary demand is isometric stability rather than dynamic joint excursions.

reasoning: Primary action is an isometric anterior-loaded hold: the arms maintain shoulder flexion and horizontal adduction while the elbows remain flexed to clamp the load to the chest. Shoulders and elbows perform the primary positioning; the trunk and lower limbs act isometrically to maintain upright posture. Major demands are on upper-body adduction/flexion to secure the load and on the core (anti-flexion/anti-rotation) to resist trunk collapse and any rotational perturbation. Lower-limb extensors (quads/glutes) provide isometric support in standing.
notes: Classified as CARRY because it is an anterior loaded hold; if performed while marching or with asymmetric loading, add ANTI_ROTATION (and CARRY becomes locomotion+carry). Variations (seated, unilateral hug) alter lower-limb and anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: This is loaded marching/walking with an anterior load held in a bear-hug. Primary dynamic joint actions are repeated hip flexion and extension, with knee flexion/extension and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion producing the march (sagittal plane). The arms/shoulder girdle maintain an isometric anterior hold (shoulder horizontal adduction/flexion, elbow flexion) to secure the load. The trunk must produce isometric anti-flexion and anti-rotation (transverse/sagittal) and the hip abductors perform isometric stabilization during single-leg stance. Because the task is locomotion with a carried anterior load and the core resists rotation and flexion moments, the primary patterns are CARRY and ANTI_ROTATION.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion/horizontal adduction to secure load
isometric abduction/adduction control for pelvic stability

notes: Commonly categorized as a carry variant; single-leg stance/march increases transverse and frontal plane stabilization demands. If performed asymmetrically (uneven hold) or with significant offset load, anti-rotation demand increases further. Variation: added weight increases posterior chain and core demand; slow/high-knee march increases hip flexor and anti-rotation challenge.

reasoning: Primary task is loaded stepping (moving the body over an obstacle while holding a load in a bear-hug). Primary joint actions are repeated single-leg hip and knee flexion (swing/clearance) and extension (push-off) in the sagittal plane with ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion for clearance and propulsion. The load is held anteriorly in a bear-hug which isometrically taxes the shoulders/chest to maintain grip and the core to resist rotation and preserve trunk alignment during alternating single-leg support. Thus the movement is primarily a CARRY (loaded locomotion) and LOCOMOTION (step-over/step-up mechanics) with appreciable ANTI_ROTATION core demand for stability during single-leg transitions.
notes: If no external load is used the CARRY classification still applies when the arms are hugging a load; without load the movement reduces to LOCOMOTION with lower anti-rotation demand. Asymmetric loading or uneven step pattern increases anti-rotation and lateral stability demands. Box height affects required hip ROM and single-leg strength.

reasoning: Bench jump is a plyometric vertical jump onto an elevated surface driven by concentric triple-extension of the lower limb. Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension producing vertical force (sagittal plane) with ankle plantarflexion contributing to takeoff. Muscles generating the movement are primarily the quadriceps (knee extension) and gluteus maximus/hamstrings (hip extension) with calf muscles (gastrocnemius/soleus) adding plantarflexion. The trunk and hip abductors/adductors act isometrically to stabilize the spine and frontal-plane alignment on takeoff and especially on landing; shoulders/arms can contribute momentum if an arm swing is used but are secondary. Eccentric control on landing (hip/knee/ankle flexion) is also a key component for safety and force absorption.
notes: Plyometric emphasis (power) and landing mechanics are important; variations (depth/step-down, single-leg bench jump) increase demand on eccentric control and frontal/transverse stability. If significant arm swing or rotational components are present, consider adding upper-body or ROTATION descriptors, but primary pattern remains SQUAT.

reasoning: Bench Sprint is a plyometric locomotion drill performed on an elevated, narrow surface. The primary movement is cyclical sagittal-plane locomotion: repeated hip flexion and extension, knee flexion and extension, and ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion to produce forward propulsion and rapid ground contact. Primary movers produce concentric hip extension and plantarflexion on push-off and concentric hip/knee flexion during swing. The trunk and hips act isometrically to stabilize the spine and resist rotation and frontal-plane collapse during single-leg stance; plantar- and foot-intrinsic muscles contribute to balance on the bench. If hands contact the bench for support, the shoulders provide isometric stabilization but are not primary movers.
notes: Classified as LOCOMOTION because primary purpose is rapid alternating single-leg propulsion. reasoning: Primary motion is humeral (shoulder) flexion/extension in the sagittal plane as the dumbbell moves from overhead/behind the head to over the chest and back. reasoning: The bent press is primarily a trunk rotation/lateral-bend movement performed under a unilateral overhead load while the lifter lowers the hips and knees to get under the weight. Primary joint action is spinal lateral flexion combined with axial rotation (transverse + frontal planes) as the torso moves down and to the side. Secondary primary actions are single-leg/offset hip and knee flexion (a squat-like lowering) in the sagittal plane as the body descends. Muscles producing the movement include the obliques and quadratus lumborum for controlled lateral bend/rotation and the hip extensors/quadriceps for the lowering/return; deltoid, rotator cuff, lats and triceps provide isometric overhead stabilization. Substantial thoracic mobility and unilateral hip control are required to safely coordinate the rotation and the squat-lowering components.
notes: Bent press is an old-time strongman/one-arm overhead maneuver — classification emphasizes trunk rotation/lateral bend and unilateral squat-lowering with significant overhead anti-rotation demand. Variations (different implement, deeper single-leg emphasis) may shift relative contribution between rotation and squat components. High thoracic mobility and unilateral hip control are required; shoulder stability is critical.

reasoning: Bicycling is a repetitive, cyclic locomotor task driven primarily by sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion/extension with accompanying ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion to produce pedal force and forward propulsion. The primary joint actions are hip and knee extension on the downstroke (power phase) and hip and knee flexion on the upstroke, with the ankle contributing to push/pull on the pedal. The trunk and pelvis act as isometric stabilizers to maintain posture and transfer force to the pedals; the arms/shoulders provide static support on the handlebars. Muscles produce concentric and eccentric contractions in a cyclic pattern rather than a single concentric movement pattern, so the overall pattern is best classified as LOCOMOTION.
notes: Seated vs standing cycling shifts load: standing increases hip extensors and core demand. One-legged drills or asymmetric hand positions can add anti-rotation demands. Stationary cycling emphasizes concentric work and reduces impact compared with overground cycling.

reasoning: Stationary bicycling is a cyclical locomotor task driven primarily by repeated hip and knee flexion/extension and ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion in the sagittal plane. Core and pelvic stabilizers act isometrically to maintain trunk posture and resist excessive rotation or tilt, and hip abductors/adductors contribute to frontal-plane pelvic stability when seated or standing.

reasoning: Primary visible joint actions are contralateral hip extension (sagittal) and ipsilateral/contralateral shoulder flexion (sagittal) as the leg is driven posteriorly and the arm reaches anteriorly. reasoning: Bird dog is primarily a core stability (anti-rotation/anti-extension) exercise. Gluteal and hamstring muscles generate the hip extension, anterior deltoid and scapular stabilizers control the arm reach, and deep/core musculature (transverse abdominis, obliques, multifidus, erectors) provide anti-rotational and anti-extension stabilization. reasoning: Box skips are a plyometric locomotion drill characterized by repeated single-leg or alternating leg propulsive steps over/onto a box. The primary joint actions during the propulsive phase are hip extension, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane producing vertical and horizontal propulsion; the recovery phase requires hip and knee flexion and ankle dorsiflexion. Muscles producing the movement are primarily the gluteus maximus and quadriceps for hip and knee extension, and the gastrocnemius/soleus for plantarflexion, with hamstrings and hip flexors contributing to swing. The trunk and hip abductors/adductors act isometrically to stabilize posture and frontal-plane balance during single-leg support and landing. Landing requires eccentric control (quads, glutes, calves) to absorb impact and prepare for the next takeoff.
notes: Variations include forward/over/onto box, lateral box skips (increasing frontal-plane demand), single-leg emphasis, and box height adjustments. Emphasize soft, controlled landings, adequate ankle/hip mobility, and progressive plyometric loading to reduce injury risk.

exercise: Bottoms-Up Clean From The Hang Position
reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant explosive extension from the hang (hip hinge) to generate upward momentum, followed by an upper-body pull (shrug and pull into rack) with elbow flexion to receive the load. The bottoms-up, single-arm nature creates a large isometric anti-rotation demand on the core and shoulder/forearm to stabilize the inverted load. Joints moving: hip extension (sagittal) and knee/ankle extension (sagittal) for triple extension; scapulothoracic elevation and upward rotation (frontal/transverse) and glenohumeral flexion into rack (sagittal) with elbow flexion (sagittal) to catch; wrist/forearm and trunk provide isometric stabilization (transverse/frontal) to prevent rotation and control the unstable bottoms-up load.
notes: If performed single-arm (typical), anti-rotation demand increases substantially; bottoms-up grip adds high wrist/forearm and rotator cuff stabilization demands. If performed bilateral or with a two-handed implement, anti-rotation requirement is reduced. Variations (heavier load, lower hang) alter relative contribution of hip drive vs. upper-body pull.

reasoning: Bottoms-up is primarily a loaded carry (typically a kettlebell held upside-down) performed while walking or marching: the lower extremity produces repeated sagittal-plane hip/knee/ankle motion for locomotion while the upper limb and trunk produce strong isometric stabilization to keep the inverted load vertical. Primary joint actions are hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension for gait and isometric shoulder/elbow/wrist stabilization to control the unstable, unilateral load. The unilateral, top-heavy orientation produces significant anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion demand on the obliques, transverse abdominis and contralateral spinal stabilizers; scapular rotators/rotator cuff and serratus anterior work isometrically to stabilize the shoulder girdle and maintain joint alignment, and forearm flexors maintain grip.

Progressions: march → loaded carry distance → add perturbations. Watch shoulder mobility and grip strength; unstable top-heavy orientation increases rotator cuff and core demand.

exercise: Bosu Ball Cable Crunch With Side Bends
reasoning: Primary movement is dynamic trunk motion: combined spinal flexion (crunch) in the sagittal plane and lateral trunk flexion (side-bend) in the frontal plane — this places the exercise in the ROTATION category (trunk/orientated core movement). The prime movers produce spinal flexion and lateral flexion (rectus abdominis and obliques), while deeper stabilizers (transverse abdominis, multifidus, quadratus lumborum) and hip/gluteal musculature resist rotational and translational forces.

reasoning: Primary movement is unilateral sagittal-plane lower‑limb extension: the stepping limb produces hip extension and knee extension to elevate the body onto the box. The concentric phase is driven primarily by knee extensors and hip extensors; eccentric control on descent uses the same muscle groups.
notes: Single‑leg, step‑up height and tempo (Tabata) increase demand on knee extensors and cardiovascular system. Higher box -> greater hip extension demand. If performed as a stepping gait (alternating rapidly), it may also be described as a locomotion/step variant, but primary joint actions align with a unilateral squat pattern.

reasoning: Primary action is dynamic transverse-plane trunk rotation that generates torque through the hips and transfers to the arm to produce a horizontal pushing action (the punch). Lower limb joints (hip rotation, ankle plantarflexion/knee extension) provide weight transfer and ground reaction force to augment rotational power. Stabilization demands include isometric control from contralateral obliques and transverse abdominis to control rotation, rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, traps) to stabilize the shoulder, and lower-limb co-contraction for balance during weight shift.

Heavy implements or asymmetric loading (e.g., holding a weighted ball) would increase ANTI_ROTATION demands. Variation in punch type (jab vs. cross vs. hook) shifts relative emphasis between pure transverse rotation and additional frontal/sagittal components.

reasoning: Boxing Tabata consists primarily of repeated punches (jab, cross, hooks) performed at high intensity. Shoulders and elbows produce the ballistic pushing action while the core (obliques, rectus abdominis) and hips produce/transfer rotational force; scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, traps) control protraction/retraction and shoulder stability. Lower limb and ankle actions are mainly for weight transfer, stance and quick rebounds (plantarflexion/dorsiflexion) and to facilitate rotation. reasoning: The Bulgarian split squat is a unilateral sagittal-plane lower-body push where the front limb performs hip and knee extension against load (dumbbells). reasoning: The Bulgarian split squat is a unilateral, single-leg descent and rise where the front limb performs knee and hip flexion during the lowering phase and knee and hip extension during the rising phase — characteristic of the lunge/split-lunge pattern. The elevated rear foot increases hip range of motion and demands greater single-leg stability: gluteus medius and other hip stabilizers control frontal-plane pelvic stability while core muscles isometrically stabilize the trunk. reasoning: Primary movement is a unilateral sagittal-plane lower-body descent and ascent from a split-stance (rear-foot-elevated) — functionally a single-leg lunge/split-squat. reasoning: The burpee is a compound, plyometric conditioning movement that primarily consists of a rapid squat-to-jump and a horizontal push (push-up) with an intervening plank. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion to descend and then powerful hip and knee extension plus ankle plantarflexion for the jump (SQUAT pattern). The push-up phase involves shoulder horizontal adduction/shoulder flexion and elbow extension in the sagittal/transverse region (PUSH pattern). Priority is given to the explosive lower-body triple extension and the horizontal pressing action as the main movement patterns.
notes: Variations may alter pattern weighting: a burpee without push-up reduces emphasis on PUSH (more purely SQUAT/plyometric). Chest-to-ground push-up inclusion increases horizontal push demand. Single-leg or tuck-jump variations add unilateral or greater power demands. Shoulder stability and core anti-extension are important stabilizers throughout.

reasoning: Burpees are a compound, cyclical movement combining a rapid squat pattern (hip and knee flexion to lower into a crouch and powerful hip/knee/ankle extension to jump) with a horizontal push (when the torso contacts the ground and performs a push-up or push-off). Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane for the lower-body squat/jump (hip/knee/ankle flexion → extension) and in the transverse/sagittal plane for the upper-body push (shoulder horizontal adduction/flexion and elbow extension). notes: Variations affect pattern weighting: removing the push-up (hands on floor only) reduces PUSH emphasis and increases SQUAT/jump dominance; stepping feet back instead of jumping is lower impact; adding a tuck/box jump increases plyometric demand. Burpees are primarily conditioning/plyometric with high core stabilization and full-body metabolic demand.

reasoning: The burpee is a multi-phase, bodyweight movement. reasoning: The burpee is a compound, plyometric movement combining a lower-body squat/jump and an upper-body horizontal push. reasoning: Burpees combine a rapid squat/stand (hip and knee flexion → extension) and explosive vertical propulsion (ankle plantarflexion) with a horizontal/vertical push component (push-up: elbow extension/shoulder flexion) and a plyometric jump/landing (locomotion). reasoning: The Cable Judo Flip is a diagonal low-to-high cable pull that is driven by transverse-plane trunk and hip rotation while the upper limb performs a pulling action on the handle. reasoning: Primary joint action is ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane against resistance. reasoning: Cable shrugs are primarily a scapulothoracic movement consisting of upward translation/elevation of the scapulae against resistance. The primary joint action is scapular elevation (shoulder girdle), occurring in the frontal plane, produced mainly by the upper trapezius and levator scapulae. The glenohumeral joint undergoes minimal motion; the elbows and hands act isometrically to hold the cable handle. The spine and core provide isometric stabilization to maintain an upright posture. notes: Variation in cable angle or unilateral cable shrugs can change loading and require additional anti-rotation/stability. Keep neck neutral to avoid using cervical extension; primary emphasis is on upper trapezius/levator scapulae rather than glenohumeral movers.

reasoning: Primary movement is wrist (radiocarpal) flexion in the sagittal plane: the hand is drawn toward the anterior forearm against resistance (a distal pulling action). The elbow and shoulder are held isometrically to position and stabilize the forearm while wrist flexors generate movement. Eccentric/isometric activity of wrist extensors controls the return and stabilizes the joint. exercise: Calf Press On The Leg Press Machine
reasoning: Primary movement is ankle plantarflexion against a fixed platform in the sagittal plane — the foot/ankle pushes the plate away by extending the ankle. The knee and hip remain largely isometric (near static) to position the limb on the sled and transfer force. reasoning: Child's Pose is primarily a sagittal-plane flexion posture: the hips and knees move into end-range flexion while the spine flexes anteriorly as the torso folds over the thighs. When the arms are extended forward there is shoulder flexion and scapular protraction. Although performed as a passive/mobility position rather than a loaded strengthening task, the primary joint actions mirror the hip+knee flexion pattern typical of a squat-type movement (hip and knee flexion in sagittal plane). Stabilization demands are low and largely passive/isometric (breath and gentle core control, scapular/shoulder relaxation or low-level serratus/upper trapezius activity if arms are extended).

reasoning: This is a passive mobility/cool-down posture rather than a loading or force-production task. reasoning: This is a passive mobility/cooldown stretch rather than a loaded or dynamic strength pattern. Primary movement is multi-segment sagittal flexion: hips flex as the pelvis moves posteriorly toward the heels, knees are flexed to allow the hips to descend, and the spine undergoes lumbar/thoracic flexion as the torso folds over the thighs. If the arms are extended forward, the shoulders go into flexion with scapular protraction. There is minimal concentric/accelerative muscle production and no primary push/pull/hinge/squat/lunge/rotation/carry pattern. Stabilization is primarily passive (ligaments, connective tissue) with low-level isometric activity from postural muscles to control descent and breathing.

reasoning: This is primarily a mobility/resting posture rather than a loaded or force-producing exercise. Primary joint actions are spinal flexion (thoracic/lumbar) in the sagittal plane and increased knee flexion with the hips moving into greater flexion as the torso folds forward. Shoulders are flexed/forwardly elevated and the scapulae protract to allow the arms to extend anteriorly (sagittal/horizontal plane). The movements are slow/passive with minimal concentric force production; muscular activity is largely eccentric/isometric or passive stretch. Stabilization is required from the anterior core to control spinal flexion and from the posterior chain and surrounding soft tissues to accept the stretch, but there is no primary push/pull/hinge/squat pattern present.
notes: This is a passive/mobility cooldown posture not well represented by standard dynamic movement patterns (SQUAT, HINGE, LUNGE, PUSH, PULL, etc.). Use as a flexibility/recovery technique; variations include arms alongside body for a more posterior chain stretch or reaching arms forward for increased thoracic stretch.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are deep hip and knee flexion in the sagittal plane with concurrent trunk (thoracic/lumbar) flexion as the torso folds over the thighs. The movement pattern most closely matches an unloaded, passive deep knee/hip flexion posture similar to a resting squat position rather than a hinge, lunge, or push/pull pattern. Shoulders and elbows are typically in sagittal plane flexion/extension as secondary, unloaded segments for arm placement; scapular protraction may occur. Stabilization demands are low and primarily passive (soft-tissue stretch) but require some thoracic mobility and passive control from the core and hip musculature to maintain the folded position.
notes: This is primarily a mobility/stretching posture rather than a loaded strength pattern. Classifying as SQUAT reflects the deep hip/knee flexion posture (unloaded). Modify stance width for knee pain or pregnancy; arms may be beside the body for a variation that reduces shoulder demand.

reasoning: This is a passive, static mobility/relaxation posture with primary joint positions rather than a dynamic movement pattern. The main joint actions are sustained hip flexion, knee flexion and spinal (thoracic/lumbar) flexion in the sagittal plane while diaphragmatic breathing is emphasized. Muscle activation is primarily isometric/lengthened for postural and breathing muscles rather than concentric/ballistic prime-mover actions characteristic of the listed dynamic movement patterns, so none of the provided movement pattern categories (HINGE, SQUAT, LUNGE, PUSH, PULL, CARRY, ROTATION, ANTI_ROTATION, LOCOMOTION) apply as primary patterns.

reasoning: This is a passive mobility/postural stretch rather than a loading movement pattern. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane spinal flexion (thoracic/lumbar), hip flexion (sitting back onto heels) and knee flexion. Shoulders are placed in flexion/forward reach with scapular protraction. There is minimal concentric force production or load carriage; the position emphasizes lengthening of posterior chain and shoulder girdle tissues and requires low-level isometric stabilization of the hips and core to control the fold.
notes: Primarily a cooldown/mobility posture — not classified as a standard movement pattern. Variations: arms extended, arms by sides, knees wide (wider hip external rotation), or thread-the-needle (adds thoracic rotation).

reasoning: Child's Pose is primarily a deep hip and knee flexion posture in the sagittal plane (sitting back onto the heels) with concurrent spinal flexion and forward shoulder reach. The dominant joint actions are hip flexion and knee flexion (analogous to the bottom position of an unweighted, unloaded squat pattern), with thoracic/lumbar flexion and shoulder flexion as secondary motions. Muscles that produce hip flexion (iliopsoas, rectus femoris, TFL) and knee flexion (hamstrings, sartorius) are involved in achieving/maintaining the posture; spinal flexion is assisted by rectus abdominis/obliques, and anterior deltoid/serratus anterior contribute to the forward arm reach. Stabilization is largely passive/contact-based (shins/feet on mat) but requires low-level isometric control from the core, scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower traps) and ankle musculature to maintain comfort and alignment.
notes: Primarily a mobility/resting posture rather than a loaded strength move; classified as SQUAT because the dominant mechanical pattern is deep hip + knee flexion. Modify for knee pain (bolster between hips and calves, knees wider) or for tight shoulders (arms by sides). Avoid if acute knee/hip contraindications exist.

reasoning: This is a mobility/stretch exercise that produces primary cervical spine flexion in the sagittal plane. The only moving joint is the cervical spine (neck flexion); there is minimal to no motion at hips, knees, ankles, shoulders, or elbows and no loading or translational locomotion. Because movement is isolated to the neck and is an active/passive stretch rather than a functional loaded pattern (push, pull, hinge, squat, lunge, carry, rotation, anti-rotation, locomotion), it does not map cleanly to the provided movement pattern categories.
notes: Classified as no applicable standard movement pattern — mobility/stretch. Caution with cervical spine pathology; perform gently or under guidance. Variations include active chin tucks (strengthening/deep neck flexors) versus passive end-range chin-to-chest stretches.

reasoning: This is primarily a mobility/stretching/relaxation posture rather than a resistance movement pattern. The primary joint actions are hip flexion (bringing the hips toward the heels), knee flexion (knees bent under the torso), and spinal flexion (thoracic and lumbar rounding) in the sagittal plane. If the arms are extended forward, there is shoulder flexion and scapular protraction (sagittal). Movement is largely passive/controlled with diaphragmatic breathing; stabilization demands are low but include isometric engagement of the deep core (diaphragm/transversus abdominis) and scapular stabilizers to control arm position.
notes: This is a restorative/mobility position rather than a strength movement; it does not map cleanly to common strength movement pattern categories (HINGE, SQUAT, PUSH, etc.). Variations: knees together or wide (feet apart) change hip stretch; arms can be extended forward, alongside the body, or overhead. Modify for knee or hip pathology and late-stage pregnancy (use bolster or widen stance).

reasoning: This is primarily a loaded-walking task: transporting a cinder block in a wheelbarrow requires sustained gait mechanics under external load. The primary joint actions are repeated hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane producing locomotion (propulsion and stance control). Upper limb joints (shoulder and elbow) act predominantly isometrically to grip and steer the handles and control the load. The trunk and hip musculature provide postural and frontal/transverse plane stabilization to resist collapse and unwanted rotation while moving the asymmetric/unstable load. Overall the dominant demand is carrying (loaded locomotion) with secondary demands for upper-body isometric stabilization and core anti-flexion/anti-rotation control.
notes: If performed with a single-handed grip, uneven load, or one-side pushing, include ANTI_ROTATION. Steep inclines or repeated lowering/raising the barrel can increase posterior-chain (HINGE) demands.

reasoning: The chin-up is primarily a vertical pulling exercise. The main joint actions are elbow flexion and glenohumeral extension/adduction with associated scapular retraction and depression — these actions bring the torso toward the bar. Prime movers (lats, teres major, biceps) generate the concentric pull while scapular stabilizers (rhomboids, middle/lower traps) control scapular motion. The spine and hips act isometrically to prevent excessive swing and maintain a rigid torso during the vertical pull.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (neutral or slight flexion, prevents excessive leg swing)

notes: Grip influences muscle emphasis (supinated 'chin' grip increases biceps contribution). Strict chin-ups are pure vertical pulls; kipping or swinging variations introduce dynamic hip drive and reduce strict spinal stabilization. Assisted or eccentric-only chin-ups change load but remain PULL pattern. Asymmetric loading or single-arm variations would add ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: The clean is a multi-phase Olympic lift. Primary action begins with a hip-dominant hinge off the floor (first pull) producing hip and trunk extension (posterior chain), transitions to an explosive triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) producing a powerful vertical pull (second pull/high pull) to accelerate the bar, and finishes with rapid re-bend and drop into a front-rack catch (receiving often as a front squat). Shoulders/elbows move to rack the bar (elbow flexion/shoulder flexion) and the spine and scapulae act isometrically to stabilize the load during the pull and catch. Thus the dominant movement patterns are a PULL (barbell vertical pull), a HINGE (hip extension/posterior chain drive), and a SQUAT (receiving in front-racked squat).

joint_actions.action: plantarflexion (triple extension) and then dorsiflexion on catch
extension and strong isometric trunk stabilization
flexion/elevation to rack the bar in the front position
flexion to pull under and rack the bar (catch)

notes: Includes both power clean (shallower catch, less squat depth) and squat clean (deeper receiving squat) variations; unilateral/asymmetric considerations uncommon. High demand on timing, triple extension, and eccentric control on catch. Requires strong scapular stability and grip/forearm endurance.

reasoning: The clean pull is primarily a sagittal-plane triple-extension movement at the hip, knee and ankle (hinge-dominant) that drives a vertical pull of the bar using an explosive hip/knee extension and powerful scapular elevation (shrug). Primary joint actions are hip extension and knee extension producing upward acceleration of the load, with ankle plantarflexion contributing to triple extension. The shoulder girdle produces scapular elevation (upper trapezius) while the arms remain essentially extended and act as hooks to transmit force (isometric elbow). Stabilization requires strong spinal/bracing isometric extension (erector spinae, core) and grip/forearm endurance to maintain connection to the bar.
notes: Arms remain straight (no active elbow flexion) — movement emphasis is on lower-body propulsion and scapular shrug. Variations (hang clean pull, mid-thigh pull, high pull) alter bar start position and emphasis but retain HINGE + PULL pattern. Ensure thoracic/spinal stability and proper hip hinge to reduce lumbar shear.

reasoning: Primary action is a unilateral vertical press: shoulder elevation (flexion/abduction and scapular upward rotation) with elbow extension to drive the bell overhead — a vertical PUSH in the sagittal plane. Because the load is held on one side and often manipulated from the shoulder, the spine and core perform isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion to resist tipping and rotation, so ANTI_ROTATION is a required pattern. If the implement is cleaned from the floor or a push-press/jerk technique is used, the lift additionally involves hip/knee extension (hip hinge/leg drive) but the dominant pattern remains a unilateral overhead push with strong core anti-rotation demands. Stabilization requires rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers to control the bell, and obliques/quadratus lumborum/erector spinae to resist lateral flexion and rotation.

If performed as a clean-and-press or push-press, include transient hip/knee extension contribution but the primary pattern remains a unilateral vertical PUSH with anti-rotation demand. Handle thickness and instability increase scapular/rotator cuff and core stabilization demands.

reasoning: The clean shrug is performed by producing powerful lower-body triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to drive the bar upward followed immediately by a strong scapular elevation (shrug) to further translate force to the bar. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee extension (posterior chain drive) and frontal-plane scapulothoracic elevation (shrug) via the upper traps. Elbows typically remain extended (isometric) while the spine must be held rigid by the erector spinae and core. Thus the movement combines a HINGE-like hip-dominant extension phase with a vertical PULL component (scapular elevation) as the bar is moved upward.
notes: Variation by start position: from the hang or floor will alter relative contribution of hinging vs. shrug. Some performers emphasize minimal hip hinge and focus only on scapular elevation (more PULL-dominant); when performed as part of a full clean the hinge contribution is larger. Scapular control and trunk stiffness are important for safe, effective force transfer.

reasoning: The Clean and Jerk is a multi-phase Olympic lift. The initial pull (first and second pull) is a powerful hip-dominant triple extension and vertical pull (PULL) where hips, knees and ankles extend in the sagittal plane and the upper back/arms pull the bar. The clean catch requires rapid deceleration into a front-squat position (SQUAT) with hip and knee flexion to receive the load on the anterior shoulders. The jerk phase is a dip-and-drive vertical push (PUSH) — a short knee/hip dip followed by explosive leg drive and overhead arm/shoulder and elbow extension to lock the bar overhead. Throughout the lift the spine and core act isometrically to transfer force and stabilize the torso; the upper traps and shoulders provide powerful elevation and support during the pull and overhead lockout.

joint_actions.action: flexion/elevation (front rack during catch) and overhead flexion/abduction during jerk
joint_actions.plane: sagittal (vertical push) / frontal component in lockout

joint_actions.action: flexion (rack position during catch) then extension (lockout in jerk)
