notes: Variation: split jerk introduces a LUNGE-like single-leg stabilization pattern during the jerk phase. The lift requires mobility in wrists/shoulders/ankles and high intermuscular coordination; significant isometric shoulder/scapular stabilization and core stiffness are required but do not change the primary movement-pattern classification.

reasoning: The Clean and Press is a compound lift combining a rapid hip-dominant drive and vertical pull (the clean) with an overhead vertical press. Primary joint actions during the clean are hip, knee and ankle extension (triple extension) in the sagittal plane producing upward force, plus scapular elevation/upper trap activity to assist the high pull and elbow flexion to pull the bar into the rack/catch. The press phase is primarily shoulder flexion and elbow extension in the sagittal plane (vertical push). The spine and core produce strong isometric stabilization throughout to transfer force between lower and upper body. Thus the movement simultaneously requires a posterior-chain hinge, a pull phase (high pull/receive) and a vertical push.

joint_actions.action: upward rotation/elevation (high pull) and protraction/stability in press

notes: Variation: power clean + strict press emphasizes HINGE+PULL then PUSH; full squat clean would add SQUAT as a primary pattern. Push-press or jerk variations increase lower-body drive during the PUSH phase. Technique and mobility (thoracic, shoulder, hip) alter joint contributions.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal push: concentric elbow extension with shoulder horizontal adduction (pressing the body away from the floor). Because the hands/body shift around 'clock' positions, the trunk and shoulder girdle must resist unwanted rotation and maintain alignment — an anti-rotational/isometric core demand. Shoulders and elbows produce the movement (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, triceps) while serratus anterior and scapular stabilizers control scapular protraction/retraction. The hips and legs provide a stiff, isometrically stabilized bridge to transfer force. If performed with large reaches or single-arm emphasis the rotational demand increases, but the primary pattern remains a horizontal push with anti-rotation stabilization.
notes: Standard clock push-up = horizontal push with strong anti-rotation demand. Variations: wide-handed or reaching/rotational versions increase transverse rotational movement (may shift toward ROTATION if performed as active rotational reaches); single-arm or heavily offset hands substantially raise anti-rotation and unilateral shoulder demand.

reasoning: This is primarily a horizontal push. The primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal adduction (bringing the arms together across the chest) in the transverse plane and elbow extension in the sagittal plane. The pectoralis major and anterior deltoid produce shoulder horizontal adduction while the triceps brachii produces elbow extension; serratus anterior and rotator-cuff muscles stabilize the scapula and glenohumeral joint. The spine and lower body act isometrically to stabilize the torso during the press. Because the load is typically bilateral and symmetrical, anti-rotation is not a primary pattern.
notes: Close-grip variation shifts emphasis toward triceps versus wider presses. Using dumbbells increases unilateral shoulder/glenohumeral stabilization demands; if performed as a standing/overhead variation the primary pattern would change to vertical PUSH and include lower-body drive.

reasoning: The clean from blocks is an explosive multi-phase lift. Primary joint actions are rapid hip, knee and ankle extension (triple extension) producing vertical force (HINGE pattern dominates the propulsion). Simultaneously the upper body performs a high pull (scapular elevation/trap activity) and the athlete actively pulls themselves under the bar with elbow flexion and shoulder movement (PULL). The finish requires receiving the bar in a front-rack position with rapid knee/hip flexion to absorb the load (SQUAT). Spine is maintained in extension for force transfer and the core and grip act isometrically to stabilize during the pull and catch. Plane of motion is predominantly sagittal for the lower limb triple extension and catch, with frontal/scapular motion for the shrug/upper-body pull phase.
notes: Block height alters the relative contribution of the hinge (higher blocks reduce hip ROM). If performed as a power clean (minimal descent) the SQUAT component is shallow; a full squat clean increases the SQUAT demand. Requires strong grip, thoracic mobility for front-rack, and high rate of force development for the pull phase.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane as the forearm is brought toward the humerus. Forearm supination (transverse plane) often accompanies the curl, and the shoulder girdle and trunk act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm and torso. Movement is an upper-body pulling action about the elbow joint rather than a locomotor, carry, hinge, squat, lunge, push, rotation, or anti-rotation pattern.
notes: Close-grip on an EZ bar can alter wrist comfort and slightly shift emphasis among brachialis/brachioradialis vs biceps depending on hand rotation. Variations (preacher, incline, strict vs cheat curls) change shoulder involvement and stabilization demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane (concentric/eccentric elbow flexion) producing forearm elevation toward the shoulder—this classifies as an upper-body PULL pattern. The band provides variable resistance but does not change the primary joint action. Shoulders, trunk, hips and lower limbs act isometrically to stabilize posture; the forearm may contribute supination depending on grip/technique.
notes: Close-grip on an EZ-bar slightly shifts emphasis toward brachialis and brachioradialis and may reduce biceps long-head contribution; adding a band increases resistance at the top of the curl. Variations (seated, preacher) change stabilization demands but remain PULL pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane (bringing the bar toward the shoulder) — an upper-body pulling action. The biceps brachii, brachialis and brachioradialis produce the concentric/eccentric motion at the elbow. Shoulders, scapular stabilizers and wrists act isometrically to maintain arm position and bar control. The trunk and hips provide isometric stabilization to prevent body sway or 'cheating' hip extension; if the lifter uses momentum (body swing) the pattern can recruit HINGE components, but in strict form the dominant pattern is PULL.

exercise: Close-Grip Push-Up off of a Dumbbell
reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal push: the shoulders perform horizontal adduction (and some flexion) while the elbows extend to raise the body from a lowered position. The scapulae protract on the concentric phase and retract on the eccentric phase; the trunk/hip musculature contracts isometrically to maintain a rigid plank. Because the hands are on dumbbells (elevated and allowing a neutral wrist), ROM is increased and emphasis shifts slightly toward the triceps due to the narrow hand position, but the fundamental movement pattern remains a horizontal PUSH.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are elbow extension (sagittal) and shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse) as the bar is pressed away from the torso. The movement is a horizontal push: triceps produce elbow extension while pectoralis major and anterior deltoid produce horizontal adduction and shoulder flexion; rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers maintain humeral head position and a stable scapular base. The thoracic spine, core, and glutes act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and transmit force (leg drive if performed on bench with feet planted). Close-grip narrows hand spacing, increasing elbow extension (triceps) demand relative to a wider bench press while still being categorized biomechanically as a horizontal push.
notes: Close-grip variation shifts emphasis toward the triceps and reduces shoulder horizontal abduction torque compared with wide-grip bench press. Performed on a flat bench the movement is a horizontal PUSH; floor press or partial-ROM variations change shoulder/elbow ROM and stabilization demands. EZ-bar grip may reduce wrist stress compared with straight bar.

reasoning: Club swinging is a dynamic, multiplanar shoulder and thoracic mobility drill that primarily produces rotational and circumductive motion through the shoulder girdle and thoracic spine. Primary joint actions are repeated shoulder rotation/circumduction (combined flexion/extension and abduction/adduction components) and thoracic spine rotation with some extension; the elbow and wrist perform light flexion/extension and pronation/supination to control the club. Scapulothoracic protraction/retraction and upward rotation occur as the shoulder moves. The core and lower limb provide anticipatory and reactive stabilization to control momentum and maintain posture, but they are secondary to the rotational mobility of the shoulder/spine. Muscles generating the movement include the deltoids and rotator cuff (control and guide the club path), scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) for scapular motion, and thoracic/abdominal rotators (obliques, erector spinae) for spinal rotation and stabilization. Forearm pronators/supinators and wrist extensors/flexors control club orientation and grip.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor, supraspinatus, subscapularis)

Light implements recommended; momentum control and thoracic rotation quality determine load on stabilizers. Not an anti-rotation pattern—the movement intentionally creates rotation rather than resisting it.

Light stretching adds multi-planar spinal mobility and joint range-of-motion work but does not change the primary movement pattern. Stabilization demands are low-intensity: hip abductors (gluteus medius) and intrinsic core muscles control frontal-plane pelvis stability and transverse-plane rotation during gait and arm swing.

If the session included a loaded or asymmetric carry during walking, add CARRY and/or ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: Primary component is unloaded ambulation (easy walking) which is a locomotion pattern. The primary joint actions are cyclic sagittal-plane hip flexion and extension, knee flexion and extension, and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion producing step and push-off. Pelvic and thoracic axial rotation occur passively in the transverse plane and require core and hip stabilizers to maintain posture during gait. reasoning: Conan's Wheel is primarily a loaded walking/carry variation: the athlete holds a heavy implement in one hand and walks in a circular path, so the primary movement pattern is a CARRY (loaded locomotion). The asymmetric, eccentrically cantilevered load produces a large rotational torque about the spine and requires the trunk to resist rotation and lateral collapse, so ANTI_ROTATION is a required secondary/primary stabilization pattern. Primary joint actions are hip/knee/ankle alternating flexion-extension for gait (sagittal plane) while the shoulder/elbow provide an isometric hold of the load and the trunk (obliques, rectus abdominis, erector spinae) works isometrically to resist rotation and lateral flexion (transverse/frontal planes). Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles maintain shoulder position; grip/forearm muscles maintain hold on the implement.

joint_actions.action: isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion (with controlled transverse-plane rotation as body orients around the load)
isometric stabilization (maintains elbow angle under load)

notes: Typically performed single-arm with a cantilevered load; intensity and demands scale with load, radius of the implement, and distance walked. Variations include bilateral holds, different arm positions, or walking direction changes. Because locomotion is integral, some coaches may also categorize as LOCOMOTION, but CARRY best captures the loaded-walking intent; include ANTI_ROTATION due to asymmetric torque on the trunk.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane producing forearm/hand movement toward the distal humerus (a pulling action). The elbow is the prime mover joint; the radioulnar joint often adds forearm supination (transverse plane) as the weight is curled. The shoulder is held relatively fixed (adducted and slightly flexed) and acts isometrically to position the arm; scapular and core muscles provide stabilization. Primary movers (biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis) generate concentric elbow flexion while rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers prevent unwanted shoulder motion and the trunk provides isometric stability.
notes: Seated elbow-braced execution minimizes trunk and shoulder movement, making this a primarily single-joint elbow flexion (PULL) exercise. Grip variation (neutral/hammer vs supinated) shifts emphasis toward brachioradialis. Single-arm nature can create small rotational demand on the trunk, but when seated and braced this rarely constitutes a true ANTI_ROTATION pattern.

reasoning: Pigeon Pose places the lead (front) hip into transverse-plane external rotation and sagittal-plane flexion while the trail (back) hip is placed into sagittal-plane extension. The pose is therefore primarily a hip-rotation/stretch pattern (transverse plane) combined with an asymmetrical hip flexion/extension relationship similar to a kneeling lunge. Primary joint actions are front-hip external rotation and flexion, back-hip extension, and front-knee flexion; the spine may be neutral or actively flexed depending on whether the practitioner folds forward. Stabilization requires pelvic control from the contralateral hip abductors/adductors and isometric core tension to maintain pelvic alignment and protect the lumbar spine.

exercise: Core Conditioning (Finisher: alternating Mountain Climbers / Dead Bugs)

reasoning: Depth jumps involve an eccentric landing followed by an immediate concentric explosive rebound (stretch–shortening cycle) driven by bilateral hip and knee extension and ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane. reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant triple extension from the hang position (hip, knee, ankle extension) to generate vertical force — a hinge/power pattern. reasoning: Primary movement is a ballistic hip-dominant triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to generate vertical momentum (HINGE). Shoulders and elbows execute a rapid upward movement to lock the load overhead while the trunk and scapular stabilizers control the load. reasoning: This is a static stretch that produces relative shoulder horizontal abduction (transverse plane) as the torso moves forward away from a fixed, posteriorly placed hand/arm on a doorframe. reasoning: The Double Kettlebell Jerk is primarily a vertical push pattern. Primary joint actions producing movement are sagittal-plane triple extension of the lower limbs for drive and sagittal/vertical shoulder elevation and elbow extension for the press/catch. Stabilization demands include scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff to control the overhead load, and core/erectors to resist trunk flexion/rotation during the drive and catch. If performed as a full squat jerk variant the catch includes greater hip/knee flexion, but the initiating and finishing action remains a vertical PUSH.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical PUSH (overhead press) — shoulder elevation and elbow extension to drive kettlebells overhead. reasoning: This is a plyometric locomotor drill that mimics running gait with bilateral, rapid knee flexion to bring the heels toward the glutes and cyclical hip extension/ankle plantarflexion during push-off. reasoning: Primary action is a hip hinge (sagittal) to fold at the hips while the thorax laterally flexes and rotates (frontal + transverse) to reach toward the lower limb. notes: Double (bilateral) overhead load reduces asymmetric anti-rotation demands compared with single-arm windmills but still requires strong trunk rotational/lateral control and overhead shoulder stability. Variations: single-arm windmill (adds ANTI_ROTATION), suitcase or racked variations change loading and shoulder demands. reasoning: Primary joint action is bilateral hip flexion with concurrent knee flexion and lumbar (spine) flexion in the sagittal plane as the knees are drawn toward the chest. reasoning: Primary joint actions occur at the glenohumeral joint: the humerus is taken into horizontal abduction (transverse plane) and external rotation to open the anterior chest, producing a passive stretch of the pectoralis major/minor. The elbow is commonly flexed to place the forearm on the frame (elbow flexion, sagittal plane) and the thorax leans forward slightly (small sagittal flexion) to increase stretch. Because the humerus moves posteriorly relative to the torso (horizontal abduction/shoulder extension) this motion is mechanically similar to the open‑chain component of a horizontal 'pull' pattern (rows produce horizontal shoulder extension/abduction). reasoning: Downward-facing dog is a closed-chain, upper-body weight-bearing posture where the shoulders and arms support body weight against the ground. The primary joint demands are isometric shoulder loading (shoulder flexion with scapular depression/ upward rotation) and elbow extension to transmit force into the floor; the hips are elevated into hip flexion with knee extension and the spine is in a forward-folded (flexed) orientation. Because the arms are actively pressing into the ground to support and partially elevate the torso, the exercise aligns most closely with a PUSH pattern (an isometric/loaded upper-body push). Lower-body actions are primarily passive/isometric (hamstrings and calves lengthened and providing support) and the core/shoulder girdle act as stabilizers rather than producing a primary pulling or hinging movement.

reasoning: The Drag Curl is primarily an elbow-flexion movement (a curl) performed with the elbows drawn posteriorly so the bar or implement is 'dragged' up the torso. reasoning: Downward Dog is a bilateral, closed‑chain, isometric weight‑bearing posture on the hands with the hips elevated in an inverted-V. Primary mechanical demand is on the shoulders/scapulae to support and depress the trunk through a pushing contact with the ground (PUSH pattern). Secondarily the hips are held in substantial flexion with knees near extension, placing an isometric/lengthened load on the posterior chain (hip hinge-like posture) and therefore a HINGE classification is appropriate as a secondary pattern. Primary joint actions are shoulder flexion with scapular upward rotation and depression to accept load (sagittal/frontal), hip flexion (sagittal) with knee extension (sagittal) and ankle dorsiflexion (sagittal) as the heels are driven toward the floor. The spine is held in a relatively long, neutral to slight thoracic flexion position requiring core isometric control.

reasoning: Downward Facing Balance is a single‑leg variation of Downward Dog: the hands remain weight‑bearing on the floor (closed‑chain shoulder loading = PUSH pattern, isometric/force‑transmission through the shoulders/elbows) while one leg lifts into hip extension with knee extension (dynamic hip extension = HINGE pattern). Because the posture is asymmetric (one leg lifted), the trunk and hips must resist rotation and lateral collapse, so anti‑rotational core/hip stabilization is a primary stabilizing demand. Primary movers for the lifted leg (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) produce hip extension in the sagittal plane; the shoulder complex (deltoids, serratus anterior, triceps acting isometrically) transmits load to the hands; obliques and deep core (transverse abdominis) along with contralateral hip abductors/isometrics resist rotation and frontal‑plane drop.

exercise: Duffel Rows (2-s squeeze to low ribs)
reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal/vertical pulling motion: elbow flexion combined with shoulder extension/adduction and scapular retraction to bring the load to the low ribs. The prime movers are the lats, rhomboids and middle/lower traps with assistance from posterior deltoid and elbow flexors; the trunk and hips act isometrically to maintain a hinged torso and resist rotation. If performed unilaterally (single-arm), significant anti-rotation demand is placed on the core to prevent axial rotation; if performed supported or bilaterally, anti-rotation demand is reduced but the primary pattern remains a PULL.
notes: If performed single-arm and standing/unsupported, include ANTI_ROTATION (as listed). If performed with chest support on a bench or as a bilateral row, anti-rotation demand is minimal and PULL alone would suffice. '2-s squeeze to low ribs' emphasizes scapular retraction and lat engagement.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane produced by concentric shortening of the elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis). The forearm typically supinates (transverse plane) during a supinated curl, increasing biceps engagement. The shoulder and scapula act isometrically to position and stabilize the arm while the contralateral/unilateral load creates an asymmetric moment on the trunk requiring anti-rotational/isometric core activity to resist lateral flexion and rotation. Therefore the movement is primarily a PULL (elbow flexion) with a secondary ANTI_ROTATION demand from unilateral loading and alternating single-arm execution.
notes: If performed as a hammer grip (neutral), brachioradialis contribution increases. Excessive trunk lean or shoulder movement indicates technique breakdown; unilateral execution increases anti-rotational core demand. Strict seated curls reduce anti-rotation requirement and isolate elbow flexors more.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane produced by the elbow flexors. The biceps brachii, brachialis and brachioradialis concentically shorten to produce elbow flexion; the biceps also contributes to forearm supination (transverse plane) when the forearm is not already supinated. The shoulder complex and trunk act primarily isometrically to stabilize the upper arm and torso (prevent shoulder flexion/extension and trunk sway) while the wrist and radioulnar joints control hand position. No primary hip/knee/ankle movement is required.
notes: If performed unilaterally or with trunk lean, ANTI_ROTATION demands increase. Hammer-grip variation shifts emphasis toward brachioradialis and reduces supination contribution. Cheating with shoulder/elbow motion converts some work to shoulder flexion and reduces isolation.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are scapulothoracic retraction (scapular adduction) and elbow flexion as the hand/weight is drawn toward the torso — a horizontal pulling action (transverse plane for shoulder/scapula, sagittal for elbow). The movement is driven primarily by shoulder extension/scapular retraction and elbow flexion; the trunk and hips act isometrically to maintain posture. The 2-second squeeze emphasizes isometric scapular retraction at the top of the pull.

reasoning: The dumbbell clean is initiated by a hip-dominant triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to generate upward momentum (HINGE pattern). This is followed by an active upper-body pull (shrug and rapid elbow flexion/forearm movement) to accelerate the load and transition into the rack/catch position (PULL pattern). Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee extension for the propulsive phase, sagittal-plane ankle plantarflexion for final drive, and scapulothoracic elevation plus elbow flexion/shoulder motion to pull and receive the dumbbells. The trunk must isometrically stabilize (prevent excessive lumbar flexion/extension) and the shoulder girdle and grip musculature stabilize the load during the catch. If the clean is caught in a deep squat (squat clean) an additional SQUAT pattern may be present, and unilateral or alternating dumbbell variations add anti-rotation demands.
notes: Variation-dependent: hang or power clean primarily HINGE+PULL. Deep squat catch converts to HINGE+PULL+SQUAT. Single-arm dumbbell cleans introduce significant ANTI_ROTATION/stabilization demands.

exercise: Dumbbell Deadlift (component of Burpee → Dumbbell Deadlift)
reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge (hip extension) with concurrent knee extension to stand from a hip-flexed position — sagittal plane. The posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, erector spinae) generates the primary extensor torque while the quads assist knee extension. The upper body performs a loaded pull-stabilization: scapular and shoulder girdle act isometrically with the lats/traps and forearms maintaining grip and trunk position. Core and spinal extensors resist flexion and maintain neutral spine throughout.
notes: As part of a burpee sequence fatigue and tempo may reduce technical fidelity (increased lumbar flexion). Dumbbell grip is typically neutral; symmetrical loading means no anti-rotation pattern. Variations (Romanian, sumo) shift relative knee vs hip contribution.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal push: shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) combined with elbow extension (sagittal plane). The chest (pec major) produces horizontal adduction, anterior deltoid assists shoulder movement, and triceps brachii produces elbow extension. Scapular and core musculature act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and scapulae; on the floor scapular posterior tilt/retraction is limited, reducing shoulder extension ROM and increasing relative triceps contribution.
notes: Floor press is a horizontal push variation with restricted shoulder ROM (contact with floor). Bilateral DB floor press = PUSH; unilateral/single-arm variations add significant anti-rotation demand. Useful for reducing shoulder strain and increasing triceps emphasis compared to full-range bench press.

reasoning: Primary movement is a bilateral squat pattern: hip and knee flexion during descent and coordinated hip and knee extension during ascent in the sagittal plane. The anterior-held dumbbell isometrically loaded at the chest requires trunk anti-flexion (core/erector spinae) to maintain an upright torso and shoulder/elbow isometric flexion to hold the implement. Quadriceps and gluteus maximus are the primary force producers for knee and hip extension; hamstrings, adductors and calves contribute secondarily. Scapular/shoulder and grip musculature stabilize the load, and the core resists forward trunk collapse and maintains neutral spine.

reasoning: Primary joint action is shoulder horizontal adduction (bringing the humerus from an abducted position toward midline) performed in the transverse (horizontal) plane. The shoulders are the prime moving joints; the elbows remain slightly flexed and largely isometric. The pectoralis major produces the horizontal adduction, with the anterior deltoid as a secondary mover. Rotator cuff muscles and scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius) work isometrically to stabilize the glenohumeral joint and scapula throughout the ROM. Because the movement moves the arm toward the front of the body against resistance, it is classified as a horizontal PUSH pattern (a horizontal adduction variant of a push).
notes: High end-range shoulder stress — maintain a slight elbow bend and scapular retraction. Incline/decline bench changes the dominant portion of the pectoralis major (more clavicular or sternal). Unilateral/single-arm fly variations introduce anti-rotation demand on the core and may be classified additionally as ANTI_ROTATION for asymmetric stabilization.

reasoning: Performed prone on an incline bench, the exercise raises the humerus posteriorly/away from the torso (shoulder horizontal abduction/extension and often some external rotation) — primary joint action is at the glenohumeral joint producing a backward pull of the upper arm. Scapular retractors (middle trapezius, rhomboids) and posterior deltoid/rotator cuff drive the movement; the elbows remain slightly flexed and relatively static. exercise: Dumbbell Lying One-Arm Rear Lateral Raise
reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder horizontal abduction (transverse plane) of the humerus — an upper-body pulling action that moves the arm posteriorly away from the midline. The posterior deltoid produces the main humeral movement while the rotator cuff (infraspinatus/teres minor) assists and stabilizes the glenohumeral joint. Scapular retractors (middle trapezius, rhomboids) control scapulothoracic motion. The elbow remains in a fixed, slightly flexed position (isometric) and the spine/torso is isometrically stabilized against extension/rotation when lying prone. Because the dominant joint action is an upper-body pull (horizontal/posterior), this is classified as a PULL pattern. Lying reduces anti-rotation demand compared with standing unilateral variations.
notes: If performed standing/unilateral without torso support, add ANTI_ROTATION due to asymmetric load. Thumb orientation and arm path can shift emphasis between posterior deltoid and lateral rotators. Performed prone on a bench minimizes lower-body involvement.

reasoning: This exercise produces transverse-plane rotation of the forearm at the radioulnar joint (pronation). The motion is not a push/pull/carry/horizontal or vertical displacement of the body, but a rotational action of the forearm against resistance.
notes: Commonly performed unilaterally with the elbow supported; variations include seated or standing forearm pronation. Ensure wrist/shoulder stability; small loads typically used due to lever arm and smaller pronator muscles.

reasoning: Primary action is transverse-plane rotation of the forearm (supination) at the proximal and distal radioulnar joints. The elbow is typically held isometrically (often flexed) to position the forearm while the shoulder and scapula provide isometric stabilization to resist unwanted movement. Holding a dumbbell increases external rotational torque, requiring greater forearm supinator and stabilizer activation.
notes: Single-joint rotation exercise for forearm supination. Variation: performing with elbow at side vs. elevated changes biceps contribution. reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder horizontal abduction (transverse plane) with concomitant scapular retraction; the motion is essentially a posterior shoulder/upper-back pulling action. The rotator cuff (infraspinatus/teres minor) eccentrically/stabilizes the glenohumeral joint and the spine/core maintain a neutral, isometric trunk position while the elbow remains slightly flexed as a positional/stabilizing joint.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: shoulder elevation (shoulder flexion/abduction in the sagittal/scapular plane) with elbow extension to press the dumbbell overhead. Deltoids and triceps are the prime movers. Because the load is unilateral, the core (obliques, quadratus lumborum, contralateral erector spinae) must produce isometric anti-rotation and resist lateral flexion, so ANTI_ROTATION is a required secondary pattern. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius) and rotator cuff muscles act to stabilize the glenohumeral joint and scapula. Lower-limb and pelvic muscles provide an isometric/bracing base.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane with the lifter chest-supported on an incline bench (prone incline). reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow extension in the sagittal plane produced by the triceps brachii (with anconeus assisting). Because the load is unilateral, the torso/core must resist rotation and lateral flexion (transverse/frontal plane isometric stabilization) — therefore an anti-rotation demand is present as a secondary stabilization requirement when performed standing or seated without trunk bracing. notes: If performed supine (skullcrusher) or with full bench support, anti-rotation demand is minimal and classification could be solely PUSH. Standing or seated single-arm variations increase core anti-rotation demands. Primary purpose: elbow extension (isolated triceps work).

reasoning: Primary movement is an upper-limb pull: shoulder extension (and scapular retraction) combined with elbow flexion in the sagittal/transverse regions to bring the DB toward the torso. reasoning: Commonly performed as a lateral (or sometimes front) shoulder raise: the primary joint action is shoulder abduction (lateral raise) in the frontal plane (or shoulder flexion in the sagittal plane for a front raise). Because this is an isolated, open-chain shoulder elevation against gravity/resistance, it is best classified with the PUSH family of upper-body single-joint/shoulder-dominant patterns.
notes: Exercise name is ambiguous (lateral vs front raise). If performed as a single-arm movement with an asymmetric load, include ANTI_ROTATION for lateral trunk stabilization; if performed as an overhead press (elbow extension against load) reclassify as a vertical PUSH.

reasoning: Primary movement is explosive triple-extension from a seated start: hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane to propel the body vertically onto a box. Quadriceps produce knee extension, gluteus maximus (with hamstrings assisting) produces hip extension, and gastrocnemius/soleus produce ankle plantarflexion. Holding dumbbells isometric in the hands increases load and requires grip and shoulder/scapular stabilization but does not change the primary sagittal-plane, knee/hip-dominant propulsive pattern. notes: Seated start reduces countermovement amplitude compared with standing jumps; dumbbells increase load and require additional grip/shoulder stabilization but do not create significant frontal/transverse components unless held asymmetrically. reasoning: Primary movement is glenohumeral elevation in the scapular plane (scaption) — an abduction/forward-abduction of the humerus against gravity. The glenohumeral joint produces the primary motion while the scapulothoracic articulation undergoes upward rotation to allow full elevation. Elbow remains near-extended and acts largely as a static link; the thorax/spine provides isometric postural stabilization. Muscles producing the movement are primarily the middle deltoid and supraspinatus with contribution from the anterior deltoid; scapular upward rotation is provided by upper/lower trapezius and serratus anterior. Core and rotator cuff muscles provide stabilization and control. Because this is a single-joint shoulder elevation (vertical push-type action) the movement pattern is classified as PUSH.
notes: Performed with thumbs-up (external rotation) to reduce impingement. Bilateral scaption is symmetrical (no anti-rotation requirement); single-arm variations introduce asymmetric load and increased anti-rotation/core demand. Typically a low-load, single-joint shoulder strengthening/rehab exercise.

reasoning: Primary motion is scapulothoracic elevation (shoulder girdle elevation) in the frontal plane — the shoulders are driven upward to raise the load. Primary movers are the upper trapezius and levator scapulae with assistance from the rhomboids and middle trapezius for scapular control. The glenohumeral joint and elbows remain relatively static (elbows hold the weight isometrically) while the spine and core act isometrically to maintain upright posture and prevent excessive lumbar extension.

reasoning: Primary joint action is ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane performed unilaterally from a seated position. notes: This is primarily a single-joint ankle plantarflexion (calf raise) isolating the soleus in seated posture; none of the provided movement-pattern labels cleanly represent ankle isolation. reasoning: Primary movement is unilateral lateral flexion of the lumbar/thoracic spine in the frontal plane (side bend) performed with a loaded hand. The spine performs lateral flexion toward the load (concentric) and controls return eccentrically. Primary movers producing the lateral flexion are the ipsilateral quadratus lumborum and obliques with assistance from ipsilateral erector spinae. reasoning: Primary action is a vertical press: concentric glenohumeral elevation (shoulder flexion/abduction into overhead) with concomitant elbow extension to drive the dumbbells upward. The trunk and hips act isometrically to stabilize the spine and transfer force (especially when performed standing). Rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control humeral head position and scapular motion. primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

reasoning: Primary movement is unilateral sagittal-plane hip and knee extension of the lead leg to elevate the body onto a raised surface (step-up). If dumbbells are held symmetrically at the sides, load is bilateral and does not create significant anti-rotation demand.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow extension in the sagittal plane produced by the triceps complex. primary_muscles: rotator cuff / scapular stabilizers (infraspinatus, supraspinatus, subscapularis, serratus anterior, trapezius)

reasoning: Dynamic lunges are primarily a sagittal-plane lunge pattern involving sequential hip and knee flexion on the lead limb during descent and hip and knee extension during the drive/return. The movement requires active concentric and eccentric control of the quadriceps and gluteal complex to lower and raise the body, with ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion at the talocrural joint and isometric core and frontal-plane hip stabilization (gluteus medius/abductors) for balance. If performed as walking lunges the locomotor component is present, but the primary pattern remains a lunge.
notes: Variations (forward, reverse, walking, lateral) alter emphasis: longer step increases hip extension demand (glutes), shorter step increases knee/quad demand. Walking lunges add a locomotion element; added load or asymmetry introduces carry/anti-rotation requirements. Pay attention to knee tracking and trunk alignment for safety.

reasoning: A Dynamic Back Stretch is primarily a spinal mobility exercise that produces repeated sagittal plane flexion/extension of the spine and often includes thoracic rotation (transverse plane) depending on the variation. The primary joint actions occur at the spinal segments (thoracic and lumbar) with secondary movement or assistance from the hips (small sagittal plane motion) and shoulders (if hands are used to push or reach). Muscles producing the dynamic actions include the spinal extensors during extension, the abdominals during controlled flexion, and the obliques/multifidus during any rotational components. Stabilization is provided isometrically by deep core stabilizers (transversus abdominis, multifidus) and the hip extensors/gluteals to maintain pelvic position; the scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, rhomboids) assist if the upper limb contacts the ground or reaches.
notes: Exercise is a mobility/stretching movement with considerable variation (cat–cow, cobra, thoracic rotations, rocking child’s pose). If the specific variation emphasizes thoracic rotation, keep ROTATION classification; if it is purely sagittal spine flexion/extension using hands to push up (cobra), consider also treating it as a light PUSH for shoulder action in programming. Manual review recommended if a more specific variant is provided.

reasoning: Dynamic mobility drills are a heterogeneous category typically composed of walking/stepping patterns, rotational thoracic/hip/shoulder movements, and repeated lunge-based hip mobilizations. Primary joint actions include repeated hip flexion/extension during stepping (sagittal), hip abduction/adduction and frontal-plane movement for lateral mobility drills, and spinal (thoracic/lumbar) rotation in the transverse plane for thoracic wind-ups and reach/rotate drills. Many drills also include knee flexion/extension and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion for gait-like patterns and require shoulder flexion/rotation for arm swings. Stabilization demands are primarily isometric core control (anti-extension/anti-rotation) and single‑leg balance control via glute medius and ankle stabilizers during unilateral steps/lunges.
notes: This classification is intentionally broad; specific drills (e.g., leg swings, world's greatest stretch, inchworms, walking lunges) will emphasize particular patterns more strongly. Provide a specific drill for a more precise single/multiple pattern assignment.

reasoning: The dynamic chest stretch primarily opens the anterior shoulder by moving the humerus into horizontal abduction/shoulder extension with the elbows commonly extended — movements that are mechanically analogous to a horizontal pull (scapular retraction and posterior shoulder excursion). Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal abduction (transverse) and shoulder extension (sagittal) often coupled with external rotation; the thoracic spine commonly extends to increase the chest opening. Stabilization demands are low for the lower body but require isometric activity of the scapular stabilizers and spinal extensors to maintain upright posture and allow the shoulder girdle to retract and the thoracic spine to extend.
notes: Variation exists: some dynamic chest stretches are passive (doorway stretch) or include arm swings; if performed as active band pull-aparts the classification as PULL is stronger. Scapular retraction/protraction is a key component but scapula is represented here via shoulder girdle mechanics.

reasoning: The exercise title is ambiguous but describes a dynamic warm‑up/setup sequence that most commonly uses stepping/marching/controlled gait-like movements. Primary joint actions are repeated hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane (locomotion pattern). Secondary actions often include trunk stabilization and occasional transverse/frontal plane components (arm/shoulder swings, hip internal/external rotation) depending on drills. Muscles producing the primary movements are the hip extensors/flexors, knee extensors/flexors and plantarflexors/dorsiflexors; the trunk and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to control posture and equipment setup.
notes: Exercise description is non‑specific. Typical dynamic warm‑ups contain locomotion elements (marching, carioca, lunges, arm swings). If the actual drill includes lunges, single‑leg hops, or rotational drills, add LUNGE, HINGE, LOCOMOTION or ROTATION accordingly. Recommend manual review or supplying a short video/step list to refine classification.

exercise: Dynamic Mobility (Cat-Cow, Arm Swings, Hip Circles)
reasoning: This sequence primarily moves axial and appendicular segments through multi-planar, rotational and sagittal excursions rather than producing a loaded push/pull or locomotor force. Cat–Cow produces spinal flexion/extension (sagittal) with dynamic mobility through the thoracic and lumbar segments; arm swings create shoulder flexion/extension and horizontal/transverse swings of the humerus (sagittal and transverse); hip circles produce hip internal/external rotation and circumduction (transverse and frontal components). The dominant mechanical quality is controlled rotation/circumduction of spine, shoulder, and hip joints rather than resisted linear push/pull or load carriage. Stabilization is primarily dynamic: deep spinal stabilizers and obliques control segment motion, scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff guide shoulder motion, and hip abductors/adductors stabilize pelvis during hip circles.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (with thoracic rotational mobility components in transverse)

No external load, no anti-rotation/isometric requirement beyond normal dynamic stabilization.

reasoning: Dynamic Pigeon is primarily a hip mobility drill that moves the femur through transverse-plane rotation (external/internal) combined with frontal-plane abduction/adduction and sagittal-plane hip flexion/extension as the pelvis rocks. The primary joint moving is the hip (rotation + some flexion/extension and ab/adduction); the knee remains in flexion but is largely a passive hinge; the lumbar/pelvic complex provides rotational and postural stabilization. Movement is driven by hip external rotators and abductors when opening the hip (gluteus medius/minimus, piriformis, deep external rotators) and by hip internal rotators/hip flexors and adductors when returning/closing (gluteus minimus anterior fibers, TFL, adductors, iliopsoas). Core (obliques, transverse abdominis) and contralateral hip stabilizers act isometrically to control pelvic position and prevent unwanted lumbar rotation or drop.
notes: Commonly performed from a prone/quadruped or seated variation (90/90); primarily a mobility/rotational pattern rather than a load-bearing strength pattern. Progressions may add loaded isometrics or dynamic flow but the core mechanic remains hip rotation and pelvic control.

reasoning: This is a multi‑planar dynamic mobility sequence primarily producing hip and shoulder rotations and multi‑planar excursions. Primary joint actions are hip internal/external rotation, hip flexion/extension and abduction/adduction (transverse + sagittal + frontal planes) and shoulder internal/external rotation, flexion/extension and abduction/adduction (transverse + sagittal + frontal planes). The spine (thoracic) commonly contributes transverse rotation and extension for shoulder/upper‑body mobility. Movement is driven by active muscular contractions (not loaded carry/push/pull patterns), so the dominant pattern is ROTATION/multi‑planar mobility. Stabilization demands include isometric core control (obliques/erector spinae) to control trunk rotation, and scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) to control shoulder blade motion during arm swings/rotations.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow extension in the sagittal plane (lying supine), produced by the triceps brachii as the weight is lowered and pressed back up. The shoulder is held relatively fixed (isometric stabilization) to maintain upper-arm position; scapular and rotator cuff muscles provide stabilization. This is a horizontal pressing pattern focused on elbow extension rather than whole-body movement.
notes: Single-joint isolation for triceps; changing shoulder angle (incline/decline) alters long-head involvement. Caution with elbow joint stress—control eccentric phase and avoid terminal hyperextension. When performed with elbows flared vs tucked, shoulder stabilization demands change slightly but movement pattern remains PUSH (elbow extension).

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane produced by concentric contraction of the elbow flexors. The EZ-bar curl is an upper-body pulling action at the elbow; the shoulder complex and core act isometrically to stabilize the humerus and torso. Forearm supination contribution is reduced but present depending on grip, and wrist extensors/flexors stabilize the bar. Primary joint action is elbow flexion (sagittal); shoulder and spine provide isometric stabilization.
notes: EZ-bar's semi-supinated/snake-like grip alters forearm supination demand and can reduce wrist strain compared with straight-bar curls; variations (incline, preacher, hammer) change shoulder orientation and relative muscle emphasis but do not change primary pattern of elbow flexion (PULL).

exercise: Dynamic mobility (hip circles, leg swings, Spiderman lunges)

Primary joint actions are hip flexion/extension (sagittal), hip abduction/adduction (frontal) and hip internal/external rotation (transverse); Spiderman lunges add knee flexion/extension and dynamic single‑leg loading/stepping mechanics. Stabilization demands include single‑leg balance and isometric core control (obliques/erectors) to control pelvic/spinal orientation during rotation and limb pendulum.

reasoning: Dynamic stretching/mobility drills are multi-planar, movement-focused activities that frequently emphasize spinal and limb rotation (transverse), deep squat/postural opening (sagittal/frontal hip and knee flexion/abduction), and stepping/lunge patterns (sagittal hip/knee flexion-extension with frontal stability). Primary joint actions typically include thoracic and pelvic rotation, hip flexion/extension and abduction/adduction, knee flexion/extension, and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion. Muscles producing these actions include the hip extensors/flexors and knee extensors/flexors for squat and lunge mechanics and the obliques/erector spinae and rotator cuff/shoulder musculature for rotation and upper-body mobility. Significant isometric stabilization from the core and scapular stabilizers is required to control posture through ranges of motion. reasoning: Elbow circles are primarily a rotational/circumduction mobility exercise of the upper limb. The dominant joint motion arises from the glenohumeral joint producing cyclic flexion/extension and abduction/adduction (circumduction) with accompanying transverse-plane rotation; the elbow undergoes repetitive flexion/extension as it traces a circular path and the forearm may pronate/supinate slightly. Primary movers are the deltoid heads and rotator cuff muscles producing and controlling the shoulder rotation, with biceps and triceps producing the elbow flexion/extension component. Scapular stabilizers (trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids) act isometrically to position the shoulder girdle, and core muscles provide minor stabilization of the trunk. Because the exercise's primary characteristic is repeated rotational motion of the shoulder/elbow complex, it best maps to the ROTATION movement pattern.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

notes: Variation: performing with hands on shoulders emphasizes shoulder circumduction (less forearm rotation). Performed as a mobility/stretching drill rather than a force-producing pattern. Low load, primarily movement quality and ROM — not a strength-focused pattern.

reasoning: This is a two-phase compound upper-body sequence. Phase 1 (eccentric reverse curl) primarily involves controlled lengthening of the elbow flexors under a pronated grip (brachioradialis/ brachialis / biceps) as the elbow moves toward extension in the sagittal plane — a pulling pattern at the elbow. Phase 2 (fast push) is an explosive horizontal pushing action from the shoulder (primary shoulder horizontal adduction/transverse plane) with concurrent concentric elbow extension (triceps) — a horizontal PUSH. Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles act isometrically to stabilize the glenohumeral joint and scapula; the trunk provides anti-rotation/isometric stabilization especially if performed unilateral or asymmetrically.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction / protraction (primary during fast push)

notes: If performed single-arm or with offset loading, add ANTI_ROTATION consideration. Emphasis: eccentric control of elbow flexors followed by explosive horizontal push. Ensure adequate rotator cuff and scapular stability; progressive loading of eccentric and plyo push phases for rehab/strength work.

reasoning: Primary demand is isometric trunk stabilization in the sagittal plane—the core resists spinal flexion (and secondary sagging/extension) to maintain a neutral spine. Hips and knees are held in near-full extension isometrically to keep a rigid torso; shoulders and scapulothoracic muscles produce isometric stabilization to support the upper body on the forearms. Although this is primarily an anti-extension/anti-flexion core hold (not a rotational task), the exercise requires anti-rotation capacity to resist any transverse-plane torque and maintain alignment, so ANTI_ROTATION is the best fit from the available patterns.
notes: This classification interprets core isometric anti-extension/anti-flexion as best represented by the available ANTI_ROTATION pattern because the exercise requires resisting transverse and sagittal deviations. Variations: side plank emphasizes lateral (frontal plane) anti-lateral-flexion and would be classified with greater anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion emphasis; plank with arm/leg lifts increases anti-rotation demand.

reasoning: The elbow plank is an isometric core stabilization exercise whose primary demand is resisting sagittal-plane spinal flexion (anti-extension) and resisting rotational perturbation — classified under ANTI_ROTATION because the core (transverse abdominis, obliques, rectus) and spinal extensors produce isometric torque to maintain neutral spine. Secondarily the shoulders and elbows produce isometric support (vertical load-bearing / pressing demand) to hold the torso off the ground, fitting a PUSH-type shoulder/elbow isometric action. Hips, knees and ankles are held in isometric extension to maintain a rigid lever. Stabilization demands include scapular stability (serratus anterior, traps), gluteal activation to prevent hip sag, and isometric quadriceps to maintain knee extension.
notes: Elbow plank is primarily an anti-extension/anti-rotation core isometric. Listed secondary PUSH reflects the shoulder/elbow isometric load-bearing demand. Variations (side plank, single-leg plank, high plank) increase anti-rotation or shoulder demand. If strictly classifying by anti-extension only, a bespoke ANTI_EXTENSION label would be ideal but is not available in the provided pattern list.

reasoning: The elbow plank is an isometric, anterior-chain/core stabilization task performed in a horizontal (prone) body position. Primary joint demands are isometric shoulder flexion and elbow flexion at the upper limb supporting the body, and isometric hip and knee extension maintaining a straight line. The spine is held in neutral against sagittal flexion (anti-extension). Although there is no concentric push, the posture and force vector are equivalent to a horizontal push hold (similar to the bottom of a push-up) so the exercise maps to the PUSH pattern; the core also resists rotational perturbations and any asymmetric loading, so ANTI_ROTATION is included as a secondary pattern. Muscles produce mainly isometric force to prevent joint motion rather than creating movement.

joint_actions.action: isometric (resists sagittal flexion / maintains neutral extension)
isometric elbow flexion (forearm on ground supports load)

notes: Primary purpose is anti-extension/core stabilization. reasoning: This is primarily a trunk/spine flexion with transverse-plane rotation movement (typical in bicycle/crunch variations where the elbow moves toward the opposite knee). Primary joint actions are spinal flexion and contralateral rotation plus hip flexion to bring the knee up. The obliques and rectus abdominis produce trunk flexion and rotation while hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) flex the hip. The pelvis and lumbar spine must be stabilized by the deep core (transverse abdominis) and gluteal/hip stabilizers to control spinal position; shoulders/neck act as passive anchors if hands are behind the head.
notes: Commonly performed as a supine bicycle crunch (cross-body) or standing elbow-to-knee; if performed anti-rotation (isometric) or as a marching carry variation, classification would change. Watch for neck strain in supine variations; range of rotation and hip flexion determines emphases on obliques vs hip flexors.

reasoning: The elbow plank is an isometric core-stability exercise. The primary joint action is isometric trunk stabilization in the sagittal plane (preventing lumbar sag/extension and maintaining a neutral spine) with concomitant resistance to rotational and lateral perturbation (anti-rotation/anti-extension). Secondary primary demand is isometric load-bearing at the shoulder and elbow to support bodyweight in a horizontal orientation (functionally similar to an isometric horizontal push). Hips and knees are held in isometric extension to maintain a rigid lever between shoulders and feet. Muscles of the anterior core (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, obliques) produce the anti-extension/anti-rotation torque, while glutes/quads maintain hip/knee extension and deltoids/triceps/serratus anterior stabilize the shoulder girdle.

joint_actions.action: isometric trunk stabilization (anti-extension and resistance to rotation)

notes: Symmetric elbow plank primarily trains anti-extension/anti-rotation and isometrically loads the upper body (hence ANTI_ROTATION + PUSH). Variations: side plank emphasizes anti-lateral-flexion; single-arm/leg plank increases anti-rotation and unilateral shoulder demand; wrist plank shifts shoulder loading patterns.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal/decline PUSH: shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) paired with elbow extension (sagittal plane) to drive the torso away from the hands. The torso and hips act isometrically to resist spinal flexion/extension (anti-extension) and maintain a rigid plank, and the scapulothoracic musculature controls protraction/retraction for stable shoulder mechanics. Feet-elevated (decline) increases relative load on the shoulders/upper chest but does not change the fundamental push-dominant pattern.
notes: Feet-elevated/decline variation shifts more load toward clavicular fibers of pec and anterior deltoid (greater shoulder demand). Hand width and box height alter emphasis (narrow increases triceps demand; higher foot elevation increases vertical component). No substantial rotational or carry component.

reasoning: The elliptical replicates a gait-like, alternating lower-limb movement dominated by hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane — essentially a closed-chain locomotion pattern. Primary propulsion comes from repeated concentric/eccentric action of the glutes, hamstrings and quadriceps with plantarflexors assisting. Trunk muscles act isometrically to maintain upright posture and resist unwanted rotation. Arm handles (when used) add optional reciprocal sagittal shoulder flexion/extension (push/pull) but are secondary to the lower-limb locomotor pattern.
notes: Primary classification is LOCOMOTION. If using moving handles, include secondary upper-body push/pull involvement but lower-limb gait mechanics remain dominant. Low rotational/anti-rotation demand unless performing single-arm or asymmetric handle use.

reasoning: The elbow plank is an isometric core stabilization hold in the sagittal plane. Primary joint demands are isometric control of the spine (preventing sagittal-plane collapse/extension) and maintenance of hip and knee extension; the shoulder complex and scapulae provide isometric support to keep the torso elevated. Although there is no concentric movement, the exercise functions as an anti-movement (anti-extension/anti-rotation) pattern: the anterior trunk (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, obliques) resists spinal extension and rotation, glutes and quads maintain hip/knee extension, and scapular stabilizers/anterior shoulder musculature stabilize the shoulder girdle.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion/stabilization (holds torso up, scapular stabilization)
joint_actions.plane: sagittal (stabilization) with frontal/transverse components at scapula

notes: Plank is fundamentally an anti-extension/anti-rotation core hold. reasoning: The cue "Elbows Back" primarily drives scapular retraction and posterior movement of the humerus, which biomechanically is a pulling/scapular retraction action. Primary joint actions are shoulder extension/horizontal abduction (moving the upper arm posteriorly) and scapular retraction; the thoracic spine often extends to allow the shoulder blades to come together. This recruits scapular retractors (middle trapezius, rhomboids) and posterior shoulder/latissimus musculature to actively pull the elbows back while anterior chest structures (pectoralis major/minor) are lengthened. Stabilization requires isometric elbow flexion (if elbows remain bent) and engagement of thoracic extensors and scapular stabilizers to control posture during the movement.

notes: Typically performed as a mobility/activation cue to strengthen scapular retractors and open the chest. If performed actively against resistance (band/weight), it functions as a horizontal pull/row variation. Ensure thoracic extension rather than cervical retraction; watch for compensatory elevation of shoulders (upper trap dominance).

reasoning: Primary movement is repeated spinal flexion (lumbar and thoracic) in the sagittal plane — the trunk 'hinges' forward over the pelvis. Rectus abdominis concentrically shortens to produce flexion, with external obliques assisting; hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) often contribute to initiate or stabilize the pelvis. The pelvis and hips act as a proximal anchor and may exhibit small sagittal motion; the exercise also requires cervical and scapular stabilization to maintain head/shoulder position on the ball. The stability ball increases thoracic ROM and requires additional balance control from the core and hip stabilizers.
notes: Although not a classic 'hinge' of the hip, the exercise is best mapped to a trunk/spinal hinge pattern. Variations: adding rotation (oblique crunches) would add ROTATION; bracing/anti-rotation holds (static ball roll-outs) would include ANTI_ROTATION. Pay attention to neck positioning and avoid excessive hip flexion that shifts work from rectus abdominis to hip flexors.

reasoning: Primary movement is external (lateral) rotation of the glenohumeral joint in the transverse plane. The rotator cuff (infraspinatus and teres minor) and posterior deltoid generate the rotational torque. The elbow is commonly held at ~90° and functions as a lever/stabilized joint; the scapulothoracic musculature (lower/middle trapezius, rhomboids, serratus anterior) provides scapular stability/isometric positioning. The spine and core act isometrically to maintain neutral posture during the movement. Because the dominant joint action is transverse-plane rotation of the shoulder, this classifies as a ROTATION pattern.
notes: Common variations: band or cable external rotation (standing), side-lying dumbbell ER, prone ER at 90° abduction. Elbow position (tucked at side vs. abducted) changes lever arm and scapular demand. Primarily an isolation/rotator-cuff strengthening movement rather than global push/pull/squat/hinge pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is glenohumeral external rotation in the transverse plane. The rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor) eccentrically/ concentrically rotate the humerus laterally; posterior deltoid can assist. The elbow is typically held in ~90° flexion as a stable lever (isometric), and the thorax/scapular stabilizers (trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids) act isometrically to prevent scapular winging and trunk compensation. Movement is isolated rotation of the shoulder with minimal sagittal/frontal plane displacement.
notes: Common variations: performed with elbow at side (standing) or at 90° abduction (prone/side-lying). Emphasize scapular stabilization to avoid substitution (shoulder extension or trunk rotation). Progress via band tension, range of motion, or added repetitions.

reasoning: The movement is performed from a plank position with the feet/shins on a stability ball and the knees drawn toward the chest. Primary joint actions are concentric hip flexion and knee flexion in the sagittal plane (bringing the lower limb toward the trunk) driven by the hip flexors and rectus abdominis. The upper body (shoulders/scapulae) performs an isometric push-style stabilization to maintain a plank and resist lumbar extension, so the shoulders/triceps/serratus anterior act isometrically. The trunk/abdominals produce dynamic spinal flexion/pelvic posterior tilt to shorten the distance between hips and ribs. Stabilization demands include scapular stability and anti-extension of the lumbar spine throughout the movement.
notes: Variation: a pike (hips elevated) emphasizes hip flexion and rectus abdominis more. Key considerations: maintain scapular stability and neutral lumbar alignment to avoid shear; regress by performing bent-knee tucks on stable surface or progress to pike/instability variations.

exercise: Explosive knee strikes to sandbag/Bob (alternating sides)
reasoning: Primary movement is an explosive unilateral knee drive/strike produced by rapid hip flexion and knee extension in the sagittal plane with concurrent transverse-plane rotation of pelvis and torso toward the striking side. The drive transfers force into the target (a propulsive/striking action — classified as a PUSH pattern) while the torso/hips generate and amplify force through axial rotation (ROTATION). Stabilization requirements include single‑leg support demands on the stance limb (hip abductors, glute medius) and isometric core control (obliques, erector spinae) to manage frontal-plane stability and to sequence rotation.
primary_muscles: gluteus medius/gluteus maximus (stabilization and hip torque)

flexion to load then rapid extension at strike/contact

exercise: Extended Range One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
reasoning: Primary movement is a unilateral horizontal push: shoulder moves through horizontal adduction/forward elevation to bring the kettlebell away from the chest while the elbow extends to lockout. Primary concentric movers are the pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps producing shoulder adduction/flexion and elbow extension (transverse and sagittal planes). Because the load is unilateral and offset from the midline, the core (obliques, transverse abdominis) and contralateral shoulder girdle must produce isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion torque to resist trunk and scapular rotation. Rotator cuff and serratus anterior work to stabilize the glenohumeral joint and scapula during the press.
notes: Extended range (larger ROM) increases shoulder demand; kettlebell neutral-grip may alter shoulder rotation stress. Single-arm nature increases anti-rotation/core demand and requires more scapular stability than bilateral presses.

reasoning: Primary joint action is external rotation of the glenohumeral (shoulder) joint in the transverse plane against cable resistance. The movement is produced concentrically by the external rotators of the rotator cuff while the elbow is typically held in a fixed (isometric) flexed position. Scapular and thoracic stabilizers act isometrically to maintain a fixed shoulder blade and trunk position and prevent substitution. Because the defining motion is rotation about the humeral long axis, the appropriate movement pattern is ROTATION.
primary_muscles: scapular stabilizers (middle/lower trapezius, serratus anterior) -- isometric
notes: Common variations: standing (cable) with elbow pinned to side, side-lying DB external rotation, or banded versions. Keep load light to target rotator cuff and avoid scapular substitution; cue scapular stabilization and minimal trunk motion. Small ROM, transverse-plane focused exercise used for shoulder health and external rotator strength.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal pulling action with dominant scapular retraction and glenohumeral external rotation performed in the transverse plane. Elbow flexion assists to bring the hands toward the face while the scapulothoracic joint retracts and slightly upwardly rotates the scapulae. The rotator cuff (external rotators) and posterior deltoid produce shoulder external rotation and horizontal abduction; middle trapezius and rhomboids produce scapular retraction. Core and thoracic extensors act isometrically to stabilize the spine and maintain posture; the scapular stabilizers control scapula motion throughout the pull.

notes: Common variations change emphasis: wide/externally rotated grip increases rotator cuff and posterior delt demand; elbows-high orientation emphasizes scapular retraction and posterior deltoid. Use controlled tempo to emphasize eccentric posterior shoulder loading and to protect the glenohumeral joint.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are scapulothoracic retraction (scapular adduction) and glenohumeral horizontal extension/abduction with external rotation, plus elbow flexion — all executed predominantly in the transverse (horizontal) plane. The movement is a horizontal pull: middle/lower trapezius and rhomboids drive scapular retraction, posterior deltoid and external rotators (infraspinatus/teres minor) drive the horizontal/rotational component of the humerus, and the biceps/forearm muscles assist elbow flexion. The spine and core act isometrically to maintain a neutral thoracic position and resist unwanted trunk motion; the shoulder complex requires active scapular control for healthy mechanics.
notes: Commonly coached as a horizontal pull with emphasis on scapular retraction and shoulder external rotation to improve posterior shoulder health. Variations (band vs cable, rope hand position) alter load curve but not primary pattern. Ensure thoracic extension and scapular control to avoid compensation by upper traps/levator scapulae.

reasoning: Face pulls are primarily a horizontal/transverse-plane pulling pattern: the arms are drawn back toward the face via scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction) and glenohumeral horizontal abduction, with deliberate glenohumeral external rotation. Elbow flexion contributes to the pull but is secondary. The spine and thoracic region act isometrically to stabilize posture while the scapular retractors and posterior shoulder control the movement.
notes: Commonly performed with rope on a cable or band. Emphasize external rotation and scapular retraction to target posterior cuff and posterior shoulder; avoid excessive thoracic flexion. Variations: high-elbow face pulls (greater posterior deltoid emphasis) vs lower-elbow rows (different line of pull).

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal pulling action with scapular retraction/adduction and glenohumeral external rotation while the elbows move into flexion — overall a horizontal PULL in the transverse plane. Primary joint actions are scapular retraction (middle/lower traps, rhomboids), external rotation of the glenohumeral joint (infraspinatus, teres minor) and assisting elbow flexion (biceps). The thorax and spine remain isometrically stabilized to provide a stable base; shoulder girdle muscles must control scapular motion and rotator cuff muscles decelerate and control humeral rotation. This is an accessory posterior-shoulder/upper-back pull rather than a trunk-rotation or carry task.
notes: Commonly performed as a horizontal pull/rotator-cuff accessory. Variations (high-elbow face pull, single-arm) change shoulder elevation/abduction demands and may increase anti-rotation/stability requirements. Light band emphasizes rotator cuff and scapular control rather than maximal horizontal force production.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are scapulothoracic retraction (scapular adduction) and glenohumeral external rotation/horizontal extension as the hands are pulled toward the face in the transverse plane, with concurrent elbow flexion. The movement is a pulling pattern driven by posterior shoulder and scapular retractors; the trunk and hips act as isometric stabilizers. Primary movers produce scapular retraction (middle trapezius, rhomboids) and humeral external rotation/posterior shoulder elevation (posterior deltoid, infraspinatus, teres minor). Elbow flexors (biceps brachii) assist. Core and thoracic extensors maintain a neutral posture to provide a stable base for the shoulder girdle.

joint_actions.action: external rotation and horizontal abduction/extension (scapular plane)

notes: Face pulls are primarily a horizontal/transverse plane pull emphasizing scapular retraction and shoulder external rotation. Variations (high-elbow vs low-elbow, band vs cable) shift emphasis between posterior deltoid and upper trapezius. Cue thoracic extension and scapular control to minimize compensatory shrugging.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction) and shoulder external rotation with a horizontal pull component — performed primarily in the transverse plane — plus elbow flexion in the sagittal plane. Movement is driven by posterior shoulder and scapular retractors (posterior deltoid, infraspinatus/teres minor, middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids). The thorax/spine and scapular stabilizers work isometrically to maintain posture and control scapular motion; core stability is required to prevent trunk flexion or rotation.
notes: Typically classified as a horizontal/face-level pull. Variations (rope vs band vs cable) change loading but not primary pattern. Emphasize external rotation and scapular retraction to target posterior cuff and scapular stabilizers; avoid excessive thoracic flexion.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal/upper-body pull: scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction) and glenohumeral external rotation with some shoulder horizontal abduction as the band is pulled towards the face. Elbow flexion is present but not primary. Movement occurs mainly in the transverse plane at the shoulder/scapula. The spine and lower body act isometrically to stabilize posture and transfer force through the torso.
notes: Commonly used for posterior shoulder and rotator cuff strengthening and scapular stabilization. Band height and hand position alter emphasis (higher pull emphasizes upper traps/rear delts; external rotation emphasis increases with elbow separation). Single-arm variations introduce anti-rotation demands on the core.

reasoning: Face pulls are primarily a horizontal/diagonal pulling pattern performed to the face that produces scapular retraction and external rotation of the humerus. The primary joint actions are shoulder external rotation and horizontal abduction (transverse plane) with scapulothoracic retraction (scapular adduction) and assisted elbow flexion. The movement is driven by posterior shoulder and scapular retractors; the trunk/spine remains isometrically stabilized to provide a stable base. Therefore the dominant movement pattern is a PULL (horizontal pull with emphasis on scapular movement and rotator cuff external rotators).
notes: Band height and elbow position change emphasis: elbows high/flare increases posterior deltoid/upper-trap contribution; elbows lower emphasize mid-trap/rhomboids. Emphasize external rotation and scapular retraction; avoid excessive cervical protraction or anterior shoulder impingement. Typically performed as a horizontal pull variation rather than a trunk-rotation exercise.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal/transverse-plane pulling motion of the upper limb with concurrent scapular retraction (adduction) and shoulder external rotation. The glenohumeral joint undergoes external rotation and horizontal abduction while the scapulothoracic complex retracts and upwardly rotates; the elbow flexes slightly. The movement is a horizontal pull pattern emphasizing posterior shoulder and scapular stabilizers. Stabilization requirements include isometric trunk/hip stability and scapular control from rotator cuff and periscapular muscles to maintain scapular position and control humeral head motion.
notes: Light-band variation maintains the same primary mechanics but may increase demand on timing and cuff endurance. Emphasize scapular retraction and external rotation; avoid excessive scapular elevation or shrugging to target intended muscles and protect the shoulder.

reasoning: Loaded walking: primary action is bilateral gait (hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane) while holding loads at the sides. The carry pattern is primary because the objective is transporting load; locomotion is included because the exercise is performed while walking. Shoulders and elbows act isometrically to hold the load (glenohumeral neutral/adduction and elbow extension), and the spine and lateral core muscles provide isometric trunk stabilization to maintain upright posture and resist flexion/lateral collapse. Grip and scapular stabilizers must produce isometric force to secure the implements.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / maintain adduction (arms at sides)
isometric axial/trunk stabilization (resist flexion and lateral collapse)

notes: Bilateral symmetric farmers carry is primarily CARRY + LOCOMOTION. Asymmetric variations (suitcase, single-arm) add ANTI_ROTATION/ANTI-LATERAL FLEXION. Load magnitude affects trunk and scapular demand; surface/stride can modify ankle/knee involvement.

reasoning: Primary action is loaded walking — repeating hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension to produce gait while maintaining an upright torso and carrying heavy loads at the sides (CARRY). The legs drive sagittal-plane locomotion (LOCOMOTION) through hip extension and ankle plantarflexion on push-off. Upper limbs and shoulder girdle act isometrically to hold the load (grip, scapular stabilization). The trunk and lateral chain produce isometric anti-lateral-flexion and anti-rotation stabilization to resist load-induced side-bending, but these are stabilizing demands rather than primary movement patterns.

notes: Symmetric bilateral carries are classified primarily as CARRY (with locomotion mechanics).
