Load, stride length, and handle position alter trunk lean and scapular demand; grip strength frequently limits performance.

reasoning: Primary action is loaded walking (CARRY): repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane to produce gait while maintaining an external load. Because the load is offset/asymmetric, the trunk and shoulder girdle produce isometric anti-lateral-flexion and anti-rotation forces (ANTI_ROTATION) to keep the spine upright and prevent collapse toward the loaded side. Shoulders/elbows/wrists provide isometric grip and shoulder stabilization; hips, quads and calves produce propulsion and weight acceptance.

joint_actions.action: isometric adduction/depression and stabilization of load

notes: Offset (single-sided) farmer carry increases lateral and rotational trunk demand compared with bilateral carries. Variations: suitcase carry (single arm), across-body carry, double-arm farmer carry (symmetrical CARRY only). Footwear, load height, stride length and terrain modulate hip/knee/ankle demands.

reasoning: Primary action is loaded walking — bilateral, symmetrical load held in the hands while the lower limbs produce gait. Primary joint actions are repeated sagittal-plane hip, knee and ankle extension/flexion to produce step propulsion (CARRY + LOCOMOTION). Upper limbs and shoulder girdle act isometrically to support and transmit load (grip, scapular stabilizers). The spine and core produce isometric stabilization to maintain upright posture and resist lateral flexion and excessive rotation during single-leg phases of gait. Muscles of the posterior and anterior chain produce propulsive forces (glutes/quads/hamstrings/calves) while forearms and scapular stabilizers maintain the load.

joint_actions.action: isometric support/neutral position with scapular depression/stabilization
isometric stabilization against flexion, lateral flexion and rotation

notes: This classification assumes bilateral equal loads in both hands. If performed single-arm (suitcase or unilateral farmer carry), add ANTI_ROTATION due to greater lateral/rotational core demand. Heavy loads increase grip and shoulder-girdle/isometric spinal demand. Chain-handle style can allow slight handle rotation but does not change primary patterns.

reasoning: Primary task is loaded walking: repeated sagittal-plane gait cycles while bearing external load in the hands. Primary joint actions producing net movement are hip extension (propulsion), knee extension, and ankle plantarflexion during stance; hip/knee/ankle flexion during swing. Upper limbs/shoulders and elbows act isometrically to hold the load (grip and scapular/rim stability). The spine and core act isometrically to resist flexion, lateral flexion and rotation, preserving upright torso and load carriage. Muscles producing propulsion are gluteus maximus, hamstrings and quadriceps, with calf musculature contributing to push-off. Forearm flexors produce grip, upper-trap/lat/serratus muscles stabilize the shoulder girdle, and erector spinae/transverse abdominis/obliques provide trunk stability.
notes: If performed unilaterally (single-arm farmer carry or suitcase carry) add ANTI_ROTATION to account for asymmetric loading. Grip endurance and scapular/trunk isometric capacity often limit performance; surface/pace influences demand on ankle/knee mechanics. As a finisher, emphasis is on conditioning and load tolerance rather than heavy concentric strength development.

reasoning: Primary task is loaded walking (CARRY): repeated hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane producing forward locomotion (glutes, hamstrings, quadriceps, calves). Because loads are mixed/asymmetric, the trunk must resist lateral flexion and rotation — an isometric anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demand in the frontal and transverse planes (obliques, transverse abdominis, erector spinae, contralateral glute medius). Upper limbs/shoulder girdle provide isometric load support and grip (forearm flexors, scapular stabilizers) rather than dynamic pushing/pulling.
notes: Mixed/asymmetric loads increase anti-rotation and lateral hip/glute demand (higher on one side). Grip strength and scapular/shoulder stability often limit load. Variations: bilateral symmetric farmer carry reduces anti-rotation (still CARRY only), single-arm or suitcase-style increases ANTI_ROTATION markedly.

reasoning: Loaded walking: primary movement is locomotion produced by repeated hip, knee and ankle sagittal-plane flexion/extension. The load is held isometrically at the shoulders/forearms, requiring substantial grip and scapular/shoulder stabilization. The trunk works isometrically to maintain upright posture and resist lateral flexion/rotation under load. Primary movers for the displacement are glutes/quadriceps/hamstrings and calf complex; upper body musculature (forearm flexors, traps, scapular stabilizers, rotator cuff) and core (erectors, obliques, rectus abdominis) provide isometric support and stabilization.

isometric stabilization against lateral flexion/rotation and sagittal flexion

reasoning: Primary task is a loaded walk: repeated sagittal-plane lower-limb joint excursions produce forward progression while carrying external loads in the hands. Primary joint actions are hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension for gait (sagittal). The upper limbs and shoulder girdle act isometrically to support and stabilize the load (scapular depression/retraction and rotator cuff activity) while the forearm/wrist maintain a strong grip. The trunk performs isometric axial stabilization (anti-flexion and general anti-rotation demands increase with load asymmetry or swinging chains). reasoning: This is a loaded-walking exercise: primary task is carrying heavy loads while producing gait (locomotion). Primary joint actions are rhythmic hip, knee and ankle extension/flexion in the sagittal plane to propel the body forward while the shoulders, elbows and spine act isometrically to support and stabilize the load. Propulsion is generated by hip extensors and plantarflexors during stance; the core and paraspinals maintain an upright trunk and resist flexion/rotation; scapular stabilizers, rotator cuff and forearm flexors maintain grip and load carriage.

reasoning: Fast skipping is a plyometric gait variation — repeated single-leg push-offs and ballistic flight phases. Primary joint actions are concentric hip and knee extension and ankle plantarflexion during propulsion, followed by hip and knee flexion and ankle dorsiflexion during recovery and landing. Movement occurs predominantly in the sagittal plane with frontal-plane hip/ankle control during single-leg stance. Muscles produce force via a stretch–shortening cycle (calves, quadriceps, glutes) while hip abductors and core provide stabilization to maintain pelvis alignment and balance during alternating single-leg support.

joint_actions.action: abduction/adduction control (frontal-plane stabilization during single-leg support)

notes: Fast skipping is a locomotion/plyometric pattern emphasizing ankle- and hip-dominant propulsion using the stretch–shortening cycle. Progressions/regressions depend on flight time, unilateral emphasis, and surface. Pay attention to landing mechanics (knee alignment, hip control) and conditioning of calf/Achilles for high-repetition plyometrics.

reasoning: Primary task is loaded walking (CARRY). The exercise produces cyclic hip, knee and ankle motion in the sagittal plane to create locomotion while the upper limbs and spine act isometrically to support and stabilize the load. Shoulders/scapulae and elbows are held in near-extension with isometric scapular stabilization; forearm/wrist flexors provide sustained grip force. Core and paraspinals resist trunk flexion and unwanted rotation, but because the load is bilateral and symmetric there is minimal anti-rotation demand beyond normal gait stabilization.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension (cyclic during gait; primary propulsive = extension)
isometric stabilization/scapular depression and retraction to support load

notes: Bilateral symmetric load with plate carrier grips is a prototypical carry. If load is asymmetric (single-side carry) add ANTI_ROTATION. Variations (farmers walk with straps, uneven terrain, loaded march) change emphasis on grip, core, and locomotor demand.

reasoning: Primary movement is flexion of the finger joints (MCP, PIP, DIP) in the sagittal plane, producing a distal finger 'pull' on the implement. The primary joint action is finger flexion driven by forearm flexors; the wrist and more proximal joints act mainly as stabilizers (isometric) to maintain hand/forearm position. This is an isolation, distal pulling action rather than a gross upper-limb pull (rows/pulldowns), so PULL is used as the closest movement-pattern match.
notes: Isolated grip/finger-flexion exercise. If performed as part of loaded gripping tasks (e.g., with walking or pulling), include CARRY or PULL as additional patterns. Variations (wrist position, barbell vs. dumbbell) change stabilizer demands but not primary pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal PUSH: shoulder-driven horizontal adduction (with some shoulder flexion) and elbow extension to press the body away from the ground. Shoulders and elbows produce the concentric push (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, triceps). The trunk and hips act isometrically to maintain a rigid plank (anti-extension in the sagittal plane) and the scapulothoracic muscles control protraction/retraction during the press. Feet elevation (decline push-up) shifts load superiorly, increasing shoulder/upper-chest demand and scapular control requirements.
notes: Feet-elevated (decline) push-up increases demand on shoulders/upper pectorals and scapular stabilizers; places greater shear/impingement risk at the shoulder for some individuals and increases lumbar extension torque if core is weak. Progress/regress with box height or hand elevation.

reasoning: Loaded walking pattern in which repeated sagittal-plane lower-limb joint actions (hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension) produce locomotion while the upper limbs and trunk hold external loads isometrically. Primary joint actions are hip extension, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion during propulsion; the spine and shoulder girdle act isometrically to resist flexion, lateral flexion and rotation and to stabilize the load. Grip and scapular/shoulder stabilizers maintain load position. Thus the dominant pattern is CARRY (loaded locomotion) with substantial isometric core and shoulder stabilization demands.

joint_actions.action: isometric extension/anti-flexion and anti-lateral-flexion (resists trunk collapse and lateral deviation)
isometric stabilization (scapular depression/retraction control to support load)

notes: Symmetrical two-handed farmer's walk = CARRY. Single-arm or asymmetrical variations add ANTI_ROTATION/anti-lateral-flexion demands. Overhead carries, suitcase carries, or loaded marches change shoulder/core emphasis and may add PUSH/ANTI_ROTATION patterns respectively.

reasoning: Primary actions are forceful horizontal/forward arm strikes (shoulder horizontal flexion and elbow extension) produced concurrently with trunk and hip axial rotation to generate torque and transfer force from the lower body to the fist. Shoulders and elbows produce the push (transverse/sagittal planes) while the spine and hips undergo transverse-plane rotation. Lower-limb extension/plantarflexion provide ground reaction force and weight transfer. Core and scapular musculature act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and shoulder girdle against reactive forces.
notes: If the drill emphasizes repeated punches in place, PUSH + ROTATION remain primary. If the bobbing includes substantial lower-body dips/returns (slip/weave), additional stabilization and brief sagittal knee/hip flexion occur but do not change primary patterns. Asymmetric unilateral punching increases anti-rotational stabilization demand on the contralateral core (not primary movement).

reasoning: This drill emphasizes repeated kicking actions which primarily use transverse-plane hip rotation for roundhouse-type strikes (hip internal/external rotation and pelvic/trunk rotation) and sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion/extension for chambering and extending the kick and for the bobbing/squat-like lowering. Primary joint movers are the hip (rotation, flexion/extension) and the knee (extension during kick). The spine and core act to produce and control rotation while providing anti-rotational stabilization during single-leg support; the ankle contributes to push-off and foot placement. Stabilization requirements include single-leg balance (glute medius/hip abductors) and isometric core control (obliques/erector spinae) to transmit rotational forces and prevent unwanted torso collapse.
notes: Exact emphasis can shift with kick type: front kicks emphasize hip flexion and knee extension (more sagittal), roundhouses emphasize transverse hip rotation. Single-leg balance increases anti-rotation and hip abductor demand. If the drill includes continuous stepping/movement, LOCOMOTION may also be appropriate.

reasoning: Primary actions are repeated unilateral/alternating punches (horizontal push) combined with transverse-plane trunk and hip rotation to generate force. The shoulder and elbow produce the pushing action (horizontal flexion/protraction and elbow extension) while the spine and hips provide axial rotation and weight transfer. Lower limbs act isometrically/dynamically to stabilize and drive rotation. Stabilization demands include anti-extension/anti-lateral-flexion from the core and single-leg stance stability through the hips and ankles to transfer force into the strike.
notes: If the drill is purely stationary shadowboxing with head bobbing, emphasize ROTATION + PUSH. If performed with significant lateral movement or loaded implements, consider adding LOCOMOTION or ANTI_ROTATION. Unilateral punching increases rotational torque and single-leg stabilization demands.

exercise: Finisher Circuit - Ground and Pound (Elbows & Punches)
reasoning: Primary actions are horizontal pushing actions of the upper limb (punches) combined with active axial rotation of the torso to generate power and speed. Shoulders perform horizontal adduction and scapular protraction while the elbows extend to deliver punches; the spine produces/transfers axial rotation in the transverse plane to increase strike velocity. The core (obliques, TA) works both as a rotator (dynamic rotation) and as an anti-rotator between strikes to stabilize the torso. Hips and lower limb musculature act isometrically to provide a stable base and transfer force from the ground/core to the upper limb. Scapular stabilizers and serratus anterior control protraction/retraction and shoulder position.
notes: Variations: performing strikes from different ground positions (mount, guard, plank) alters demands—more unilateral striking increases anti-rotation demand; elbow strikes may involve more proximal humeral motion and less elbow extension than full punches. Emphasis is on horizontal push + torso rotation with substantial core stabilization.

reasoning: This circuit alternates a horizontal pushing exercise (pushups) with a trunk-dominant abdominal exercise (crunches). Pushups: primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) and elbow extension (sagittal plane); scapular protraction/retraction and core anti-extension act as stabilizers. Muscles producing the push are pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps, with serratus anterior and rotator cuff stabilizing the scapula. Crunches: primary joint action is spinal flexion (sagittal plane) produced by rectus abdominis with assistance from external obliques; hip flexors and pelvic stabilizers act isometrically to control pelvis. Because the provided movement-pattern list does not include a separate 'spinal flexion' category, the trunk-dominant crunch is mapped to ROTATION as the available core/trunk movement pattern. Both exercises require significant core stabilization: anti-extension during the push and lumbopelvic control during the crunch.
notes: Alternating format creates a compound session but each rep is dominated by one primary pattern (PUSH for pushups; trunk flexion for crunches). Modify pushups (knees, incline) or crunches (reverse crunch, tempo) for intensity; watch neck strain during crunches and maintain core bracing during pushups. If a dataset requires an explicit 'spinal flexion' pattern, consider adding that category rather than mapping to ROTATION.

reasoning: This is a kicking-focused conditioning finisher: the primary movements are hip-driven kicks which use transverse-plane hip rotation for rotational strikes (roundhouse/sidekicks) and sagittal-plane hip flexion/extension for front/teep-style kicks. Knee extension produces the distal striking segment, and the exercise is performed from single-leg support or alternating single-leg support, requiring isometric core and frontal-plane hip stabilization to resist rotation and lateral collapse. Therefore the dominant movement pattern is ROTATION (transverse hip/spine motion) with a strong ANTI_ROTATION stabilization demand on the trunk and stance hip.

joint_actions.action: extension (rapid concentric to snap the kick)
plantarflexion/dorsiflexion and stiffening for foot positioning

notes: Exact emphasis depends on kick type and drill setup: front/teep kicks emphasize hip flexion/sagittal actions; roundhouse/side kicks emphasize transverse rotation. If the drill includes travel or repeated stepping, LOCOMOTION could be added; if performed against a held pad with pushing contact, consider adding PUSH. Lack of a detailed description lowers certainty.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are repeated upper-extremity pushing strikes: shoulder horizontal adduction/protraction and elbow extension to deliver punches/elbow strikes (transverse/sagittal planes), combined with active trunk rotation to generate torque and transfer force from the core to the arm (transverse plane). Lower limbs and hips typically act isometrically to stabilize the torso and provide a stable base while force is transmitted. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, traps) control protraction/retraction and shoulder position. Therefore the dominant pattern is a horizontal PUSH (punch/elbow strike) with an integrated ROTATION component for force generation and sequencing.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (if kneeling/grounded) or weight-bearing stabilization

notes: Variations: elbow-focused strikes may emphasize more proximal shoulder/internal rotation and less elbow extension; performing from guard vs mount or standing changes lower-limb involvement. Significant anti-rotational stabilization occurs and could be listed as a secondary ANTI_ROTATION pattern in contexts with strong asymmetric bracing demands.

reasoning: This finisher alternates two distinct actions. Pushups: primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) and elbow extension (sagittal plane) produced mainly by the pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps; the scapulothoracic musculature (serratus anterior, rhomboids) and deep trunk muscles act isometrically to stabilize the shoulder girdle and resist spinal extension. Crunches: primary joint action is spinal flexion (sagittal plane) produced mainly by the rectus abdominis with assistance from the external obliques and hip flexors; pelvic and neck stabilization is required to isolate trunk flexion. Because the available core patterns are grouped under ROTATION in this taxonomy, the crunch component is classified under ROTATION to represent a trunk-dominant core movement even though it is sagittal-plane flexion rather than axial rotation. The sequence therefore pairs a horizontal push pattern with a trunk-dominant core (rotation/flexion) pattern, with alternating demands on pressing musculature and dynamic trunk flexors while the opposite regions stabilize between efforts.
notes: Bodyweight exercise. Pushups also require anti-extension/anti-rotation core stabilization while crunches require pelvic/neck stabilization and primarily train dynamic trunk flexion. Variations (incline/decline pushups, weighted crunches) change intensity but not primary patterns.

exercise: Finisher: Fast Punches (50) — Repeat for time
reasoning: Primary action is an open-chain horizontal pushing motion at the shoulder (punch/protraction) with elbow extension to deliver the strike, produced in conjunction with transverse-plane axial rotation of the spine and hips to generate power and reach. The shoulders and triceps produce the push/protraction while the obliques, rectus abdominis and hip rotators drive and transfer rotation. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower trapezius) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint; pelvis/hip and lower limb muscles provide a stable base and transfer force through the kinetic chain. Because the movement explicitly involves transverse-plane rotation to create force, ROTATION is included; the pushing action of the arm classifies as a horizontal PUSH.
notes: Often performed alternating/unilateral — increases unilateral anti-rotation/stability demands. Speed and conditioning focus reduce range/perfect form; footwork and ground reaction force contribution vary between stationary vs. stepping punches.

reasoning: Primary motion is glenohumeral horizontal adduction (bringing the arms together across the chest) in the transverse plane — a horizontal push pattern. The movement is produced primarily by the pectoralis major with assistance from the anterior deltoid and coracobrachialis. Elbows remain slightly flexed and act mostly isometrically to maintain arm position. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) and the rotator cuff act isometrically to stabilize the shoulder girdle and humeral head throughout the arc.
notes: Typically a horizontal push isolation exercise. Single-arm or unilateral cable fly variations introduce lateral/rotational stabilization demands (increasing anti-rotation/core involvement). Incline/decline bench angle shifts emphasis between clavicular and sternal heads of the pec major.

reasoning: Slam ball slams are an explosive, sagittal-plane compound movement that uses powerful hip/knee extension (posterior chain) to generate force and upper-body extension/acceleration at the shoulders/elbows to drive the ball downward. The primary force generation comes from a hip-dominant triple-extension (hip/knee/ankle) and rapid trunk flexion to direct the implement; the arms/shoulders transfer and accelerate the load (a vertical/horizontal push action) and then decelerate on contact. Core and spinal stabilizers control trunk flexion/extension and absorb impact.

joint_actions.action: extension/controlled flexion (isometric to dynamic depending on technique)

notes: Variations (rotational slams, chest-level slams) alter emphasis (more oblique/rotation or less hinge). High-impact, high-velocity conditioning movement — requires shoulder and lumbar control during repeated impact; retrieve phase can add slight eccentric loading. If performed from deep squat, SQUAT contribution increases.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane, hip-dominant motion (hip flexion) raising the legs from horizontal toward vertical. Hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris, sartorius) produce the upward leg movement; the anterior trunk (rectus abdominis, obliques) and iliofemoral region act to posteriorly tilt the pelvis and control lumbar position. Knees are typically extended and function isometrically. The upper body is fixed on the bench so scapulothoracic/shoulder joints primarily stabilize the torso. Overall this is a hip-dominant sagittal movement — the closest primary pattern is HINGE (hip-focused sagittal pattern), noting the direction is hip flexion rather than hip extension.
notes: Variation: performing with knees bent reduces moment at the hip and shifts demand toward the lower abs. Hanging leg raises (no bench) increase hip torque and require greater lumbopelvic control. Although classified as HINGE here because it is a hip-dominant sagittal pattern, the movement is hip flexion (not the typical hip-extension emphasis of many hinge exercises).

reasoning: Primary movement is hip flexion bringing the femurs toward the torso (legs pulled in) with concomitant spinal flexion/posterior pelvic tilt as the pelvis rotates posteriorly. Hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) and rectus abdominis generate the concentric movement; obliques and deep core actometrically to stabilize. Upper body (hands on bench) provides an isometric anchor requiring scapular/shoulder stabilization. Because the dominant action is bringing the lower limb toward the trunk (a 'pulling' action of the femur in the sagittal plane), this maps best to the PULL pattern from the available list.

joint_actions.action: flexion (if performed with bent knees) / minimal change if legs kept straight

notes: Variation: performed with knees bent (reverse crunch style) increases spinal flexion and reduces hamstring length tension; performed with straight legs increases hip-flexor and rectus abdominis lever demand. Upper body functions as an isometric anchor—scapular and shoulder girdle must stabilize (hands grasping bench). Not a sagittal-lower-body hinge or squat pattern; classified as PULL because the femur is actively drawn toward the trunk.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal (transverse-plane) pushing motion at the shoulder with concurrent elbow extension. The shoulder undergoes horizontal adduction (with some shoulder flexion component depending on grip/arc) and the elbow extends to press the dumbbells upward. Pectoralis major and anterior deltoid produce shoulder horizontal adduction/flexion while triceps brachii produces elbow extension. Scapular stabilizers (rhomboids/trapezius), rotator cuff musculature and serratus anterior provide glenohumeral and scapular stability; the spine and hips act isometrically (with possible leg drive) to transfer force into the bench.
notes: Bilateral flat dumbbell bench press is a textbook horizontal push. Single-arm or strongly asymmetric variations add ANTI_ROTATION demands. Incline/decline variants change shoulder flexion vs. horizontal adduction emphasis. Dumbbells increase stabilizer recruitment vs. barbell.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane (open-chain elbow flexion). The incline position places the shoulder into relative extension, increasing long-head biceps length and biasing elbow flexors. Muscles producing the movement are the biceps brachii, brachialis and brachioradialis; forearm supination (radioulnar) often contributes to peak torque. The shoulder and scapula act primarily as stabilizers (rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers) while the torso/bench provide isometric support. No primary rotational or carry components unless performed asymmetrically.
notes: Standard incline dumbbell curl is a single-joint elbow flexion (PULL) exercise. Single-arm or standing variations introduce anti-rotation demands; hammer grip shifts emphasis toward brachioradialis; seated/incline bench reduces torso involvement. Equipment field in prompt noted as unknown but exercise uses dumbbells.

reasoning: Primary motion is scapulothoracic and glenohumeral movement as the arms travel from the sides to overhead: active scapular upward rotation, posterior tilt and retraction with concurrent shoulder flexion/abduction and external rotation. These actions emphasize the scapular stabilizers (middle/lower trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids) which are classically part of the 'pull'/scapular retraction/upward-rotation pattern. The thoracic spine extends passively/actively on the roller to allow greater overhead range; core and cervical musculature provide positional stabilization.
notes: Mobility/drill rather than loaded strength pattern; classified as PULL because primary emphasis is on scapular control (retraction/upward rotation). Variations (palms up/down, abducted vs more sagittal reach) change emphasis toward more glenohumeral flexion or frontal-plane abduction but still center on scapular mechanics.

reasoning: The floor glute-ham raise primarily loads the posterior chain in the sagittal plane. The movement requires the hamstrings to control knee extension eccentrically as the torso lowers and then produce knee flexion and assist hip extension concentrically to return upright; the gluteus maximus contributes to hip extension when the hips are driven. Secondary stabilizers include the erector spinae and core to maintain neutral spine and pelvic position, and the ankles/hip flexors act isometrically to stabilize the lower limb. Because the exercise emphasizes hip extension/controlled knee motion of the posterior chain, it is best classified as a hinge-dominant posterior chain movement.
notes: If performed with pronounced hip drive (pushing hips forward) the hip-extension component increases (stronger hinge pattern). If performed strictly as a Nordic-style knee-dominant lowering with minimal hip motion, it emphasizes knee-flexor isolation; consider that variation when programming.

reasoning: Floor Angels are a supine shoulder mobility drill that primarily moves the glenohumeral joints into elevation (flexion/abduction) while driving coordinated scapulothoracic upward rotation and posterior tilt. Primary joint actions are shoulder flexion/abduction in the sagittal/frontal planes; the scapula undergoes upward rotation and posterior tilt (frontal/transverse components). The thoracic spine commonly extends to allow full overhead range. Muscles producing the movement include the anterior/middle deltoids and supraspinatus for arm elevation, with serratus anterior and upper/lower trapezius driving scapular upward rotation and posterior tilt. Rotator cuff muscles act isometrically to center the humeral head. Thoracic extensors assist by allowing spine extension; the elbow typically remains extended/isometric. Stabilization requires scapular and rotator-cuff control to maintain contact/near-contact with the floor and thoracic posture, and tension in the anterior core to keep the ribcage connected to the spine.
notes: Often performed as a mobility/neuromuscular control drill. Variations: wall angels (more vertical), band-assisted floor angels, or reduced ROM for shoulder impingement. Cue scapular posterior tilt and thoracic extension; avoid forcing painful end ranges.

reasoning: The floor press is a horizontal pressing movement performed supine. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) and elbow extension (sagittal plane). Pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps brachii produce the concentric press. The supine/floor position limits scapular protraction/retraction and end range shoulder extension, shifting load slightly toward the triceps and reducing shoulder shear. Rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, rhomboids) act isometrically to stabilize the glenohumeral and scapulothoracic joints; the spine and core maintain a neutral isometric posture for force transfer.
notes: Variation: single-arm floor press introduces anti-rotation demands. Barbell vs dumbbell changes stabilizer involvement; floor press reduces shoulder ROM and increases relative triceps contribution compared with full-range bench press.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal pressing motion from a supine position. The shoulder performs horizontal adduction in the transverse plane while the elbow extends in the sagittal plane to drive the load away from the chest/floor. Chains provide accommodated (variable) resistance but do not change the fundamental joint actions. Scapulothoracic structures act isometrically against the floor, reducing scapular retraction and limiting shoulder extension, which increases relative triceps demand. Core/spine must maintain a neutral, isometric position for force transfer and stability.
notes: Chains create variable resistance (load increases as chains lift), floor contact limits shoulder ROM and scapular movement, increasing triceps contribution. If performed single-arm or asymmetrically, ANTI_ROTATION considerations would apply; bilateral symmetrical setup remains a horizontal PUSH pattern.

reasoning: Floor Pigeon is primarily a hip mobility/stretch that places the lead (front) hip into transverse-plane external rotation with concurrent sagittal-plane hip flexion and some frontal-plane abduction; the trailing leg is positioned in sagittal-plane hip extension. The primary joint actions are hip external rotation (transverse) and hip flexion/extension (sagittal). Because the pose emphasizes hip rotation/mobility rather than sagittal loaded strength (no stepping or loaded carry), ROTATION is the dominant movement pattern. Muscles acting (isometrically or eccentrically/lengthening in a stretch) include the hip external rotators and hip flexors; the core and contralateral hip muscles stabilize the pelvis and lumbar spine to maintain alignment.

joint_actions.action: stabilization (can be flexion if folding forward)

notes: Primarily a mobility/stretching pose (not a loaded strength movement). Modify (reclined figure-four, prop under hip) for limited hip external rotation or knee discomfort. Maintain pelvic square to avoid excessive lumbar rotation; watch for front knee strain in those with prior knee pathology.

reasoning: Flutter kicks are driven by alternating hip flexion and controlled hip extension in the sagittal plane, mimicking the reciprocal leg action of locomotion while performed supine. Primary joint action is repeated hip flexion of each leg (bringing the thigh/leg upward) with the contralateral leg moving downward under control. The lumbar spine and pelvis act isometrically to prevent lumbar hyperextension (anti-extension) and maintain a neutral spine; the abdominal wall (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis and obliques) and hip musculature provide that stabilization. Knees are generally near-extended and act mostly isometrically; ankles may be plantarflexed but are secondary.
primary_muscles: gluteus maximus / hamstrings (eccentric control on descent)

joint_actions.action: near-isometric extension (minor movement if knee bend varies)

notes: This classification treats flutter kicks as a supine, reciprocal hip flexion pattern analogous to locomotion. Some trainers may label it primarily a core (anti-extension) exercise; if the emphasis is strictly core bracing with minimal hip motion, consider adding an 'ANTI-ROTATION'/'anti-extension' descriptor for programming context.

reasoning: Primary actions are spinal extension (thoracic/lumbar) and hip extension as the chest and legs lift off the floor (sagittal plane), which aligns with a hip-dominant hinge pattern. Simultaneously the shoulder complex lifts with scapular retraction and posterior shoulder activation (shoulder extension/scapular adduction), resembling a horizontal pull pattern. Movement is produced primarily by the posterior chain (erector spinae, glutes, hamstrings) with upper-back musculature controlling scapular motion and shoulder position. Core and pelvic stabilizers isometrically control spinal alignment and prevent excessive lumbar hyperextension.
notes: Primarily targets spinal/hip extension; can be progressed with added load or unilateral arm/leg lifts. If emphasis is strictly thoracic extension (arm lift only) or purely glute-dominant (leg lift only), pattern weighting may shift. No significant knee or elbow motion. Variations that add unilateral loading introduce larger anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Floor slides are an unloaded overhead shoulder elevation pattern: the primary joint action is shoulder flexion/overhead elevation (with a component of abduction and external rotation) as the arms slide from the torso to overhead in the sagittal/frontal planes. Scapulothoracic upward rotation and posterior tilt accompany glenohumeral elevation and are driven by serratus anterior and lower/upper trapezius. Elbow position typically moves toward extension but is not the primary driver. The spine (thoracic) moves into relative extension/extension mobility to allow the arms to pass overhead. Stabilization requires isometric control from the rotator cuff to maintain humeral head centering and from the scapular stabilizers to control upward rotation; core/thoracic extensors provide a stable platform. Because the pattern is an unloaded overhead elevation (vertical push) movement pattern rather than a resisted press, it is classified under PUSH (vertical overhead elevation pattern).

joint_actions.action: external rotation (to clear greater tubercle and reduce impingement)
extension (often gradual as arms reach overhead)
thoracic extension (mobility to permit overhead path)

notes: Primarily a shoulder/scapular mobility drill; can be progressed with bands or performed standing/against wall. If performed aggressively with load or forceful pressing, classification could include PUSH more strongly; if emphasis is scapular retraction/upward rotation only, view as scapular mobility exercise. Watch for compensatory excessive lumbar extension or scapular winging; regress by elevating torso (foam roll) or reducing range.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are thoracic spine extension (sagittal plane) and shoulder girdle retraction/shoulder horizontal abduction with external rotation (transverse/frontal planes). The position passively opens the anterior chest while the scapulae move into retraction/adduction and the thoracic extensors produce extension (or allow passive extension) — biomechanics are analogous to a controlled scapular retraction / horizontal shoulder opening (a pull-like shoulder girdle action). Stabilization is required from the thoracic extensors and deep spinal stabilizers to maintain alignment on the roller, and rotator cuff muscles assist in externally rotating and stabilizing the glenohumeral joint during the stretch.
notes: Mobility/cooldown exercise that is largely passive; classified as PULL because the dominant movement at the shoulder girdle is scapular retraction (a pull-type action). If performed with active scapular protraction/retraction emphasis or with arm movement crossing the torso, consider adding ROTATION for transverse spinal/shoulder rotation components.

reasoning: Foam rolling is a self-myofascial release / mobility technique rather than a strength or locomotor pattern. Joint actions depend on the body region being rolled and are typically small, controlled positional changes and bodyweight-driven translations rather than deliberate concentric/eccentric muscle-driven movement patterns. Primary mechanical features are local tissue compression, short-range spinal flexion/extension or lateral shift (when rolling thoracic spine), and small hip/knee/ankle adjustments to reposition the body. Stabilization is predominantly isometric (core and scapular stabilizers) to control pressure and body position rather than to produce movement through a logical movement pattern (e.g., squat, hinge, push, pull). Because the mechanics are region-specific and variable, it does not map cleanly to the provided movement-pattern list.
primary_muscles: latissimus dorsi/teres major (when rolling upper back/lat region)

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension and short-range sagittal plane translation
small flexion/extension to alter lever arm/pressure
dorsiflexion/plantarflexion adjustments when rolling calves/plantar surface
protraction/retraction and positional adjustment to control thoracic roll

notes: Foam rolling is a region-specific mobility/manual therapy technique rather than a repeatable kinetic movement pattern. Classify as 'mobility/warmup' in programming; do not treat as a primary movement pattern for strength progressions. If intent is to train a pattern while rolling (e.g., rolling while performing mobility drills that involve loaded movement), re-evaluate and classify based on the added movement (squat, hinge, etc.).

reasoning: Primary movement is thoracic spine extension in the sagittal plane (segmental spinal extension over a roller). Secondary actions often include scapular retraction and shoulder positioning as the thoracic segments extend. The movement is primarily spinal (thoracic) rather than hip/knee dominant, and it functions to open the anterior chest and load the posterior thoracic musculature and scapular stabilizers. Stabilization demands include isometric control of the lumbar spine and pelvis to localize motion to the thoracic segments and core/bracing to prevent compensatory lumbar hyperextension.

joint_actions.action: positioning (flexion/abduction to allow thoracic extension; may produce scapular retraction)

notes: This is a thoracic-spine mobility drill rather than a force-producing exercise; classify as a posterior/thoracic opening pattern—mapped here to PULL due to dominant posterior chain and scapular retraction mechanics. Variations (arms overhead, arms crossed, hands behind head) change shoulder/scapular demands. Cue to limit lumbar extension and focus on segmental thoracic movement.

reasoning: Foot self-myofascial release (SMR) is primarily a mobility/tissue-loading technique rather than a functional movement pattern. The action consists of localized rolling/pressure applied to the plantar surface and soft tissues of the foot, producing small passive/active adjustments at the ankle (plantarflexion/dorsiflexion) and subtalar joint (inversion/eversion) and motion at the toes (flexion/extension) in sagittal and frontal planes. These are low-amplitude, largely passive movements and tissue deformation rather than purposeful multi-joint locomotor or resistance patterns; there is minimal global joint torque production or limb-drive that would map to HINGE, SQUAT, PUSH, PULL, LUNGE, LOCOMOTION, CARRY, ROTATION or ANTI_ROTATION.
primary_muscles: intrinsic foot muscles (e.g., flexor digitorum brevis, abductor hallucis)
notes: SMR is a mobility/recovery technique; it does not fit standard functional movement pattern categories. Variations (standing ball roll, seated roller, active mobilization) change loading and muscle activation slightly but do not create a primary movement-pattern classification. Recommend manual review if a pattern must be assigned for programming systems that require one.

reasoning: Primary demand is isometric trunk stabilization resisting sagittal collapse (anti-extension/anti-flexion) with the core preventing lumbar hyperextension and maintaining neutral pelvis. Shoulders and scapulothoracic musculature provide isometric support of the upper body, functioning like a static horizontal push/stabilization. Hips and knees are held in near-full extension isometrically to maintain a rigid torso. Because available pattern options do not include an explicit anti-extension category, the core stabilization role is classified under ANTI_ROTATION (general anti-movement/core stabilization) and the upper-limb weight-bearing stabilization is classified as PUSH (isometric horizontal push/stabilization).
notes: EMOM/time-based increases metabolic and endurance demand. Variations (side plank, single-leg plank) introduce clear ANTI_ROTATION/ANTI-LATERAL-FLEXION and single-leg asymmetries. Cue scapular depression/protraction and posterior pelvic tilt to optimize trunk bracing.

reasoning: The forearm plank is an isometric core stabilization exercise that primarily resists sagittal-plane spinal collapse (antagonizes trunk flexion) and also resists rotational perturbations, fitting the ANTI_ROTATION pattern. Primary joint demands are isometric: hips held in near-extension to maintain a straight line, knees in extension, shoulders and elbows isometrically supporting upper body while the thoracolumbar spine is held neutral. Muscles of the anterior and lateral core (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, obliques) produce the primary anti-flexion/anti-rotation force while glutes, quadriceps and erector spinae contribute to hip and trunk alignment and the shoulder girdle (deltoids, serratus anterior, rotator cuff) provides scapulothoracic stability. Tabata tempo (interval timing) does not change the biomechanical pattern — it only alters work/rest parameters.

joint_actions.action: isometric shoulder flexion/support and scapular stabilization
isometric plantarflexion / stabilization through foot contact

notes: Forearm plank is a purely isometric core stabilizer. Variations (single-arm/leg lift) increase anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demands and would still map to ANTI_ROTATION, potentially lowering confidence for single-joint pattern exclusivity if asymmetric progressions are used.

reasoning: This is a mobility/stretching exercise rather than a locomotor or load-bearing compound movement. Primary joint actions are at the wrist (flexion or extension depending on the specific forearm stretch variant) and the fingers (flexion/extension) performed typically in the sagittal plane; the elbow is commonly held near full extension and may be slightly extended or relaxed. The action is usually passive or active-assisted (one hand pulls the wrist/fingers of the other), so there is minimal concentric force production and no primary push/pull/squat/hinge/rotation/carriage movement pattern. Stabilization is primarily isometric from the shoulder girdle and scapular stabilizers to position the arm, and the core provides minimal postural support if performed seated or standing.

joint_actions.action: extension or flexion (depending on stretch variant)
extension or flexion (depending on stretch variant)

notes: This exercise is primarily a mobility/stretch rather than a functional movement pattern from the provided list; no primary pattern (PUSH/PULL/SQUAT/HINGE/etc.) applies. Variations: wrist-flexor stretch (wrist/fingers extended), wrist-extensor stretch (wrist/fingers flexed), or assisted stretches using the opposite hand. Caution with neural tension (e.g., median nerve) and with existing wrist/forearm pathology.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are hip flexion and thoracic/lumbar spine flexion in the sagittal plane. From standing the pelvis tilts posteriorly and the hips flex while the trunk flexes forward; knees are typically held near full extension (may be slightly flexed). This pattern functions like a hip-dominant hinge for gross sagittal flexion, but includes substantial spinal flexion so it is primarily classified as a HINGE-style sagittal-plane movement for movement-pattern taxonomy. Stabilization requires isometric control at the knees (quadriceps) and eccentric/isometric control of the posterior chain to modulate descent (hamstrings and spinal erectors); the core (rectus abdominis/obliques) and hip flexors contribute to initiating/controlling forward flexion.
notes: Primarily a mobility/stretching movement; if performed with neutral spine and hip-dominant motion (e.g., RDL) the HINGE classification is clearer. Bending the knees shifts emphasis away from hamstring stretch and increases spinal flexion contribution. Caution with acute low-back pathology — spinal flexion may be contraindicated.

reasoning: Primary demand is locomotion: repeated hip, knee and ankle extension in the sagittal plane to drive forward gait while towing a load. Simultaneously there is a horizontal/hand-held pulling component on the implement (shoulder extension and scapular retraction with elbow flexion) to overcome sled/drag friction and keep the load moving (PULL). The added press requires shoulder elevation/flexion (or upward/forward push) with elbow extension (PUSH). The trunk and pelvis act isometrically to transfer force between lower and upper body and resist rotation/lateral flexion under load. Therefore primary joint actions are hip/knee/ankle extension for locomotion, shoulder and elbow flexion/extension depending on pull vs press actions, with multi-planar core stabilization.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (resist rotation and trunk flexion)

notes: Exact emphasis shifts with implement and technique: a hand-held forward drag emphasizes upper-body pull and grip more; a harnessed drag increases lower-body/hip drive (more locomotive/hinge-like). A single-arm press introduces stronger ANTI_ROTATION demand. Monitor low-back and shoulder loading when combining heavy drag with pressing.

reasoning: Primary joint motion is hip flexion in the sagittal plane with concurrent lumbar spine flexion (trunk flexion). The movement is dominated by a hip-dominant flexion pattern (hinge-like) with the knees often held near extension to emphasize hamstring length. If performed actively, hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) and trunk flexors (rectus abdominis/obliques) produce the flexion; more commonly during a passive cooldown gravity-driven descent is controlled eccentrically by the posterior chain (gluteus maximus and hamstrings) and the erector spinae lengthen. Stabilization requirements include pelvic control and core stability to manage lumbar flexion and protect the spine; maintaining slight knee flexion reduces passive hamstring tension and changes joint loading.
notes: Common variations: bent-knee forward fold (reduces hamstring stretch, increases spinal flexion control), seated forward fold, or towel-assisted. For clients with lumbar disc pathology, avoid deep spinal flexion and prioritize hip hinge with neutral spine. As a cooldown/stretch the movement is often passive rather than a loaded concentric hinge.

reasoning: The forward fold is primarily a sagittal-plane hip flexion movement combined with trunk/spinal flexion. The dominant joint actions are hip flexion (torso moving anterior relative to pelvis) and spinal flexion (lumbar and thoracic flexion). Knees may be near full extension or slightly flexed to modify hamstring tension; ankles show minimal movement. Muscularly, spinal flexors (rectus abdominis/obliques) and hip flexors can drive trunk-on-pelvis flexion, while the hamstrings and gluteus maximus lengthen and may eccentrically control the descent. Erector spinae act as passive lengthened tissue or eccentrically if folding slowly, and the core and hip stabilizers control posture. Because the primary motor pattern is hip-dominant flexion (hinge-like) rather than a vertical push/pull, HINGE is the best-fit pattern for classification.

joint_actions.action: near-extension (may be slight flexion to modify stretch)

notes: Variation: bending the knees shifts emphasis away from hamstrings and reduces spinal flexion; performing as an active trunk hinge (initiating at hips with neutral spine) is more true to a HINGE pattern, while an excessive spinal rounding emphasizes spinal flexion mobility. Use caution with lumbar spine pathology; modify with knee bend or half-forward fold.

reasoning: Frog hops are a plyometric squat variation performed from a deep (often wide) squat and involve repeated explosive triple-extension (hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion) to produce vertical and/or forward propulsion. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee extension during takeoff, with ankle plantarflexion contributing to propulsion. Landing requires eccentric hip and knee flexion and ankle dorsiflexion to absorb force, and the core and lower-limb stabilizers control trunk position and frontal-plane knee alignment during repeated hops. If performed as forward-traveling jumps, the movement also functions as a locomotion/propulsive pattern in addition to the squat-type loading.
notes: Variation: in-place frog hops emphasize vertical power and landing control; forward frog hops add a locomotion/progressive distance component. High-impact plyometric; ensure progressive loading, soft surface, and attention to knee valgus control. If performed with pronounced lateral hip movement, frontal-plane hip stabilization demands increase.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip flexion in the sagittal plane as the pelvis tilts anteriorly and the torso moves toward the thighs (a hinge-like action). The lumbar and thoracic spine also undergo spinal flexion (sagittal) and the knees are typically held in extension, increasing stretch at the hamstrings. Shoulders/arms reach overhead or forward to place fingers under toes but are secondary. Stabilization requires control of pelvic tilt and spinal flexion/extension by the trunk musculature and ankle stability for balance. Because the defining joint action is sagittal hip flexion with coordinated spinal flexion, HINGE is the best movement-pattern classification.
notes: Variation with bent knees shifts emphasis away from hamstring stretch and increases spinal flexion; a strict hip-hinge with neutral spine is more 'hinge' in the strength-training sense, whereas excessive lumbar rounding increases spinal flexion emphasis and potential low-back load. Fingers-under-toes increases lumbar/thoracic flexion and requires greater hamstring length or knee flexion.

reasoning: Primary action is explosive bilateral lower‑extremity triple extension (hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion) in the sagittal plane to propel the body onto a raised surface. Movement is driven by concentric force generation of the quadriceps and gluteus maximus with contribution from hamstrings and plantarflexors; an eccentric loading phase (hip/knee flexion) precedes the concentric jump. The trunk and hip abductors/adductors act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and control frontal/transverse plane motion on takeoff and landing. Arm swing can assist but is not a primary mover.
notes: Plyometric emphasis (rate of force development) distinguishes it from a slow squat but primary mechanics map to the SQUAT pattern. Unilateral or step-up variations (single‑leg box jump, depth jump) can introduce LUNGE/single‑leg/specialized plyometric demands and greater anti‑rotation/frontal control requirements. Box height, landing technique (soft vs rigid) and arm contribution alter load and injury risk.

reasoning: Primary movement is repeated trunk (spinal) flexion in the sagittal plane — a short-range curl of the thoracic/lumbar spine produced primarily by the rectus abdominis and assisted by the external obliques. The hips are held in a flexed/abducted (frog) position with knees flexed; hip joints act mostly as static/stabilizing segments (isometric hip abduction/flexion) rather than primary movers. Core deep stabilizers (transverse abdominis, pelvic floor) and hip abductors/adductors provide pelvic and leg position stability. Because the dominant moving joint is the spine producing sagittal flexion, this is classified under HINGE-like trunk flexion for the pattern set provided.
notes: Frog-leg position reduces ability of the hip flexors to contribute to the curl and increases reliance on abdominal flexors and core stabilizers. If feet are anchored or legs extended, hip flexor involvement increases. This exercise is a core/trunk-flexion movement and does not involve horizontal/vertical push or pull, carries, lunges, or rotational primary actions.

reasoning: Frog sit-ups are performed primarily in the sagittal plane and involve combined trunk (spinal) flexion and hip flexion as the torso rises toward the thighs. The spine (thoracic and lumbar) undergoes active flexion (primary) while the hip flexors assist by bringing the pelvis/thighs into flexion; knees remain flexed in a butterfly/frog position which alters hip mechanics but is not a primary mover. Because the available movement categories do not include a dedicated 'trunk flexion/abdominal' pattern, the best fit is HINGE due to substantive hip‑flexion contribution and sagittal hip movement. Stabilization demands include isometric control from the posterior chain (erector spinae, glutes/hamstrings) during the lowering phase and anti‑extension control from the abdominals; shoulder and pelvic stabilizers are also engaged to maintain foot/ankle position if feet are held.
notes: If the movement is performed more as a pure abdominal curl (minimal hip motion) it would be better classified as a core/trunk‑flexion pattern (not available in the provided list). Anchoring the feet or increasing hip drive shifts emphasis toward hip flexors (supports HINGE mapping). Butterfly (frog) leg position reduces hamstring tension and changes hip ROM compared with straight‑leg sit‑ups.

reasoning: Front cone/hurdle hops are a plyometric locomotion task characterized by repeated single- or double-leg hops forward over obstacles. Primary joint actions are rapid sagittal-plane triple extension at the hip, knee and ankle during takeoff (hip extension, knee extension, ankle plantarflexion) and eccentric sagittal-plane hip/knee/ankle flexion during landing. Muscles producing concentric force include the gluteus maximus and hamstrings (hip extension), quadriceps (knee extension), and gastrocnemius/soleus (plantarflexion); these work together to create propulsive ground reaction force. Secondary requirements include frontal- and transverse-plane stabilization — trunk/core and hip abductors/adductors (gluteus medius/minimus, adductors) control lateral balance and single-leg stability, and the intrinsic foot/ankle stabilizers control frontal-plane foot position. There is substantial demand for eccentric control (quadriceps, glutes, tibialis anterior) on landing and reactive elastic recoil (calf complex, Achilles tendon) on takeoff. Because the primary purpose and mechanics are forward locomotor hopping (propulsion and landing), LOCOMOTION is the dominant movement pattern.
notes: Variations (single-leg, lateral cone hops, higher hurdles) increase unilateral and frontal/transverse stabilization demands. Soft or uneven surfaces increase eccentric control and ankle stabilizer activation. If performed with significant lateral or rotational displacement, include ROTATION or ANTI_ROTATION for asymmetric/rotational variants.

reasoning: Primary joint action is concentric shoulder (glenohumeral) flexion in the sagittal plane as the hand/handle is lifted forward and upward. The movement is driven by anterior deltoid with assistance from the clavicular head of pectoralis major and coracobrachialis; supraspinatus assists the initial elevation. The elbow remains relatively fixed (isometric) while the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, upper trapezius, rhomboids) control humeral head position and scapular upward rotation. The spine/core provides isometric stabilization to prevent torso momentum. Bilateral, symmetrical front raises are primarily an isolated shoulder flexion (vertical push-type) pattern; unilateral/asymmetric variations increase anti-rotation core demand.
notes: Cable provides continuous tension; perform to ~90° to limit subacromial impingement risk. Unilateral/front-raise variations create significant ANTI_ROTATION demand on the core and should be classified as PUSH + ANTI_ROTATION when performed single-arm or asymmetrically.

reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder flexion in the sagittal plane as the arm is lifted anteriorly. The glenohumeral joint performs concentric flexion while the elbow is held relatively static (isometric). Scapular upward rotation and protraction must be controlled by scapular stabilizers. Trunk/spine must isometrically stabilize to prevent torso lean. Because the primary action is moving the load away from the body at the shoulder (anterior/vertical lift), this maps to a PUSH-type shoulder pattern rather than a lower-body pattern. If performed single-arm or asymmetrically, substantial anti-rotation demand is added to the core (see notes).
notes: Single-arm or alternating variations introduce lateral/rotational core anti-rotation demand. Common cautions: raised load above ~90° can increase subacromial impingement risk; variations include kettlebell/dumbbell, plate front raise, or bilateral simultaneous raises which reduce anti-rotation demand. Slow controlled tempo emphasizes deltoid control and scapular stabilization.

reasoning: Primary motion is shoulder flexion in the sagittal plane as the arm is raised anteriorly against load — an anterior deltoid-dominant concentric action. Elbow remains slightly flexed and largely isometric to hold the weight; the scapulothoracic musculature and trunk stabilize the shoulder girdle and torso (especially when performed seated on an incline). This is an open-chain shoulder flexion/isolation pattern functionally aligned with a PUSH-type movement (raising a load away from the body).
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (glenohumeral stabilizers: supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis, teres minor)

joint_actions.action: flexion (shoulder flexion / anterior elevation of humerus)

notes: Typically performed bilaterally or unilaterally. If done single-arm, anti-rotation demands on the core increase (consider adding ANTI_ROTATION). Incline torso angle shifts emphasis onto anterior deltoid and may reduce upper-trapezius elevation compared with standing front raises. Avoid excessive shoulder elevation/forward flexion past comfortable range to reduce impingement risk.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip flexion in the sagittal plane — lifting the leg forward. The hip is concentrically flexed by the hip flexors; if the leg is kept straight the knee remains in extension (or isometrically controlled). When performed standing/supported this mimics the single-leg swing phase of gait/marching and therefore matches a locomotion-style hip-flexion pattern. Stabilization demands include pelvic/spinal bracing by the abdominals and obliques and frontal-plane hip stabilization by the gluteus medius/minimus on the stance side. If performed supine, the same primary joint action (hip flexion) applies but stabilization shifts to anti-extension of the lumbar spine.

joint_actions.action: extension (if performed with a straight leg) / neutral (if knee flexed)

notes: Variation matters: standing/unsupported front leg raises act like a marching/locomotion pattern with single-leg balance demands. Supine leg raises (lying leg raise) shift emphasis to core anti-extension and may be classified differently. Range (straight vs bent knee) changes knee action and relative muscle emphasis.

reasoning: Primary joint action is shoulder (glenohumeral) flexion/forward elevation in the sagittal plane. The movement is an anti-gravity pushing/lifting action of the arm(s) from hanging to ~shoulder height or above, driven primarily by the anterior deltoid with assistance from the upper clavicular fibers of pectoralis major and coracobrachialis. Scapulothoracic upward rotation/elevation (serratus anterior, upper trapezius) occurs as a secondary action to allow full humeral elevation. Elbow and wrist remain largely isometric to hold the plate. Core and thoracic/posterior chain muscles provide isometric stabilization to prevent excessive lumbar extension and to stabilize the shoulder girdle.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (slight flexion or extended hold)

notes: Typically a bilateral, symmetric anterior shoulder raise—classed as a PUSH pattern because it is a single-joint antigravity shoulder lifting action. Single-arm or asymmetrical variations introduce significant anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demands. Performed in the scapular plane reduces impingement risk; bent-elbow variations shorten moment arm and alter deltoid demand.

reasoning: This combined exercise contains two primary shoulder actions performed in the sagittal plane. The Front Raise is primary shoulder flexion (concentric anterior deltoid action) — functionally similar to a unilateral/ bilateral anterior push of the humerus. The Pullover is primary shoulder extension/adduction (latissimus dorsi, teres major, sternal pectoralis major) — functionally a pulling motion of the humerus. Elbow joint is held in slight flexion/isometrically controlled during the pullover. Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles act isometrically to control scapulothoracic position and humeral head stability; the trunk/spine must be stabilized (especially if performed supine on bench or standing) to prevent lumbar extension or torso drift. Because the movement alternates/opposes shoulder flexion and extension, the dominant patterns are PUSH (shoulder flexion/front raise) and PULL (shoulder extension/pullover).
notes: Execution context matters: performed standing or seated (front raise) vs supine (pullover) changes stabilization demands. Single-arm variations introduce lateral/rotational core demands (may add ANTI_ROTATION). Pullover technique can bias lats vs pecs depending on path and elbow angle; both actions should be loaded cautiously due to shoulder impingement risk.

reasoning: The front plank is an isometric full‑body hold in which the primary requirement is to resist trunk flexion (anti‑flexion / maintain neutral spine) while the shoulders and hips provide rigid link between torso and extremities. Primary joint actions are isometric: the spine is held neutral to resist sagittal plane flexion, the shoulders are held in a flexed/loaded position to support bodyweight (scapular stabilizers active), hips are held in near‑neutral extension to keep a straight line. Knees and ankles are isometrically extended/plantarflexed to maintain posture. Muscle action is predominantly isometric for core and gluteal muscles, with secondary isometric activity of anterior shoulder and scapular stabilizers.
notes: Variation: high (straight‑arm) plank increases shoulder loading and resembles a static push/top of push‑up; forearm plank reduces shoulder moment but increases anti‑extension demand. Plank is primarily an anti‑extension core exercise (not a rotational pattern); include ANTI_ROTATION only when asymmetric or single‑arm variations are used.

reasoning: The front-lean plank is an isometric anterior support position where the shoulders and elbows produce an isometric pushing/support demand while the trunk and hips provide anti-extension/isometric stabilization. Primary joint actions are isometric shoulder flexion and elbow extension to hold the upper body off the ground (sagittal plane), with the spine held in neutral against sagittal-plane flexion (anti-extension) and the hips/knees maintained in extension to keep a straight line. The upper-body pushing posture (similar to the top of a push-up) makes PUSH the primary movement pattern; the core and posterior chain act isometrically to prevent spinal collapse and hip flexion.
notes: Tabata format emphasizes endurance and repeated isometric holds. Variations (elbow plank, knee plank) change shoulder/elbow demand; unilateral arm/leg lifts introduce significant anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion demands.

reasoning: This is primarily a bilateral shoulder flexion movement in the sagittal plane (front raise). The glenohumeral joint produces concentric shoulder flexion/forward elevation primarily via the anterior deltoid with assistance from the clavicular head of pectoralis major and coracobrachialis. Elbows are held in slight flexion and act isometrically to maintain dumbbell position; the scapulothoracic musculature (upper trapezius, serratus anterior) stabilizes/upwardly rotates the scapula as the arm is raised. The spine and core act isometrically to maintain an upright torso and prevent excessive lumbar extension or anterior sway. Because the load is held bilaterally and symmetrically, there is no significant anti-rotation demand. Primary movement pattern aligns with an upper-body PUSH-type pattern (vertical/sagittal plane shoulder elevation rather than a pressing pattern with elbow extension).

joint_actions.action: upward rotation (and mild protraction for positioning)

notes: Typically performed bilaterally with symmetric load — single-arm variations introduce ANTI_ROTATION demands. Range above ~90° increases scapular contribution and potential impingement risk; use slight elbow bend and controlled ROM to minimize shoulder impingement. This is an isolation shoulder elevation movement rather than a multi-joint pressing motion that involves elbow extension.

reasoning: Gentle stretching is a mobility/soft-tissue routine rather than a distinct locomotive or loading pattern. Joint actions vary by specific stretch (spine flexion/extension/rotation, hip and knee flexion/extension, shoulder flexion/abduction, ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion) and are performed slowly with low force and minimal concentric/plyometric loading. Because there is no dominant primary pattern of loaded joint action (no intentional hinge, squat, push, pull, carry, lunge, locomotion or sustained anti-rotation), it does not map cleanly to the standard movement-pattern taxonomy. Stabilization is typically low-level isometric core and scapular control to protect joints and maintain posture during the stretch.
notes: This classification is intentionally non-specific. Provide a specific stretch (e.g., seated hamstring stretch, thoracic rotation, standing quadriceps stretch) to map to 1–2 defined movement patterns with higher confidence.

exercise: Front-leaning rest plank (accumulate 60 s in 2-3 sets)
reasoning: The front-leaning rest plank is an isometric anterior weight-bearing position where the shoulders and upper thorax support bodyweight similar to the top-of-push-up posture, so the primary external mechanics align with a PUSH pattern. Primary joint demands are isometric shoulder girdle loading (scapular protraction/stability and shoulder flexion moment) and isometric trunk stabilization resisting sagittal-plane collapse (anti-extension/anti-flexion of the spine). Hips, knees and ankles are held in near-extension isometrically to maintain a straight plank line. Muscles of the anterior shoulder complex (deltoids, serratus anterior) and scapular stabilizers maintain the upper-body support while core musculature (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, obliques, erector spinae) prevent spinal sagging/extension. Lower-limb and hip extensors (gluteus maximus, quadriceps) provide a rigid lever between shoulders and feet.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion (forearm plank) or near-extension (high plank) to support bodyweight

notes: Commonly viewed as an anti-extension core exercise; classified here as a PUSH because the upper body bears load in a push-support posture. Variation: high plank (on hands) increases triceps/shoulder loading; single-arm or offset-foot variations introduce anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demands. Cue neutral spine, posterior pelvic tilt as needed, and diaphragmatic breathing to avoid Valsalva.

reasoning: This is primarily an isometric loaded hold. In the overhead-hold variation the primary joint action is isometric shoulder flexion/abduction with elbow extension to maintain a vertical, locked-out arm — a vertical PUSH pattern. In the front-rack variation the sandbag is supported on the anterior shoulders/upper chest with shoulder flexion and elbow flexion/neutral wrists — functionally an anterior rack carry (CARRY) pattern. Both variations place high demand on scapular stabilizers, rotator cuff, and core anti-extension/anti-rotation to resist sagging or rotation. Lower limbs act isometrically for upright stance and to transfer load to the ground.
notes: Treat as PUSH when performed locked out overhead (vertical isometric push). Treat as a CARRY/rack-hold when held in the front-rack position (anterior load). Single-arm or asymmetric versions add ANTI_ROTATION demand; walking while holding converts into a dynamic CARRY. Ensure wrist/front-rack mobility and scapular upward rotation capacity for overhead holds; core bracing to prevent spinal extension is critical.

reasoning: This mobility/cooldown exercise primarily applies axial traction to the spine (decompression) rather than producing large limb excursions. In common implementations (active/passive bar hang or traction), the primary mechanical context is a vertical pull/traction through the shoulders into the spine: the shoulders are held overhead (shoulder flexion/abduction) with the elbows generally extended or slightly flexed while the spine is elongated/subjected to longitudinal distraction. Muscle activity is limited and often isometric — scapular depressors and latissimus dorsi assist in maintaining the hang, forearm flexors maintain grip, and the erector spinae and deep trunk stabilizers modulate spinal position and control. Stabilization requirements include scapular stability (lower trap, serratus anterior), grip endurance, and some core/bracing to prevent excessive swinging or rotation. Because the dominant mechanical intent is vertical traction through the shoulder-to-spine linkage, this best matches a vertical PULL pattern despite minimal concentric joint movement.
notes: Variation-dependent exercise: supine traction or child's-pose-style decompression will reduce shoulder/elbow demands and shift primary tissues toward passive spinal stretch. Contraindications: uncontrolled hypertension, recent spinal surgery, acute shoulder/elbow pathology. Progression/regression: active scapular depression/retraction increases muscular demand; fully passive traction or inversion reduces active pull demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pulling action: shoulder moves from flexion/overhead toward extension/adduction while elbows flex to bring the sternum/chest to the bar. Scapular depression and retraction are emphasized, and the thoracic spine extends as the torso leans back to meet the bar. Shoulders and elbows are the prime moving joints producing the pull; the spine and core act isometrically/dynamically to maintain posture and allow the sternum-to-bar trajectory.

joint_actions.action: extension with adduction component and scapular depression/retraction
joint_actions.plane: sagittal primary (with frontal/transverse components depending on grip and torso lean)

joint_actions.action: thoracic extension / posterior tilt of torso (isotonic/isometric control)
stabilization (slight extension/neutral to maintain body angle)

notes: Gironda/sternum pull-ups are a pronounced variation of the pull-up that increases scapular depression/retraction and thoracic extension; performed wide with flared elbows it emphasizes lower-lat and upper-back engagement. Monitor shoulder mobility/impingement risk in deep scapular depression positions. Core/bracing is important to control torso angle and sternum-to-bar path.

reasoning: Gironda Sternum Chins are a vertical pulling exercise performed from a hanging/high-bar position and finished by pulling the sternum up toward the bar. The primary joint actions are elbow flexion and shoulder extension/adduction in the sagittal plane, with prominent scapular retraction and depression (shoulder girdle) to bring the thorax toward the bar. The movement is produced by the latissimus dorsi and teres major (shoulder extension/adduction) and elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis), with rhomboids and middle/lower trapezius controlling scapular retraction/depression. The core and thoracic extensors provide stabilization to maintain torso angle and allow the sternum to clear the bar; the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control humeral head position throughout the range.
notes: Variation of pull-up/chin-up that emphasizes pulling the sternum to the bar; typically performed with a wider grip and flared elbows to increase lat/upper-back emphasis. Requires good thoracic mobility and scapular control; potential increased shoulder stress for those with limited mobility.

reasoning: The Gladiator Deadlift is primarily a deadlift variant so the dominant action is hip hinge (hip flexion to extension) with concurrent knee extension in the sagittal plane to raise the load. The lift also requires a vertical pulling/bracing action of the upper body (scapular stabilization/retraction and strong grip) to control the load as it is lifted — hence a PULL component. Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension and trunk extension in the sagittal plane; the shoulder girdle acts isometrically via scapular retraction/depression (transverse/sagittal components) and the elbows remain largely isometric. Stabilization demands include spinal/trunk stabilization (erector spinae, deep core) to maintain neutral spine and upper-back tension (lats/traps) to transfer force from hips to hands.
notes: If performed unilaterally or with asymmetric loading, add ANTI_ROTATION due to lateral spinal/core stabilization demands. Grip variations (straps, mixed grip) change upper-back/forearm emphasis but do not alter primary HINGE classification.

reasoning: The Gladiator Squat is a squat variation where the primary movement is repeated hip and knee flexion on the descent and hip and knee extension on the ascent in the sagittal plane. The movement is produced mainly by the knee extensors driving knee extension and the hip extensors driving hip extension; the torso remains generally upright requiring isometric trunk stabilization. If performed with a wider/toed-out stance (common in some 'gladiator' variations) there is additional adductor/hip rotation demand, but the dominant pattern remains a bilateral squat-type vertical displacement of the hips.
notes: Bodyweight/unknown load. If performed with pronounced lateral shifting, single-leg emphasis, or rotational elements, include LUNGE or ROTATION/ANTI_ROTATION as secondary patterns. Stance width/toe angle will increase adductor/hip rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is closed-chain hip and knee flexion/extension in the sagittal plane characteristic of squatting. The hips and knees descend into flexion then extend to stand, with the ankles dorsiflexing/plantarflexing to maintain balance. The movement is driven primarily by knee extensors (quadriceps) and hip extensors (gluteus maximus, hamstrings to a lesser extent). The trunk and core (erector spinae, rectus abdominis, obliques) act isometrically to maintain a neutral spine; shoulder girdle/arms may isometrically stabilize a held dumbbell (goblet or front-loaded variants). Secondary stabilization demands come from ankle invertors/evertors and hip abductors/adductors to control mediolateral motion.
notes: If performed as a unilateral/split-stance variation the exercise retains a squat pattern but increases single-leg stability demand (greater hip abductor/adductor and ankle stabilizer involvement). If the dumbbell is held asymmetrically (single-arm), ANTI_ROTATION should be added due to increased core anti-rotation demand. Variation as a Cossack/side-biased pattern would add frontal-plane hip abduction/adduction emphasis.

reasoning: Primarily a closed‑chain squat pattern: the exercise consists of hip and knee flexion during the descent and concentric hip and knee extension to stand (sagittal plane). Ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion occur as secondary joint motions. Primary movers producing the vertical rise are the quadriceps and gluteus maximus, with hamstrings as synergists; the trunk/erector spinae and abdominals stabilize the spine while hip abductors/adductors and foot intrinsic muscles control frontal/transverse plane alignment. If performed with an altered foot position or unilateral emphasis, additional frontal/transverse stabilization demands increase, but the dominant pattern remains SQUAT.
notes: Listed as a bodyweight/unknown variation—if performed unilaterally, asymmetrically, or with trunk rotation, include LUNGE or ANTI_ROTATION/ROTATION as secondary patterns. Requires adequate hip/knee mobility and ankle dorsiflexion for full depth; trunk stability is important to maintain neutral spine.
