reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge: the hips move from flexion to extension in the sagittal plane driving the lift. Knee extension occurs to a lesser extent to straighten the legs. The posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, erector spinae) produces the primary concentric force. Upper-body involvement is primarily isometric/scapular stabilization while holding the dumbbells (grip/forearms, lats/traps), so the action also maps to PULL as a loaded vertical/lifting pull pattern. Core and spinal extensors work isometrically to maintain a neutral spine and resist flexion during the hinge. Stabilization of the shoulders and scapulae prevents flexion of the arms and controls the load during the movement.
notes: Assumed to be a conventional deadlift-style dumbbell variation. If the exercise is performed single-leg or with marked lateral trunk bias, include ANTI_ROTATION and/or LOCOMOTION/CARRY as appropriate. Technique cues: hinge at hips, maintain neutral spine, drive through heels, keep load close to body to minimize lumbar shear.

reasoning: Gladiator squats are a unilateral split‑stance exercise that primarily involve sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion on the descent and hip and knee extension on the ascent. The primary movement pattern is a lunge/unilateral squat pattern. Ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion occur to allow depth, while the trunk and pelvis require isometric stabilization to maintain balance and control frontal/transverse plane moments. Primary movers produce knee extension (quadriceps) and hip extension (gluteus maximus, hamstrings); gluteus medius/adductors and core act as stabilizers.
notes: If performed rear-foot-elevated (Bulgarian variant) balance and hip-extensor demand increase. Asymmetric loading or single-arm weight would add ANTI_ROTATION demands. Technique cues: maintain knee tracking over toes, upright torso as able, and control descent to emphasize glute/quadriceps engagement.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip extension in the sagittal plane performed as a single-leg, isolated hip hinge. The gluteus maximus produces the prime hip extension torque with assistance from the hamstrings; gluteus medius/minimus and the contralateral hip complex provide pelvic stabilization in the frontal plane. The lumbar extensors and core act isometrically to maintain a neutral spine. Knee position is variable (often extended if leg straight or flexed in some variations) but is not the primary driver of the exercise.

joint_actions.action: extension (if leg straight) or flexion (if leg bent) — secondary/variable

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (primary stabilization), also resisting frontal/transverse perturbation

notes: Common variations: quadruped or standing cable/band kickbacks; knee can be bent or straight which changes hamstring length-tension. Requires strong pelvic/contralateral hip stabilization to prevent pelvic drop (frontal plane). Typically classified as an isolated hip-hinge accessory exercise rather than a compound lift.

reasoning: Glute bridge is a sagittal-plane hip extension movement: the pelvis is raised by concentric hip extension with the torso supported on the floor. Primary joint action is hip extension produced mainly by the gluteus maximus with hamstring assistance. The knees remain flexed and largely isometric (does not drive the movement), and the lumbar spine/pelvis must be controlled to transfer force and avoid excessive lumbar extension. Stabilization demands include neutral lumbar control (erector spinae and core) and frontal/transverse plane hip stability (glute medius/minor), especially in unilateral or loaded variations.
notes: Variations: single-leg bridge increases anti-rotation and unilateral hip-stabilizer demand; barbell/weighted bridges increase load but remain a hinge-dominant pattern; hip thrust (bench-supported) is a close but distinct variation with greater ROM and trunk angle.

reasoning: Primary movement is a unilateral sagittal-plane lower-limb single-leg lunge variant: the front/lift leg performs hip and knee flexion during descent and hip and knee extension during ascent. The rear foot is elevated (split-squat position), increasing demand on the front limb for concentric hip extension and knee extension driven mainly by quadriceps and gluteus maximus. The exercise also requires substantial frontal-plane stabilization of the pelvis/hip (gluteus medius/minimus) and single-leg balance (ankle stabilizers, intrinsic foot muscles). If performed as a goblet (anterior chest load) the anterior load increases torso uprightness and axial/core isometric demand but does not change the primary lunge pattern.
notes: Goblet anterior load (if present) increases core isometric demand and may slightly shift torque at the hip but does not change the primary LUNGE classification. Foot position (more forward or rearward) alters emphasis between quadriceps and gluteus maximus. Rear-foot elevation increases hip range of motion and unilateral load per front limb.

reasoning: This is a unilateral split-squat (rear-foot-elevated) performed in the sagittal plane. Primary joint actions are hip and knee flexion during descent and hip and knee extension during ascent driven mainly by the front-leg. The ankle undergoes dorsiflexion on the descent and plantarflexion on the ascent. The goblet load is held anteriorly with isometric shoulder/elbow and trunk stabilization to maintain an upright torso. Primary movers are the quadriceps and gluteus maximus (hip and knee extension), with hamstrings and soleus/gastrocnemius assisting; hip abductors/adductors and core muscles (erector spinae, obliques) provide frontal/transverse plane stability and balance.
notes: Unilateral lunge variant with increased hip range due to rear-foot elevation; anterior goblet load increases demand on trunk extension and upright torso. Variations (dumbbell/kettlebell front hold, rear foot height) alter balance and hip ROM but do not change primary LUNGE pattern.

reasoning: The glute-ham raise is primarily a posterior-chain, hip-extension dominant movement in the sagittal plane. The exercise requires strong concentric hip extension to return the torso upright (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) and large eccentric/concentric hamstring activity as the knee moves through flexion/extension depending on setup. Although the knee undergoes flexion/extension, the defining pattern is hip hinge mechanics with the hamstrings acting biarticularly to control both hip extension and knee motion. Stabilization demands include pelvic control and lumbar spine stabilization (erector spinae, deep core) while the feet/ankles are fixed.

joint_actions.action: flexion then extension (eccentric control then concentric return)

notes: Variation-dependent: a strict GHD back-extension emphasis is more purely hinge (hip dominant); a Nordic-style kneeling version shifts more knee-dominant hamstring curling action. Foot/ankle fixation and pad height alter hip vs knee contribution.

reasoning: Bilateral, closed-chain squat pattern: the primary joint actions occur at the hip and knee (sagittal plane) with concurrent ankle motion. Descent is hip and knee flexion with ankle dorsiflexion; ascent is hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion. Quadriceps produce the majority of knee extension force, gluteus maximus produces hip extension (with hamstrings assisting). The front-loaded goblet position requires strong trunk isometric control (erector spinae, rectus abdominis, obliques) to resist torso flexion and maintain an upright posture, and the upper back/shoulder/elbow musculature holds the load isometrically. Stabilization demands of the core and scapular/shoulder girdle are secondary but important.
notes: Front-loaded (goblet) variation increases anterior trunk demand and quad emphasis relative to some back-squat variations. Depth, stance width, and load position alter glute/quad ratio; symmetric load → no anti-rotation movement classification. Can be progressed to single-leg or loaded variations for higher demand.

reasoning: Primary movement is a bilateral squat: hips and knees undergo sagittal-plane flexion during descent and extension during ascent. Ankles dorsiflex/plantarflex to accommodate depth. The front-loaded (goblet) position enforces a more upright torso, increasing isometric anterior core (anti-flexion) and upper-back/shoulder/elbow stabilization to hold the load, but these are secondary to the primary squat pattern. Primary force production comes from knee and hip extensors in the sagittal plane.

joint_actions.action: controlled flexion/extension (neutral trunk with anti‑flexion demand)

notes: Front-loaded position encourages upright torso and greater core/upper-back isometric demand. If performed bodyweight (no load) mechanics remain SQUAT but with reduced upper-body stabilization demand. Mobility limitations (ankle dorsiflexion, hip flexion) and wrist/elbow discomfort when holding the goblet should be considered.

reasoning: Primary movement is a bilateral squat pattern: hip and knee flexion during descent and hip and knee extension during ascent in the sagittal plane. Ankles undergo dorsiflexion/plantarflexion to accommodate depth. The anteriorly held load (goblet) produces an external flexion moment at the trunk, so the posterior chain and core (erector spinae, abdominals/obliques) act isometrically to maintain an upright/neutral spine. Holding the weight requires isometric elbow flexion and shoulder girdle stabilization but these are secondary to the lower-body squat mechanics.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion/hor. plane stabilization (holding load at chest)

notes: If the load is held asymmetrically or offset from midline, include ANTI_ROTATION. Depth, stance width, and anterior load will influence torso lean and relative hip vs knee demand. Modified-from-step-up descriptor does not change primary pattern for the goblet squat unless converted to unilateral stepping.

reasoning: Primary task is maintaining a loaded squat position: hips and knees are held in flexion in the sagittal plane with the posterior chain and quadriceps producing isometric extensor torque to prevent collapse. Ankles dorsiflexed and plantarflexors stabilize the ankle. Holding the weight anteriorly requires isometric shoulder flexion and elbow flexion with scapular stabilizers active. The core and erector spinae act isometrically to resist trunk flexion (anti-flexion) and maintain an upright/neutral spine. Therefore the dominant movement pattern is a SQUAT (isometric variation) with upper-body/isometric stabilization demands.

joint_actions.action: flexion (isometric, holding load close to chest)

notes: Isometric variation of the goblet squat — primary SQUAT pattern. If load is held asymmetrically (single-arm goblet) add ANTI_ROTATION. Depth and torso angle can shift relative loading between quads and glutes; unloaded bodyweight squat hold is similar but lower upper-body demand.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion held isometrically (bottom or mid-squat). The ankles maintain dorsiflexion to support tibial angle. The anterior load (goblet) requires an upright torso and demands isometric spinal/bracing (anti-extension) and upper-body isometric holding (shoulder/elbow flexion) but these are secondary stabilizers. Primary force production and loading pattern match a SQUAT: quadriceps and gluteals resist knee and hip flexion while the posterior chain and core maintain posture during the isometric hold.
notes: Isometric variant of the goblet squat — primary pattern is SQUAT. Anterior load increases quad demand and requires greater thoracic extension and core bracing. If load is asymmetric or the hold shifts, add ANTI_ROTATION to classification.

reasoning: This is an isometric squat in the bottom position: primary joint demands are sustained hip and knee flexion with ankle dorsiflexion in the sagittal plane. Quadriceps and gluteus maximus produce/isometrically resist the tendency to collapse while hamstrings, adductors and calf musculature assist and stabilize. The anteriorly held load (goblet) requires isometric shoulder/elbow positioning to cradle the weight and significant trunk extensor and abdominal activation to maintain an upright torso and resist trunk flexion. Primary pattern = SQUAT because the dominant mechanical posture and load is a closed-kinetic-chain, bilateral hip/knee sagittal-load demand.

joint_actions.action: flexion / adduction (isometric, holds load at chest)

notes: Bottom isometric emphasizes quadriceps and core anti-collapse. Anterior (centered) goblet load does not create anti-rotation demand; if held asymmetrically or single-arm, add ANTI_ROTATION. Progressions: add time, load, or unilateral stance to increase difficulty.

reasoning: Primary movement is a sagittal-plane hip hinge: the hips flex as the torso descends and then extend to return upright. The posterior chain (hamstrings and gluteus maximus) produces hip extension concentrically and controls hip flexion eccentrically; the erector spinae and other spinal extensors control trunk flexion/extension and act isometrically to maintain spinal alignment. Knees remain slightly bent (minimal sagittal motion) to unload the quads and allow greater hamstring lengthening; ankles show small dorsiflexion/plantarflexion adjustments. Stabilization demands include isometric control from the spinal extensors and core to prevent excessive lumbar flexion, and hip abductors/adductors to maintain frontal-plane alignment.

joint_actions.action: slight flexion/extension (primarily stabilized with small ROM)

notes: Bodyweight/warmup variation emphasizes mobility and motor control of the hip hinge. Cue neutral spine and hinge at the hips rather than excessive lumbar flexion. Loaded or barbell variants maintain HINGE pattern but increase spinal loading and stabilization demands.

reasoning: This is an isometric squat variation: the primary joint positions are hip and knee flexion held in the bottom/partial squat position (sagittal plane) with ankle dorsiflexion. The anterior-loaded goblet position requires the lower limbs to produce/isometrically resist extension torque (quadriceps for knee, gluteus maximus and hamstrings for hip) to maintain depth while the core and posterior chain resist trunk collapse. Shoulders and elbows hold the load isometrically at the chest as stabilizers. Stabilization demands include trunk anti-flexion (spinal erectors and abdominal musculature) and frontal/transverse plane knee tracking (glute med/min).
notes: Time-based isometric strength/core challenge. Anterior (central) load increases trunk and hip extensor demand; if load is held asymmetrically (single-arm) add ANTI_ROTATION. Depth and tempo variations convert it to dynamic SQUAT.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge: the torso rotates around the hip producing hip flexion on the descent and hip extension on the ascent in the sagittal plane. Knees remain relatively static (slight flexion) while the thorax/trunk undergoes controlled flexion with eccentric/isometric loading of the spinal extensors and concentric extension to return upright. The hamstrings and gluteus maximus produce the primary hip extension force; erector spinae controls and produces trunk extension; abdominal/core musculature provides isometric spinal stabilization.
notes: Warmup/bodyweight variation emphasizes coaching the hip hinge and neutral spine. Degree of knee bend and trunk ROM can alter hamstring vs. lumbar loading; progressions include added load (barbell) which increases compressive/spinal shear forces—cue bracing and limited forward flexion for safety.

reasoning: This stretch typically combines hip abduction/external rotation to lengthen the groin/adductor region while producing a rotational component of the lumbar spine to mobilize the back. Primary joint actions are at the hip (abduction and external rotation in the frontal and transverse planes) and the lumbar spine (rotation in the transverse plane). Movement is primarily mobility/rotation rather than a loaded strength pattern; stabilizers (hip abductors, glutes, obliques, multifidus, erector spinae) act eccentrically or isometrically to control the movement and protect the lumbar spine while the adductors are lengthened.
notes: Exercise is a mobility/stretching pattern (not a strength pattern). Exact joint emphasis depends on variation (e.g., seated butterfly vs. supine twist): seated butterfly emphasizes hip abduction/external rotation and may include forward flexion; supine figure‑4 with knee drop emphasizes hip flexion/external rotation and lumbar rotation. Avoid forced rotation with acute low‑back pain or disc pathology.

reasoning: Groiners are a dynamic mobility drill that repeatedly moves one leg forward into a deep lunge-like position from a plank or standing split stance while often opening the thorax. Primary joint actions are hip flexion (bringing the knee/chest forward into the lunge) and subsequent hip extension as the leg returns, plus hip external rotation/abduction as the foot is placed outside the hand. The thoracic spine undergoes rotation/extension as the chest opens toward the lead leg. Knees and ankles move in sagittal plane (flexion/extension, dorsiflexion) to accommodate the lunge. Shoulders and scapulae act isometrically to support bodyweight when performed from plank. Thus the movement maps primarily to a LUNGE pattern (hip/knee sagittal loading) with a ROTATION component (thoracic rotation and hip opening). Stabilization demands include core/obliques for controlling rotation and the shoulder girdle/scapular stabilizers for weight-bearing support.
notes: Variants: performed from high plank (more shoulder/scapular load) or from standing/half-kneel. Emphasizes hip mobility (flexion, external rotation) and thoracic rotation. Not a heavy loading pattern—primarily mobility/functional movement rather than strength-loading. If performed as repetitive stepping it can also be considered a dynamic lunge progression.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pulling action (chin-up style) produced by shoulder extension/vertical pull and elbow flexion in the sagittal plane. The exercise is commonly combined with a crunch/knees-to-chest component, which produces spinal flexion (sagittal) and often hip flexion if knees are drawn up; these are secondary to the primary pull. Primary movers for the pull portion are the latissimus dorsi, biceps brachii and scapular retractors/depressores; the crunch component is produced by the rectus abdominis and hip flexors (iliopsoas). Stabilization demands include scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff control during the pull, and anti-extension/isometric control of the lumbar spine and pelvic positioning by the core musculature throughout the movement.
notes: If performed purely as a chin-up without spinal flexion, classification is exclusively PULL; if the crunch/knees-to-chest is emphasized the exercise is a compound PULL + core spinal flexion movement. Hanging variations increase scapular and grip demands; straight-leg variations shift more load to lats and increase lever arm for the core.

reasoning: This ground-based core flow predominantly challenges the trunk in both rotational and anti-rotational modes while the hips and shoulders provide dynamic transitions. Primary joint actions are spinal rotation and anti-rotational isometric control in the transverse plane, with repeated sagittal-plane spine flexion/extension and hip flexion/extension during bridges, shrimping, or technical transitions. Shoulders and elbows provide weight-bearing stabilization (isometric/controlled movement) in frontal and sagittal planes. The movement therefore prioritizes core (rotational and anti-rotational) control over pure pushing/pulling or loaded locomotion.

joint_actions.action: flexion (often maintained or cycled during transitions)

notes: Exercise variations (e.g., using a block as an asymmetric prop, adding crawls or carries) can increase anti-rotation demand or add LOCOMOTION elements. If the flow includes loaded walking or unilateral loaded holds, add CARRY and/or ANTI_ROTATION as appropriate.

reasoning: Primary actions are upper‑body pushing (shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension) to project the fist and torso rotation in the transverse plane to generate force. The shoulder complex (pec major, anterior deltoid, serratus anterior) and triceps produce the push while the thorax rotates via the obliques/rectus abdominis and hip stabilizers to add torque. Kneeling fixes the lower limbs (isometric hip/knee flexion) so the movement emphasis is on horizontal push and transverse rotation with concomitant scapular protraction and core stabilization.
notes: Variation: single‑arm strikes emphasize transverse rotation and unilateral core work; alternating strikes reduce sustained anti‑rotation demand. Kneeling reduces contribution from lower‑body drive—if performed from standing, pattern would add LOCOMOTION/hip extension involvement. Watch scapular control and neck posture for safety.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical press (PUSH) as the sandbag is driven from chest/shoulder level to overhead—this requires shoulder elevation (flexion/abduction in the sagittal/scapular plane) and elbow extension. If performed from the ground (ground-to-press) the lift commonly begins with a hip-dominant drive/cleaning phase (HINGE) using hip and knee extension to transfer the load into the rack/chest before the press. The posterior chain (gluteus maximus, hamstrings, erector spinae) produces the initial hip extension/drive; the deltoids and triceps produce the overhead press. The spine and scapular stabilizers (erector spinae, lats, serratus anterior, rotator cuff, obliques) act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and shoulder girdle during the transfer and press.

joint_actions.action: flexion/abduction (overhead elevation) and upward rotation of scapula

notes: If performed as a strict floor press (no ground-to-chest transfer) classification would be primarily PUSH with reduced HINGE; unilateral or asymmetric sandbag variations add ANTI_ROTATION. If the lift emphasizes a pull/clean prior to press, a PULL designation could be added for the scapular/elbow pull phase.

reasoning: Primary actions are upper-extremity pushing (shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension) delivering striking force while the trunk generates/transmits rotational torque (axial rotation in the transverse plane). The shoulders and triceps produce the push; the obliques/rectus and hip complex generate and transfer rotational power. Lower limbs and contralateral core act isometrically to stabilize the base and resist opponent forces.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (hip extension/flexion to maintain base)

notes: Variations (mount vs guard, hammer fist vs straight punch) change emphasis: hammer fists may bias vertical/axial force while straight punches emphasize horizontal push + rotation. Significant scapular protraction (serratus anterior) and rotator-cuff stability are required; if movement is more isometric (bracing against opponent) ANTI_ROTATION considerations may be relevant.

exercise: Ground and Pound (striking from ground) - 15 strikes prescribed
reasoning: Primary actions are repeated upper‑body pushing (shoulder horizontal adduction/forward flexion with elbow extension) delivered often with trunk rotation to generate force. Shoulders and elbows produce the ballistic push in the transverse/sagittal planes while the thorax and pelvis rotate in the transverse plane to add force and reach. Scapular protraction (serratus anterior) and rotator cuff/scapular stabilizers control shoulder positioning. Hips and knees commonly act isometrically to stabilize the torso on top of an opponent (or to drive the strike), and the core (obliques, rectus abdominis) actively produces and controls transverse rotation and resists counter‑rotation. Because the movement includes dynamic transverse plane rotation of the trunk and shoulders, ROTATION is included alongside the primary horizontal/forward PUSH.
notes: Pattern depends on position: striking from top (mount/side) emphasizes horizontal push + rotation; striking from bottom (closed guard) may involve more pliability and less hip-driven force. High demand on scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff for repeated strikes; transverse plane mechanics and trunk timing are key. If strikes are purely vertical (hammer fists down) classification remains PUSH but with different joint plane emphasis.

reasoning: Primary demand is anti-rotation of the trunk: the cable/band applies a transverse-plane rotational torque that the core must resist isometrically. Secondary dynamic joint actions occur at the shoulder/elbow as the hands press the handle/band away from the chest (horizontal/sagittal press). Hip and knee remain in a half-kneel position and act primarily as isometric stabilizers to provide a stable base and single-leg bias. Thus the movement pattern is primarily ANTI_ROTATION (transverse-plane trunk stabilization) with a secondary horizontal/forward PUSH action at the shoulder/elbow.

joint_actions.action: forward press / horizontal flexion (dynamic pressing away from torso)

notes: Load position/direction (band/cable in front, side, or offset) changes moment arm and anti-rotation demand. Half-kneel increases single-leg/core stability demand compared with standing. Emphasize scapular control (serratus anterior) during press to avoid excessive scapular protraction/retraction.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane with a neutral (thumb-up) forearm position. The brachialis and brachioradialis are the primary movers producing elbow flexion; the biceps brachii contributes but less than in a supinated curl. The shoulder complex and scapula act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm (rotator cuff, deltoid, scapular stabilizers), and the spine/core provide anti-extension and postural stabilization during standing variations. Wrist flexors/neutral wrist stabilizers control hand position. No primary rotational or carry component in the standard bilateral hammer curl.
notes: Unilateral/single-arm hammer curls add lateral/rotational trunk stabilization demands (may introduce ANTI_ROTATION when performed standing); seated or braced variations reduce core demand. Grip/arm path variations (cross-body hammer curl) slightly alter recruitment but remain primarily an elbow-flexion (PULL) pattern.

reasoning: This flow sequence combines hamstring-focused hinge actions (single- or double-leg hip hinge/straight-leg reach) with lunge patterns (split stance knee/hip flexion → extension). The primary joint actions are hip flexion → hip extension during the hinge (sagittal) and hip/knee flexion → extension during the lunge (sagittal). Hamstring mobilization portions emphasize eccentric/isometric lengthening of the posterior chain and balance demands (single-leg), while lunges load the lead-leg knee and hip concentrically and eccentrically. Stabilization requires core isometric control to maintain neutral spine, and frontal/transverse plane control from the glute medius and trunk to preserve balance and pelvic alignment during single‑leg hinge and stepping lunges.
primary_muscles: core (rectus abdominis, obliques, erector spinae) — stabilization

joint_actions.action: flexion → extension (hip hinge and lunge drive)

notes: Variations include single-leg Romanian deadlift-style hinges (increasing HINGE and balance demands) and forward/reverse/lateral lunges. If the flow includes significant transverse trunk rotation or reach-acrosss moves, add ROTATION. For strictly bilateral, stationary stretches the balance/stabilization demands are reduced.

reasoning: Hand strikes are primarily a horizontal pushing action of the upper limb combined with force generation and transfer from rotational torque of the hips and trunk. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal adduction/protraction and elbow extension (producing the forward strike) in the transverse and sagittal planes respectively, while coordinated hip rotation and spinal rotation in the transverse plane generate and transmit power from the lower body. Lower-limb extension (hip/knee/ankle) and ground reaction forces contribute to the kinetic chain. Stabilization demands include anti-rotation/isometric control of the core and scapular stabilizers to transfer rotational force and maintain posture during combos.

joint_actions.action: rotation (external/internal) and some extension for drive

notes: Variations: jab emphasizes proximal shoulder/elbow push with less hip rotation; cross and hooks use greater hip and trunk rotation. Hooks may include more frontal/transverse shoulder mechanics. Significant isometric anti-rotation core control is required to both produce and resist rotational forces during combos and footwork.

reasoning: Primary joint action is sagittal-plane hip flexion with the knee placed into extension (straight leg) to load the posterior thigh. The movement pattern is a hip-dominant sagittal motion (hinge-like) used here in a stretching context: the hamstrings are lengthened while the torso or leg is brought into hip flexion. Stabilization requires control of pelvic position and spinal posture (core and hip extensors/erector spinae isometrically control pelvis/spine) to isolate hamstring lengthening. If performed as an active straight-leg raise, hip flexors and quadriceps produce the lifting action while hamstrings eccentrically control; if passive/static, the stretch is imposed and hamstrings are the targeted tissues being lengthened.
primary_muscles: hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) — when active
notes: Variation dependent: bending the knee reduces hamstring tension; ankle dorsiflexion increases gastrocnemius stretch; active straight-leg raise engages hip flexors/quadriceps and introduces eccentric control by hamstrings, whereas passive/static holds primarily lengthen hamstring tissues. Classified as HINGE because the dominant motion is sagittal hip flexion/extension mechanics.

reasoning: Hamstring self-myofascial release (SMR) primarily involves sagittal-plane length changes and loading of the posterior thigh tissues via hip and/or knee motion. The primary joint actions are small, controlled hip flexion/extension (moving the pelvis/torso to roll the hamstrings over a roller) and often minor knee flexion/extension depending on leg position. Because the hamstrings span the hip and knee, the net mechanical action most closely maps to a sagittal-plane posterior-chain pattern (HINGE) even though the activity is primarily passive/compressive tissue work rather than a loaded concentric hip-extension task. Stabilization isometric demand is low-to-moderate for the trunk and contralateral limb to control body position and roll pace.
notes: SMR is primarily a mobility/myofascial technique, not a strength movement. Classification as HINGE is an inference because the hamstrings are posterior-chain tissues crossing hip/knee; variations (bent-knee rolling, single-leg) change knee/hip contributions. Avoid aggressive pressure over acute injury sites or neurologic symptoms.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pushing action performed with the body inverted: concentric elbow extension and shoulder-driven vertical press to raise the body away from the ground, with eccentric elbow flexion and controlled shoulder descent on the way down. Shoulders and elbows are the prime moving joints in the sagittal/vertical plane. The trunk, hips, knees and ankles act isometrically to maintain a rigid, straight line (spinal extension/anti-flexion) and the scapulothoracic muscles provide dynamic stability throughout the range. Balance and wrist stability are also required.

joint_actions.action: vertical push (shoulder flexion/extension component with scapular upward rotation for ROM)
isometric spinal extension (anti-flexion) to maintain straight line

notes: Handstand push-ups are an inverted bodyweight vertical push (overhead press pattern). Variations (wall-assisted, deficit, freestanding) alter balance and ROM demands. Significant wrist and scapular mobility/strength required; core must resist sagittal collapse though this is not classified as ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: The hang clean is a multi-phase, explosive lift. Primary phase is a hip-dominant hinge to generate power from the posterior chain (hip extension) with concurrent knee extension and ankle plantarflexion (triple extension) in the sagittal plane to accelerate the load (HINGE). The body then performs a high/vertical pull (scapular elevation, shoulder girdle upward rotation and elbow flexion) to elevate the bar and create time/space to pull under (PULL). The finish requires dropping under and receiving the bar in a front-rack position via rapid knee/hip flexion into a partial or full squat to absorb the load (SQUAT). Throughout, the spine and core act isometrically to resist flexion and transfer force, and the shoulders/traps control and decelerate the bar for a secure catch.

joint_actions.action: plantarflexion (triple extension) and dorsiflexion on drop
elevation/forward displacement to front rack (scapular elevation, shoulder flexion/forward positioning)

notes: Variation: power clean (shallower catch) emphasizes HINGE+PULL more; squat clean (deep catch) increases SQUAT demand. Barbell vs dumbbell/KB hang cleans alter grip and stabilization demands. No significant transverse rotation; primarily sagittal-plane explosive/plyometric pattern with strong anti-flexion trunk demand.

reasoning: Primary movement is an explosive hip-dominant triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) from a hinged hang position to produce vertical bar velocity (HINGE). Simultaneously the upper-body performs a vertical pull (shrug/scapular elevation and elbow flexion/turnover) to elevate the bar and prepare to receive it (PULL). The spine remains in extension/neutral to transfer force and resist flexion; the lats/shoulder stabilizers keep the bar close to the body. If a deep catch is performed it introduces a squat-like absorption, but the primary pattern is hinge-driven pull.

joint_actions.action: extension (concentric during drive; eccentric if catching into squat)
elevation/shrug and upward rotation (vertical pull component)

notes: Hang position below the knees increases range of pull vs high hang and emphasizes posterior chain power. A deep catch converts part of the pattern to include SQUAT for absorption — include SQUAT if exercise prescription emphasizes receiving in a full front squat. Requires coordinated timing and significant core and scapular stabilization.

reasoning: Primary action is an explosive lower-body triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to generate upward force, followed by an aggressive vertical pull (scapular elevation/upper trap-driven shrug and arm pull) to accelerate the bar and permit pulling under to receive it overhead. Hip extension (glute/hamstring driven) and knee extension (quadriceps assist, particularly in transitioning/power phase) in the sagittal plane produce the main propulsive force (HINGE-dominant). The upper-body vertical pull (PULL) involves scapular elevation/upward rotation and shoulder elevation to transfer bar speed into vertical displacement; spinal erectors and core act isometrically to stabilize the torso during the explosive transfer. Receiving the bar overhead may incorporate overhead shoulder stabilization but the primary movement pattern remains hinge + vertical pull.
primary_muscles: deltoids (primarily posterior/medial during pull and stabilizing when overhead)

joint_actions.plane: primarily frontal (scapular elevation) with overhead sagittal component on lockout

joint_actions.action: near-extension / rapid flexion when pulling under (arms act as levers rather than primary movers)

notes: If the exercise is caught in a deep overhead squat (full-depth catch), SQUAT becomes a relevant secondary pattern (HINGE + PULL [+ SQUAT]). Variations (power hang snatch vs squat snatch) alter the emphasis on receiving mechanics. High demand on mobility (shoulder, thoracic, hips) and rapid force transfer (second pull).

reasoning: The hang snatch begins with a hip-dominant hinge and a rapid triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to generate vertical force, followed by a powerful vertical pull (scapular elevation/upward rotation and shoulder elevation) to bring the bar overhead. The lifter then drops under and receives the bar in an overhead squat position (hip and knee flexion with an overhead-locked shoulder). Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip/knee/ankle extension for the drive (hinge), scapulothoracic and shoulder elevation/abduction for the pull, and sagittal-plane knee and hip flexion to receive the catch (squat). Stabilization demands include strong core anti-flexion/anti-rotation (erector spinae, abdominals, obliques), rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers to lock the bar overhead, and lower-limb control to absorb and stand out of the catch.

joint_actions.action: extension (maintain posture during drive) / controlled flexion/neutral (receive)
flexion/abduction to overhead and external rotation for catch

notes: Complex Olympic lift combining power (hinge + pull) with a receiving overhead squat. Requires thoracic and shoulder mobility, robust rotator cuff and scapular stability, and high coordination/timing. Depending on depth of catch some coaches emphasize more of the 'squat' or more of the 'pull' component.

exercise: Hanging Knee Curls (hanging knee tucks) - finisher
reasoning: Primary dynamic action is sagittal-plane spinal and hip/knee flexion as the knees are drawn toward the chest while hanging. The upper body (shoulders, scapulae, elbows, forearms) performs an isometric vertical pull to maintain the hang and stabilize the torso on the bar, so the movement is classified under the PULL pattern (vertical pulling/grip support) with the dominant movement emphasis on core-driven knee/hip flexion. Primary movers producing the tuck are rectus abdominis and hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) with knee flexion contributed by hamstrings; lats, scapular stabilizers and forearms act isometrically to maintain the hanging position. Stabilization requirements include strong grip endurance, scapular depression/stabilization, and isometric anti-extension of the lumbar spine.
notes: If performed with legs straight (toes-to-bar) hip flexor and spinal flexion demand increases. If performed with alternating single-leg tucks or twisting, add ROTATION or ANTI_ROTATION as appropriate. Classification chooses PULL because the upper body provides the primary support via a vertical hang; the exercise is fundamentally a core/spinal flexion movement performed from a hanging (pull) position.

reasoning: The heaving snatch balance is a compound Olympic-weightlifting drill that uses an aggressive leg drive (dip and drive) to propel the bar while rapidly dropping into and receiving an overhead squat. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee extension during the dip/drive and rapid hip/knee flexion to receive the bar in a squat; the ankle plantarflexes during drive and dorsiflexes on catch. The bar is stabilized overhead, requiring vertical push-type shoulder and elbow lock-out/isometric control (delts, triceps, rotator cuff, traps) to secure the load. Core and scapular stabilizers work isometrically to maintain trunk alignment and an overhead stable platform. Because the movement's main work is driven by lower-limb vertical displacement and receiving into a squat, SQUAT is prioritized; overhead stabilization/lockout functionally maps to a vertical PUSH pattern as a secondary pattern.
notes: Variants emphasizing a more powerful leg drive (heave) increase the explosive SQUAT/jump component; lighter technical snatch-balance variations may feel more like a reactive drop into SQUAT. Upper limb contribution is primarily stabilizing (vertical PUSH pattern), not a primary pressing action.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane hip flexion combined with spinal (lumbar) flexion as the legs are elevated into a pike. The body is suspended from the hands, so the shoulders, scapulae and grip perform an isometric vertical-pull role to support bodyweight while the hip flexors and rectus abdominis produce the moving action. Stabilization requirements include isometric scapular depression/shoulder extension and grip strength (lats/teres major/traps/rhomboids/forearms) as well as anti-extension control from the erector spinae eccentrically and obliques/isometric transverse stabilization to control pelvic tilt and leg trajectory.

joint_actions.action: isometric support (scapular depression/stabilization, shoulder extension tension)

notes: Primary intent is core/hip-flexor driven sagittal flexion; classified as PULL because the hanging support requires isometric vertical-pull shoulder/scapular and grip demand. Variations: tuck pike, toes-to-bar, single-leg pike. Ensure active scapular depression/shoulder stability to protect the shoulder while performing dynamic hip/spine flexion.

reasoning: Primary actions are repeated closed-chain upper-limb pushes (punches) and transverse-plane trunk/hip rotation to generate and transfer force. The shoulder performs horizontal adduction/protraction and the elbow extends to deliver punches (PUSH pattern). Simultaneously the thorax and pelvis rotate in the transverse plane to create torso torque and transmit force from the lower body to the striking limb (ROTATION pattern). Lower-limb joints produce weight transfer, rotation and ground reaction force while the core and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to maintain posture and transfer load.
notes: If the round emphasizes stationary technical punching, PUSH + ROTATION is primary. Heavy bag rounds with extensive footwork/stepping could add LOCOMOTION; single-arm striking drills or asymmetrical loading increase anti-rotation/stabilization demand. Kicks would add additional lower‑limb patterns.

reasoning: Primary action is forceful transverse-plane trunk and hip rotation driving an upper‑limb horizontal push/strike. The torso and pelvis rotate (transverse plane) to generate torque, hips shift/extend to transfer weight, and the shoulder performs horizontal adduction/flexion with the elbow extending to deliver the punch/elbow. Scapular protraction and stabilization (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) support effective force transfer. Secondary sagittal-plane actions (hip extension, knee extension, ankle plantarflexion) contribute to ground reaction force transfer; core must both produce rotation and stabilize against unwanted lateral/ sagittal motion.
notes: High-velocity, transverse-dominant compound movement. Variations (standing in place vs stepping/rotational power shots) change contribution of lower‑limb drive; prolonged unilateral striking patterns can create asymmetric loading demands on core and hips but do not change primary classification. If performing without rotation (pure jab from guard) PUSH would be relatively more dominant; if static isometric anti-rotation required (holding guard) ANTI_ROTATION may be relevant.

reasoning: Primary motion is sagittal-plane hip flexion with concomitant lumbar spine flexion (trunk curl) while the hands/shoulders remain fixed in an overhead hang. The hips/knees bring the legs toward the torso driven by hip flexors and assisted by rectus abdominis; the shoulders and scapulae act isometrically to support the hanging position and maintain torso position. Because the body is moving relative to a fixed overhead grip and the upper body provides a vertical, loaded support, this maps best to a vertical PULL pattern (with the main training emphasis being core/trunk flexion and hip flexion rather than upper-extremity pulling).
notes: This is fundamentally a core/hip-flexion exercise. Variations: straight-leg raises or toes-to-bar increase hip flexor and spinal flexion demand and can introduce more transverse-plane momentum; kipping versions add dynamic hip extension/shoulder involvement. If classifying by trunk movement only, a dedicated 'CORE FLEXION/ANTI-EXTENSION' pattern would be more precise, but from the provided pattern list the vertical hang with body motion maps to PULL.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip flexion (lifting the legs) with concurrent spinal flexion (anterior tilt/posterior pelvic tilt and rectus abdominis shortening) in the sagittal plane. The hands/shoulders remain isometrically loaded in an overhead hang to provide a stable anchor — this demands sustained scapular and grip/isometric pull strength (latissimus/forearms) but those are stabilizers rather than prime movers. Because the provided movement pattern set does not include a dedicated 'CORE' or 'HIP FLEXION' category, the best available pattern is PULL to reflect the overhead hanging/isometric upper-body pull demand while the prime movers are hip flexors and abdominal muscles.

joint_actions.action: flexion (lumbar/trunk flexion and posterior pelvic tilt)
isometric extension (typically straightened) or flexion if performed with bent knees

Should check mapping if a 'CORE' or 'ANTI-EXTENSION' pattern is available in your taxonomy.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion against a cable resistance with the pulley set high. The biceps and accessory elbow flexors generate concentric elbow flexion in the sagittal plane while the shoulder and scapular muscles act isometrically to position and stabilize the humerus. The trunk/core provides postural stabilization to resist extension/rotation from the cable line; no purposeful hip/knee/ankle movement.
notes: If performed single-arm or with significant torso lean, include ANTI_ROTATION for asymmetric loading. High-pulley position increases constant tension and may alter shoulder plane (slight abduction/flexion) compared with standard cable curl.

reasoning: Heavy bag work is primarily striking: repeated upper‑limb extension and horizontal adduction (punches) constitute horizontal/anteior pushing, while generation of power and transfer through the trunk and hips involves transverse plane rotation. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal adduction/protraction and elbow extension to deliver strikes, with coordinated thoracic rotation and hip internal/external rotation to generate force. Lower‑limb actions (hip/ankle plantarflexion, knee extension) produce force transfer and footwork but are secondary. Core musculature performs anti‑rotational/isometric stabilization between strikes while the shoulder girdle stabilizers manage scapular positioning.
notes: Variation depends on style: predominantly straight punches emphasize horizontal PUSH; hooks/roundhouse strikes increase ROTATION. Footwork/continuous circling may add LOCOMOTION as a secondary pattern. Clinch or repeated kicking would change primary patterns (add HINGE/SQUAT/LUNGE). Heavy bag striking also demands significant isometric anti‑rotation core stabilization even when ROTATION is the dominant dynamic action.

reasoning: High knees are a locomotor drill consisting of rapid, alternating single-leg support and swing phases. The primary joint action is repeated hip flexion (to lift the knee) in the sagittal plane on the swing leg, with reciprocal hip extension/plantarflexion and knee extension on the stance leg to produce push-off. Knee flexion occurs during swing to clear the foot. Movement is primarily sagittal; frontal-plane stabilization of the pelvis and single-leg balance are required from the hip abductors and core. Muscles that actively produce the movement are the hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris), assisted by knee extensors during drive (quadriceps) and plantarflexors for push-off (gastrocnemius/soleus); gluteals and hamstrings contribute to stance-phase extension and stabilization. Core and hip abductors act isometrically to control pelvic tilt and frontal-plane stability.
notes: Variation by tempo: slow marching high knees emphasizes mobility and hip flexor activation; fast/high-intensity version adds plyometric demand. Maintain upright torso and neutral pelvis to limit excessive lumbar extension; unilateral single-leg balance demands increase hip abductor/core stabilization. If performed asymmetrically or with load, add ANTI_ROTATION/CARRY as appropriate.

reasoning: The heavy bag thrust is an explosive forward shove of an external load: the upper limbs/shoulders produce a horizontal pushing force on the bag while the lower body generates force through rapid hip (and often knee/ankle) extension to drive the body and load forward. Primary joint actions are hip extension (power generation) and shoulder horizontal push/elbow extension (force transfer to the bag). Secondary knee extension and ankle plantarflexion (triple extension) contribute to the explosive drive; the trunk and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to transmit force and resist unwanted rotation. Therefore it combines a horizontal PUSH pattern (primary task of moving the load anteriorly with the arms/shoulders) with a HINGE-dominant lower-body power pattern (explosive hip extension driving force).
notes: Variations: if bag is held in a bear-hug and thrusted with hip drive, the HINGE (hip extension) role increases; if the movement is performed mainly with arm extension from a more upright stance the PUSH role is dominant. Asymmetric hand placement or single-arm contact increases anti-rotation demands (consider adding ANTI_ROTATION). Being described as plyometric implies emphasis on rapid triple-extension for power transfer to the bag.

reasoning: The Helms Row is a horizontal bodyweight pulling exercise. Primary joint actions are shoulder extension/horizontal pull with concomitant scapular retraction and elbow flexion occurring in the transverse/sagittal planes. The body is held in a plank-like posture, requiring isometric hip and trunk extension to maintain a straight line. Primary movers produce the pull (lats, rhomboids, mid-traps and elbow flexors), while the core, glutes and erector spinae act isometrically to stabilize the spine and hips and prevent sagging or excessive thoracic flexion.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (maintain neutral spine, resist flexion/extension)

notes: Typically performed as a horizontal row/inverted row variation. Grip width, bar/ring height and torso angle alter loading and emphasize different shoulder/scapular muscles. Requires good scapular control and thoracic extension mobility; progress by elevating feet or adding load, regress by raising bar or reducing torso angle.

reasoning: Primary movement is repeated horizontal push actions (punches) produced by shoulder horizontal flexion/adduction and elbow extension in the transverse/sagittal planes, and by force transfer through the trunk and hips via axial rotation (transverse plane). Punches commonly originate from hip/torso rotation and weight transfer through the lower limb, so trunk rotation and hip rotational/extension actions are primary contributors to power. Stabilization requirements include scapular stability (rotator cuff, serratus anterior) to protect the shoulder during high-velocity protraction/retraction, and lower-limb/trunk stability to control weight shift and maintain balance—these produce both rotational torque and resist unwanted counter-rotation.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension for stance and weight transfer

notes: Variation by punch type: jab is more upper-limb dominant (less hip rotation), cross/hook involve greater hip/trunk rotation. Footwork/stepping introduces locomotion elements and increases lower-limb demand. Repetitive high-velocity nature increases need for scapular stabilization and eccentric control of rotator cuff and forearm muscles.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip circumduction — a multiplanar motion composed of hip flexion/extension (sagittal), abduction/adduction (frontal) and internal/external rotation (transverse). The hip joint is the primary mover performing repeated rotational and circular displacement of the femur in the acetabulum. Muscles producing the movement include hip flexors, extensors, abductors/adductors and the deep/external rotators. The knee is typically held extended isometrically and the lumbar/pelvic region provides stabilization to allow isolated hip motion. Because the primary action is rotation/circumduction of the femur at the hip, this maps to the ROTATION movement pattern.

joint_actions.action: circumduction (combination of flexion/extension, abduction/adduction, internal/external rotation)

notes: Typical prone hip circles are a mobility/drill exercise emphasizing multiplanar hip control. Variations include performing with knee bent (reduces lever and changes loading of rotators) or performing smaller/larger circles. Caution with individuals with hip impingement or active pain — modify ROM or perform bent-knee variation.

reasoning: High knees are a rapid, in-place locomotion pattern emphasizing repeated hip flexion to bring the thigh toward the torso and alternating single-leg support. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: powerful concentric hip flexion (swing leg) and cyclical knee flexion/extension and ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion for push-off and landing. Propulsion is produced by hip extensors and plantarflexors during stance; hip flexors drive the swing phase. Single-leg support phases require frontal- and sagittal-plane stabilization from the gluteus medius and core. As a conditioning/HIIT drill the movement is rhythmic and high cadence rather than a load-bearing strength pattern, so LOCOMOTION best describes the primary mechanical pattern.
notes: High knees are a high-cadence locomotion drill. Single-leg stance demands hip abductor (glute med) stabilization and ankle proprioception. Regress to marching or reduce cadence for lower impact; progress by increasing speed, adding arm drive or load (which may introduce ANTI_ROTATION/CARRY considerations). Ensure upright trunk and controlled landings to limit knee/ankle impact.

reasoning: Hip circles are a multi‑planar circumduction drill of the femur at the hip joint — primary joint motion is hip circumduction which combines hip flexion/extension (sagittal), abduction/adduction (frontal) and internal/external rotation (transverse). The movement is produced by coordinated action of the hip flexors/extensors, abductors/adductors and the deep/external rotators while the core and contralateral hip stabilizers control pelvic position. Knees and ankles remain largely static and act as stabilizers. If performed standing or single‑leg, additional balance and anti‑rotation stabilization from the trunk and supporting hip is required.
primary_muscles: deep external rotators (piriformis, obturator internus/externus, gemelli)

joint_actions.action: rotational control and minor pelvic tilting (stabilization)
joint_actions.plane: primarily transverse (with sagittal tilt as needed)

notes: Variations: performed supine (controlled hip circumduction), quadruped, or standing (balance demand). Watch for lumbar compensation — emphasize pelvic stability if low‑back motion appears. Can be progressed with band resistance or single‑leg stance for increased stabilizer demand.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip extension in the sagittal plane against band resistance — a hip-dominant (hinge) action. The gluteus maximus and hamstrings produce concentric hip extension while the lumbar extensors and core stabilize the pelvis and spine. The band provides posterior-directed resistance throughout the movement; if performed standing or prone the knee may be relatively fixed (minimal change) or flexed (donkey-kick) but the primary joint action remains hip extension. Stabilization of the pelvis, ipsilateral glute medius, and trunk is required to prevent compensatory lumbar extension or hip rotation.

notes: Variation-specific: standing banded hip extension or prone donkey-kick still classify as HINGE. Single-leg variations increase demand on gluteus medius and introduce anti-rotation/lateral stabilization demands. Glute bridge style with bands is also hip extension but includes greater hip flexor length-tension effects and may involve more knee flexion.

reasoning: Hip circles are a multi-planar, rotational hip mobility exercise. The primary joint moving is the hip performing continuous combined flexion/extension (sagittal), abduction/adduction (frontal) and internal/external rotation (transverse) to create a circular path. Primary production of motion comes from the hip rotators (internal and external), gluteus medius/minimus and maximus, TFL, iliopsoas and adductors. The lumbar spine and pelvis act primarily as isometric stabilizers (core/obliques, erector spinae) to control pelvic position and prevent compensatory trunk motion.
primary_muscles: hip internal rotators (TFL, anterior glute med/min components)
notes: Variation: performed standing (single- or double-leg) or supine; single-leg versions increase demand on pelvis/contralateral hip stabilizers. Emphasize slow, controlled, multi-planar motion; avoid forcing range if pain or prior hip pathology.

reasoning: Hip circles are a multi-planar hip mobilization performed by moving the femur through a circular path: primary joint action is hip rotation combined with sequential flexion/extension and abduction/adduction (transverse + sagittal + frontal planes). Movement is produced by the hip rotators and dynamic hip movers while the torso and stance limb provide isometric stabilization. The exercise is movement-focused (mobilization of the hip joint) rather than a load-bearing push/pull/carry pattern, so ROTATION is the primary movement pattern.
notes: Variation: can be performed supine (leg circles) or standing; standing/single-leg variations increase demand on contralateral hip abductors and balance, and require greater anti-rotation core stabilization. No external load—primarily a mobility exercise.

reasoning: Primary joint action is hip flexion in the sagittal plane against elastic resistance. The exercise mimics the thigh drive phase of gait/march so it aligns with the LOCOMOTION pattern. Primary movers produce concentric hip flexion (iliopsoas group, rectus femoris, sartorius, TFL, portions of adductors). The knee may show concurrent slight flexion or remain relatively neutral depending on technique; the lumbar spine and pelvis must isometrically stabilize to prevent excessive anterior pelvic tilt or lumbar extension when the hip flexors contract. Band line of pull can create small transverse/frontal components, but the dominant movement is sagittal-plane hip flexion.

joint_actions.action: flexion (may be variable depending on technique)
isometric stabilization (prevent excessive extension/ant. pelvic tilt)

notes: Variation: performed as standing resisted march (clear LOCOMOTION), supine banded straight-leg hip flexion (isolated hip flexor strengthening). Cue neutral pelvis and avoid lumbar compensation. If performed as marching with progressive steps, consider adding CARRY or anti-rotation only when gait/arm load or asymmetric band placement introduces additional patterns.

reasoning: The Hip Flow is primarily a hip mobility sequence that emphasizes transverse-plane hip rotation (internal and external rotation) combined with repeated sagittal-plane hip flexion/extension and frontal-plane abduction/adduction excursions. Primary joint motion occurs at the hip (internal/external rotation being the defining feature), with secondary knee flexion/extension as the limb moves and is repositioned. The spine and core provide tonic stabilization and occasional transverse-plane motion during transitions. Because the exercise's defining quality is rotational mobility of the hip rather than a loaded pattern like a squat, hinge, or carry, ROTATION is the appropriate movement classification.
primary_muscles: deep external rotators (piriformis, obturator internus, gemelli)
notes: Common variations include 90/90 transitions, open-book rotations, and dynamic deep-squat to half-kneeling movements. Load is typically bodyweight; primary training effect is mobility and motor control rather than strength. Core and contralateral hip stabilizers work isometrically to control movement.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip flexion (bowing forward) and hip extension (returning upright) in the sagittal plane — this is the defining hinge pattern. Knees remain relatively fixed or in slight flexion as stabilizers; the lumbar spine is held neutral with isometric control by the trunk extensors and abdominal wall to transfer load. Muscles producing the movement are primarily the posterior chain (gluteus maximus and hamstrings) with erector spinae controlling torso position; core musculature stabilizes the spine and pelvis.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / controlled sagittal flexion limit

notes: Typical bodyweight hip-hinge drills emphasize a neutral spine and are a textbook HINGE movement. Variations: Romanian deadlift, kettlebell swing (power hinge), single-leg hinge (adds more balance/stability demands). Watch for excessive lumbar flexion — cue posterior chain and hip-driven motion.

reasoning: Typically performed from a half-kneeling or split-stance (lunge) position with the rear hip moving into extension (sagittal plane) to lengthen the hip flexors. Primary joint action is hip extension on the rear limb (and hip flexion on the front limb) in the sagittal plane. Knees are flexed to varying degrees (rear knee often flexed on the ground; front knee flexed to support). The movement is a static stretch variant of a lunge—primary movers for producing the hip extension (if performed actively) are the gluteus maximus and hamstrings, while the exercise primarily stretches the iliopsoas and rectus femoris. Core and pelvic control (isometric stabilization of the lumbar spine and anterior pelvis) are required to avoid compensatory lumbar extension and to increase stretch specificity.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / slight extension control (neutral spine maintenance)

notes: Commonly performed as half‑kneeling or standing lunge variation; emphasize posterior pelvic tilt or core bracing to target iliopsoas and avoid lumbar hyperextension. Variations (e.g., adding posterior tilt or trunk extension) change spinal loading and stretch emphasis; performing standing quad-dominant version (rear leg extended) increases rectus femoris stretch.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane hip flexion followed by hip extension (hinge) with minimal knee motion. The hip extensors (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) produce the movement while the lumbar erector spinae and deep core muscles isometrically stabilize the spine to preserve a neutral torso. Knees remain relatively extended or with slight flexion as a secondary joint action to allow hip-driven motion; ankles play a minimal role. This is a classic hinge pattern used to train correct hip hinge mechanics and posterior chain activation.
primary_muscles: deep core stabilizers (multifidus, transverse abdominis) — stabilization role
notes: Coaching cues: hinge at the hips with a neutral spine, push hips back, maintain slight knee bend. Variations/progressions include Romanian deadlift, kettlebell deadlift, dowel/club-assisted hinge; regressions include wall hinge or band-assisted patterning. Watch for excessive lumbar flexion in individuals with limited hip mobility.

reasoning: This warm-up emphasizes repeated hip flexion and controlled hip extension in the sagittal plane with minimal knee change. The primary joint action is movement about the hip (hip flexion into a hinged position and active hip extension to return upright). The lumbar and thoracic spine must maintain neutral extension control (erector spinae and core isometrically control trunk angle). Knees exhibit small amounts of flexion/extension to allow the hips to travel, and the ankles provide positional stability. Primary movers (gluteus maximus and hamstrings) drive hip extension while the posterior chain and spinal extensors control trunk posture; core musculature stabilizes the spine and prevents excessive lumbar flexion.

joint_actions.action: trunk flexion control / extension isometric control

notes: Mobility/warm-up focus on patterning the hip hinge — cue neutral spine, push hips back, slight knee bend. Variations: dowel/cueed RDL patterning, kettlebell dead-stop hinge. Avoid excessive lumbar flexion during repetition.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip flexion (forward hinge) followed by hip extension to return to upright — a sagittal-plane hip-dominant pattern. Knees remain relatively fixed with slight flexion/extension adjustments; the lumbar spine is held in neutral with isometric control. Gluteus maximus and hamstrings produce hip extension; erector spinae and core produce spinal/postural control. Stabilization demands include resisting trunk flexion and maintaining neutral spine while transferring load through the hips.
notes: Warmup/rehearsal of hip-hinge mechanics. Cue posterior displacement of hips, neutral spine, and drive through the heels. Progressions: loaded RDL/deadlift, single-leg hinge. Regressions: box-supported hinge, limited ROM hip hinge.

reasoning: Hip Openers primarily produce rotation at the hip joint (internal and external rotation in the transverse plane) and commonly include hip abduction/adduction (frontal plane) and some hip flexion/extension (sagittal plane) depending on the variation. The primary joint action is hip rotation (moving the femoral head within the acetabulum) with secondary actions of abduction/adduction and occasional sagittal hip/knee movement. Stabilization demands include isometric control of the pelvis and trunk by the core and contralateral hip abductors to maintain pelvic alignment during single-leg or dynamic variations.
notes: Wide variety of hip opener drills exist: lying or seated drills emphasize passive/active rotation and abduction (pure ROTATION pattern). Dynamic standing or World's Greatest Stretch–type variations add a lunge component; in those cases include LUNGE + ROTATION. Adjust classification if a specific variation is provided.

reasoning: Primary joint action is hip rotation (internal/external rotation in the transverse plane) often combined with hip flexion/extension (sagittal) and hip abduction/adduction (frontal) depending on the variation. Many common 'hip opener' drills (90/90, leg swings, world’s greatest stretch) emphasize transverse-plane rotation of the femur in the acetabulum and may be performed from a split-stance or lunge position, bringing in lunge mechanics. Muscles producing the movement include deep external rotators and gluteal muscles for rotation and abduction, and hip flexors/extensors during sagittal excursions. Stabilization demands include pelvic stabilization by the gluteus medius/minimus and core to control pelvic tilt/rotation, and knee stability if performed in a lunge stance.
notes: ‘Hip Openers’ is a broad mobility category. If performed purely supine/sitting (90/90 or isolated rotation), ROTATION is primary; if performed from a split-stance/lunge (world’s greatest stretch, lunge + twist), include LUNGE mechanics. Progressions can add dynamic loading or reach/rotation to increase anti-rotation/core demand.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip extension in the sagittal plane (a bridging/hip-thrust pattern) produced by concentric action of the gluteus maximus and assisted by the hamstrings. The resistance band placed around the knees adds a frontal-plane demand (outward band tension) that increases gluteus medius activation to drive/maintain hip abduction and prevent knee valgus. Knees generally remain flexed and act isometrically to transmit force; the lumbar spine and core act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and prevent lumbar hyperextension. Overall the dominant mechanical pattern is a hip hinge (hip extension) with secondary lateral stabilization from the abductors due to the band.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (prevent lumbar hyperextension, control pelvic tilt)

notes: Band placement (around knees vs. above knees vs. mid-thigh) changes magnitude of frontal-plane demand. Single-leg variation shifts pattern toward unilateral hinge and increases core/hip stabilizer demand. Cue neutral pelvis and avoid lumbar overextension.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip flexion/extension in the sagittal plane with the pelvis translating over a relatively fixed knee angle — a classic hinge pattern. Gluteus maximus and hamstrings produce hip extension; the lumbar erector spinae and core act isometrically to maintain a neutral spine. Knees typically show only slight flexion/extension as a secondary, allowing hip-dominant range of motion. As a warmup/mobility drill the emphasis is on controlled hip hinge mechanics and lumbar stability rather than load-bearing pulling or pushing.
notes: Warmup version emphasizes rhythm and range-of-motion; cue a neutral spine and hinge from the hips. Variations: Romanian-style hinge, single-leg hinge (adds balance/anti-rotation demand), or added load (progresses toward deadlift pattern). Watch for excessive lumbar flexion — cue posterior chain engagement.

reasoning: Primary movement is dynamic hip flexion and extension (leg swings forward/back) in the sagittal plane — a pendulum-style hip hinge with minimal knee motion. Muscles producing the movement are the hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) to swing the thigh forward and the hip extensors (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) to decelerate and drive it back. Variations include frontal-plane side-to-side swings that load hip abduction/adduction (gluteus medius/minimus, adductors) and transverse-plane leg crosses. Single‑leg stance requires isometric knee and ankle stabilization and core/bracing to control pelvic motion, but the primary pattern is unweighted hip flexion/extension (hinge-like) used for mobility and dynamic range-of-motion.
notes: Commonly performed front-to-back (sagittal) or side-to-side (frontal) as a dynamic mobility drill. Unweighted, ballistic/pendulum character — primary goal mobility rather than strength; classification as HINGE reflects dominant hip flexion/extension mechanics. If emphasis is on transverse pelvic rotation variants, consider adding ROTATION.

reasoning: Hip swings are a dynamic open‑chain mobility exercise whose dominant action is repeated hip flexion and extension in the sagittal plane (forward/back leg swings). The movement primarily mobilizes the hip joint through alternating concentric/eccentric activity of the hip flexors and extensors while the pelvis and trunk are held relatively stable. Stabilization demands include isometric activity from the contralateral hip abductors (gluteus medius/minimus), core musculature and spinal erectors to keep the pelvis level and the lumbar spine neutral. If performed side‑to‑side, the primary joint action shifts to hip abduction/adduction in the frontal plane (a different plane but similar mobility purpose).

reasoning: The hollow hold is an isometric core stabilization pattern where the trunk is held in a flexed/rounded position while the hips are flexed and the limbs are elevated. Primary joint actions are spinal flexion (maintained isometrically to hold the hollow posture) and hip flexion (isometric to keep legs off the floor) in the sagittal plane. Although it is primarily a sagittal-plane trunk/hip flexion hold (an anti-extension demand), it functions as an anti-movement core stabilization exercise (resisting spinal extension and posterior pelvic rotation). Stabilization demands include isometric tension of the deep abdominals and obliques to maintain posterior pelvic tilt and prevent lumbar extension; the shoulders/scapulae and quads act isometrically to support limb position.
notes: This exercise is fundamentally an anti-extension/isometric core hold rather than a rotational or locomotor pattern; 'ANTI_ROTATION' is the closest available classification from the provided list. Regressions: tuck hold, knees bent, feet lower to floor; Progressions: hollow rock, weighted hollow. Caution for lumbar extension — ensure posterior pelvic tilt and diaphragmatic breathing; discontinue if pain occurs.

reasoning: Hip swings are primarily a sagittal-plane dynamic hip flexion/extension drill (forward/back leg swings). The stance limb and trunk provide stabilization (isometric core and ankle/hip stabilizers) to maintain upright posture and balance. If performed side-to-side, the exercise also imposes frontal-plane demand (hip abduction/adduction) on the swinging limb and increased single-leg stabilizer activity, but the dominant motion in the common front-to-back variation is hip flexion/extension, which maps to a hip-dominant (hinge-like) movement pattern.
notes: This is primarily a mobility/balance drill rather than a loaded strength pattern. reasoning: Hip swings are a dynamic mobility pattern that primarily move the hip through flexion and extension (front-to-back swings) and often include transverse plane motion when performed as circles or with pelvis rotation. reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane spinal flexion with the core maintaining a posterior pelvic tilt and resisting lumbar extension (an anti-extension / core-stabilization demand). reasoning: House-cleaning as an active-recovery cooldown primarily involves low-intensity locomotion (walking/marching, stepping, shifting weight) driven by repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane. reasoning: Hurdle hops are a plyometric hopping task that requires repeated explosive triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to propel the body over a hurdle and then rapid eccentric control on landing. notes: Variation: single-leg hurdle hops increase unilateral demand and frontal-plane/rotational stabilization. Emphasis is on reactive strength and short ground contact times. Proper landing technique requires eccentric hip/knee control to reduce injury risk.

reasoning: Hollow rocks are a dynamic core stabilization exercise that primarily requires sustained spinal flexion with small sagittal rocking motions and maintained hip flexion to keep legs elevated. Primary joint action is lumbar/thoracic spine flexion (dynamic concentric/eccentric of the rectus abdominis) while the hips remain flexed (iliopsoas/rectus femoris) to hold the lower limbs off the floor. Knee extensors (quadriceps) and hip flexors act isometrically to keep the legs straight and elevated; scapular stabilizers/shoulder flexors may isometrically support arm position if arms are overhead. Overall this is best classified as an anti-rotation/anti-extension core pattern emphasizing sagittal-plane control rather than a limb-dominant push/pull or hip-dominant hinge/squat movement.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are hip flexion and knee flexion in the sagittal plane with concomitant spinal (lumbar) flexion. reasoning: Primary joint actions are hip extension and lumbar spine extension in the sagittal plane. reasoning: Primary movement is trunk (thoracic) rotation in the transverse plane as the exerciser rotates the torso while holding the ball. reasoning: This is a recovery/mobility/self-myofascial technique targeting the distal upper limb rather than a loading movement pattern. reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane trunk (spinal) extension often performed with concomitant hip extension. reasoning: Primary action is hip external rotation (transverse plane) often combined with hip flexion (sagittal) in common variations such as the supine figure‑4. reasoning: This is a self-myofascial release/mobility technique rather than a functional resistance or locomotor pattern. reasoning: Primary action is rapid triple extension of the lower limb (hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion) to produce vertical and small horizontal displacement when jumping into and out of the tire — this maps to the SQUAT pattern (closed-chain sagittal plane extension). reasoning: Primary motion is a horizontal/row-style pulling action: glenohumeral posterior movement with scapular retraction and elbow flexion to bring the torso or load toward the bench. reasoning: The inchworm is primarily a hip hinge pattern: the exercise begins with hip flexion (folding forward) and finishes with hip extension when the feet are walked toward the hands, loading the posterior chain (glutes/hamstrings). Simultaneously the shoulders drive/accept bodyweight as the hands walk forward and back (dynamic shoulder flexion/extension and scapular protraction/retraction), which functions like a horizontal push/stability demand. The core (especially anti-extension via abdominals and erectors) stabilizes the trunk during the plank portion. reasoning: Primary movement is glenohumeral elevation in the scapular plane (arm lift into a 'Y') with prominent scapulothoracic upward rotation. reasoning: Primary joint actions are shoulder flexion with a horizontal/diagonal adduction component and elbow extension to drive the load away from the body in an inclined (diagonal) plane. reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder horizontal adduction (bringing the arms together) performed on an inclined plane, with a component of shoulder flexion due to bench angle. reasoning: Primary movement is a pressing action: shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) with elbow extension (sagittal plane) to push the torso away from the elevated surface.
