joint_actions.action: protraction/retraction (scapular movement for stable shoulder girdle)

notes: Incline variation reduces relative load vs. floor push-up; steeper incline (hands higher) decreases shoulder/elbow torque. Hand width and incline angle alter emphasis between pectoralis major and anterior deltoid. Requires wrist mobility; can be regressed (higher surface) or progressed (lower surface or weighted).

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal pressing action: shoulder horizontal adduction combined with elbow extension in the transverse and sagittal planes respectively. Concentric phase produced by pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps brachii. Scapular protraction (serratus anterior) accompanies the press while the thorax/trunk, hips and lower limbs act isometrically to maintain a rigid plank alignment (anti-flexion). Incline reduces the percentage of bodyweight compared with a flat push-up but does not change the primary horizontal push pattern.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction (pressing concentric) / horizontal abduction (lowering eccentric)
protraction during press / controlled retraction on descent
isometric trunk stabilization (anti-flexion / maintain neutral spine)

notes: Incline angle alters loading (higher incline = easier). Hand width and incline change shoulder vs triceps emphasis. Requires core/bracing for spinal neutrality but does not inherently involve rotational/anti-rotation emphasis unless performed asymmetrically.

reasoning: Primary movement is an upper-body horizontal/forward press (push). The shoulders perform horizontal adduction with some shoulder flexion while the elbows extend to move the body away from the elevated surface. This occurs primarily in the transverse plane at the glenohumeral joint (with a sagittal component from shoulder flexion) and sagittal plane at the elbow. Reverse (supinated) hand orientation changes forearm/wrist and elbow mechanics slightly (increased biceps/forearm stabilizer demand and altered clavicular/upper-pec vs sternal-pec loading) but does not change the primary push pattern. Core and hip extensors act isometrically to maintain a rigid plank (anti-extension) and scapular stabilizers/serratus anterior control scapular protraction/retraction throughout the rep.
notes: Incline reduces load vs floor push-up. Reverse (supinated) grip increases wrist/forearm and biceps stabilizer demand and may bias clavicular head/anterior deltoid. Be cautious with wrist or elbow pathology; use handles or fists if wrist discomfort occurs.

reasoning: Primary action is an explosive horizontal push: rapid elbow extension with shoulder horizontal adduction to drive the body away from the incline surface (plyometric concentric). Shoulders and elbows are the prime movers (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, triceps), while the trunk must isometrically resist spinal extension and rotation to maintain a rigid plank during the explosive phase and landing. Scapular protraction/retraction and serratus anterior activity are required for shoulder girdle control on takeoff and impact absorption on landing.
notes: This is an upper-body plyometric horizontal push variation; progression requires solid scapular control and core stability. Variations (decline/incline, feet elevated, clapping) change loading and landing mechanics. Watch for shoulder impingement risk on high-repetition/poorly controlled landings.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal/vertical push pattern performed with the body in a plank line against an elevated surface. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) with some shoulder flexion (sagittal) and elbow extension (sagittal) producing the concentric push. The scapulothoracic joint performs protraction/retraction to allow shoulder girdle movement (serratus anterior and pecs assist). The hips and spine act isometrically to maintain a neutral plank (core anti-extension/stabilization). Wide hand placement increases the horizontal adduction moment and shifts emphasis to the pectoralis major; the incline reduces the percentage of bodyweight load compared to a flat push-up. Stabilization requirements include scapular control (serratus anterior, lower/ middle trapezius) and core/hip extensor isometric activity to prevent sagging or rotation.

joint_actions.action: extension (concentric during press, eccentric on descent)

notes: Incline reduces load vs. standard push-up; wide hand placement increases pectoralis major emphasis and may reduce triceps relative contribution. Ensure scapular mobility and core/bracing to avoid spinal collapse; wrist discomfort is common—use handles or fists to modify. Variation: decline (feet elevated) increases load and shifts demand.

reasoning: This is primarily an isolated glenohumeral internal rotation performed against band resistance — a transverse‑plane rotational movement at the shoulder. The primary joint action is internal rotation of the humerus at the glenohumeral joint. The rotator‑cuff internal rotator (subscapularis) and larger internal rotators (pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major, anterior deltoid) produce the concentric internal rotation while scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) and other rotator cuff muscles act isometrically/eccentrically to center the humeral head and stabilize the scapula. The elbow is commonly held in a flexed, isometric position and the torso/spine remains neutral.
notes: Variations include performing at 0° or 90° shoulder abduction (changes moment arm and rotator cuff demand). Emphasize scapular stabilization and avoid excessive internal rotation force if symptomatic; progress with band tension or range of motion.

reasoning: Primary joint actions occur at the hips: large frontal-plane hip abduction (moving the femur away from midline) often combined with transverse-plane external rotation of the femur/pelvis. The hips may also be held in modest sagittal flexion while the knees are flexed to facilitate the stretch. Because the movement is a lateral opening of the legs (or a controlled lateral descent similar to a side/lateral lunge), the LUNGE pattern (frontal-plane single-leg loading/lateral displacement) describes the primary mechanical pattern. When the stretch includes turning the femur outward (externally rotating) or rotating the pelvis to deepen the adductor stretch, the ROTATION pattern is also relevant. Stabilization demands include an isometric hip and trunk control to prevent collapse into excessive pelvic drop or lumbar rotation while the adductors lengthen and the abductors control motion.
notes: Name covers several common groin stretches. If the specific intermediate variation is a seated butterfly (bilateral hips abducted and externally rotated) the movement is primarily ROTATION/frontal mobility with limited single-leg loading; if it is a lateral/cossack-style stretch it more strongly maps to the LUNGE (lateral lunge) pattern. Adjust classification accordingly.

exercise: Intermediate Hip Flexor and Quad Stretch
reasoning: This stretch places the body in a split-stance/kneeling lunge position where the rear limb is taken into hip extension while the rear knee is flexed to emphasize rectus femoris lengthening. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip extension of the trailing leg (to lengthen the hip flexors/iliopsoas) and knee flexion of the trailing leg (to tension the rectus femoris). The front limb remains in hip and knee flexion to stabilize the split-stance. Stabilization requires isometric control of the lumbar spine and pelvis (core and gluteal activation) to maintain anterior pelvic alignment and avoid lumbar hyperextension.
primary_muscles: gluteus maximus (active to achieve/maintain hip extension)

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / control of anterior pelvic tilt

notes: Commonly performed as a kneeling lunge hold. Emphasize posterior pelvic tilt or active glute contraction to increase stretch on iliopsoas; if the goal is rectus femoris lengthening, ensure the trailing knee is flexed. Modify for knee pain (pad under knee) or perform standing quad/hip-flexor variations. Watch for lumbar hyperextension — cue neutral spine and core bracing.

reasoning: Primary joint positions are sustained hip and knee flexion in the sagittal plane (a static squat). Muscles generate isometric extension torque at the hips and knees to hold the position (quadriceps and gluteus maximus) while the ankle is held in dorsiflexion. A front-loaded goblet position places an anterior moment that increases demand on the thoracic spine and anterior core for postural support; the shoulders and elbows hold the load isometrically. Stabilization requires isometric activation of the core (erector spinae, rectus abdominis, obliques) to maintain an upright torso and the calves (soleus) to control the ankle joint.
notes: Front-loaded (goblet) position increases anterior torque and core/thoracic demand compared with unloaded or back-loaded squats. Depth, cadence (static hold duration), and load change relative muscle demands. If performed without a front load, joint actions and pattern remain SQUAT but upper-body demands reduce.

reasoning: Primary joint action is axial (spinal) rotation of the thoracic/lumbar spine in the transverse plane as the torso is guided/rotated. Secondary joint actions commonly include unilateral hip flexion with adduction/internal rotation as the leg is brought across the body (sagittal/frontal/transverse), and the shoulders are held in abduction/external rotation (frontal/transverse) as stabilizers. The movement is primarily a rotational mobility/stretching pattern targeting transverse-plane mobility; the shoulders and scapula act isometrically to stabilize the upper torso while core (obliques, multifidus) produces/controls rotation and the hips guide the leg across the midline.
notes: Commonly performed supine with knees bent; can be active or passive. If performed as a dynamic limb-driven thoracic rotation it is clearly ROTATION. Variations (standing windmill, arms by side) change shoulder/scapular stabilization demand but do not alter primary rotational classification.

reasoning: Primary joint action is isometric horizontal adduction at the glenohumeral joint (pressing the hands/palms together in front of the chest) in the transverse plane. The pectoralis major and anterior deltoid generate the adductive/pressing force while the scapulothoracic musculature (primarily serratus anterior) stabilizes/protracts the scapulae. Elbow joints are typically held isometrically (flexed) while the rotator cuff and core provide stabilization to maintain shoulder position and trunk posture. Because the exercise is an isometric anterior pressing action across the chest, it maps to a horizontal PUSH pattern.
notes: If performed unilaterally or with one arm offset, anti-rotation demands increase. Variations (standing vs seated, hands vs medicine ball squeeze) change core and scapular stabilization demands but do not change primary classification as a horizontal PUSH/isometric press.

reasoning: The Iron Cross is an isometric gymnastic ring hold whose primary mechanical demand is at the shoulder joint resisting collapse of the arms to the sides. The shoulders are held abducted ~90° in the frontal plane while large adduction moments are generated/isometrically resisted by the chest, lats and deltoids to maintain the 'T' position. Elbows are locked in extension (isometric) and the scapulothoracic muscles and rotator cuff provide intense stabilization. The trunk and hips must remain rigid (isometric core and hip extensors) to keep a straight body line. Because the primary joint action is an isometric/adductive control at the shoulder (functionally similar to a maximal horizontal push/fly hold), it best maps to the PUSH pattern. Significant scapular and rotator-cuff stabilization is required but these are stabilizing roles rather than separate movement-pattern categories.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
rectus abdominis/obliques and gluteus maximus (core/hip stabilization)

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (resists flexion/rotation, maintains neutral alignment)
isometric extension (maintains a straight body line)

notes: Classic gymnastic static hold on rings. High shoulder and rotator-cuff stress — advanced progression from ring support holds and partial cross progressions recommended. Symmetric hold (not an anti-rotation pattern). Variations (leaning cross, one-arm cross progressions) change demands toward more unilateral/rotational stabilization.

reasoning: This is an isometric cervical (neck) lateral flexion task: the cervical spine is held in lateral flexion (frontal plane) against an external force or self-applied resistance. Primary joint action is isometric lateral flexion of the cervical spine (no dynamic movement). The ipsilateral neck lateral flexors (sternocleidomastoid, scalenes, levator scapulae, splenius capitis/cervicis) generate/isometrically hold the position while contralateral neck muscles provide opposing tension. Upper thoracic posture and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to provide a stable base for the cervical musculature. Because the exercise is an isometric stabilization of the neck against lateral bending/rotation forces, it best fits an ANTI_ROTATION/anti-movement stabilization pattern.
notes: Classified as ANTI_ROTATION because this is an isometric stabilization against lateral bending/rotational forces at the cervical spine. Exercise requires careful progression and screening for cervical pathology; perform bilaterally and avoid heavy resisted holds in symptomatic individuals.

reasoning: Primary mechanical demand is an isometric horizontal push: the shoulders and elbows produce/maintain a pushed-away position against gravity (horizontal push pattern). Shoulders resist horizontal abduction/allow horizontal adduction force (transverse plane) while the elbows resist flexion via isometric extension. The trunk must resist sagittal flexion (anti-extension) so core musculature works isometrically to maintain a neutral spine. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower/middle trapezius) isometrically control protraction/retraction and prevent scapular winging. Hips and knees remain in isometric extension to keep a rigid plank line.
notes: Isometric horizontal push variation — classification as PUSH is clear. Secondary demands: scapular stabilization and strong anti-extension core activation. Variations (hand width, incline/decline, single-arm offset) change load and may introduce anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: This exercise places the trunk in a static rotated position while the lower limbs are held out (or controlled) across the midline. The primary joint action is isometric rotation of the lumbar spine in the transverse plane. Hips are held in flexion (to keep the legs elevated) and provide a stable lever; there may be isometric adduction/abduction forces at the hips depending on leg position. The obliques and rectus abdominis generate/maintain the rotational torque; hip flexors (iliopsoas) maintain leg elevation; pelvic and scapular stabilizers prevent unwanted translation or extension. Stabilization demands include resisting gravitational torque that would return the legs to midline (or to neutral), requiring strong isometric core activation and pelvic control.
notes: If performed dynamically (legs sweeping side-to-side) classification remains ROTATION but involves greater hip adduction/abduction torque. If performed hanging, additional lat/scapular stabilization is required. As an isometric hold it primarily challenges transverse-plane trunk rotation endurance rather than concentric hip motion.

reasoning: The JM Press is a narrow-grip/angled bench press variant combining elements of close-grip bench and triceps extension. The primary joint actions are elbow extension (producing the pressing force) with concurrent shoulder horizontal adduction/flexion as the hands move toward the torso while supine. The movement is therefore a horizontal push pattern. Stabilization demands include isometric spinal/core stability and scapular stabilization (rotator cuff, serratus anterior, rhomboids) to control shoulder position and protect the joint during the narrow-path press. Because the exercise emphasizes elbow-driven extension, the triceps are the primary mover with pectoralis major and anterior deltoid contributing to shoulder horizontal adduction.
notes: Commonly performed with barbell, EZ-bar or dumbbells; often described as a hybrid of skullcrusher and close-grip bench. Has higher elbow/ulnar stress than standard bench—technique and load management important. Variations change shoulder/elbow emphasis slightly.

exercise: Isometric Neck Exercise - Front And Back
reasoning: This is an isometric cervical (neck) exercise performed in the sagittal plane with two opposing actions: an anterior (front) isometric cervical flexion effort and a posterior (back) isometric cervical extension effort. Primary joint action is at the cervical spine (isometric flexion and extension). Because the exercise involves sustained muscle contraction against resistance (held position) rather than gross limb movement, it maps best to the conceptual PUSH (anterior/neck flexor isometric action) and PULL (posterior/neck extensor isometric action) categories when limited to the provided pattern set. Scapular and thoracic regions act as stabilizers to maintain head and torso alignment during the holds.
notes: Exercise is primarily an isometric cervical stabilization/strengthening movement used in rehab and posture training. Avoid aggressive or resisted isometrics if there is acute cervical pathology, dizziness, or vascular concerns. Progress by increasing hold time or adding gentle manual resistance; ensure thoracic and scapular stability during performance.

reasoning: Primary action is a unilateral horizontal push of the lead arm (shoulder horizontal adduction / protraction) with elbow extension to deliver the strike — a horizontal PUSH pattern. The movement is generated through transverse-plane rotation of the thorax and hips that transmits force from the lower body through the core to the shoulder — a ROTATION pattern. Stabilization demands include scapular control (serratus anterior, lower trapezius) and anti-extension/anti-lateral-flexion control from the core during trunk rotation and arm acceleration.
notes: If the jab includes a step forward it also involves a brief locomotion/weight-transfer component. Variations (pull-jab, jab from guard) change stabilization demands; rear-hand punches emphasize greater rotational torque. Scapular stability and core anti-extension are important to reduce injury risk.

reasoning: This boxing combo is primarily a horizontal push action from the upper limb (punch) delivered through coordinated transverse-plane rotation of the pelvis and trunk. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal flexion/adduction with elbow extension (producing the push), and sequential hip and spinal axial rotation that generate and transfer force from the lower body into the punch. Scapular protraction (serratus anterior) and rotator cuff activity stabilize the shoulder during the push. Core musculature (obliques, transverse abdominis) and glutes produce and control trunk rotation and transfer ground reaction forces; they also perform anti-rotational/isometric stabilization of segments not actively rotating. Foot/ankle/knee adjust and transfer weight but are secondary to hip/trunk rotation and shoulder/elbow push.
notes: Variations include stepping (greater lower-body drive), pivoting rear foot (increases hip rotation), or performing punches on the spot (more trunk-dominant). Unilateral loading and stance asymmetry produce additional anti-rotation/core stabilization demands.

reasoning: This striking combination is primarily composed of horizontal pushing actions at the shoulder/elbow (punches) coupled with force generation through axial rotation of the pelvis and thorax. Each punch (jab, rear cross, rear upper) is produced by rapid shoulder horizontal flexion/adduction and elbow extension (PUSH) while the rear cross and rear upper especially use powerful transverse-plane rotation of the spine and hips to generate torque and transfer force (ROTATION). Stabilization demands include anti-rotational/isometric core control to sequence and decelerate rotation, scapular stabilization by rotator cuff/serratus anterior, and lower-limb force transfer through hip extensors and ankle/knee extension during weight shift.
notes: Stationary shadowboxing emphasizes upper-body PUSH + ROTATION with less lower-limb drive; stepping into punches increases hip/knee/ankle involvement. Uppercut has a more vertical vector component but still functions as a push combined with rotation. Core anti-rotation is an important stabilizer though the primary intended action is rotational generation.

reasoning: Repeated single-arm punches from a kneeling position are primarily a horizontal pushing action of the upper limb (shoulder horizontal flexion/protraction and elbow extension) performed in the transverse plane. Concurrently the trunk and pelvis produce dynamic transverse rotation to generate and transfer force, so spinal rotation is a primary component. Scapular protraction (serratus anterior) and rotator cuff activity stabilize the shoulder. Hips and knees are held isometrically in kneeling to provide a stable base and require core anti-rotational control to modulate and sequence the rotational forces.
notes: Kneeling reduces lower-limb contribution so emphasis shifts to shoulder and core. Although punches produce rotation, there is also substantial anti-rotational core control between strikes—if the drill is heavily one-sided, include ANTI_ROTATION considerations in programming.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane flexion centered at the hip and spine: simultaneous hip flexion (bringing thighs toward torso) and spinal (lumbar/thoracic) flexion (curling the ribcage toward the pelvis). The hips produce the majority of the large-range sagittal movement while the trunk flexors actively shorten to flex the spine. Stabilization of the pelvis and lower extremities is required to isolate the hip/trunk flexion; knees are typically extended and act mostly isometrically. Because the available pattern set lacks a dedicated 'trunk flexion/core' category, HINGE is used as the closest sagittal, hip-dominant pattern, though this exercise also strongly emphasizes spinal flexion (rectus abdominis) rather than posterior chain hip extension typical of textbook hinge movements.
notes: This is fundamentally a trunk/hip-flexion (core curl) exercise. If a dedicated 'TRUNK FLEXION' or 'CORE' pattern is available, that would be more accurate. Classification as HINGE here is an approximation due to available pattern options. Variations (bent knees, anchored feet) change hip vs. spinal contribution.

reasoning: Primary movement is slow, controlled sagittal-plane flexion of the spine with accompanying hip flexion. Although the exercise emphasizes segmental spinal flexion (sequential vertebral flexion/extension), the hips also flex/extend and the posterior chain (hamstrings/glutes) and spinal extensors control and produce the return — mechanics most closely map to a hinge-style posterior chain dominant pattern rather than a squat, push, or rotation pattern. Stabilization requires lower-limb and core control to maintain balance and to manage pelvic position while the erector spinae eccentrically control descent and concentrically extend during the return.
notes: This labeling selects HINGE as the closest available pattern because of hip involvement and posterior chain loading, but the Jefferson Curl is atypical due to pronounced segmental spinal flexion. Use caution with spinal pathology; weighted variations increase hinge/loaded spinal flexion demands. If a dedicated 'spinal flexion/mobility' pattern were available, that would be more precise.

reasoning: The Jefferson Curl is a controlled forward-fold emphasizing segmental spinal flexion with concurrent hip flexion in the sagittal plane. Primary movement is spinal flexion (sequential thoracic → lumbar) while the hips flex to bring the torso toward the legs; knees are typically near full extension (may have a small bend). The movement is therefore a sagittal-plane hip/spine hinge pattern where spinal extensors and hip extensors eccentrically control the descent and concentrically extend on the return. Core musculature and scapular/shoulder stabilizers act isometrically to control load and preserve positioning.
notes: Primarily a loaded spinal flexion + hip hinge pattern — emphasize light loads and progressive loading due to increased intradiscal pressure with flexion. Variations: stricter knee extension increases hamstring stretch; slight knee bend reduces hamstring demand. Avoid heavy loading if spinal flexion tolerance is unknown.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane forward flexion with the pelvis/hips and spine moving together. The exercise is performed as a slow, segmental spinal flexion with accompanying hip flexion (and often a small knee micro-bend). Primary joint actions: spinal flexion (segmental thoracic/lumbar/cervical), hip flexion. The lowering phase is controlled eccentrically by the spinal extensors and hip extensors/hamstrings while spinal flexors and abdominals contribute to segmental flexion and control; the return requires concentric hip extension and spinal extension. Stabilization demands include isometric control of the pelvis and core to manage lumbar loading, and lower-limb stability to allow controlled spine/hip movement.
primary_muscles: rectus abdominis / obliques (spinal flexors and segmental control)
notes: Jefferson Curl emphasizes spinal flexion more than a classic hip-dominant hinge; HINGE is the closest available pattern because the exercise is forward-bending in the sagittal plane with major hip/spine interplay. Variations: straight-legged increases hamstring/hip demand; loaded versions increase spinal compressive/shear forces — use caution with lumbar disc pathology. If your pattern taxonomy included 'spine flexion' it would be more precise.

reasoning: The movement is a slow, segmental spinal flexion performed from standing with concomitant hip flexion in the sagittal plane. Although the exercise emphasizes vertebral flexion (spine articulation), the hips flex to allow the torso to descend (hip hinge-like action) and the posterior chain eccentrically controls the movement. Primary movers are the spinal extensors (erector spinae) lengthening eccentrically and the gluteus maximus/hamstrings controlling hip motion; shoulders/scapular stabilizers hold the load isometrically. Stabilization requirements include scapular/shoulder isometrics to grip the bar, thoracic mobility to allow segmental flexion, and core control to modulate the rate of spinal flexion and re-extension.
primary_muscles: shoulder/scapular stabilizers (traps, rhomboids, rotator cuff) — isometric
notes: Primarily a spinal mobility/segmental flexion drill with hip hinge characteristics; not a strength-focused pull. Use very light load and progress slowly. Avoid aggressive spinal flexion in those with acute low-back pathology.

reasoning: Primarily a sagittal-plane forward-folding pattern that combines segmental spinal flexion with hip flexion. The exercise deliberately rounds the spine (lumbar thoracic flexion) while allowing the hips to flex to reach range; hip motion and posterior chain lengthening are primary mechanical features, so it is best matched to the HINGE family (sagittal flexion of trunk/hip) within the available pattern set. Muscles producing the motion include the abdominal complex and hip flexors driving spinal/hip flexion, with the erector spinae and hamstrings eccentrically controlling the descent and acting concentrically on the return. Stabilization requires lumbopelvic control, pelvic tilting control, and active hip/knee stability; slow, controlled execution emphasizes segmental spinal mobility rather than a neutral-spine hip-dominant hinge.

joint_actions.action: near full extension / slight flexion (depends on variation)

notes: Jefferson Curls emphasize controlled spinal flexion; if performed with marked hip-dominant movement and spinal neutrality it would be a clearer HINGE. Variation: deeper knee bend reduces hamstring stretch and increases spinal contribution. Caution: repeated loaded spinal flexion (especially under load) may be contraindicated for some with lumbar disc pathology.

reasoning: Primary movement is spinal (trunk) flexion in the sagittal plane produced by concentric shortening of the rectus abdominis and assisted by the obliques. The exercise is often performed with posterior pelvic tilt to reduce iliopsoas dominance, but some hip flexor contribution at the hip joint can occur if the pelvis is not stabilized. Feet are commonly anchored, requiring isometric activation of the hip extensors (glutes/hamstrings) to maintain pelvic position and limit lumbar substitution. Overall the movement is a sagittal-plane trunk curl with secondary hip/ pelvic control.
notes: Janda sit-up emphasizes abdominal (spinal) flexion while attempting to limit hip-flexor dominance via posterior pelvic tilt and gluteal isometric activation. If performed with pronounced hip flexion (torso lifted by hip flexors) it would shift more toward a hip-dominant pattern; feet anchored variations can increase hip extensor stabilization demand.

reasoning: The Jefferson curl is a controlled sagittal-plane forward-fold that sequentially combines spinal flexion with hip flexion. Primary joint action is spinal flexion (cervical → thoracic → lumbar) while the hips flex to allow greater range; knees are typically slightly flexed to allow spinal rounding. Although the spine is the main mobile region, hip flexion behaviorally matches a hinge pattern (sagittal-plane hip motion) and the posterior chain eccentrically controls the descent. Stabilization demands include pelvic positioning and eccentric control of the lumbar extensors and hamstrings during the descent and concentric control on the return.
notes: This exercise emphasizes spinal flexion mobility rather than a textbook hinge (hip-dominant) pattern; HINGE is the closest available classification due to sagittal hip motion. Perform with light load and progressive exposure to end-range spinal flexion; caution for histories of disc pathology.

reasoning: The Jefferson curl is a sagittal-plane, segmental spinal flexion exercise combined with hip flexion. Primary joint action is controlled spinal flexion/extension (vertebral articulation) while the hips flex as the torso folds toward the legs. The hips and posterior chain govern the gross sagittal motion (hinge-like), while the spinal erectors and abdominal complex control the sequential vertebral flexion/extension. Knees are often slightly bent or near full extension depending on the variation, and ankles move into slight dorsiflexion. Stabilization demands include isometric control from the core and eccentric control from the spinal extensors and hamstrings to protect intervertebral structures and control descent/ascent.
notes: Primarily a spinal-articulation mobility exercise performed in the sagittal plane; classified as HINGE because the hips provide the principal sagittal mechanism. Variations (locked knees vs bent knees, added load) change hamstring and hip demand. Contraindicated for acute lumbar disc pathology or poor motor control without regression.

reasoning: The Jefferson curl is a slow, segmental forward flexion movement that emphasizes spinal flexion with concurrent hip flexion in the sagittal plane. Although the spine (thoracic and lumbar vertebrae) is the primary mobile region (segmental spinal flexion/rounding), the hips undergo hip flexion as the torso lowers. The knees typically stay in slight flexion or move very little to allow hamstring lengthening. Biomechanically this differs from a pure hip hinge (neutral spine), but because the hips contribute significant sagittal-plane motion and the exercise loads the posterior chain (eccentric control through hip flexion), HINGE is the best-matching available movement pattern. Stabilization requirements include active control from the erector spinae eccentrically during descent and concentrically during ascent, deep spinal stabilizers (multifidus) and the abdominals to control movement, and hip extensors/hamstrings controlling hip motion.
notes: This is primarily a spinal mobility/drill rather than a strength HINGE; classification as HINGE is an inference because available pattern list lacks a dedicated spinal-flexion/mobility category. Perform with light load or bodyweight; contraindicated for acute discogenic pain or unstable spine. Variations: deeper hip flexion or straighter knees change hamstring vs lumbar emphasis.

reasoning: Treadmill jogging is a cyclical locomotion pattern driven primarily by repeated sagittal-plane hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension producing forward progression. Hip extensors (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) drive propulsion during stance; knee extensors (quadriceps) control stance and support; ankle plantarflexors (gastrocnemius/soleus) provide push-off while dorsiflexors (tibialis anterior) clear the foot during swing. Trunk and hip abductors stabilize the pelvis and resist frontal/transverse plane motion; arm/shoulder swing provides counter-rotation and balance. Primary movers are lower-limb extensors/flexors; stabilization demands include core, hip abductors/adductors and foot/ankle intrinsic control.
notes: Treadmill vs overground alters belt mechanics but movement pattern remains LOCOMOTION. Speed, incline and footwear change relative muscle demands (incline ↑ hip extensor demand, faster pace ↑ ankle/knee power). No loaded carry or purposeful rotational/anti-rotation emphasis in standard treadmill jogging.

reasoning: The Jefferson curl is dominated by sagittal-plane flexion through the spine with concurrent hip flexion; the movement is a slow, segmental spinal flexion performed from standing and therefore shares mechanics with hip-dominant forward folding (HINGE) but with an emphasized spinal rounding. Primary joint actions are spinal (lumbar/thoracic) flexion and hip flexion; the knees are typically held slightly flexed or controlled to allow hamstring lengthening. Stabilization requires coordinated core control for segmental spinal motion and eccentric control of the posterior chain (erector spinae, hamstrings) to modulate descent.
notes: This exercise emphasizes intentional spinal flexion/mobilization rather than a textbook hip-dominant hinge with a neutral spine; heavy loading while performing spinal flexion can increase injury risk. Variations: performed with greater knee extension shifts more stretch to hamstrings; loaded Jefferson curl increases demand on posterior chain and spinal control.

reasoning: This is a multi-planar cervical spine mobility exercise emphasizing rotation (transverse plane) with concurrent flexion/extension (sagittal) and lateral flexion (frontal). Primary joint motion occurs at the cervical spine: active rotation produced by contralateral/ipsilateral cervical rotators and assisted by superficial neck muscles. Movement requires fine motor control of deep neck flexors/extensors and isometrically engages thoracic/scapular stabilizers to keep the shoulders and upper trunk stable while the head moves.
primary_muscles: longus colli / longus capitis (deep neck flexors)
notes: Primarily a mobility drill for the cervical spine. Should be performed slowly with control; avoid large ballistic circles in those with cervical pathology. Can be broken down into isolated flexion/extension, lateral flexion, and rotation for safer progression. Scapular/upper thoracic stabilization is important to ensure isolated cervical movement.

reasoning: Jerk Balance is a split-jerk footwork/receiving drill. The primary actions are rapid sagittal-plane lower-limb extensions to drive the body and then a controlled drop into a split/lunge receiving position. Primary joint movement occurs at the hip, knee and ankle (dip -> drive: hip/knee extension and ankle plantarflexion; receive: asynchronous hip and knee positions with front leg in hip flexion/knee flexion and rear leg more hip extension). The shoulders/elbows hold the bar in the front/back rack and act isometrically to stabilize the load; the spine and core provide anti-flexion/anti-extension stability during the drive and when receiving. Quadriceps and gluteus maximus produce the drive/extension, calves contribute to plantarflexion, hamstrings assist hip control, and the trunk/shoulder girdle stabilize the barbell in the rack.

joint_actions.action: hip flexion (initial dip) then hip extension (drive) and asymmetric hip positions when receiving: front hip remains in relative flexion, rear hip in relative extension
knee flexion (dip) then knee extension (drive); upon receiving both knees are flexed but front and rear knees adopt different flexion angles in split position
ankle dorsiflexion (dip) then plantarflexion (drive/extension) with demand for ankle stability on both feet during split landing
isometric shoulder flexion/holding in rack (stabilization of barbell)
isometric elbow flexion/partial extension depending on rack; stabilizes bar position
isometric anti-flexion/anti-extension to maintain torso posture during drive and reception

notes: Variation: can be performed from front or back rack and with full bar press or without upward drive; primary training emphasis is on split/lunge foot placement and receiving mechanics rather than vertical pressing. Requires coordination and single-leg control on landing; clinicians/coaches may also view it as a plyometric/skill drill.

reasoning: Jump rope is a cyclic locomotor/plyometric task where repeated short-duration vertical propulsion and controlled landings produce forward/rhythmical locomotion in place. The primary joint action producing movement is ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane generating propulsion; knees and hips undergo modest sagittal flexion/extension to absorb and re-extend. The upper limbs (shoulder/elbow/wrist) produce low-amplitude rotational and sagittal actions to rotate the rope. The trunk and hips act isometrically to stabilize posture and transfer forces; the shoulders/scapulae stabilize the arms during rope rotation.

joint_actions.action: low-amplitude rotation and horizontal ab/adduction to drive rope
pronation/supination and flexion/extension to flick/turn rope

notes: Variations alter emphasis: double-unders increase plyometric demand; single-leg jump rope adds unilateral LOCOMOTION and greater ankle/knee/hip stabilization demands; high-knee variations increase hip flexor involvement. Primarily a conditioning/locomotion pattern with significant ankle-driven propulsion and core/upper-limb stabilization for rope turnover.

reasoning: This is a repetitive plyometric/locomotor task driven primarily by ankle plantarflexion and knee/hip extension in the sagittal plane to produce vertical propulsion and absorb landing forces. The movement pattern is locomotion (rhythmic jumping/propulsion) with a squat-like lower-body extension/flexion pattern on each cycle. Rope turning uses small shoulder/elbow/forearm movements but these are secondary to lower-body propulsion. Core and lower-limb stabilizers act isometrically/eccentrically to control trunk position and landing deceleration.
primary_muscles: core stabilizers (rectus abdominis, obliques, erector spinae)
shoulder/forearm muscles for rope turn (deltoids, rotator cuff, wrist/finger flexors-extensors)

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (maintain neutral posture) with small sagittal/transverse adjustments
repetitive transverse-plane rotation / small horizontal flexion-extension to turn rope

notes: Reach-jumps add greater shoulder flexion and overhead reach (increasing anterior chain and shoulder demand) and emphasize greater hip/knee extension. Single-leg or high-intensity variations increase unilateral balance and anti-rotation/core demand. Primary training effect is plyometric conditioning rather than pure strength pattern.

reasoning: KB Halos are a controlled circular/tracking movement of a loaded implement around the head, producing primary transverse-plane rotation/ circumduction of the shoulder girdle and thoracic spine. The shoulders perform horizontal adduction/abduction and internal/external rotation as the bell travels around the head; the thoracic spine rotates to allow smooth arc. Elbows and wrists remain relatively fixed (isometric grip) while the core (obliques, erector spinae, deep stabilizers) and scapular stabilizers control torso position and prevent unwanted translation. Primary movement intent is rotational/mobility of the shoulder and thoracic spine rather than a push/pull or carry pattern.
notes: Primarily a mobility/rotational pattern for the shoulder and thoracic spine. Variations include single-arm halos (increased anti-rotation demand) or bottoms-up hold (increased rotator cuff and grip challenge). Caution with cervical issues — emphasize thoracic movement and controlled load close to the head.

reasoning: Jump rope is a cyclic, locomotor/plyometric task driven primarily by repeated plantarflexion and small sagittal-plane knee and hip extension to produce vertical displacement and rebound. The primary joint actions are ankle plantarflexion (propulsion) and controlled dorsiflexion on landing, with knee and hip flexion/extension contributing to shock absorption and minimal vertical impulse. The core and spinal erectors act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and maintain posture; the shoulders, elbows and forearms provide low-amplitude rhythmic rotation/coordination to turn the rope. Primary force production is distal-to-proximal for rebound (calf complex) with contributions from quadriceps and gluteals for knee/hip control. Stabilization demands include ankle and hip neuromuscular control for single- or double-leg landing tolerance and core control for upright posture and efficient force transfer.

joint_actions.action: flexion / extension (small amplitude for recoil and landing)
mild flexion/extension and stability for rope turnover

notes: Primarily an ankle-dominant locomotion/plyometric task. Variations (double-unders, high knees) increase hip/knee contribution and core demand. Impact/loading considerations for novices or those with lower-limb joint issues.

reasoning: Primary action is dynamic trunk flexion with transverse-plane trunk rotation as the kettlebell is passed across the midline (floor-to-floor) while the hips remain in a flexed (V-sit) position. Joints moving: spine (segmental flexion and rotation) and hips (isometric/dynamic hip flexion to maintain leg elevation); shoulders/arms move through horizontal/transverse patterns to guide the load. The movement is driven by the rectus abdominis and obliques producing trunk flexion and rotation, with hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) maintaining the V position and the anterior shoulder/rotator cuff controlling the pass. Significant core stabilization (anti-extension and anti-rotation components) is required to control spinal position during dynamic transverse-plane movement.

joint_actions.action: flexion (isometric emphasis to hold legs elevated)

notes: Although primarily a rotational core exercise, there are important anti-extension and anti-rotation stabilization demands. Asymmetric loading or heavier kettlebells increase rotational/anti-rotation demand. Variations: lying passovers, seated V-sit, or slower tempo to emphasize control. Cue neutral lumbar spine and avoid momentum-driven swings.

reasoning: Jumping jacks are a rhythmic plyometric locomotor drill combining lower‑body propulsion and lateral limb excursion with coordinated arm abduction/adduction. Primary lower‑body actions are triple extension (ankle plantarflexion, knee extension, hip extension) to produce the vertical/jumping impulse and hip abduction/adduction in the frontal plane as the legs move apart and together. Simultaneously the shoulders perform large‑range abduction (frontal plane) and adduction. Core and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to maintain trunk posture and control the shoulder girdle. Because the drill is a dynamic, repetitive displacement/jumping pattern rather than a loaded push/pull/lift, LOCOMOTION best describes the primary movement pattern.
notes: Variations include low‑impact stepping jacks (reduced plyometric demand), weighted or banded arm movements (increase shoulder/resistance demand), or single‑leg versions (increase balance and unilateral loading). Jumping jacks are primarily an aerobic/plyometric locomotor pattern rather than a pure strength ‘squat’ or ‘hinge’ movement.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane trunk and hip flexion: the torso and legs move toward one another (spinal flexion + hip flexion) to form the 'V'. Shoulders may perform sagittal flexion if the kettlebell is held overhead/reached to the feet. Stabilization requires isometric control of the pelvis/lumbar spine and scapular/shoulder stability to control the kettlebell. This pattern library lacks a discrete 'core/trunk flexion' category; the closest general movement family is hip-dominant (HINGE) but the action is hip flexion rather than classic hip extension hinge, so classification is approximate.

joint_actions.action: isometric/extended (if holding KB with arms extended)

notes: Library does not include a dedicated 'trunk flexion/core' pattern. If mapping must reflect trunk/hip flexion explicitly, add a 'CORE/TRUNK FLEXION' or similar pattern. Unilateral or offset KB holds introduce anti-rotation/lateral stabilization demands and would merit adding ANTI_ROTATION when load is asymmetric.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane spinal flexion and hip flexion to lift torso and legs (classic V-up), performed in an alternating/overlapping pattern that introduces a transverse-plane component as the trunk and reaching arm/hand cross the midline to clear or touch the kettlebell. Thus the movement is primarily a dynamic trunk/hip flexion pattern with a clear rotational/transverse element. Muscles producing the movement are the rectus abdominis and hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) for sagittal flexion, with external and internal obliques contributing to the alternating transverse/rotation and cross-body reach. Stabilization requires anti-extension from the deep core ( TVA, multifidus ), isometric control from the lats/shoulder girdle when reaching over the KB, and pelvic/hip stability to prevent excessive lumbar loading.
notes: If performed strictly sagittally without cross-body reach the primary pattern would be core/trunk flexion; the alternating/cross-over variant increases transverse/rotational demand. Maintain posterior pelvic tilt and avoid momentum to reduce lumbar shear. Can be progressed/loaded with a KB held overhead or regressed by bending knees or reducing ROM.

reasoning: Kettlebell swings are a ballistic hip-hinge dominated movement. The primary joint action is rapid hip extension in the sagittal plane producing the propulsive force. Knee extension occurs minimally as a secondary action to complete the stance, while the thorax and lumbar spine act isometrically to resist flexion and transfer force. The shoulders and scapulae provide positional control of the kettlebell (isometric/stabilizing shoulder flexion) rather than primary concentric pulling or pushing. Primary power comes from the posterior chain (glutes and hamstrings) with spinal extensors and core stabilizers controlling trunk position; the shoulders, lats and grip stabilize the load as a pendulum.
notes: Classic two-handed Russian swings = HINGE. Single-arm swings introduce significant anti-rotation demands (would add ANTI_ROTATION). American/OHS-style swings (overhead finish) add greater shoulder/vertical components. Emphasize hip drive, posterior chain power, and trunk bracing; shoulders act mainly as stabilizers rather than primary movers.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: bilateral shoulder elevation (primarily shoulder flexion/abduction in the sagittal/scapular plane) with elbow extension to drive the keg overhead. Scapulothoracic upward rotation and elevation occur to allow full overhead range. The trunk, hips and lower limbs act isometrically to stabilize the spine and transfer force. Major concentric movers are the deltoids and triceps, with scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, upper/lower traps) and rotator cuff providing shoulder stability; core and posterior chain resist hyperextension and lateral/unwanted movement.
notes: This classification assumes a bilateral, strict (no leg drive) overhead press of a keg/log. If performed unilaterally or with substantial trunk rotation/asymmetry, include ANTI_ROTATION and/or ROTATION. If a push press variation with leg drive is used, consider adding lower-body drive as a secondary pattern.

reasoning: Keg loading is a compound strongman task that begins with a ground pickup (primary hip hinge with knee extension) to lift the keg into a carryable position (lap/shoulder). Once up, the athlete moves the loaded implement to a platform (loaded walking or marching) and often resists tipping/rotation of an awkward/asymmetric mass. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee extension (power from posterior chain) during the pick, sagittal-plane shoulder/elbow actions to cradle or shoulder the keg, and isometric trunk/oblique activity to prevent rotation or lateral collapse during transport and loading. Stabilization demands include substantial core anti-rotation/anti-flexion, scapular/shoulder stability for maintaining the hold, and single-leg hip stabilization during the walk and step onto/onto the platform.
notes: Variations alter emphasis: two-arm bear-hug carries reduce rotational demand, single-arm or offset carries increase ANTI_ROTATION. Loading onto higher platforms may add a partial squat/vertical press element when finishing; technique differences (shouldering vs. bear-hug) change shoulder/elbow mechanics but not the primary hinge/carry nature.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push — shoulder elevation (press) with elbow extension to move the load overhead. The kettlebell Arnold press also includes humeral rotation (internal -> external) through the press but the primary pattern is vertical PUSH. When performed single-arm or unilaterally, the asymmetrical load creates a significant anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demand on the trunk and shoulder girdle, so ANTI_ROTATION is included as a secondary/stabilizing pattern. Shoulders (deltoids) and triceps produce the concentric push; rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control the rotational component and glenohumeral stability; core (obliques, QL, erector spinae) resists lateral flexion and rotation isometrically.

joint_actions.action: external rotation (transition from internal to external during press)
upward rotation and protraction (scapular movement during overhead press)

notes: Classification assumes single-arm/unilateral kettlebell variant (if performed strict bilateral bilateral dumbbells/kettlebells, ANTI_ROTATION demand is reduced but PUSH remains primary). Variation emphasizes the rotational component at the shoulder; load placement and stance (standing vs seated) alter core demand and stability requirements.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge: the hips extend in the sagittal plane while the knees extend to a lesser degree, driving the load upward from the floor. Posterior chain (gluteus maximus and hamstrings) produce hip extension; erector spinae and intrinsic core maintain a neutral spine isometrically. The upper back (lats/traps) and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to keep the handle close and prevent thoracic flexion—this gives a secondary 'pull' characteristic (scapular control) though there is minimal elbow flexion. Stabilization demands include core bracing, spinal extension control, and scapular/shoulder stabilization under load.
notes: Warm-up emphasis: lighter load, cue hip-hinge and neutral spine. Variations (sumo stance, single-leg RDL) change knee/hip contribution and may alter secondary patterns (increase unilateral ANTI_ROTATION demands). Avoid spinal flexion; focus on loading hips rather than knees.

reasoning: Primary movement is a transverse-plane passing/rotational pattern as the kettlebell is swung in a figure-8 path between the legs, producing spinal rotation and shoulder transverse motion. The hips remain in a slight hinge (sagittal hip flexion/extension) to create space and control the bell; knees are flexed and act as dynamic stabilizers. The core must both produce rotation and resist unwanted rotation/lateral flexion during the pass, so anti-rotational stabilization is significant. Shoulders and elbows control the hand-off and decelerate/accelerate the bell while forearm/grip control the handle.

joint_actions.action: rotation (dynamic) and stabilization (isometric against unwanted rotation)
horizontal adduction/abduction and flexion/extension (hand transfer and control)
flexion/extension (slight hinge to create space and absorb load)

notes: Variations: two-handed figure-8 reduces asymmetric torque (less anti-rotation demand); more ballistic swings increase hip/horizontal momentum and shoulder load. Emphasize neutral spine and hip hinge to protect lumbar spine. If performed with a deep squat posture the pattern shifts toward SQUAT + ROTATION.

reasoning: The kettlebell dead clean is initiated from a hip hinge (deadlift-style) producing powerful hip extension and triple-extension (hip/knee/ankle) in the sagittal plane to generate upward momentum. This is followed by an upper-body pull/receive phase where the arm/shoulder and elbow guide the bell into the rack position (elbow flexion/forearm supination) — a PULL-dominant action. Because the implement is typically held unilaterally, the trunk and obliques produce isometric anti-rotational stabilization to resist spinal rotation and lateral flexion throughout the movement. Primary movers are therefore posterior chain muscles for the hinge and scapulohumeral/forearm muscles for the pull, with strong isometric core activation for anti-rotation.

joint_actions.action: rapid elevation/assistive flexion to receive rack
supination/pronation to rotate bell into rack

notes: Typical kettlebell dead clean is unilateral, so anti-rotation demand is significant; bilateral/alternating variations reduce asymmetry. Key coaching cues: maintain hip hinge, protect lumbar spine with neutral posture, avoid excessive active arm pulling (use hip drive). Risk of wrist impact if timing is poor; emphasize smooth supination into the rack.

reasoning: Primary movement is a bilateral sagittal-plane squat: hip and knee undergo flexion during descent and concentric extension during ascent, with ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion accommodating depth. The kettlebell is held in a front-racked (goblet) position, so the anterior load demands greater upright torso and increased isometric core and spinal extension control but does not introduce primary rotational or carry mechanics. Prime movers are quadriceps and gluteus maximus producing knee and hip extension; hamstrings act as synergists and hip stabilizers; erector spinae and core muscles act isometrically to maintain posture. Shoulders/elbows hold the load isometrically at the chest.
notes: Anterior (goblet) loading promotes a more upright torso and greater core anti-flexion demand compared with back-loaded squats. Asymmetric or single-arm variations would add ANTI_ROTATION; adding a walking component would add CARRY.

reasoning: Primary movement begins with a hip hinge and explosive triple extension (hip/knee/ankle) in the sagittal plane to generate upward momentum (HINGE). This is followed by an upper-body pull/shrug and rapid elbow flexion to pull the bell to the rack position (PULL). When performed single‑arm (common), the asymmetric load produces significant anti‑rotational/isometric core demand to resist lateral flexion and rotation (ANTI_ROTATION). Stabilization also requires spinal/bracing control and scapular stability throughout the pattern.
notes: If performed bilateral (two‑hand or double kettlebell symmetrical), ANTI_ROTATION is reduced and classification can be limited to HINGE + PULL. Movement is ballistic/power oriented; effective technique requires bracing, neutral spine, and scapular control.

reasoning: The primary movement is a hip hinge: the hips flex as the torso pivots forward and then the hips extend to return upright (sagittal plane). Knees remain slightly flexed but relatively static, while the spine is held neutral via isometric spinal extensor activity. Primary movers producing the movement are the gluteus maximus and hamstrings, with the erector spinae and deep core acting to stabilize the spine. Stabilization also requires isometric knee control from the quadriceps and pelvic/core bracing to resist spinal flexion.

joint_actions.action: isometric extension / resist flexion (maintain neutral spine)

notes: Variation in kettlebell position (behind neck, across upper back, or held in front rack) can alter loading and anti-rotation demands. Emphasize neutral spine and hinge at hips; avoid excessive lumbar flexion. Single-arm or offset loading would add ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a single‑leg hip hinge: the hip moves into flexion as the torso drops forward and then into extension to stand, with the stance knee remaining slightly flexed. Because the kettlebell is held unilaterally, the trunk must produce isometric anti‑rotation and lateral stability to prevent torso twist and collapse toward the loaded side. Secondary stabilization includes shoulder/arm isometric loading to hold the kettlebell and ankle/hip musculature for single‑leg balance.

joint_actions.action: resisted axial rotation / isometric trunk stability
isometric load bearing / stabilization of the kettlebell

notes: Commonly performed as a single‑leg RDL variation with a single kettlebell; unilateral load increases anti‑rotation demand and balance requirements. If performed bilaterally or without unilateral load the anti‑rotation component is reduced and classification would be primarily HINGE. Variations (e.g., reaching/kettlebell sweep) can add transverse rotation and would include ROTATION.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: concentric shoulder elevation (shoulder flexion/abduction into overhead) with simultaneous elbow extension in the sagittal/vertical plane. Scapular upward rotation (scapulothoracic motion) is required to allow full overhead range. The seated position minimizes lower‑body drive so the deltoids and triceps are the prime movers while the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control humeral head position. The trunk and hips act isometrically to stabilize the spine; a single‑arm kettlebell press also imposes an anti‑rotational/lateral stabilization demand on the core.
notes: If performed single-arm, add an ANTI_ROTATION requirement due to asymmetric load; seated position reduces leg/hip drive compared with a standing press. Variations (neutral vs pronated grip, single vs double arm) slightly shift muscle emphasis but do not change primary pattern (PUSH).

reasoning: Primary action is a single-arm vertical press: shoulder elevation (flexion/vertical abduction into overhead) with elbow extension in the sagittal plane — this maps to a PUSH pattern (vertical push). Because the load is held asymmetrically and often rocked/shifted across the torso (seesawing), the torso and core must produce isometric anti-rotation torque in the transverse plane to resist spinal rotation and lateral flexion, so ANTI_ROTATION is a required secondary pattern. Stabilization demands include scapular control (upward rotation and protraction), rotator cuff activity to center the humeral head, and lower‑limb/hip isometric extension to provide a stable base.

joint_actions.action: flexion (vertical press / upward movement of humerus)
joint_actions.plane: sagittal (with scapular upward rotation in frontal plane)

notes: Variation: if performed with the bell inverted/gripped by the horns or with both hands shifting, transverse/shoulder horizontal components increase. Ensure anti-rotation/core bracing to prevent unwanted trunk twist; progression/regression can alter degree of asymmetry (two-arm seesaw reduces anti-rotation demand).

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant sagittal hinge: the lifter adopts hip flexion to reach the kettlebell between the legs and then drives hip extension to stand. Knees flex/extend to a lesser degree to accommodate the reach. The hands and shoulders move through the transverse plane to transfer the kettlebell across midline, producing a rotational/transverse component of movement in the upper body; the trunk shows slight rotation and must control rotation during the transfer. Stabilization demands include isometric spinal erector and core activation to maintain a neutral spine and control rotational forces during the hand-to-hand pass. Primary movers are posterior chain (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) for the hinge, with erector spinae and core/obliques stabilizing and deltoids/forearm muscles controlling the hand transfer.
notes: Primary classification is HINGE due to hip-dominant loading; include ROTATION because the kettlebell transfer travels across the midline and involves transverse plane motion of the arms/trunk. Variations (seated pass, wider/narrower stance, heavier load) change stabilization demands; emphasize neutral spine and hip hinge mechanics to avoid excessive lumbar flexion. Asymmetric, single-arm transfers increase anti-rotational core demand even though ROTATION is included as a movement pattern.

reasoning: The kettlebell swing is primarily a sagittal-plane hip-hinge power movement. The movement is driven by explosive hip extension (hip hinge) while the knees stay semi-flexed to allow hip travel; the shoulders and arms act largely as a pendulum/guide rather than primary movers. Primary joint action is rapid hip extension producing posterior chain power; the spine must be held in a neutral/near-extension isometric position for force transmission and to resist flexion. Stabilization demands include isometric trunk control (lumbar extensors and abdominals) and scapular/shoulder stability to control the kettlebell path.
notes: Variations (Russian vs American swing) alter end-range shoulder position but do not change primary hinge pattern. Single-arm or alternating swings add anti-rotation demands and would warrant ANTI_ROTATION as a secondary pattern. Emphasize hip hinge and neutral spine to reduce lumbar flexion risk.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant explosive extension from a wide (sumo) stance that generates upward force (hinge pattern). That drive is transferred into an explosive upper-body pull: scapular elevation/shoulder abduction and elbow flexion to bring the kettlebell to chest/upper-chest height (vertical/high pull). The spine and core act isometrically to transfer force and resist flexion, and the lower limb (quads) assist knee extension during the drive. No systematic rotation or carry pattern is required unless performed single-arm/asymmetrically.
notes: If performed single-arm or asymmetrically, include ANTI_ROTATION for trunk stabilization. Sumo stance increases hip abduction and may reduce knee travel relative to conventional stance; exercise is ballistic/power-oriented rather than a pure strength isolation.

reasoning: Kettlebell swings are a ballistic hip-dominant movement: the primary joint action is powerful hip extension in the sagittal plane produced by the posterior chain. The knees move through a small range (slight flexion to extension) to allow the hip hinge and absorb force, while the shoulders and arms act largely as a passive pendulum to guide the load. The spine must resist flexion (isometric trunk extension/anti-flexion) to transfer force safely. Primary movers are gluteus maximus and hamstrings producing rapid hip extension, with erector spinae and core stabilizers maintaining spinal posture; scapular and shoulder musculature stabilize the kettlebell trajectory without primary concentric shoulder elevation.

joint_actions.action: extension (powerful concentric; also flexion on backswing)
flexion/extension of the glenohumeral joint is minimal/passive (guides bell)
maintains slight flexion/lock; minimal concentric action

notes: Variation notes: two-handed Russian swing is a pure hinge; American (overhead) swings increase shoulder involvement and require greater scapular/shoulder mobility. Single-arm or uneven loading introduces anti-rotation demands. As a Tabata finisher the movement is ballistic and emphasizes power/endurance; maintain neutral spine and hip-dominant mechanics to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.

exercise: Kettlebell Swings (assumed same KB as goblet hold)
reasoning: Kettlebell swings are a ballistic hip-hinge pattern: the primary movement is forceful hip extension in the sagittal plane producing kettlebell momentum. The knees undergo small flexion/extension changes but are not the primary driver. The shoulders and arms act mostly to guide the bell (pendulum) and receive the load at the top; the trunk and posterior chain eccentrically and isometrically control spinal position. Stabilization demands include core brace to prevent lumbar flexion/extension and shoulder/scapular stability to control the kettlebell path.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / resisted flexion (maintain neutral to slight extension)

notes: Two-handed/double-arm swings are primarily HINGE. Single-arm or alternating swings add significant anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demand (consider adding ANTI_ROTATION). Russian swings (chest height) emphasize hip extension; American swings (overhead) add greater shoulder vertical control demands.

reasoning: Kettlebell swings are a ballistic hip-hinge pattern: primary movement is rapid hip extension produced by forceful contraction of the posterior chain while the arms act mainly to guide the load. The hips drive the kettlebell upward from a loaded hip- or slight-flexed position (backswing) into hip extension in the sagittal plane. Knees undergo small flexion–extension adjustments, the spine is held in a neutral/near-extended isometric posture to transfer force, and the shoulders/elbows function largely as pendulum guides and decelerators rather than primary movers. Muscles producing the movement are the gluteus maximus and hamstrings (prime hip extensors), with erector spinae and core providing trunk stability; lats and scapular stabilizers assist in decelerating the bell at the top of the arc.

joint_actions.action: extension (powerful concentric on upswing; flexion on backswing)
small flexion–extension adjustments (lesser contributor than hip)
flexion/extension as the arm guides the bell (primarily passive/pendulum)
near-extension/isometric (acts as hinge/pivot, minimal active flexion)

notes: Classic ballistic hip-hinge / power conditioning exercise. Variations: Russian swings (chest-height) vs American swings (overhead) change shoulder ROM demands; single-arm swings add anti-rotation and unilateral core demand. Emphasize hip drive and neutral spine; avoid excessive lumbar flexion or active shoulder lifting.

reasoning: A thruster combines a loaded squat (hip and knee flexion to extension) immediately followed by a vertical push (shoulder flexion and elbow extension) to drive the load overhead. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: hip/knee/ankle extension to stand from the squat (SQUAT pattern) then shoulder flexion and elbow extension to press the kettlebell overhead (vertical PUSH). Core and scapular musculature act isometrically to stabilize the spine and shoulder girdle during the transition; single-arm variants introduce notable anti-rotation demand but the fundamental mechanics remain squat + vertical push.
notes: If performed single-arm or strictly unilateral rack position, include ANTI_ROTATION due to asymmetric load; double-rack or bilateral kettlebell/dumbbell thrusters emphasize SQUAT + PUSH in the sagittal plane.

reasoning: Kettlebell swings are driven primarily by rapid, repeated hip extension in the sagittal plane (a ballistic hinge). The hip extensors (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) produce the concentric drive; the lumbar extensors (erector spinae, multifidus) and abdominals isometrically stabilize the spine to transfer force. The knees undergo modest sagittal motion (small extension/absorption) while the shoulders and arms act as a passive link to guide the bell (shoulder flexion and scapular control) rather than primary movers. Stabilization demands include anti-flexion of the lumbar spine, scapular/lat control to manage the bell arc, and strong grip.
notes: Variation: Russian swing (to chest/eye level) and American swing (overhead) alter shoulder demand; single-arm swings introduce significant anti-rotation demands and would add ANTI_ROTATION. Emphasis: posterior-chain power and lumbar/core stabilization rather than upper-body pulling.

reasoning: Primary motion is sagittal-plane hip flexion combined with spinal flexion as the torso and legs converge into a 'V'. The hips and lumbar spine produce the bulk of the movement (hip flexors drive leg elevation; rectus abdominis and obliques produce spinal flexion and trunk shortening). Shoulders/arms may perform shoulder flexion/isometric stabilization if the kettlebell is held overhead or in front of the chest. Stabilization demands include isometric control of the lumbar spine during the dynamic flexion/extension cycle and shoulder girdle stability if the load is held in the hands.

joint_actions.action: flexion / isometric stabilization (if kettlebell held overhead or forward)

notes: If the kettlebell is held asymmetrically (single-arm), add ANTI_ROTATION due to asymmetric load. Bent-knee V-ups reduce hamstring/achilles tension and shift emphasis more to rectus abdominis. If performed with strict spinal neutrality and emphasis on hip drive only, interpretation of pattern may vary; here the dominant visible action is sagittal hip/spine flexion (classified under HINGE as primary hip sagittal movement).

reasoning: Kick drills are primarily transverse-plane, rotational lower-limb actions performed dynamically (roundhouse, hook, pivoting front/side kicks) with repeated hip internal/external rotation and transverse rotation through the spine and pelvis. Primary joint actions on the kicking limb are hip flexion/extension and hip internal/external rotation with knee extension (sagittal) to snap or extend the leg; the support limb and trunk perform isometric/isokinetic anti-rotation and frontal-plane stabilization to resist the rotational torque generated by the kicking limb. Thus the dominant movement pattern is ROTATION (dynamic transverse-plane hip/spine rotation) with a strong ANTI_ROTATION demand from core and hip stabilizers to maintain balance and transfer force.
notes: Series variation: individual kicks emphasize different planes (front kick = sagittal hip flexion; roundhouse/hook = transverse rotation; side kick = frontal hip abduction/extension). Single-leg support increases demand on glute medius and contralateral core for anti-rotation and frontal-plane stability. If drills are purely linear front-kick repetitions with no rotation, ROTATION confidence would be lower and sagittal descriptors increased.

reasoning: Kick combinations primarily produce transverse-plane rotation about the hip and spine (e.g., roundhouse, hook-like motion, torque generation for power) and sagittal-plane hip/knee actions for front/back kicks. Primary joint actions: hip internal/external rotation (transverse) and rotation of the trunk/spine to generate angular momentum; hip flexion/extension and knee extension (sagittal) drive the kicking leg. The stance limb and torso provide isometric anti-rotation stabilization to maintain balance and transfer force (single-leg stance requires strong hip abductors and core anti-rotation). Secondary actions include ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion for foot positioning and shoulder/arm actions if punches are included in combos for counterbalance/guarding.
notes: Variation-dependent: a front kick-dominant combo emphasizes hip flexion/knee extension; roundhouse/back-kick-dominant combos emphasize transverse hip rotation and hip extension. Inclusion of punches increases trunk rotation and upper-body anti-rotation demands. Single-leg balance and reactive stability are important; barefoot vs shod and contact/no-contact change neuromuscular demands.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are spinal/trunk flexion and hip flexion in the sagittal plane as the torso and legs are brought together into a V position. The movement is dominated by concentric hip flexion (iliopsoas/rectus femoris) and spinal flexion (rectus abdominis) rather than a vertical push/pull or locomotion pattern. The kettlebell increases anterior load and may require additional shoulder/scapular stabilization if held overhead, but the primary movers remain trunk and hip flexors. Stabilization demands include isometric control of the lumbar spine and co-contraction of the obliques and deep core to maintain alignment and prevent excessive lumbar flexion. Because the exercise is a sagittal-plane, hip- and trunk-dominant core movement and there is no clear dedicated 'trunk flexion' pattern in the provided list, HINGE is used as the closest hip-dominant sagittal pattern.
notes: If the kettlebell is held unilaterally or offset, include ANTI_ROTATION as an additional pattern due to asymmetric load; if the KB is held with both hands centered, the movement remains primarily trunk/hip flexion. Variation with bent knees reduces hamstring/quad demand and isolates rectus abdominis/hip flexors more.

reasoning: Kickboxing primarily consists of repeated trunk axial rotation to generate power (transverse-plane rotation) and upper‑limb striking actions that function biomechanically as pushes (shoulder horizontal adduction/protraction with elbow extension). Secondary components include dynamic footwork (locomotion/shuffle) and single‑leg support during kicks requiring balance and hip stabilization. Primary movers producing rotation are the obliques and erector spinae; punches rely on pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps with scapular protraction from serratus anterior; kicks/footwork recruit hip flexors, gluteus maximus/medials and quadriceps for limb acceleration and stance control. Stabilization demands include rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers for safe striking, gluteus medius and core for single‑leg balance, and transverse abdominis/obliques for force transfer and anti‑extension/anti‑lateral flexion during dynamic rotation.
notes: Exact emphasis varies by technique (jab/cross vs hook/uppercut vs front/roundhouse kick). Some strikes emphasize more transverse rotation (hooks) while others emphasize linear push mechanics (jab). High unilateral/balance demand during kicking increases gluteus medius and core stabilization requirements. Can be classified with greater specificity if the session is primarily punching (ROTATION+PUSH) or primarily footwork/drills (LOCOMOTION+ROTATION).

reasoning: Primary motion is a loaded trunk lateral flexion with controlled rotation of the spine toward the unloaded side while hinging at the hips to lower the torso (spine frontal + transverse, hip sagittal). The working shoulder holds a unilateral overhead load and resists torque, producing strong anti-rotational/isometric demand at the shoulder girdle and core. Hip hinge pattern (posterior chain: glutes/hamstrings) produces the descent and ascent; spinal obliques and erector spinae control lateral flexion and rotation; deltoid/rotator cuff and triceps maintain overhead lock and resist rotational torque.
