notes: High unilateral/anti-rotational demand — requires shoulder stability and thoracic mobility. Common variations: bottoms-up kettlebell windmill (increases shoulder/core stability), lighter load for mobility-focused version. Pay attention to loaded-side shoulder and ipsilateral hip mobility; not a pure hinge like a deadlift but uses hip hinge mechanics combined with trunk rotation/lateral flexion.

reasoning: Heavy-bag kickboxing primarily consists of repeated striking actions: punches are upper-body pushes (shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension) delivered with force transfer through transverse-plane trunk rotation. Kicks are lower-body force-producing movements that use hip rotation and knee extension to strike; they also involve hip flexion/extension and single-leg stability. Primary joint actions are therefore sagittal-plane elbow extension/hip/knee extension for force production and transverse-plane axial rotation of the spine for power transfer. Stabilization requirements include single-leg balance, anti-rotation/isometric core control from the obliques/TA, and scapular stabilization (serratus anterior, rotator cuff) during repeated punches.
notes: Pattern selection depends on emphasis: if session is predominantly punching include stronger PUSH emphasis; if predominantly kicking consider adding lower-body pattern labels. Frequent single-leg work increases anti-rotation/stability demand. Clinch or grappling elements would add PULL/ANTI_ROTATION components.

reasoning: Heavy-bag striking primarily consists of high-velocity pushing actions with the limbs (punches/kicks) combined with powerful axial rotation of the trunk and hips. Primary joint actions for punches are shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension in the transverse and sagittal planes, produced by pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps, with scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, upper/lower traps) controlling scapulothoracic motion. Kicks involve hip flexion/extension, hip axial rotation and knee extension (sagittal and transverse planes), produced by hip flexors, gluteal complex and quadriceps/hamstrings. Throughout, the trunk performs dynamic rotation (transverse plane) and requires isometric anti-rotational control from the obliques and deep core to transfer force and protect the spine. Footwork/weight shift involves ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion and hip/knee action for push-off and retraction. Therefore the movement patterns are primarily PUSH (limb-driven strikes) and ROTATION (axial/trunk and hip rotation driving and sequencing strikes).
notes: Variation-dependent: sessions emphasizing punching/power will bias upper-body PUSH and trunk ROTATION; kick-heavy sessions increase lower-limb power and hip rotation demands. Although ROTATION is included as an active movement pattern, significant anti-rotation/isometric core stabilization is also required for force transfer and injury prevention.

reasoning: Kickboxing combines repeated transverse-plane trunk and hip rotation (rotational punches and kicks) with repeated horizontal pushing actions (punches: shoulder horizontal flexion and elbow extension) and continuous footwork/stepping (locomotion). Primary joint actions are thoracic/spinal rotation and hip rotation generating torque, shoulder horizontal flexion and elbow extension producing the punch, and alternating hip/knee/ankle flexion–extension for stepping and kicking. The core (obliques, transverse abdominis) and hip musculature act both as prime movers for rotation and as stabilizers to control rotational transfer; lower-limb muscles produce and control locomotion and single-leg stability during striking.

joint_actions.action: horizontal flexion (protraction) and transverse-plane rotation during punches

notes: Wrist weights increase rotational and distal limb load (higher demand on shoulder/elbow and trunk stabilizers). exercise: Kickboxing (warm-up) w/ 1.5lb wrist weights + MMA gloves

Footwork and shifting weight/stepping during combos produce repeated gait-like movements (LOCOMOTION). Joints moving primarily: thorax/pelvis axial rotation in transverse plane (obliques/erector spinae drive and transfer force), shoulder horizontal flexion/adduction and protraction with elbow extension for punches (anterior deltoid, pec major, triceps), and hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension for stepping and kicks (glutes, hip flexors, quads, hamstrings, calves). Stabilization demands include anti-rotational/isometric core control to transfer force between lower and upper body, scapular stabilization by serratus anterior and rotator cuff, and single-leg balance/stability during stepping or kicking.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension and transverse rotation (for kicks/weight transfer)

notes: Light wrist weights increase rotational and inertial demand on shoulders and trunk but do not materially change primary patterns. MMA gloves alter hand position and potential range of motion. If session emphasizes stationary shadowboxing without stepping, LOCOMOTION weight should be reduced or omitted.

reasoning: Kickboxing warm-ups consist primarily of repeated transverse-plane trunk and hip rotation (punches, hooks, roundhouse / turning kicks) and horizontal pushing actions (jabs/crosses: shoulder horizontal flexion with elbow extension). Footwork/stepping and weight shifts (forward/backward/side-to-side) are also integral, so locomotion is a secondary pattern. Primary joint actions are axial rotation of the spine and transverse hip rotation, shoulder horizontal flexion and elbow extension for strikes, and sagittal/frontal plane hip/knee/ankle actions for stepping and kicking. Core (obliques, transverse abdominis) and hip stabilizers work both concentrically for rotation and isometrically to control trunk alignment; lower-limb muscles produce stepping/kick force and stabilize single-leg support.

reasoning: Warmup kickboxing combines repeated axial trunk rotation (torque generation for punches and rotational elements of kicks) with continuous footwork/stepping (locomotion) and repeated horizontal pushing actions (punching). Primary joint actions are spinal axial rotation in the transverse plane, hip flexion/extension and transverse hip rotation for kicks and pivots (sagittal + transverse), and shoulder horizontal flexion/shoulder protraction with elbow extension for punches (transverse and sagittal). Stabilization demands include single-leg balance during kicking, dynamic postural control through the hips and ankles during footwork, and anti-rotational/isometric core control to transfer force between lower and upper body.
notes: Warmup drills vary widely; emphasis shifts classification (e.g., a drill focused only on punches could be ROTATION+PUSH, while footwork-heavy drills are LOCOMOTION+ROTATION). Single-leg kicking increases anti-rotation and balance demands; added implements or partner drills could introduce additional patterns.

reasoning: Kicking drills are primarily transverse-plane power/technical actions driven by rapid hip rotation and limb trajectory (ROTATION) while the stance leg and core resist unwanted rotation and maintain balance (ANTI_ROTATION). Primary joint actions on the kicking limb include hip rotation (internal/external depending on kick), hip flexion/extension and often hip abduction (for roundhouse/side kicks), plus knee extension and ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion in the sagittal plane. The supporting limb/torso produce isometric anti-rotation and frontal/sagittal stability via hip abductors, obliques and erector spinae. Therefore the dominant pattern is rotational power with strong anti-rotational stabilization demands.

joint_actions.action: extension (power delivery) and rapid deceleration eccentrically
rotation and extension (torso twist and posture)

reasoning: This is primarily a transverse-plane rotational stretch where the femur and pelvis/trunk are guided across the midline. The primary joint actions are hip adduction with internal rotation and axial rotation of the lumbar spine (transverse plane); the knee is typically held in flexion (sagittal) to assist the maneuver. Muscles that would actively produce the movement (if performed actively) are hip internal rotators/adductors (TFL, anterior gluteus medius/minimus, adductor group) and trunk rotators (internal/external obliques, multifidus). The stretch primarily lengthens the hip external rotators (piriformis, deep external rotators) and gluteus maximus. Stabilization requirements include maintaining pelvis contact with the floor (contralateral hip abductors and core isometrically stabilize) and keeping the contralateral shoulder/upper back down to allow true lumbar rotation rather than compensatory posterior pelvic tilt.
notes: Commonly performed supine as a spinal/hip mobility stretch. Cue to keep shoulders glued to the floor and avoid forcing the knee past comfort to protect the lumbar spine. Variations: performed with bent knee or extended leg to change emphasis on hip vs. lumbar rotation.

reasoning: Primary action is explosive triple-extension (hip, knee, ankle) in the sagittal plane to produce vertical propulsion (characteristic of SQUAT pattern). Immediately after takeoff the athlete actively flexes the hips and knees to pull the knees toward the chest (tuck) while airborne; the movement is a plyometric vertical locomotor task, so LOCOMOTION is included. Muscles produce concentric extension for takeoff and eccentric control on landing; core and lower-limb stabilizers control orientation and absorb impact.
notes: Plyometric vertical jump with an added hip/knee flexion phase (tuck). Requires strong eccentric control on landing and core stabilization to prevent excessive trunk flexion or knee valgus. Variations: arm swing increases propulsion, single-leg or added load changes pattern emphasis; monitor landing mechanics.

reasoning: Knee circles are primarily a hip circumduction / rotation mobility exercise performed with the knee flexed. The primary joint motion occurs at the hip in the transverse plane (internal/external rotation) with accompanying frontal-plane abduction/adduction as the thigh describes a circular path; the knee remains flexed and relatively static as a hinge. The lumbopelvic region and core act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and prevent unwanted lumbar rotation or extension. Because the movement is essentially rotational/multi‑planar at the hip rather than a push/pull, carry, hinge or squat pattern, it is classified as ROTATION.
notes: Commonly performed supine with knees bent (feet on floor) or standing with hands on hips. If performed with the femur fixed and only tibial rotation, classification may shift toward a knee joint rotation mobility focus. Avoid aggressive rotations with knee pain; progress by increasing circle diameter or loading limb. Variations: single-leg knee circles (greater hip demand), small vs large circles (range of motion focus).

reasoning: The kipping muscle-up is a compound, ballistic movement that combines an initial pull phase with a transition and a final push (dip). Primary joint actions: a dynamic hip swing (rapid sagittal-plane hip flexion followed by explosive hip extension) generates upward/forward momentum (HINGE-like hip action facilitating the kip). The upper limb then performs a powerful pull (elbow flexion with scapular retraction/upward rotation) to bring the chest toward the bar/rings (PULL), followed by a transition into a top position and a pressing/dip action (shoulder horizontal adduction/extension and elbow extension) to lock out above the bar (PUSH). The core and scapular muscles provide substantial stabilization and force transfer during the kip-to-transition. Sequence and primary movers prioritize pull and push actions, with the hip drive serving as a primary momentum generator (hence inclusion of HINGE as a supportive pattern).

joint_actions.action: rapid flexion then explosive extension (hip drive)
combined pull-phase shoulder extension/vertical adduction into transition with shoulder flexion and horizontal adduction at top
flexion during pull phase then rapid extension during push/dip
dynamic sagittal flexion/extension with isometric stabilization (force transfer and body alignment)

notes: Variations: strict (no kip) muscle-up emphasizes PULL + PUSH with less hip contribution and would be classified primarily as PULL + PUSH. Rings increase transverse-plane instability and require greater anti-rotation/shoulder stabilization compared to a rigid bar. The kipping variant uses hip drive to reduce required pure upper-body strength and to generate momentum for the pull-to-transition.

exercise: Kneeling Cable Crunch With Alternating Oblique Twists
reasoning: Primary movement is trunk flexion combined with alternating trunk rotation. The spine undergoes sagittal plane flexion (crunch) driven by the rectus abdominis, and repeated transverse plane rotation to each side driven by the external and internal obliques. Hips and knees remain in a fixed kneeling position providing a stable base; shoulders/elbows typically hold the cable isometrically. Stabilization demands include isometric pelvic/hip stabilization and anti-extension control from the deep abdominals (transverse abdominis) and eccentric control by the posterior chain (erector spinae) during the return phase. Because the exercise purposefully produces active rotation of the trunk, it is categorized as ROTATION.
notes: Variation in cable line of pull or hand placement can alter emphasis between more pure trunk flexion vs. rotation. If an asymmetric load or unilateral hold is used (e.g., single-handle anchored to one side), anti-rotation demands increase and ANTI_ROTATION could be added to the classification.

reasoning: Primary visible movement is cyclical shoulder flexion (forward arm drive) and shoulder extension (rearward swing) performed from a kneeling base. The primary joint action used to produce the drill is shoulder flexion in the sagittal plane (a push-like action) with the posterior shoulder/upper back controlling the return. Because the lower body is fixed in a kneeling position, the torso and core must resist rotary forces generated by alternating arm swings, producing an anti-rotation/isometric stabilization demand in the transverse plane. Scapular protraction/retraction and rotator-cuff activity are required for shoulder control. Hips and knees remain in sustained flexion as stabilizers.
notes: If the drill is performed explosively with an emphasis on forward arm punch, PUSH is appropriate as the primary pattern. If performed with resisted band pull-back or objective to emphasize the rearward pull, consider adding PULL. Single-kneel or asymmetric arm loading increases transverse-plane torque and raises anti-rotation demand. Variations with added load or unilateral emphasis may change classification to include PULL or greater anti-rotation weighting.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow extension in the sagittal plane driven by the triceps brachii (with anconeus assisting). The shoulder complex and rotator cuff act isometrically to stabilize the humerus and scapula against the cable load; the trunk, hips and knees (kneeling) provide postural/isometric stability. This is primarily an elbow-extension (push-type) movement rather than a hip/knee dominant pattern, so it classifies as a PUSH movement.
notes: Cable attachment height and hand position (rope vs straight bar, single- vs double-arm) can alter shoulder moment and stabilization demands; single-arm variations introduce lateral/rotational torque that may add ANTI_ROTATION demands. This classification treats the common bilateral kneeling cable triceps extension (isolation elbow extension) as a PUSH pattern.

reasoning: Primary joint actions occur at the shoulder and elbow in the transverse/sagittal planes: humeral horizontal abduction toward the posterior and external rotation of the humerus with elbow flexion to bring the hands to the face. The movement is driven by scapular retraction (adduction) and posterior shoulder musculature, so it classifies as a horizontal/upper-body pull. Kneeling creates an isometric demand at the hips, knees and trunk for stabilization but these are secondary. Stabilization requires scapular control and core/bracing to maintain torso alignment while the shoulder complex produces the pulling and external rotation.
notes: Common cues: emphasize scapular retraction and external rotation (lead with elbows and pull shoulder blades together). Kneeling reduces lower-body contribution and increases trunk stability demand. Use moderate loading and good technique for shoulder rehab/health focus.

reasoning: Primary movement is active sagittal-plane hip flexion (bringing thighs/hips toward torso) with concomitant spinal flexion or pelvic tilt by the rectus abdominis. If performed with bent knees the knee joint undergoes sagittal-plane flexion as well. The hips and trunk perform the concentric work (iliopsoas/rectus femoris and rectus abdominis/obliques). The shoulders and elbows act isometrically to support the body on the bars (scapular and shoulder stabilization, elbow extension maintained by triceps). Classified as a PULL pattern here because the dominant mechanical action is pulling the lower limb/trunk segments toward each other against gravity (analogous to a pulling action of the limbs), with core flexion producing the visible movement.
primary_muscles: external oblique (assistive, especially for higher raises and stabilization)

notes: Variation notes: straight-leg raises emphasize hip flexors and increase lumbar demand; bent-knee raises emphasize rectus abdominis and reduce hip flexor moment. Twisting knee/hip raises add transverse-plane loading and engage obliques (would add ROTATION). If performed hanging from a bar (versus captain's chair), grip and shoulder/scapular stability demands increase.

reasoning: This is a static mobility/stretching position that places the shoulder into end-range extension in the sagittal plane while the forearm/wrist may be dorsiflexed depending on hand position. Primary joint action is shoulder extension (humeral posterior displacement) with the thoracic spine often moving into slight extension. The position lengthens anterior shoulder/arm tissues (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, biceps) while posterior shoulder musculature (posterior deltoid, lats) and scapular retractors provide isometric control. Knees and hips are in a flexed, loaded kneeling position and act as a stable base; core and thoracic musculature isometrically stabilize the trunk to control the end-range shoulder position.
notes: This is primarily a static mobility/stretch rather than a dynamic movement pattern. Variations (hands/forearm orientation, degree of thoracic extension) change local joint demands. Consider labeling as a mobility/stretch task rather than a primary training movement pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is thoracic spine rotation in the transverse plane as the practicing arm threads under the body. The shoulder complex performs transverse-plane movement (reaching/threading) with scapular protraction/retraction and rotator cuff control. Hips and knees remain in a stable, loaded kneeling position and function isometrically to maintain pelvic position. Stabilization demands include anti-extension/anti-flexion from the lumbar stabilizers and isometric hip/gluteal control to prevent pelvic rotation so the rotation is localized to the thoracic spine.

joint_actions.action: transverse-plane reach/horizontal movement with rotation (protraction/retraction of scapula)

notes: Primarily a thoracic rotation/mobility exercise used in cool-downs. Cue rotation from the thoracic spine rather than lumbar. Variations: quadruped thread-the-needle (similar mechanics), add breath/hold for end-range mobility. Avoid forcing rotation through low back if limited mobility.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal/transverse-plane pull: scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction) combined with shoulder horizontal abduction and external rotation as the hands are drawn toward the face. Elbow flexion occurs as a secondary action. Because the athlete is kneeling, lower-body joints are largely isometric and the trunk must isometrically stabilize to maintain upright posture. The prime movers are therefore scapular retractors (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids), posterior deltoid and the external rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor) with assisting elbow flexors. Rotator cuff muscles also act eccentrically/isometrically to stabilize the glenohumeral joint throughout the motion.
notes: Variations in rope height and elbow position shift emphasis between posterior deltoid (high-elbow/outer pull) and external rotators (wide, externally rotated finish). Kneeling reduces lower‑body contribution and increases trunk demand for stability. Emphasize controlled external rotation to protect the shoulder and target rotator cuff.

reasoning: This is a split-stance/kneeling lunge variation performed mostly as a static stretch. The primary joint action is sagittal-plane hip extension of the rear (kneeling) limb, with the front limb in hip flexion and both knees held in flexion. The movement pattern aligns with a unilateral lunge/split-stance pattern where one hip is driven into extension while the other is in flexion. Stabilization demands include isometric control of the pelvis and spine by the core and gluteal/hip musculature to maintain an upright torso and pelvic alignment during the stretch.

notes: Typically performed as a static stretch rather than a concentric movement. Variations (upright torso, posterior pelvic tilt, elevated rear foot) change stretch emphasis (more psoas vs. rectus femoris). Ensure pelvic alignment to avoid compensatory lumbar extension.

reasoning: This is a half-kneeling/low-lunge positional exercise. The primary joint action is sagittal-plane hip extension of the rear (kneeling) limb and sagittal-plane hip flexion of the front limb as the pelvis shifts forward to lengthen the anterior hip tissues. Knees are held in flexion (rear knee on ground, front knee ~90°) as passive positions. The movement/purpose is primarily a static lunge position used to stretch the hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris); if performed actively (pelvic drive or glute squeeze) the gluteus maximus and hamstrings produce the hip extension. Core and pelvic stabilizers (glute medius, pelvic floor, abdominals) isometrically stabilize the pelvis and lumbar spine to control anterior pelvic tilt and avoid lumbar extension.

reasoning: This is primarily a flexibility/mobility/cooldown movement rather than a load-bearing functional pattern. The primary joint actions are hip flexion and knee flexion with concomitant lumbar spine flexion/posterior pelvic tilt in the sagittal plane as the knees are brought toward the torso. Movement is typically performed passively or with assistance of the hands; when performed actively the hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) produce hip flexion and the hamstrings produce knee flexion, while the rectus abdominis and other anterior core muscles produce spinal flexion and pelvic posterior tilt. Stabilization requirements are low-to-moderate: the shoulders/scapulae and arms provide a stabilizing/holding role if the hands assist the knees, and the deep core stabilizers (transverse abdominis, multifidus) isometrically control the pelvis and protect the lumbar spine during the motion.
notes: Primarily a mobility/cooldown stretch; not well represented by the standard locomotive/strength movement pattern categories. Variations: unilateral single-knee-to-chest, double-knee-to-chest, or active (no hands) versus assisted (hands pulling knees). Avoid aggressive lumbar rounding in cases of acute low-back pain unless prescribed.

reasoning: Primary action is a unilateral/offset press of the bar from chest/shoulder region (shoulder + elbow producing a pressing action) while the trunk performs an isometric anti-rotation effort to resist the rotational moment created by the landmine load. The shoulder and elbow produce concentric pressing (diagonal/oblique pressing pattern between sagittal and transverse planes); the core (internal/external obliques, TVA, rectus abdominis) and contralateral lat/hip complex act isometrically to prevent transverse-plane rotation and maintain torso alignment. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower/upper traps) control scapulothoracic motion during the press.

notes: Variation: performed single-arm (stronger anti-rotation demand) or two-handed (lower rotation torque). Bar path is typically diagonal/oblique with landmine anchor; foot stance (narrow/wide, split stance) changes lower-body stabilization demand. Progressions: heavier load, longer lever arm from body increases anti-rotation demand; regressions: two-handed or reduced lever arm.

reasoning: Primary action is thoracic/spinal axial rotation in the transverse plane as the lifter drives the bar in an arc from hip/side across the body. The shoulders produce shoulder flexion and horizontal movement to guide the arc (sagittal + transverse planes). Lower limbs and core provide isometric stabilization (anti-extension/anti-lateral-flexion) to transfer force through the torso. Primary movers producing the rotation are the obliques and contra/ipsilateral internal/external rotators of the trunk; shoulder musculature (anterior deltoid, pec major) actively moves the bar while scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, traps) control the shoulder. Glutes and hip abductors/adductors act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and single-leg weight shifts.
notes: Two-handed landmine 180s are primarily rotational. Single-arm or step variations increase anti-rotation demand and unilateral shear on the pelvis. If finished overhead or pressed, add PUSH. Cue thoracic rotation over lumbar rotation and braced core for spinal safety.

reasoning: Primary action is an overhead/diagonal press: shoulder flexion (bringing the bar upward along an arc) with elbow extension to lockout. When performed single-arm or offset (typical landmine/Viking variations) the trunk must resist the bar's rotational torque, producing transverse-plane anti-rotation demand. Lower-body joints (hip/knee/ankle) act isometrically to provide a stable base; scapular upward rotation and protraction are required for full shoulder elevation and stability.
notes: If performed bilateral/two-handed with symmetrical load, anti-rotation demand is minimal and classification can be only PUSH. Variations (kneeling, seated, single-arm, double-arm) alter core and lower-limb stabilization demands; bar path is diagonal between sagittal and frontal planes.

reasoning: Primary action is an upper-body press pattern: shoulder elevation/flexion with elbow extension to drive the landmine bar upward (sagittal-plane push). The movement is commonly performed with leg drive — rapid hip and knee extension (triple extension) — transferring force from the lower body into the press, so hip-dominant extension (hinge-like) is a meaningful contributor. Because the implement is offset (single-arm or unilateral load path), the torso/obliques work isometrically to resist rotation and lateral flexion (anti-rotation in the transverse/frontal planes). Stabilization demands include scapular control, core anti-rotation, and lower-body stabilization during single-leg or staggered stance drive.
notes: Classification assumes a unilateral/simple landmine linear jammer using leg drive. If performed strict seated/standing without leg drive, HINGE contribution is reduced and classification would be primarily PUSH with ANTI_ROTATION. Bilateral two‑hand jammers reduce anti-rotation demand.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal/sagittal-plane pull: elbow flexion and shoulder extension (humeral posterior translation) producing a rowing motion — this is a PULL pattern. The torso is held in a hip-hinged, forward‑leaning position (isometric hip flexion with neutral spine) to create the pulling angle; the hips act as a stable hinge which recruits posterior chain isometrically and provides the leverage for the row — this is a secondary HINGE component. Prime movers are lats, rhomboids/middle traps and biceps producing shoulder extension/scapular retraction and elbow flexion. Stabilization demands include erector spinae and core to maintain a neutral trunk, and glutes/hamstrings to hold the hinged hip angle. If performed single‑arm or with asymmetric loading, significant anti‑rotation demand would be added, but narrow two‑hand grip typically remains symmetric.

joint_actions.action: isometric hip flexion (held in hinged position); posterior chain stabilization

notes: Narrow two‑hand grip landmine row is primarily a horizontal pull with an isometric hip hinge. If performed single‑arm or with the feet staggered, include ANTI_ROTATION due to asymmetric load. Technique variations (torso more vertical vs more hinged) change HINGE contribution.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal pulling/scapular retraction pattern. The working limb(s) drive elbow flexion and shoulder horizontal extension/abduction while the scapulae retract and depress to bring the load toward the torso. The torso is typically held in a hinged, braced position so the hips and spine act isometrically to stabilize and transfer force. Therefore the primary movement pattern is PULL (horizontal row).
notes: Chest-supported variations reduce spinal/hip stabilization demand. Single-arm or offset grips introduce anti-rotation demands and would add ANTI_ROTATION to the classification. Grip width and torso angle alter emphasis between lats, traps, and posterior deltoids.

exercise: Landmine Row (Narrow Grip, 45 lb plate + bar)
reasoning: Primary joint actions are elbow flexion and scapular retraction (pulling the bar toward the torso) with the shoulders moving in a horizontal/transverse plane and the elbows moving in the sagittal plane. The lifter typically adopts a hip-hinged torso position to brace and create a stable pulling platform, so the hip hinge is a secondary, stabilizing/positional pattern. Primary movers producing the pull are the latissimus dorsi, middle trapezius, rhomboids, posterior deltoid and elbow flexors (biceps, brachialis); the erector spinae, glutes and hamstrings act isometrically to maintain the hinged trunk position and resist spinal flexion. Scapular retraction and thoracic stabilization are important for efficient force transfer and to limit unwanted rotation or flexion.
notes: Classified as PULL (primary) with HINGE as a secondary/postural pattern. Narrow grip emphasizes elbow flexors and lats; if performed single-arm or offset it would add an ANTI_ROTATION demand. Trunk bracing and scapular control are important to avoid lumbar flexion and to maintain appropriate bar path.

reasoning: Primary movement is a unilateral horizontal/diagonal row (PULL): elbow flexion with scapular retraction and humeral posterior movement drive the load toward the torso. Because the load is single‑arm and placed away from the midline, the torso and core must resist rotation and lateral flexion (ANTI_ROTATION) throughout the pull. The exercise is typically performed from a bent‑over/trunk‑inclined position requiring a hip hinge to set the torso angle and transfer force (HINGE) — the hips and posterior chain act isometrically/dynamically to maintain trunk position. Stabilization demands include isometric spinal control (erector spinae, obliques) to resist rotation and maintain a neutral spine, and lower limb bracing to provide a stable base.

joint_actions.action: humeral extension / scapular retraction (pulling the arm posteriorly toward the torso)
joint_actions.plane: transverse (diagonal component depending on torso angle)

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / anti‑rotation (resist axial rotation and lateral flexion)
hip hinge (flexion position with posterior chain bracing; may have small ROM)

notes: If performed chest‑supported the HINGE and spinal stabilization demand are reduced (confidence in HINGE decreases). Two‑hand T‑row or neutral/bilateral variations reduce anti‑rotation demand. Cue: maintain neutral spine, drive scapular retraction, and control rotation on the contralateral obliques.

reasoning: Primary action is a unilateral horizontal/vertical pulling movement: elbow flexion with shoulder extension and scapular retraction to draw the bar toward the torso (primary PULL pattern). Because the load is single‑arm and offset from the midline, the trunk must resist rotational and lateral collapse, creating significant anti‑rotation/isometric core demand (ANTI_ROTATION). The lifter frequently adopts a slight hip hinge to set torso angle, which is primarily a stabilization role rather than the primary mover. Primary movers (lats, posterior deltoid, rhomboids, traps, biceps) drive the pull while core/obliques and contralateral stabilizers resist rotation and maintain posture.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction/abduction component (transverse) depending on pull path
resists rotation (anti-rotation) and lateral flexion isometrically
slight hinge / isometric stabilization of torso angle

notes: Unilateral, offset load drives anti‑rotation demand. If performed with chest support or with two hands, anti‑rotation is reduced and classification may be simply PULL. Gripping orientation and body angle change the emphasis between lats, posterior deltoid, and scapular retractors.

reasoning: Lateral bound is a lateral/mediolateral plyometric hop: the primary action is an explosive push-off on one limb to travel laterally and a single-leg landing on the opposite limb. Primary joint actions are hip abduction and hip/knee/ankle extension (takeoff) in frontal and sagittal planes; landing requires eccentric hip/knee flexion and frontal-plane control. Movement is best classified as LOCOMOTION because the goal is mediolateral displacement (a lateral gait-like, single-leg push-and-landing). Stabilization demands include single-leg balance, frontal-plane hip control (glute medius), and core anti-rotation to control trunk alignment during flight and landing.
notes: Primary emphasis is mediolateral power and single-leg landing mechanics. Progress from low lateral hops to maximal bounds; monitor knee valgus on landing and ensure adequate progressive plyometric preparation. Variations include single-leg lateral hop, lateral bound to box, or adding distance/time constraints.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical/diagonal press: shoulder elevation (predominantly shoulder flexion with an arc/diagonal trajectory) and elbow extension produce the upward force on the landmine (PUSH). When performed single‑arm or with an offset load the torso experiences a rotational moment from the eccentric bar path, requiring isometric anti‑rotation from the core and obliques to resist trunk rotation and lateral flexion (ANTI_ROTATION). Secondary scapulothoracic upward rotation (serratus anterior/traps) and rotator cuff stabilization are required to control the shoulder during the press. Hips/legs typically act isometrically to provide a stable base.

joint_actions.action: anti-rotation (isometric) and slight extension for posture

notes: Bilateral/centered Viking press reduces rotational demand and is primarily a vertical/diagonal PUSH. Single-arm or staggered-foot variations increase transverse‑plane torque and demand greater ANTI_ROTATION from obliques and contralateral lats. Thoracic mobility and scapular upward rotation capacity influence movement path.

reasoning: The lateral box jump is a plyometric locomotor task executed with explosive triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to generate vertical and horizontal/lateral displacement, matching LOCOMOTION. The primary force production is sagittal-plane extension (a squat-like pattern) so SQUAT is also appropriate. At takeoff the hips and knees rapidly extend and the ankles plantarflex; because displacement is lateral there is meaningful frontal-plane hip abduction/adduction control during push-off and especially during landing. The trunk/core acts isometrically to stabilize the spine and control rotation and frontal-plane tilt during flight and landing. Primary movers (glute max, quads, calves) produce propulsion; glute medius and adductors contribute to frontal-plane control and single-leg stabilization on landing.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (resist flexion/rotation and frontal tilt)

notes: Variations (single-leg vs bilateral, height, lateral distance) change unilateral loading and increase frontal-plane/anti-rotation demands. Emphasize eccentric control on landing; poor frontal-plane control increases risk of knee valgus and ankle sprain.

reasoning: Lateral cone hops are a plyometric lateral locomotion task: the primary goal is lateral displacement (LOCOMOTION) achieved via repeated explosive triple-extension for propulsion and eccentric absorption on landing (movement mechanics analogous to a short, single- or double-leg squat/jump, hence SQUAT). Primary joint actions during take-off are hip and knee extension and ankle plantarflexion (sagittal plane) producing vertical/horizontal force, combined with frontal-plane hip abduction/adduction to move laterally. Landings require eccentric hip/knee flexion and ankle dorsiflexion control. Hip abductors/adductors and core musculature provide frontal plane control and single-leg stabilization, while quadriceps, gluteus maximus and triceps surae produce the propulsive extension.
notes: Single-leg vs double-leg hops change stabilization demands (single-leg increases frontal-plane and rotational stabilization). Emphasize soft, controlled landings to reduce valgus/ankle inversion risk. Progression: reduce cone distance for quickness, increase distance for power. Not primarily rotational, so ANTI_ROTATION/ROTATION not included unless performed with added torso/arm perturbation.

reasoning: This is a myofascial release / stretching technique that primarily places the latissimus dorsi and associated shoulder girdle tissues on stretch. The primary joint action is shoulder flexion (arm overhead) in the sagittal plane which lengthens the lat (lat functions concentrically as a shoulder extensor/adductor during pulling). There is commonly concomitant thoracic spine lateral flexion/extension (frontal/sagittal) as the torso is leaned away or rotated while rolling. Because the exercise passively lengthens the posterior-lateral shoulder and back rather than producing a concentric push, it aligns with the shoulder girdle/pulling functional domain (the lat is a primary pulling muscle). Stabilization is primarily isometric from the contralateral trunk, scapular stabilizers and core to control torso position during the roll/stretch.
notes: SMR is primarily a mobility/stretch technique (not concentric loading). Variations (standing lat stretch, foam-roll with arm overhead, or band-assisted lat mobilizations) may include small amounts of scapular upward rotation/protraction or trunk rotation; avoid aggressive pressure with acute shoulder or rib pain.

reasoning: Leg extensions are an open-chain, single-joint knee extension performed in the sagittal plane. The primary joint action is knee extension produced by the quadriceps. The hip remains relatively static (isometric stabilization) and there is minimal requirement for axial loading or multi-joint coordination that characterizes a full squat pattern. Because the movement isolates the knee-extensor component of a closed-chain squat, it is mapped to the SQUAT movement pattern with reduced confidence.
notes: Machine or seated leg extensions isolate knee extension; lacks hip extension and axial loading of a true SQUAT. Useful for targeted quadriceps strengthening but consider limited transfer to multi-joint squat performance. Single-leg variations increase stabilization demands; knee pathology considerations apply.

reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder abduction in the frontal plane against band resistance — the arm is moved away from the midline (an outward 'push' of the limb). The primary joint action is glenohumeral abduction driven concentrically by the middle deltoid with assistance from supraspinatus. The elbow is held in slight flexion/isometric to maintain lever length; the scapular stabilizers (upper trapezius, serratus anterior, lower trapezius) control scapular upward rotation and position. When performed unilaterally, the core must isometrically resist lateral flexion and rotation (anti-rotation demand) but this is a secondary stabilization requirement rather than the primary movement pattern.
notes: Typically an accessory shoulder (abduction) exercise. If performed strictly unilateral with heavy asymmetry, include ANTI_ROTATION as an additional pattern. Hand/forearm rotation (thumb up vs down) and band anchor height change loading profile and impingement risk.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane as the platform is pushed away. Movement mechanics mirror a squat pattern (lowering and rising through hip and knee flexion/extension) with the feet fixed on a platform. Primary movers are quadriceps producing knee extension and gluteus maximus/hamstrings contributing to hip extension; ankle plantarflexors may contribute secondarily. Stabilization requirements are lower than a free-barbell squat because the machine/platform supports the torso and reduces demand on spinal/trunk stabilizers, though the hips, knees and ankles must control the platform path and resist shear/compressive forces. Foot placement and seat angle can shift emphasis (higher foot placement increases hip/glute demand, lower foot placement biases quadriceps).
notes: Machine leg press reduces trunk anti-flexion/anti-rotation demand compared with free-weight squats. Single-leg or high-foot placements can increase hip-dominant (hinge-like) recruitment; near-full-range knee flexion can increase patellofemoral stress in susceptible individuals.

reasoning: Interpreting 'Leg Lift' as a supine/hanging/lying leg raise (single- or double-leg raise) — the primary joint action is hip flexion in the sagittal plane as the femur is brought toward the torso. This movement is mechanically similar to the hip-flexion phase of marching/gait (locomotion). The hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris, sartorius, TFL) concentically produce the lift while the anterior abdominal musculature (rectus abdominis, obliques) and hip extensors act isometrically/eccentrically to stabilize the pelvis and prevent excessive lumbar extension. The lumbar spine must be stabilized (anti-extension) through the core to control pelvic tilt and protect the low back. If performed with straight legs the knee remains in near-full extension (quads provide passive tension); if knees are bent, the rectus femoris contribution is reduced.

joint_actions.action: extension (if legs kept straight; otherwise flexion when bent)

notes: The term 'Leg Lift' is ambiguous. Classification above assumes a supine or hanging leg raise (hip flexion). If the exercise meant a side-lying leg lift (hip abduction, frontal plane) the primary pattern would be different (hip abduction) and LOCOMOTION would not apply. If meant prone leg lifts (hip extension) the pattern would be closer to HINGE/hip extension. Adjust classification based on the specific variation.

reasoning: Leg Pull-In primarily produces hip flexion and spinal flexion in the sagittal plane as the knees/legs are drawn toward the torso. The primary mover action is pulling the lower limb toward the trunk (hip flexors) with concomitant anterior pelvic tilt/spinal flexion driven by the rectus abdominis. Secondary actions include knee flexion when performed with bent knees and isometric stabilization of the lumbopelvic complex and hips to control movement.
notes: Terminology/technique varies: 'leg pull-in' can be performed on a captain's chair, supine on a bench/ball, or hanging. Relative contribution of spinal flexion vs hip flexion depends on leg straightness and pelvis motion. If performed as a hanging straight-leg raise with emphasis on lumbar flexion and anti-extension, consider adding a core/anti-extension classification in context-specific protocols.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal pressing pattern performed from the floor (shoulder horizontal adduction with elbow extension) — therefore a PUSH (horizontal). Concurrently, the "leg-over" component drives hip/spine rotation as the lower limb is brought across the midline, so the movement includes active transverse-plane rotation of the trunk/hip (ROTATION). The press is produced by pecs/delts/triceps; the leg-over creates rotary torque that is produced/controlled by the obliques, deep rotators and hip flexors/adductors. The shoulders and scapulae must stabilize the load against the floor while the core resists unwanted extension and coordinates rotation. Scapular stabilizers and lumbar stabilizers act isometrically while the obliques and transverse abdominis modulate the rotary movement.
notes: Assumes a supine floor press with a single-leg crossing/leg-over motion creating transverse rotation. If the leg movement is performed isometrically to resist rotation (rather than actively rotating the trunk), consider adding ANTI_ROTATION. If bilateral symmetrical leg movement and no trunk rotation occur, omit ROTATION and classify solely as PUSH.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip flexion of the raised limb and knee extension (if the leg is kept straight). The movement is dominated by hip/knee sagittal motion rather than frontal or transverse actions, so it maps best to the hip-dominant (HINGE) pattern even though it is a mobility/stretch exercise rather than a loaded strength movement. The hamstrings are being lengthened (stretched) while hip flexors and knee extensors produce/hold the limb position. Stabilization of the pelvis and lumbar spine is required (core and contralateral hip abductors) to prevent posterior pelvic tilt and lumbar rounding during the stretch.
primary_muscles: rectus femoris / quadriceps (knee extension & assist hip flexion)
notes: Variation: can be performed passively with a strap or actively by pulling the limb — active versions increase demand on hip flexors and quadriceps. Contralateral leg position (extended on floor vs bent) alters pelvic stabilization demands; cue to maintain neutral pelvis and avoid lumbar rounding to protect the low back.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal pushing action: the shoulder moves into horizontal adduction (transverse plane) while the elbow extends (sagittal plane). The prime movers produce shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, triceps). Scapular muscles and the core act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and shoulder girdle; on a lever/machine the fixed path reduces demand on global stabilizers but scapular stabilization (serratus anterior, trapezius/rhomboids) and core/hip isometric stability remain important.
notes: Typically a machine/lever variation of the bench press — classified as a horizontal PUSH. Variations (incline/decline, single-arm lever) change shoulder moment arm and stabilization demands; single-arm or offset loading can introduce anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Leg swings are a dynamic hip mobilization that mimic the swing phase of gait. The primary joint action is at the hip: sagittal-plane flexion (forward swing) and extension (backward swing) for front-back swings, and frontal-plane abduction/adduction for side-to-side swings. Muscles that actively produce the pendular limb motion are the hip flexors (forward), gluteus maximus and hamstrings (backward), and hip abductors/adductors for lateral swings. The standing limb and trunk act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and spine (gluteus medius/min, erector spinae, obliques), and the knee/ankle remain mostly passive with small adjustments for limb positioning.
notes: Two common variants: front-back (sagittal) and side-to-side (frontal). Use a support for balance if needed. Controlled swings emphasize mobility and neuromuscular control; large ballistic swings increase momentum and should be used only with adequate control. Avoid excessive lumbar movement and maintain pelvic stability.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal/decline push: the shoulder performs horizontal adduction (transverse plane with a downward vector due to decline) while the elbow extends (sagittal plane) to drive the lever away from the torso. The pectoralis major (particularly sternal/lower fibers given the decline), anterior deltoid and triceps produce the concentric movement. Scapular protraction (serratus anterior, pec minor) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint; the trunk, hips and lower limbs act isometrically to maintain body position on the decline bench. The machine's leverage guides the path, reducing demands on multi-planar stabilizers but does not change the primary push pattern.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction (with downward vector due to decline)

notes: Decline angle biases lower/sternal pec fibers. Lever/machine reduces demand on anti-rotation and multi-planar stabilizers compared with free-weight decline bench. Single-arm or unilateral variations would add anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are shoulder elevation/forward flexion with horizontal adduction and elbow extension as the lifter presses the handles upward and away from the chest along an incline path. This produces concentric action of the clavicular head of pectoralis major and anterior deltoid to move the humerus, with triceps brachii extending the elbow to straighten the arm. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) and rotator cuff muscles act isometrically to control scapular position and glenohumeral stability; the trunk and hips provide isometric bracing. Because the device is a leverage machine, the path is generally guided which reduces demand on dynamic stabilizers compared with free-weight pressing, but the primary mechanical pattern remains a push (upper-body pressing) predominantly in the sagittal/transverse planes.
notes: Incline angle emphasizes upper/clavicular pec and anterior deltoid more than flat press. Leverage machine guidance reduces stabilizer demand relative to free-weight incline press. If performed single-arm or asymmetrically, add ANTI_ROTATION for core stabilization.

reasoning: Primarily a scapulothoracic elevation movement — the shoulder girdle is driven upward against load. The primary joint action is scapular elevation (shoulder girdle/shoulder) in the frontal plane produced mainly by the upper trapezius and levator scapulae. Elbows are typically held isometrically to maintain grip and transmit load; the spine and core act isometrically to stabilize torso position and prevent neck/upper back compensation.
notes: Leverage/lever machine variations only change load path; primary pattern remains a vertical pull of the scapulae. Watch for neck elevation/shoulder protraction compensations; emphasize scapular control and avoid excessive cervical extension.

reasoning: Primary mechanics are transverse-plane trunk and hip rotation to generate torque, combined with repeated horizontal push actions of the upper limb (punching) and dynamic stepping/weight-transfer (footwork). Shoulders perform horizontal adduction/forward flexion with elbow extension (pushing the fist); the spine and hips rotate in the transverse plane to transfer force. Knees and ankles perform sagittal-plane flexion/extension for stance changes and kicks and provide propulsion/landing during locomotion. Stabilization requires isometric anti-extension/anti-rotation from the core and unilateral lower-limb stability during stepping.

joint_actions.action: rotation (axial/longitudinal) and flexion/extension depending on strike

notes: Variations: heavier bag or power striking emphasizes ROTATION + PUSH; continuous footwork or drilling emphasizes LOCOMOTION. Slow isometric holds or resisting rotation accentuate ANTI_ROTATION, while isolated kicking drills may emphasize sagittal/lateral hip actions. Classification focuses on primary dynamic actions (rotation + pushing strikes + locomotion).

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pressing action (overhead elevation) produced by shoulder elevation and elbow extension. The shoulder (glenohumeral) performs elevation into the overhead position (primarily shoulder flexion in the sagittal/scapular plane or abduction in the frontal plane depending on grip/path), while the elbow extends to straighten the arm. Scapulothoracic upward rotation and elevation accompany humeral elevation to allow full overhead range. The trunk and lower body act isometrically to stabilize the torso; the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control humeral head position. If performed on a lever machine, some stabilization demands are reduced versus a free-weight press, but the primary pattern remains a vertical PUSH.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal / scapular plane (can be frontal depending on grip)

notes: Typical lever or machine shoulder press is a textbook vertical push variation; free‑weight or single‑arm variations increase stabilizer and anti‑rotation demands. Path can be slightly anterior (sagittal/scapular plane) or lateral (frontal) — adjust shoulder mechanics and rotator cuff load accordingly. Watch for impingement risk in individuals with limited scapular upward rotation or poor rotator cuff function.

reasoning: Primary actions are repeated open‑chain upper‑limb strikes (horizontal pushing actions) with integrated transverse trunk and hip rotation to generate force. Shoulders perform horizontal adduction/forward flexion and scapular protraction while elbows extend to deliver punches (sagittal/transverse). The thorax and pelvis rotate in the transverse plane (rotational pattern) to transfer force from the lower body through the core into the arm. Lower‑body weight transfer and single‑leg support phases provide a stable base and contribute to rotational torque; the core works both to drive rotation and to resist unwanted counter‑rotation for control.
notes: Variations (stationary punches, jab-cross, hooks, uppercuts) alter emphasis: hooks/uppercuts add more transverse shoulder rotation and frontal/sagittal components. If exercise emphasizes stationary isometric torso resisting rotation, include ANTI_ROTATION as secondary. Footwork increases LOCOMOTION contribution.

reasoning: Light boxing on a wrecking-ball bag consists of repeated ballistic punches (jab, cross, hook, uppercut) that are primarily horizontal/forward pushing actions of the upper limb combined with transverse-plane rotation of the trunk and hips to generate force and reach. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal flexion/shoulder flexion and internal rotation (transverse/sagittal) with concomitant elbow extension (sagittal) producing the push. The trunk and pelvis produce and transfer force via transverse rotation; the lower limbs and ankles produce weight transfer and push-off. Stabilization demands include scapular stability (rotator cuff, serratus anterior) and core control (obliques/rectus abdominis) to coordinate rotation and control recoil.

joint_actions.action: rotation and weight transfer (flexion/extension during step)

notes: Variations: a straight jab/cross emphasizes linear horizontal PUSH more; hooks and uppercuts emphasize ROTATION and transverse-plane force transfer. Stationary shadowing reduces LOCOMOTION contribution; incorporating footwork adds LOCOMOTION. Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff are important to protect the shoulder during repetitive strikes.

reasoning: Light boxing primarily consists of repeated horizontal pushing actions (punches) combined with transverse-plane trunk and hip rotation to generate force and transfer weight. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal flexion/protraction and elbow extension (producing the push), plus thoracic and pelvic rotation in the transverse plane (producing rotation). Lower‑limb and ankle joints perform small sagittal-plane flexion/extension and weight-shift/stepping for footwork and balance. Core and scapular stabilizers work isometrically to control trunk rotation and maintain shoulder/scapular position.
notes: Stationary shadowboxing emphasizes ROTATION + PUSH. If significant footwork or marching is performed, LOCOMOTION may be added. Use of resisted implements or asymmetric loads can introduce ANTI_ROTATION or increased PUSH demands.

reasoning: Light boxing (shadowboxing) is primarily a repeated horizontal pushing action (punches) produced by shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension in the transverse plane, combined with active spinal/pelvic rotation (transverse) to generate/transfer force. Additionally, light footwork/stepping constitutes locomotion (hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane) for positioning and weight transfer. Primary movers include pecs/delts/triceps for the punch, obliques/abdominals and hip rotators for trunk rotation, and hip/knee/ankle extensors/flexors for footwork. Stabilization demands include scapular control (serratus anterior, lower/mid traps) and anti-rotation/isometric core engagement to transmit force between lower and upper body and maintain balance during single-leg support phases.
notes: If performed stationary with only arm work, LOCOMOTION contribution is minimal and classification can be just PUSH + ROTATION. With aggressive footwork or loaded implements (e.g., medicine ball throws), emphasis and patterns may shift (more LOCOMOTION or added PULL/ANTI_ROTATION elements).

reasoning: Primary joint actions are repeated shoulder-driven punches (horizontal pushing actions) combined with axial trunk rotation and weight transfer. The punch is produced by shoulder horizontal adduction/forward flexion and elbow extension (transverse and sagittal planes) with concomitant scapular protraction; force is augmented by transverse-plane rotation of the thorax and pelvis and hip/leg weight shift. Primary movers (pec major, anterior deltoid, triceps, serratus anterior) create the horizontal push while the obliques/rectus abdominis and hip rotators generate and transmit rotational force. The core also functions to stabilize the spine (control anti-extension and resist unwanted counter-rotation) and the lower limb/hip musculature provides a stable base and weight transfer.

joint_actions.action: stabilization / small adjustments for weight shift

notes: Classification assumes typical light/mid-intensity punching on a stationary dummy. If the drill emphasizes extensive footwork or loaded striking, add LOCOMOTION or consider greater anti-rotation demands. Defensive head movement and slipping increase rotational and anti-rotation stabilization demands.

exercise: Light Calisthenics (jumping jacks, bodyweight squats, high knees, arm circles)
reasoning: This warm-up set contains discrete squat mechanics (bodyweight squats: primary hip and knee flexion/extension in the sagittal plane) and locomotor/drill mechanics (high knees and jumping jacks: repeated hip flexion/extension and knee drive with vertical displacement and rhythmic single-leg demand). Jumping jacks also include frontal-plane hip and shoulder abduction/adduction and repeated ankle plantarflexion during propulsion. Arm circles are shoulder circumduction aimed at glenohumeral mobility and scapular control. Primary movers: quadriceps and gluteus maximus drive squat extension; hip flexors and knee extensors/ankle plantarflexors drive high-knee locomotion and jumps; deltoids and rotator cuff assist arm elevation/circumduction. Core (abdominals/erector spinae) and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to maintain posture and control arm motion.
notes: Warm-up/mobility emphasis; low external load so movement patterns are skill/drill dominant. Jumping jacks add a plyometric/coordination element and frontal-plane shoulder work; high knees represent a locomotion/run-drill pattern. If the session emphasizes the squats more densely, SQUAT confidence increases; if primarily drill-based, LOCOMOTION could be considered primary.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip hinge: the hips flex as the torso tilts forward and then extend to return upright (sagittal plane). The hamstrings and gluteus maximus drive hip extension while the erector spinae eccentrically control forward trunk flexion and concentrically extend the spine. Knees maintain slight flexion and act isometrically to stabilize the lower limb. Core musculature (abdominals/obliques) and lats provide trunk stabilization to preserve a neutral spine during the hinge.
notes: Warm-up version (light/bodyweight) emphasizes motor pattern and range-of-motion; cue neutral spine and hip-dominant movement to avoid excessive lumbar flexion. Can progress to loaded good mornings but pattern remains HINGE.

reasoning: This is an isolated mobility/stretching exercise targeting the wrist and forearm rather than a multi-joint load-bearing pattern. Primary joint actions are wrist flexion/extension (sagittal) and forearm pronation/supination (transverse) performed often with the elbow extended or slightly flexed. The movement is slow and passive/assisted rather than producing forceful concentric actions, so it does not map cleanly to PUSH/PULL/HINGE/SQUAT/CARRY/LOCOTOM/ANTI_ROTATION/ROTATION/LUNGE patterns. Stabilization requirements are minimal — static elbow/shoulder/trunk stabilization and scapular posture maintain limb position while intrinsic and extrinsic forearm muscles are lengthened or mobilized.

joint_actions.action: extension or slight flexion (positioning for stretch)

notes: Common variations: wrist-flexor stretch (wrist extended with elbow straight), wrist-extensor stretch (wrist flexed). Often assisted by the opposite hand. Caution with neurodynamic tension (e.g., carpal tunnel or cubital tunnel symptoms); use gentle ranges.

reasoning: Light club swings are primarily a transverse-plane rotational/pendulum movement generated at the shoulder and trunk. The primary joint actions are shoulder axial rotation and horizontal flexion/extension as the club is swung in arcs, with concomitant thoracic axial rotation and extension to follow the implement. The elbow remains slightly flexed as a hinge/stabilizer. Scapular stabilizers and the rotator cuff eccentrically and concentrically control the club path while the obliques and multifidus produce and modulate trunk rotation. Stabilization requirements include isometric core control to guide and decelerate rotation and scapular/rotator-cuff control to protect the glenohumeral joint during repetitive transverse-plane motion.

joint_actions.action: axial rotation with slight thoracic extension

notes: Light/controlled implementation for mobility stresses transverse-plane rotation and shoulder mobility. Single-arm or asymmetrical swings increase anti-rotation and lateral core demand; heavier/ballistic club swings may add greater eccentric shoulder load and demand for scapular stabilization.

reasoning: Light kickboxing is a dynamic, cyclic activity combining trunk/hip rotation (transverse plane) for strikes and kicks, repeated pushing actions of the upper limb for punches (transverse/horizontal push) and continuous stepping/weight transfer (locomotion). Primary joint actions are pelvic and thoracic rotation produced by the obliques and transverse abdominis, hip flexion/extension and transverse hip rotation for kicks produced by hip flexors, glutes and adductors/abductors, and shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension for punches produced by pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps. Lower-limb sagittal joint movement (hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension) drives stepping and stance changes; the core and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to transfer force and maintain balance.
notes: Movement emphasis varies by style and drill—more upper-body (shadowboxing) increases PUSH/rotation emphasis; more kicking increases hip actions. Anti-rotation/isometric core control is important for force transfer but the pattern is primarily dynamic ROTATION + LOCOMOTION with repeated PUSH actions. Unilateral or resisted variations can increase anti-rotation demand.

exercise: Light Kickboxing (full toolbox; footwork, light snap)
reasoning: Light kickboxing combines repeated striking (punches) and kicking with dynamic footwork. Primary joint actions are trunk axial rotation (transverse plane) to generate and transfer torque, shoulder horizontal flexion and elbow extension for punches (transverse + sagittal) representing horizontal pushing actions, and hip/knee/ankle flexion–extension and occasional hip ab/adduction for kicks and stepping (sagittal/frontal) representing locomotion. The core (obliques, rectus abdominis, erector spinae) produces and resists rotation while transferring force between lower and upper body. Lower-limb extensors (glutes, quads, hamstrings) and plantarflexors generate push-off and kicking forces; anterior shoulder and triceps produce punch snap. Single-leg phases and changing base of support require isometric stabilization (anti-rotation and balance) but the primary patterns are ROTATION (torque generation), PUSH (punching/horizontal force), and LOCOMOTION (footwork/stepping).

joint_actions.action: abduction/adduction and axial rotation (side kicks, turning)

notes: Unloaded, high-skill, multi-planar exercise emphasizing speed, coordination and rotational power. Variations emphasize different patterns (e.g., heavy bag work increases PUSH and ROTATION force demand; shadowboxing with active stepping emphasizes LOCOMOTION and balance). Although anti-rotation/isometric core activity is important for stability, rotation (dynamic) is the dominant core pattern.

reasoning: Light kickboxing combines repeated strikes (punches) and kicks with dynamic footwork. Primary joint actions are transverse-plane spinal and pelvic rotation driving punches and roundhouse/turning kicks (ROTATION), horizontal shoulder flexion and elbow extension producing strikes (PUSH), and stepping/weight transfer for approach, retreat and stance changes (LOCOMOTION). Muscles producing movement include trunk rotators (external/internal obliques, transverse abdominis, erector spinae) for rotation, pectoralis major/anterior deltoid and triceps for horizontal pushing, and hip/knee/ankle musculature (gluteus maximus/medius, quadriceps, hamstrings, gastrocnemius) for kicks and stepping. Stabilization demands include unilateral hip abductor and ankle stabilizer activity during single-leg support for kicks, and isometric core control to sequence and transfer rotational force between lower and upper body.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension and transverse rotation (depending on kick type)

notes: Warm-up intensity is low; emphasis on coordination, timing and mobility. Variations emphasizing stationary shadowboxing focus more on ROTATION and PUSH, while drills with continuous stepping emphasize LOCOMOTION. reasoning: Light march is a locomotor pattern consisting of alternating single-leg support and swing. reasoning: Primary motion is sagittal-plane hip flexion of one limb with the knee maintained in extension, which functionally loads (and typically passively lengthens) the hamstring group. reasoning: Primary movement is a bilateral, vertical impulse produced by concentric extension at the hip, knee, and ankle in the sagittal plane (a plyometric squat/jump pattern). reasoning: A vertical pressing movement where the primary motion is elevation of the humerus (shoulder flexion/elevation in the sagittal plane for a front-path press) combined with elbow extension to drive the load overhead. reasoning: Primary action is an explosive horizontal push: rapid shoulder horizontal adduction with simultaneous elbow extension to project the ball forward. reasoning: This stretch primarily mobilizes the thoracic spine through transverse-plane rotation (often combined with a small amount of sagittal-plane extension or flexion depending on variation). reasoning: This is a ballistic, vertical downward push of a load from overhead. reasoning: This is a vertical pulling exercise: the primary joint actions are elbow flexion (sagittal) and humeral extension/adduction at the glenohumeral joint (sagittal) with concurrent scapular retraction and downward rotation (transverse/frontal) to elevate the body toward the bar. reasoning: Primary action is loaded locomotion: repeated hip/knee/ankle extension-flexion in the sagittal plane to produce walking while carrying external loads (CARRY). Because loads are mixed/asymmetric, the trunk must produce strong isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion forces (ANTI_ROTATION) to keep the spine upright and prevent lateral bend/rotation toward the heavier side. Primary movers for gait (glutes, quads, hamstrings, calves) generate propulsion while obliques, transverse abdominis and QL resist rotation/lateral flexion; forearm flexors maintain grip and traps/serratus stabilize the shoulder girdle.

reasoning: Mixed striking combines repeated horizontal/vertical pushing actions (punches, elbow strikes) with powerful transverse-plane trunk and hip rotation to generate force, plus stepping/weight transfer for range and set-up. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal flexion and protraction with elbow extension (pushing) in the transverse/sagittal planes, and axial rotation of the spine and hips in the transverse plane to produce torque. Kicks and knees involve rapid hip flexion/extension and frontal-plane hip ab/adduction with single-leg weight transfer (locomotion/stepping). Stabilization demands include unilateral single-leg support (hip abductors, glute medius), anti-flexion/anti-extension capacity from the core, and scapular stabilization during repetitive punches. Because rotation is an essential force-generating and skill element, ROTATION is included alongside PUSH; frequent stepping and weight shifts justify LOCOMOTION as a third pattern.
notes: High variability depending on specific strike combinations; some sequences emphasize vertical push (overhead elbows/knees) or greater single-leg/rotational demand. Asymmetric and ballistic nature increases anti-rotation/isometric core demands even though primary pattern is ROTATION + PUSH with locomotor stepping. Equipment/bodyweight and contact/context (bag vs sparring) will change force profiles.

reasoning: Primary actions are repeated upper-extremity pushing actions (shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension) delivered while generating force from the hips and trunk through transverse-plane rotation. Shoulders produce horizontal push (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid) with triceps extending the elbow to project the fist. The spine and pelvis perform active rotation to generate torque and transfer force from the lower body (obliques, transverse abdominis, erector spinae, glute complex). Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, rhomboids, traps) and rotator cuff muscles provide dynamic stabilization. If footwork and weight transfer are included the hips/legs contribute with hip extension and rotational drive; however the primary joint actions remain upper-body push and trunk rotation.
notes: Variations (hooks, uppercuts, overhands) change the emphasis: hooks and crosses increase transverse rotation demand; uppercuts add more vertical vector to the push. If extensive stepping or loaded implements are used, LOCOMOTION or CARRY patterns may be relevant; asymmetric striking or resisting rotational forces increase ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: Mixed striking actions primarily generate force via upper-limb forward/horizontal pushing (punches, elbow strikes) and multi-segment transverse-plane rotation (torso/hip) to transfer power. Primary joint actions include shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension for hand/elbow strikes (transverse/sagittal), spinal rotation for torque generation and force transfer (transverse), and sagittal hip/knee actions for knee strikes and kicks (hip flexion/extension and knee extension). Stabilization demands include anti-rotational core control (obliques, deep core) to transmit force, scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius) for effective shoulder mechanics, and single-leg balance control during kicking and stepping.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction (and flexion for some strikes)

exercise: Mixed Load Farmer Carry (24 kg / 70 lb Kettlebell)
reasoning: This is a loaded-walking exercise (CARRY) performed with an asymmetric/mixed load, which creates a rotational and lateral bias that the core must resist (ANTI_ROTATION). The asymmetric load imposes lateral bending and rotational moments on the spine that are resisted isometrically by the obliques, transverse abdominis and quadratus lumborum, while the posterior chain and lower limb muscles drive forward progression. Stabilization also requires strong grip, scapular depression/stability (lats/traps/rotator cuff) and single-leg balance control during stance phases.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (adduction/neutral position to support load)

notes: Mixed/asymmetric load increases anti-rotation and lateral stabilization demands vs a bilateral farmer carry. Surface, gait speed and load size change demand on lower limb power vs core stabilization.
