exercise: Play with Murray and Maggie (running & tug-of-war)
reasoning: This activity combines ambulatory locomotion (running) with an episodic horizontal pulling task (tug-of-war). Primary joint actions during running are repeated hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane produced by the gluteals, hamstrings, quadriceps and plantarflexors. During tug-of-war the primary actions are shoulder extension/scapular retraction and elbow flexion in the sagittal/horizontal plane (pulling the rope toward the body) produced by lats, posterior deltoid, biceps and scapular retractors; the lower limbs contribute force via hip and knee extension. The task also imposes rotational and asymmetric load on the trunk that requires isometric anti-rotation and anti-flexion from the obliques, transverse abdominis and erector spinae to stabilize the spine. Ankles and feet provide ground reaction stabilization and rapid direction changes during running.
notes: Playful, variable activity — intensity, direction changes and grip orientation vary. Tug-of-war can create large horizontal and rotational forces; include bracing cues. If rope pull is strictly bilateral and symmetric, anti-rotation demand is reduced; if asymmetric or single-sided, anti-rotation importance increases.

reasoning: This warm-up drill is primarily a locomotion-based, multi-directional movement (jogging/accelerations, direction changes, shuffles/marches) so the dominant joint actions are repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion–extension in the sagittal plane. Because play/chase style drills typically include quick changes of direction, weight shifts and trunk turns, there is also meaningful transverse-plane rotation of the pelvis/spine and frontal-plane hip ab/adduction when changing direction. Primary movers produce propulsion (glutes, quads, hamstrings, plantarflexors) while the core (obliques, erector spinae) and hip abductors/adductors stabilize and control rotation and frontal-plane alignment during cuts/turns.
notes: Assumed multi-directional locomotor warm-up. If the drill is strictly stationary mobility (e.g., only dynamic stretches, no stepping/locomotion) then LOCOMOTION should be removed and classification adjusted to ROTATION or SQUAT/LUNGE depending on specific actions. Scale intensity and surface for safety during direction changes.

exercise: Playing Outside (running/playing with Murray and Maggie)
reasoning: Primary action is rhythmic bipedal locomotion (running/playing) driven by repeated hip/knee/ankle cycles in the sagittal plane. Hip extension and knee extension produce push-off; hip flexion and knee flexion produce swing. Arm swing (shoulder flexion/extension) and dynamic trunk stabilization/rotation in the transverse plane accompany gait. Stabilization demands include core and hip abductors to maintain trunk/pelvic alignment during single-leg stance phases and to absorb multi-planar perturbations during play.
notes: If play includes frequent cutting, tackling, or throwing, add ROTATION and/or LUNGE/SQUAT patterns for directional changes and low-level contact. Intensity (jog vs sprint) alters muscle recruitment but not primary pattern classification.

reasoning: This activity is primarily dynamic locomotion — repeated single-leg stance and push-off producing forward (and lateral/variable) progression. Primary joint actions are alternating hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane to generate stride and propulsion. Shoulders perform alternating flexion/extension (arm swing) in the sagittal plane that aids balance and counter-rotation. The pelvis and thorax exhibit low-amplitude transverse rotation during gait; the trunk and hip abductors act isometrically to stabilize the body during single-leg support and changes of direction. Muscles producing movement include the gluteus maximus and hamstrings (hip extension), quadriceps (knee extension), and plantarflexors (gastrocnemius/soleus) for push-off; hip flexors and tibialis anterior act during swing. Core and hip stabilizers (obliques, erector spinae, gluteus medius) provide frontal and rotational stabilization.

joint_actions.action: alternating flexion/extension (shock absorption and extension for push-off)
axial rotation (contralateral pelvis/thorax rotation) and isometric trunk stabilization

notes: Unstructured play may include accelerations, decelerations, cutting, jumping and multi-planar movements; these introduce greater frontal and transverse loading demands but the primary pattern remains LOCOMOTION. Intensity, direction changes, and intermittent stops make this a variable locomotor warm-up rather than a single textbook drill.

reasoning: Primary action is an explosive horizontal push: repeated/plyometric concentric shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension to propel the body upward from a prone/plank position. Shoulders (pec major, anterior deltoid) and triceps produce the primary concentric force; scapular protractors (serratus anterior) assist the push and control landing. The trunk and hips act isometrically to maintain a rigid plank and transfer force. Kettlebells increase instability and range of motion at the wrist/shoulder but do not change the primary push-dominant movement pattern.
notes: Kettlebells create increased grip/instability and greater ROM compared with floor push-ups; plyometric component increases demand for deceleration and scapular control on landing. Watch shoulder and wrist loading; regress to regular push-ups or non-plyometric kettlebell push-ups if needed.

reasoning: This is an isolated passive stretch focused at the foot/ankle complex. Primary joint actions are dorsiflexion at the talocrural joint (sagittal plane) combined with eversion/pronation at the subtalar/transverse tarsal joints (frontal/transverse planes) to lengthen the posterior tibialis. No meaningful hip, knee, shoulder, elbow or spinal movement is produced; stabilization demands are minimal and local (intrinsic foot muscles, ankle stabilizers, and brief postural control from the hips/trunk if standing).
notes: This is primarily a mobility/stretch exercise rather than a movement-pattern exercise; therefore no high-level pattern (SQUAT/HINGE/PUSH/PULL/etc.) applies. Variations include band-assisted dorsiflexion+eversion, seated manual stretch, or weight-bearing versions. Caution with recent ankle injuries, tarsal tunnel syndrome, or neuropathy.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are rapid concentric elbow extension (sagittal) and humeral horizontal adduction (transverse) to drive the body off the ground — equivalent to a horizontal push. Primary movers are pectoralis major and anterior deltoid producing horizontal adduction and triceps producing elbow extension. The movement is plyometric (explosive concentric phase) with an eccentric lowering phase that lengthens the same muscles. Secondary requirements include isometric trunk and hip stabilization to keep a rigid plank line and scapular control (serratus anterior, lower/upper trapezius) to manage protraction/retraction during the ballistic portion.
notes: Plyometric variant emphasizes explosive concentric push and rapid scapular protraction on release. Variations (clap, depth, single-arm) increase demand on scapular stabilizers and/or anti-rotation. Ensure progressive loading to manage shoulder and wrist impact; decline/incline hand positions alter shoulder moment and relative vertical/horizontal push emphasis.

reasoning: The power clean is primarily a sagittal-plane triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to generate vertical and horizontal force—this is a hinge-dominant explosive movement—and a powerful vertical pull of the bar with scapular elevation and arm flexion to pull the body under the bar (pull). Primary joint actions are rapid hip extension driven by glutes/hamstrings, knee extension from quads, and ankle plantarflexion from calves (sagittal). Simultaneously the upper posterior chain (traps, lats, rhomboids) and elbow flexors/shoulder musculature perform a high pull and shrug to elevate the bar; then the lifter pulls under into the catch with elbow flexion. Spine musculature (erector spinae, core) maintains neutrality and resists flexion/extensive shear during the explosive phase. Stabilization requirements include strong core anti-extension/anti-flexion control, scapular stability during pull and catch, and grip/forearm endurance.
notes: Variation: power clean (high catch) vs full clean (deeper squat) alters degree of squat involvement; if the catch is a deep squat some practitioners may add SQUAT as a secondary pattern. Requires coordinated timing (triple extension then rapid pull-under), good mobility (ankle, hip, thoracic) and robust scapular/core stability.

reasoning: Primary action is an explosive vertical push of the barbell overhead via a dip-and-drive (triple extension) and upper‑limb lockout; the athlete then receives the load in a partial squat (power catch). Primary joint actions: rapid hip/knee/ankle extension (sagittal) to drive the bar, shoulder elevation and elbow extension to lock the bar overhead, then hip/knee flexion to absorb/catch the load. Scapular upward rotation and thoracic/spinal stiffness are required for stable overhead position; lower limb and core act both concentrically (drive) and isometrically/eccentrically (catch) for stabilization.
notes: Power jerk is primarily an overhead vertical PUSH with a power (partial) SQUAT catch. If performed as a split jerk, include LUNGE (split) as an additional pattern and note asymmetric loading requirements for single‑leg stability. Ensure scapular upward rotation and thoracic extension for safe overhead lockout.

reasoning: Primary action is an explosive triple-extension initiated from the hips, knees and ankles (hip extension dominant) to generate vertical velocity, followed by a high pull (scapular elevation/shoulder shrug) and rapid elbow flexion/forearm action to receive the bar. Movement occurs primarily in the sagittal plane for the lower-body triple extension and in the frontal/transverse planes for the upper-body vertical pull/turnover. The posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, erector spinae) produces the hinge-driven propulsion while the traps, deltoids and elbow flexors contribute to the vertical pull and turnover; the core/spine muscles stabilize the trunk against flexion and shear during the explosive phase. Catch can involve partial knee flexion (small squat) but is secondary to the propulsive hinge + pull pattern.
notes: From-block start shortens initial hinge ROM (higher start height) but primary mechanics remain explosive hip/knee/ankle extension plus vertical pull. Catch depth (power vs full squat) may add a secondary squat component if deeper receiving position is used. Requires good thoracic mobility, strong posterior chain, and precise timing for safe technique.

reasoning: Power partials (commonly performed as explosive partial-range squats at or above parallel) primarily involve sagittal-plane hip and knee extension performed concentrically with an emphasis on rapid force production. The primary joint actions are hip extension and knee extension with the torso maintained in a relatively upright, stabilized position; ankle plantarflexion contributes to the final drive. Stabilization demands include isometric trunk control to resist flexion and maintain vertical alignment, and ankle/foot stabilization for force transfer. If the specific implementation is a partial hip-dominant pull (rare naming variant), mechanics would shift toward HINGE, but the prototypical interpretation is a partial-range squat movement.
notes: Name ambiguity: 'Power partials' is most often a partial-range explosive squat (SQUAT pattern). If the exercise is performed as a partial hip hinge (e.g., rack pulls or partial cleans), include HINGE (and possibly PULL) instead. Adjust classification if equipment/technique indicates a different emphasis.

reasoning: The power snatch is an Olympic lift that is initiated as an explosive vertical pull driven by triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) — characteristic of both HINGE (hip-dominant explosive extension) and PULL (vertical, high pull of the bar). The lift is finished with a rapid turnover and catch in a partial/quarter squat position (SQUAT pattern) with the bar locked overhead. Primary joint actions during the pull are hip extension, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane; the catch requires rapid hip/knee flexion and ankle dorsiflexion to receive the bar. Shoulders and elbows move to lock the load overhead (shoulder abduction/flexion and elbow extension) while the spine and core act isometrically to stabilize and transmit force. Scapular and rotator cuff control are required to receive and stabilize the overhead position.

joint_actions.action: abduction/flexion to overhead (catch) with scapular upward rotation

notes: Phased movement: first pull (hinge), second/third pull (vertical high pull), turnover and partial squat catch. Arms primarily act as hooks to receive load rather than producing the primary force (not a primary PUSH). Requires thoracic mobility, shoulder/rotator cuff stability and strong core/bracing to safely receive overhead load.

reasoning: Power Stairs is typically performed by ascending a series of steps/platforms repeatedly while transporting a load (or moving bodyweight up stairs). The primary joint actions are repeated sagittal-plane hip and knee extension to drive the body/loaded object upward and ankle plantarflexion for push-off. Because it is performed as loaded stepping/walking up elevation, it functions as a locomotion pattern (repeated gait/step cycles) and, when a load is present, a carry pattern (transporting weight while moving). Trunk and shoulder girdle muscles act isometrically to stabilize the load and maintain posture; single-leg support phases increase demand on unilateral hip/knee stabilizers.
primary_muscles: upper trapezius/deltoids (if load held at/above shoulder level)
notes: If performed unloaded, primary pattern is LOCOMOTION with lower confidence for CARRY. If an asymmetric or single-arm load is used, include ANTI_ROTATION due to lateral spinal stabilization demands. Load position (yoke, farmer, front-loaded) will alter shoulder/trunk stabilization demands but does not change primary locomotion/higher-extensor drive.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane against resistance, produced mainly by the elbow flexors. The preacher pad fixes the upper arm against the support, minimizing shoulder motion and isolating elbow flexion. Scapular, shoulder and trunk musculature act isometrically to stabilize the humerus and torso; if using a supinated grip the forearm undergoes some active supination (transverse plane) by the biceps.
notes: Preacher curl is an isolation elbow-flexion movement; variations (reverse grip, hammer grip, cable preacher) alter emphasis toward brachioradialis or change forearm rotation demands. Pad height and arm placement affect shoulder stabilization demand.

reasoning: Primary action is an explosive triple-extension (hip, knee, ankle) to generate vertical velocity (HINGE emphasis on hip extension with knee and ankle extension). This is combined with a powerful vertical pull/shrug of the shoulder girdle and upper back to accelerate the bar upward and position it for the catch (PULL). The catch is received overhead with locked arms, requiring scapular and shoulder stability and core/bracing to stabilize the spine. Plane emphasis is sagittal for lower-limb extension and vertical/frontal for scapular elevation/overhead stabilization.

joint_actions.action: elevation (shrug) and upward rotation for overhead positioning
flexion/abduction to receive bar overhead and then isometric stabilization

notes: From-block start reduces initial floor pull; power snatch catches at a higher hip/knee angle than full snatch (less squat depth). Requires strong scapular stability and overhead mobility; technique variations (hang, from blocks, full vs power catch) change relative emphasis on knee flexion/squat involvement but primary patterns remain HINGE + PULL.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane producing upward forearm movement toward the humerus. The preacher pad braces the arm and minimizes shoulder and torso movement, isolating elbow flexors. Hammer (neutral) grip orients the forearm so brachioradialis and brachialis contribute strongly; the biceps brachii contributes to elbow flexion but less to supination in the neutral grip. Shoulder complex, scapulae and spine act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm and trunk against movement.
notes: Preacher bench isolates elbow flexors by removing shoulder/elbow momentum. Hammer (neutral) grip biases brachioradialis and brachialis over biceps long‑head; a supinated curl would increase biceps brachii contribution. Single‑arm execution is still primarily a PULL pattern; because the arm is braced, anti‑rotation demands on the torso are minimal.

reasoning: The exercise combines a dynamic sit-up (spinal flexion) with an upper-body pressing action. The primary locomotive/joint action that maps to the available movement patterns is the vertical/horizontal pressing action (PUSH): shoulder flexion/vertical press with elbow extension produces the push. The sit-up portion is spinal flexion (sagittal plane) driven by rectus abdominis and hip flexors; it functions as a primary mover for trunk motion but does not map to a separate listed pattern. Stabilization demands include scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff control during the press, and eccentric/isometric control from the posterior chain and spinal extensors as the trunk moves. If the press is performed asymmetrically or rotated, ANTI_ROTATION/ROTATION should be added.
notes: Variation-dependent: if the press is performed strictly overhead the PUSH designation is clear as a vertical push; if the upper-body action is a forward/horizontal press the pattern still falls under PUSH (horizontal push). The sit-up portion is primarily trunk flexion (core-driven) which is not a separate provided pattern. Asymmetric loading or single-arm press would add ANTI_ROTATION and lower confidence toward a multi-pattern classification.

reasoning: Primarily a posterior-chain, sagittal-plane movement performed prone with manual resistance: the chief motion is knee flexion produced by the hamstrings while the pelvis/hip and trunk act isometrically to stabilize. Although mechanically this is an isolated knee-flexion (leg-curl style) action, the hamstrings are biarticular and contribute to hip extension/stabilization, so the exercise is classified under the posterior-chain HINGE family given available patterns.
notes: This exercise functions as an isolated knee-flexion (leg-curl) movement; the provided pattern set lacks a dedicated 'knee-flexion/isolation' category, so HINGE is used to represent posterior-chain emphasis. Variations (standing/unilateral/manual resistance at different lever arms) alter hip involvement and could increase hip-extension (hinge) demand.

reasoning: Prone W-Y lifts are primarily a posterior shoulder/scapular retraction movement. The primary joint actions occur at the glenohumeral joint (scaption/abduction into a Y position and horizontal abduction/transverse extension into a W), with concurrent scapulothoracic retraction/adduction and upward rotation. The thoracic spine performs mild extension to allow scapular motion and maintain chest lift. Elbow position is typically flexed and relatively isometric. These actions collectively load the posterior deltoid and scapular retractors, so the movement aligns with a horizontal/posterior pull pattern rather than a push or rotational trunk pattern. Stabilization demands include thoracic extension control and scapular stability (serratus anterior, lower/middle trap) to guide upward rotation and prevent compensatory neck elevation.

joint_actions.action: abduction/scaption (Y) and horizontal abduction/extension (W); external rotation
extension (mild, to lift chest and allow scapular motion)

notes: Primarily a scapular retraction/upward rotation and posterior shoulder (pull) mobility/strength drill. Cue thoracic lift and scapular control; avoid neck elevation. Progress by adding light resistance bands or weights only after mastering scapular mechanics.

reasoning: Primary motion is shoulder elevation into a Y (scapular-plane abduction/flexion) produced by glenohumeral movers and scapulothoracic upward rotators. The glenohumeral joint performs scaption (about 30–45° anterior to the frontal plane) with the scapula undergoing upward rotation and posterior tilt. Serratus anterior and lower trapezius drive scapular upward rotation and posterior tilt while the deltoids/supraspinatus elevate the humerus; rotator cuff muscles stabilize the humeral head. Elbow remains extended isometrically and the thoracic spine/core provide postural stabilization. Because the exercise emphasizes active scapular movement and posterior shoulder control (pulling/scapular control pattern) it best fits the PULL category.
notes: Often performed prone on floor or incline bench with thumbs up to bias scapular plane/scaption. Emphasize scapular upward rotation and posterior tilt rather than excessive thoracic extension; light resistance recommended to train scapular control. Variations with weights or band increase demand but do not change primary pattern.

reasoning: Primary motion is humeral elevation in the scapular plane (a form of shoulder abduction/flexion) combined with scapulothoracic upward rotation and posterior tilt. The movement is produced by concentric action of scapular retractors/upward rotators and posterior shoulder muscles (lower and middle trapezius, serratus anterior, posterior deltoid) which lift and stabilize the arm off the surface. The glenohumeral joint performs elevation in the scapular plane while the scapula upwardly rotates and posteriorly tilts to allow full range. Elbow is maintained extended/isometric; thoracic spine and core provide stabilization to maintain prone alignment. Because the exercise primarily moves the humerus/scapula in a posterior-shoulder/scapular-control manner, it best fits the PULL pattern (posterior chain/pulling shoulder action) rather than a horizontal/vertical push.

joint_actions.action: humeral elevation (abduction/flexion in scapular plane) with slight external rotation
joint_actions.plane: scapular plane (~30–45° between frontal and sagittal)

joint_actions.action: upward rotation and posterior tilt (scapular rotation/tilt)
joint_actions.plane: frontal (upward rotation) / sagittal component for posterior tilt

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / slight extension to maintain prone posture

notes: Commonly used for shoulder health and lower-trap activation. Variations include performing on a bench, with slight external rotation (thumbs up) to bias lower trap/rotator cuff, or with bent elbows (regression) to reduce lever arm. Avoid compensatory cervical extension or excessive lumbar extension; focus on scapular control.

reasoning: The pull-through is a hip-dominant hinge pattern. The primary joint action is hip extension in the sagittal plane driven by posterior chain musculature (gluteus maximus and hamstrings). Knee angle is typically held with a slight flexion and undergoes minimal motion (secondary), while the lumbar spine and core act isometrically to maintain a neutral trunk and transfer force. Upper extremities hold the handle/band but mainly provide load location and do not perform a horizontal/vertical pull; scapular/shoulder musculature functions as a stabilizer.
notes: Commonly performed with cable or band between the legs; resembles a standing hip thrust/Romanian deadlift. Greater knee bend shifts emphasis toward glutes; straighter knees increase hamstring demand. Cue to maintain neutral spine and drive hips back and through. Not classified as an upper-body PULL despite cable handle—primary movers are posterior chain hip extensors.

reasoning: Primarily an overhead/elevation movement of the shoulder complex performed prone in the scapular plane (Y). The primary joint action is glenohumeral elevation (combined flexion/abduction in the scapular/frontal plane) with concentric scapulothoracic upward rotation. Elbows remain extended/isometric and the thoracic spine/postural extensors provide trunk stabilization. Because the limb is being lifted upward against gravity, the pattern aligns with a vertical PUSH-type shoulder elevation (similar biomechanical demands to open-chain shoulder elevation). Scapular stabilizers (lower trapezius, serratus anterior, middle trapezius) control upward rotation and posterior tilt while rotator cuff muscles centrate the humeral head; the deltoid/supraspinatus provide the primary GH elevation force.
notes: Performed in the scapular plane with thumbs-up/external rotation reduces impingement and emphasizes lower trapezius/serratus activation. Progressions include added load or prone T/Y/W sequences; regressions include reducing range of motion or performing on an incline. Avoid excessive thoracic extension or shrugging (levator/scapular elevation) which reduces lower trap emphasis.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elevation of the humerus in the scapular plane (shoulder flexion/abduction in ~30–45° anterior to the frontal plane) with concurrent scapulothoracic upward rotation and posterior tilt. Elbows remain extended (isometric). The movement is primarily a scapular-control/shoulder-elevation pattern — functionally a pulling/scapular stabilization pattern rather than a pushing or hinge/squat type. Muscles producing the movement include lower and middle trapezius and serratus anterior generating scapular upward rotation and posterior tilt, with contribution from posterior deltoid and rotator cuff for humeral control; thoracic extensors and deep spinal stabilizers provide a stable prone posture. Stabilization demands include isometric elbow and scapular stabilizers, thoracic extension control to maintain neutral spine, and core/hip control to prevent compensatory lumbar extension or rib flare.
notes: Often prescribed as a scapular mobility/activation exercise to bias lower trapezius and serratus anterior. Common variations: performed on floor (limited ROM), on an incline/bench (increased ROM), with band resistance, or with thumbs up to bias different rotator cuff fibers. Watch for compensatory lumbar extension or shrugging (upper trap dominance).

reasoning: Primary actions are scapulothoracic and glenohumeral movements that resemble horizontal/vertical pulling patterns: scapular retraction (adduction), depression and upward rotation with concurrent glenohumeral abduction/horizontal abduction and external rotation depending on Y, T, W positions. The exercise emphasizes concentric/eccentric control of scapular retractors and rotator cuff muscles rather than pushing motions. Stabilization requires thoracic extension hold and isometric core/hip stability to maintain prone alignment while the scapulae and shoulders move.

joint_actions.plane: scapular plane (approx. 30–45° between sagittal and frontal)

notes: Prone Y-T-W is primarily a scapular-control/pulling mobility exercise. Variations (elevated bench, added light resistance bands) increase loading but do not change the primary PULL pattern. Cue thoracic extension and scapular motion; avoid shrugging (levator-dominant) and aggressive GH impingement in painful shoulders.

reasoning: A pull-up is primarily a vertical pulling movement. The primary joint actions are shoulder extension/adduction at the glenohumeral joint and elbow flexion in the sagittal plane, with concurrent scapular depression and retraction (scapulothoracic motion) to position the shoulder girdle. The torso, hips, knees and ankles act isometrically to stabilize the body and limit swing. Primary movers (lats, teres major, posterior deltoid, biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis) generate the concentric pulling action while scapular retractors/depressors (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids) control scapular motion and the core prevents excessive sagittal/transverse motion.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (resists excessive flexion/extension and rotation)

notes: Classic vertical pull pattern. Variations (chin-up, neutral grip, wide grip) change muscle emphasis slightly (more biceps or lats). Kipping or leg-driven variations add dynamic hip/torso involvement. Single-arm or offset-loaded variations add anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Pull-ups are a vertical pulling pattern: the primary joint actions are shoulder extension (bringing the humerus from overhead toward the torso) and elbow flexion to elevate the torso toward the bar. Scapulothoracic retraction and depression initiate and augment the pull. The spine and hips act isometrically to stabilize the torso and prevent excessive swing. Prime movers (lats, teres major, posterior deltoid, biceps) produce the concentric pull while scapular retractors/depressors (rhomboids, middle/lower traps) control scapular motion; core musculature maintains a neutral spine and resists rotation/swinging.

joint_actions.action: extension (and some adduction depending on grip)

notes: Variations alter emphasis: supinated/underhand grip (chin-up) increases biceps contribution; wide grip emphasizes latissimus; kipping or butterfly pull-ups add hip drive and reduce strict core stabilization. Strict, controlled reps are classic vertical PULL pattern.

reasoning: The pull-up is a vertical pulling exercise. Primary joint actions are elbow flexion and shoulder extension/adduction as the body is elevated toward the bar. The scapulothoracic joints perform scapular depression and retraction to initiate and support the movement. The spine and core act isometrically to prevent excessive torso swing and maintain body alignment. Movement occurs primarily in the sagittal plane for elbow and shoulder extension, with transverse/frontal components for scapular retraction/depression and stabilization.
notes: Grip width/hand orientation changes emphasis (narrow/underhand increases biceps, wide increases lats). Kipping or butterfly pull-ups add hip extension and dynamic momentum (introducing a locomotor/hip drive component) and reduce pure pulling emphasis. Scapular control (active depression/retraction) is important for shoulder health.

reasoning: The pull-up is a vertical pulling movement. Primary joint actions are shoulder extension and adduction (humeral movement bringing the body up toward the bar) and elbow flexion to shorten the distance. The scapulae retract (scapular adduction) to assist shoulder girdle motion and stabilize the glenohumeral joint. Core and spinal musculature act isometrically to maintain a rigid torso and prevent excessive lumbar extension or swinging. Forearm/finger flexors provide sustained grip. Primary movers (latissimus dorsi, teres major, biceps brachii, brachialis) produce the concentric pull while the scapular retractors (rhomboids, middle/lower trapezius) control scapulothoracic motion and the core provides anti-extension/anti-swing stabilization.
notes: Variations: supinated (chin-up) grip increases biceps contribution; wide-grip emphasizes latissimus dorsi and reduces elbow flexor demand. As a finisher, fatigue may increase torso swing—coach strict form or use kipping as a deliberate different pattern (dynamic hip drive).

reasoning: Primary joint actions are elbow flexion and shoulder extension/adduction producing a vertical pull of the torso toward a fixed overhead bar. Scapulothoracic retraction and depression accompany the shoulder motion to initiate and finish the pull. Movement is driven by shoulder extensors/adductors and elbow flexors; the trunk and hips are held isometrically to maintain body alignment and resist unwanted spinal flexion or rotation.
notes: Classic vertical pulling pattern. Grip variation (pronated pull-up vs supinated chin-up) alters biceps vs lat emphasis. Kipping or butterfly pull-ups introduce dynamic hip/trunk drive and momentary momentum but primary classification remains PULL; strict pull-ups are textbook vertical pull.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pulling action: shoulder moves from an elevated/flexed position toward extension/adduction while the elbows flex to bring the body up toward the bar. Scapular retraction and downward rotation/depression initiate and accompany the movement. The torso and hips remain largely isometric to transfer force and prevent excessive swinging. Primary movers produce concentric shoulder extension/adduction (latissimus dorsi, teres major, posterior deltoid) and elbow flexion (biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis), while scapular retractors/depressors (rhomboids, middle/lower trapezius) stabilize the shoulder girdle and core musculature resists trunk flexion/rotation.
notes: Strict, controlled pull-ups are a textbook vertical/horizontal pull pattern (vertical when chin over bar). Variations: chin-up (supinated grip) increases biceps contribution; wide-grip emphasizes latissimus dorsi and shoulder adduction; kipping or butterfly pull-ups add hip drive and dynamic momentum, reducing pure pull emphasis and increasing need for anti-rotation control if swinging occurs.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pulling action: the humerus moves from overhead toward the torso (shoulder extension/adduction) while the forearm moves toward the arm (elbow flexion). Scapulothoracic retraction and depression (scapular adduction/depression) initiate and accompany the motion. The spine and core act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and resist excessive lumbar extension or rotation, and the lower body remains largely passive. Muscles producing the movement are primarily latissimus dorsi, teres major, and the elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis), with scapular retractors (rhomboids, middle/lower trapezius) providing scapular control.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (primarily) with transverse component for scapular motion

notes: Grip width and hand position change muscle emphasis (narrow/underhand increases biceps; wide increases lats). Kipping or butterfly variations add hip drive and dynamic extension/flexion, reducing pure vertical-pull classification. Assisted or banded variations alter loading but remain a PULL pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is an eccentric (lowering) pull: the humerus moves from a relatively elevated/flexed position toward extension (and often slight adduction) while the elbow moves from flexion toward extension under control. Latissimus dorsi, teres major and posterior deltoid eccentrically control shoulder extension; the elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis) eccentrically control elbow extension. Scapulothoracic retractors/depressors (rhomboids, middle/lower trapezius) control scapular position. The torso/spine is held isometrically to prevent excessive sagittal flexion or swing, and the forearm flexors maintain grip on the bar. Because the exercise is a vertical pulling action with primary shoulder and elbow joint involvement, it classifies as a PULL pattern.
notes: Variation by grip width/hand orientation alters the degree of humeral adduction vs. sagittal extension. Negatives emphasize eccentric loading of lats and elbow flexors and require good scapular control to avoid shrugging or excessive spinal flexion. Progressions: weighted eccentrics; regressions: assisted negatives or jumping-to-chin position before slow lowering.

The hands-wide-to-narrow transition can alter moment arms, shifting emphasis between pectoralis and triceps and slightly increasing transverse-plane/rotational stabilization demand, but the primary pattern remains a horizontal PUSH.

The variation can introduce asymmetric/rotational demands if the hand transition is uneven — in those cases add ANTI_ROTATION. Monitor wrists and scapular control; regress with knees or incline, progress with weighted or unstable surfaces.

reasoning: Pushups are primarily a horizontal pushing pattern. The prime joint actions are elbow extension (sagittal plane) and shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) with associated scapular protraction. The pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps brachii produce the concentric push while serratus anterior and the scapular stabilizers control scapular motion. The trunk and hips act isometrically to maintain a rigid plank (anti-extension/anti-flexion) so core and gluteal musculature provide stabilization but do not define the primary movement pattern. reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal PUSH during the push‑up (shoulder horizontal adduction and elbow extension producing transverse/sagittal plane pushing). reasoning: Push-ups are a horizontal push pattern. Primary joint actions are shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) and elbow extension (sagittal plane) producing the concentric push. Scapular protraction/retraction (serratus anterior, lower/mid trapezius) control the scapulothoracic rhythm but are secondary to the pressing action. Close vs wide hand positions alter moment arms and emphasize triceps (close) versus pectoralis major (wide), but do not change the fundamental horizontal push classification.

reasoning: Push-up is a horizontal pressing (push) exercise. The scapulothoracic joints control protraction/retraction and stability, and the spine/hips act isometrically to resist lumbar extension (maintain a rigid plank). reasoning: Put-away Carries are primarily a loaded-walking task (CARRY): repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane generates forward progression while the limbs accept and propel load. Because the carry is often asymmetric (single-arm or turning to place items) or requires resisting trunk rotation while walking and reaching, there is a substantial isometric anti-rotational demand on the core (ANTI_ROTATION) in the transverse and frontal planes. The shoulders and elbows act largely as isometric stabilizers to maintain the load position while lower-limb muscles produce gait. If the carry is bilateral and symmetric the anti-rotation demand is reduced; if placing overhead or turning, additional shoulder elevation or trunk rotation demands occur.

reasoning: Pyramid (commonly the standing yoga Parsvottanasana / pyramid stretch) is primarily a single‑leg hip hinge: the pelvis tilts posteriorly and the torso flexes over the front, producing hip flexion in the sagittal plane with concomitant spinal/trunk flexion. reasoning: Quadriceps self-myofascial release is primarily a mobility/soft-tissue technique rather than a functional movement pattern. reasoning: Primary joint action is unilateral knee flexion (bringing heel toward buttocks) in the sagittal plane, often accompanied by slight hip extension to increase quadriceps (rectus femoris) stretch. reasoning: Quick Leap is a plyometric bilateral bounding movement that produces horizontal/vertical displacement via rapid triple extension at the hip, knee and ankle (sagittal plane). The movement is locomotor in nature when performed as a forward/forward-biased leap, and mechanically resembles a rapid, explosive squat pattern for generating vertical/upward force. reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant sagittal-plane hinge: the hips flex as the torso moves forward and then extend to return the load to standing, driven mainly by the gluteus maximus and hamstrings. reasoning: The Romanian deadlift is primarily a hip-hinge movement: the hips flex as the torso tilts forward and then extend to return to standing (sagittal plane). notes: Dumbbell RDL is a textbook hinge variant. Single-leg or asymmetrical loading would add ANTI_ROTATION demands. Excessive knee bend shifts pattern toward deadlift/squat mechanics; thoracic rounding increases spinal flexion risk — cue neutral spine and hip-drive.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip hinge: eccentric hip flexion and concentric hip extension in the sagittal plane driven by the posterior chain. reasoning: Primary movement is a sagittal-plane hip hinge: the torso tilts forward around the hips with controlled hip flexion on descent and powerful hip extension on ascent. notes: RDL is primarily a hinge pattern; PULL is included to reflect load transfer/grip and upper-back stabilization. Variations: single-leg RDL adds balance/anti-rotation demands; heavy barbell RDL increases grip and scapular stabilization requirements.

reasoning: The movement is a hip-dominant hinge pattern: primary motion occurs at the hip with controlled hip flexion during the descent and hip extension on the ascent in the sagittal plane. reasoning: Primary action is a hip-dominant hinge: powerful hip extension from a raised bar position with limited knee flexion. reasoning: Terminology is ambiguous, but in an Olympic-weightlifting context 'rack delivery' most commonly refers to the sequence of pulling the bar/implement into the front-rack region (triple extension and upward force generation) followed by receiving/placing it in the rack (a front-rack catch which often involves a partial/full squat). exercise: Reach Jumps (arms overhead) — follow sandbag tosses

reasoning: Cyclic lower-limb pedaling primarily involves sagittal-plane hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension consistent with a locomotion/gait pattern performed in a seated, non–weightbearing posture. The concentric drive phase is produced by knee extension and hip extension (quadriceps, glutes) and plantarflexion (calf), while the recovery phase uses hip flexors and knee/ankle flexors. reasoning: Primary motion is hip extension in the sagittal plane as the rear/working leg is driven posteriorly. reasoning: Rack pulls are a partial-deadlift movement that primarily produces hip extension (posterior chain) with concurrent spinal/trunk extension to bring the torso upright while the hands maintain a pull on the bar. reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane against a pronated grip. The shoulder girdle and scapula act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm; the wrists and forearm extensors/flexors stabilize the bar in an extended/neutral position. Variations: EZ-bar or dumbbell reverse curls produce similar pattern; preacher or seated variations reduce shoulder stabilization demands.

reasoning: The dead hang is primarily an overhead, gravity-loaded hold from the hands—the body is suspended while the shoulders are placed in an overhead position and the elbows are extended. The primary mechanical demand is an isometric vertical pull through the hands (grip) and shoulder complex resisting downward translation; there is axial traction of the spine. Muscle contractions are largely isometric rather than concentric. Scapular and rotator-cuff stabilizers, plus forearm finger flexors, maintain the hold and shoulder integrity; the core and spinal extensors provide postural stabilization and resist excessive spinal flexion/rounding.

reasoning: This plyometric drill is best characterized as a unilateral sagittal-plane lunge pattern: the athlete typically loads into a staggered stance (hip and knee flexion) then performs an explosive concentric push with the front (or drive) leg to return to the starting stance. reasoning: Primary movement is lateral locomotion (side-stepping) produced by hip abduction/adduction in the frontal plane. reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane performed with the upper arm fixed on a preacher pad. The pronated (reverse) bar grip biases the brachialis and brachioradialis over the biceps brachii. reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane against resistance from the cable. The shoulder complex and scapula act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm; the core provides general torso stability while standing. reasoning: Reverse flyes are primarily a horizontal pulling movement of the shoulder girdle. The primary joint action is shoulder horizontal abduction (often described functionally as scapular retraction/shoulder horizontal extension) in the transverse plane, produced by the posterior deltoid and scapular retractors. The scapulothoracic joint actively retracts/adducts the scapulae while the elbows remain relatively stable (slight flexion). The spine (thoracic region) and core act isometrically to maintain a fixed torso position and resist flexion. Therefore the dominant pattern is PULL with significant scapular stabilization demands.
notes: Variations (prone on bench, seated bent-over, single-arm cable or band) change torso support and stabilization demands but not the primary horizontal-pull pattern. Asymmetric single-arm variations add anti-rotation stabilization requirements.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane posterior pelvic tilt and lumbar spine flexion that lifts the pelvis and lower thorax toward the hips; secondary hip flexion (bringing knees/chest) assists the motion. The movement is produced mainly by concentric shortening of the rectus abdominis and oblique complex causing posterior pelvic rotation and spinal flexion, with the iliopsoas/rectus femoris contributing to hip flexion when the pelvis/lower limb are elevated. Stabilization requires isometric control from the deep abdominals and pelvic stabilizers to control the pelvis and limit excessive lumbar extension at the start and end of the repetition.

reasoning: Primary joint actions occur at the glenohumeral joint: transverse-plane horizontal abduction (reverse fly component) combined with external rotation of the humerus. reasoning: Primary movement is hip extension in the sagittal plane as the legs lift posteriorly from a flexed/hanging position. reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane (curling the plate toward the shoulder) with a pronated (reverse) grip. The wrists often extend/are loaded in extension due to the reverse grip, and the shoulders/scapulae act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm. Core and thoracic posture are isometrically maintained for an upright position.
primary_muscles: biceps brachii (short head, reduced vs supinated curl)
notes: Reverse/pronated grip shifts emphasis toward brachioradialis and brachialis and increases wrist extensor loading. Can be performed bilateral or single-arm with a plate or bar; asymmetric single-arm variation introduces anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion against band resistance with a pronated (reverse) grip — an isolated pulling action at the elbow in the sagittal plane. The pronated hand position biases the brachioradialis and brachialis over the biceps. The shoulder and scapular muscles act isometrically to stabilize the humerus; wrist extensors maintain wrist position; core/spine stabilizers maintain posture. Because the prime mover action is elbow flexion (a pulling action), the correct pattern classification is PULL.
notes: Pronated grip (reverse curl) emphasizes brachioradialis/brachialis. Bands increase tension through ROM; control of eccentric phase recommended for elbow health. Variations include neutral-grip curls (hammer) or supinated curls (greater biceps involvement). Ensure wrist remains neutral to avoid excessive wrist extensor strain.

reasoning: Reverse lunges are primarily a unilateral sagittal-plane lunge pattern. The primary joint actions during the concentric return are hip extension and knee extension of the stance/front leg; the descent/step-back involves controlled hip and knee flexion. The exercise is driven by the quadriceps extending the knee and the gluteus maximus (with hamstrings assistance) extending the hip to return to standing. The ankle plantarflexors contribute to push-off, while hip abductors (gluteus medius) and core musculature act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and trunk in the frontal and transverse planes. Holding dumbbells bilaterally isometric increases load but does not introduce anti-rotation if loads are symmetric.
notes: Assumes bilateral dumbbells held symmetrically (no anti-rotation). Variations (forward lunge, walking lunge, loaded asymmetrically, or rear-foot elevated) can change emphasis and may add ANTI_ROTATION or CARRY as appropriate. Key coaching cues: step length affects hip vs knee emphasis; maintain knee tracking and upright trunk; ensure stance-leg hip abductors stabilize pelvis.

reasoning: Rhomboids self-myofascial release is primarily a local scapular (scapulothoracic) mobilization targeting rhomboids and mid-trapezius. The primary joint action is scapular retraction/adduction (moving the scapulae toward the spine) in the transverse plane, often combined with small thoracic extension or local segmental mobilization in the sagittal plane. Movement is typically slow/passive or very low-force active protraction/retraction; global limb or lower-body joints are not primary movers. Stabilization is minimal but requires isometric control of the scapular stabilizers and thoracic paraspinals to maintain position and apply pressure safely.
notes: This is a mobility/soft-tissue technique rather than a strength movement; classified as PULL because primary action is scapular retraction. Variations include foam roller, lacrosse ball, or therapist-applied pressure and may include small transverse/rotational movements to target trigger points. Avoid direct pressure on the spinal processes and proceed cautiously with acute shoulder or thoracic pathology.

reasoning: Ring pull-ups are primarily a vertical pulling movement. The primary joint actions are elbow flexion and shoulder extension/adduction in the sagittal plane with concomitant scapulothoracic retraction and depression (scapular movement) to initiate and complete the pull. The lats and teres major produce the shoulder extension/adduction while the biceps, brachialis and brachioradialis drive elbow flexion; rhomboids and middle/lower trapezius perform scapular retraction/depression. The core and spine act isometrically to stabilize the torso against excessive sagittal plane motion and the unstable rings increase demand on scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff for joint control.
notes: Ring instability increases demand on scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff. Grip orientation (neutral vs pronated) alters relative biceps vs brachialis emphasis. Kipping or L-sit variations change hip/spine involvement and may introduce additional movement patterns (dynamic hip drive or anti-extension).

reasoning: Ring pull-ups are a vertical pulling exercise. Primary joint actions are shoulder extension (bringing the humerus down toward the torso) and elbow flexion to elevate the torso toward the rings. Scapulothoracic retraction and slight depression initiate and support the movement. The unstable ring setting increases demand for scapular and core stabilization but does not change the primary pull pattern.
notes: Ring instability increases demand for scapular control and core anti-rotation/anti-flexion; grip orientation (neutral/rotated) alters biceps vs. lat emphasis. Kipping or leg drive variations will add hip/ballistic components but do not change the primary PULL classification for strict ring pull-ups.

reasoning: Rocket Jump is an explosive vertical plyometric movement initiated from a loaded squat position. The primary joint actions are hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane to produce vertical propulsion (classic squat-pattern triple extension). Arms often perform shoulder flexion in the sagittal plane to contribute to momentum, while the thorax and core act isometrically to transfer force and stabilize the spine. On landing the same joints perform eccentric control to absorb force, which is a locomotor/plyometric demand. Therefore the dominant pattern is SQUAT (hip/knee-driven extension) with a locomotion/plyometric component (vertical displacement through space).
notes: Variations include tuck or single-leg rocket jumps (increase unilateral/rotational demands). Emphasize plyometric stretch-shortening cycle; landing mechanics require eccentric strength and ankle/hip/knee stability. If the movement is performed primarily as a forward travel jump, LOCOMOTION becomes more dominant but sagittal triple-extension (SQUAT pattern) remains primary.

reasoning: Primary demand is an isometric pull: the hands/rings support bodyweight and the shoulder girdle and lats act isometrically to hold the humerus overhead (scapular depression and humeral support). Elbows are extended/isometric so no concentric push, but the pulling musculature (lats, teres major, scapular stabilizers) resist downward displacement. The trunk must resist swing and rotation, so anti-rotation/anti-extension core stabilization (obliques, rectus abdominis, erector spinae) is required. Grip/finger flexors produce the contact force. Rings add instability, increasing rotator cuff and scapular stabilizer demand.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion/support (humerus overhead) with scapular depression/stabilization
isometric extension (fixed straight limb supporting load)
isometric anti-rotation and anti-extension (stabilization against swinging/rotation)
neutral/isometric (leg position maintained; may be active if knees tucked/raised)
neutral/isometric (typically extended or flexed but static)

notes: If performed as a passive hang (relaxed shoulders) scapular depression demand is lower; an active hang increases lat/ scapular stabilizer recruitment. Ring instability increases rotator cuff and core anti-rotation demands. Variations (tucked L-hang, leg raises) change movement patterns (add ANTI_ROTATION/HINGE/ROTATION depending on motion).

reasoning: The Rickshaw Carry is primarily a loaded-walk: the athlete holds/controls a load while producing repeated gait cycles. Primary joint actions are cyclical hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane to generate forward locomotion while the shoulder girdle and arms hold the implement isometrically. The trunk acts isometrically to resist forward flexion and control rotation (core and erector spinae). Shoulders/scapulae and forearms provide sustained grip and scapular stabilization. Thus the dominant pattern is a CARRY (loaded walking) with LOCOMOTION mechanics (gait-driven hip/knee/ankle actions); trunk/shoulder work is primarily stabilizing rather than producing large-range joint motions.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / anti-flexion (control of trunk posture)
joint_actions.plane: sagittal (with anti-rotation demand in transverse if asymmetric)

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / scapular depression and neutral shoulder position to hold load

notes: Base classification assumes a bilateral loaded-walk version of the Rickshaw Carry. If the implement/load is strongly asymmetric or carried on one side, add ANTI_ROTATION to reflect increased unilateral trunk anti-rotation/lateral stabilization demand. Variations (yoke-style, shoulder-loaded, two-person frame) change exact shoulder/elbow mechanics but remain CARRY + LOCOMOTION dominant.

reasoning: Primary movement is repeated ankle plantarflexion (and dorsiflexion on the return) in the sagittal plane, which replicates the push-off phase of gait. The ankle joint is the primary mover while the knee and hip show minimal sagittal motion and act mainly to stabilize. Muscles producing the movement are the triceps surae (gastrocnemius, soleus) for plantarflexion and tibialis anterior for controlled dorsiflexion; intrinsic foot muscles and peroneals assist stabilization. Balance and postural control from the glutes, quadriceps and core are required during the rocking/weight-shift.
notes: If performed single-leg or with weight shift, balance and unilateral lower-limb stability demands increase. Seated variation shifts emphasis to soleus. This exercise is an ankle-dominant, gait-like movement rather than a traditional strength pattern like hinge or squat.

reasoning: Primary requirement is isometric upper-limb pushing/weight support through the rings: the arms generate a downward force via elbow extension and scapulothoracic depression to hold the torso off the rings. Concurrently the hips are held in strong hip flexion to maintain the tuck/L-sit position and the trunk (rectus abdominis/obliques) acts isometrically to prevent lumbar collapse (anti-extension). Shoulders and triceps are the primary stabilizers/pushers; hip flexors produce the leg/higher hip position. Because the exercise is predominantly an isometric supported hold where the upper limbs produce the vertical support force, it best maps to a PUSH pattern (vertical pushing/support).

joint_actions.action: flexion (isometric to hold legs in tuck/L position)
flexion (tuck) or extension (if full L-sit) — primarily isometric control
isometric support/partial flexion with scapular depression/stabilization

notes: Rings increase scapular stability demands relative to parallettes; progression from tuck to full L-sit shifts knee action from flexion to extension. This is primarily an isometric vertical push/support with heavy hip-flexor and core demands rather than a conventional limb-driven push movement.

reasoning: Rockups are a core-dominant, sagittal-plane rolling/flexion movement from supine to upright. The primary joint action is spinal (thoracic/lumbar) flexion produced concentrically by the rectus abdominis with assistance from the hip flexors to bring the pelvis/hips toward the ribcage; hips may remain partially flexed rather than producing a classic hip-hinge. Shoulders/arms can assist for momentum or balance but are not primary movers. Stabilization demands include anti-extension control of the lumbar spine and isometric control of the obliques and deep core (transversus abdominis) to control the roll and prevent unwanted rotation or lumbar shear. This movement does not clearly match the provided pattern labels (HINGE, SQUAT, PUSH, PULL, LUNGE, LOCOMOTION, CARRY, ANTI_ROTATION, ROTATION), so no pattern from the available set is assigned.
notes: Does not fit the provided movement-pattern taxonomy because it is primarily a trunk/spine flexion (core) exercise rather than a hip-dominant hinge, push, pull, lunge, squat, carry, rotation, or anti-rotation pattern. If forced to map to the available set, flag for manual review or consider adding a 'SPINE FLEXION / CORE' pattern. Variations (leg position, single-leg rockups, added rotation) can introduce anti-rotation or rotational components.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pulling action: the glenohumeral joint moves into extension/adduction while the elbow flexes to bring the body (or bar) toward the bar/cable. Scapulothoracic retraction and depression occur as the scapulae draw together. The spine and core act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and prevent excessive lumbar flexion/extension during the pull. Therefore the dominant pattern is PULL (vertical pull).
notes: If performed with a kipping/rocking swing (e.g., 'Rocky' style kip), hip drive and momentum add dynamic sagittal-plane hip flexion/extension and reduce the strictly isolated pull quality; strict controlled reps remain textbook vertical PULL.

reasoning: Rope climb is primarily a vertical pulling locomotion task. The dominant joint actions are shoulder extension (pulling the arms down from overhead) and elbow flexion to elevate the torso relative to the rope (vertical PULL). When using the feet/leg wrap technique, the hips and knees perform repeated sagittal-plane extension to push the body upward and transfer load to the lower limbs, producing a locomotion-like sequence. Grip/finger flexors and scapular retractors/depressors (lats, rhomboids, lower traps) generate the pull; the trunk (erector spinae, obliques) and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to stabilize the spine and transfer force. Secondary stabilization includes strong forearm/finger flexor activity for grip and core anti-flexion to maintain posture on the rope.
notes: Technique-dependent variation: strict arm-only climbs increase PULL and upper-body demand (higher lat/biceps and grip emphasis); foot-lock techniques shift work toward hips/quads/glutes and make the movement more of a coordinated vertical LOCOMOTION. Significant grip strength and scapular/trunk stability are required; single-arm or twisted positions may introduce rotational/anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: The rope crunch is primarily a spinal flexion movement in the sagittal plane — the torso curls forward to shorten the anterior trunk. The hands/rope are pulled down to produce or load that spinal flexion, so the external load path is a vertical pull through the upper limbs, but the primary motion is trunk/spine flexion. Shoulders and elbows act mainly to transmit the cable load (isometric/assist), hips are fixed (isometric) in kneeling. Muscles producing the movement are the rectus abdominis and obliques; erector spinae lengthen eccentrically to control flexion. Scapular/shoulder and core stabilization is required to keep force directed through the trunk.
notes: Primary intent is trunk flexion; classification as PULL reflects the cable/rope vertical pull interface. If performed without a cable (bodyweight crunch) one might instead label it as a core/trunk-flexion exercise; rotational or anti-rotation patterns only apply to variant executions (e.g., kneeling cable oblique crunch/rotation).

reasoning: The Romanian Deadlift is primarily a hip-hinge movement performed in the sagittal plane. The dominant joint action is hip flexion during the descent and hip extension during the return, with the knees held in a slight, fixed flexion. The movement is produced mainly by eccentric/concentric length changes of the posterior chain (hamstrings and glutes) while the lumbar extensors maintain a neutral spine isometrically to resist forward flexion. Upper limb involvement is limited to grip and scapular/shoulder stability and does not drive the pattern. Stabilization requirements include isometric trunk/erector spinae activity to prevent spinal flexion, and hip-abductor/hip-stabilizer activity to maintain single-plane motion if performed single‑leg or with asymmetry.

joint_actions.action: isometric trunk stabilization (resists flexion; maintains neutral alignment)

notes: Classic posterior-chain hinge. Variations: single‑leg RDL adds balance and anti‑rotation/hip-stabilizer demand; using heavy load or a trap bar may increase grip/upper-back involvement. If performed with significant knee bend or from the floor, pattern approaches SQUAT or conventional DEADLIFT characteristics respectively.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge in the sagittal plane: the pelvis tilts and the hip flexes eccentrically on the descent and extends concentrically on the ascent. Knees remain in a slight, maintained flexion (minimal movement) so quadriceps are not the primary movers. The spine must be held neutral with strong isometric anti-flexion from the erector spinae and core. Shoulders and elbows act isometrically to hold the load with scapular stabilizers preventing excessive protraction.

joint_actions.action: extension (concentric on ascent, eccentric on descent)
maintained slight flexion (minimal movement; largely isometric)
axial stabilization / anti-flexion (isometric) with controlled trunk flexion/extension
isometric stabilization (scapular depression/retraction to maintain bar/path)

notes: Common variations (barbell, dumbbell, kettlebell) retain hinge classification. Increasing knee bend shifts pattern toward SQUAT/CONVENTIONAL DEADLIFT mechanics. Emphasize hip hinge and neutral spine to target posterior chain and avoid excessive lumbar flexion.

reasoning: Rope jumping is a repetitive vertical propulsion/landing task — primary action is cyclical triple-extension (ankle plantarflexion, knee extension, hip extension) in the sagittal plane to produce upward impulse, followed by sagittal-plane flexion for landing. This fits LOCOMOTION because the body repeatedly generates propulsive force to move the center of mass relative to the base, and it maps to the SQUAT pattern because the primary lower-limb motion is knee/hip flexion-extension under load (bodyweight) with eccentric-absorption on landing. Upper-limb actions (shoulder/elbow/wrist) are low-amplitude rotational/flexion movements to rotate the rope and act as rhythm/timing; the trunk and hip abductors/adductors stabilize frontal plane and control single-leg phases during transition. Stabilization demands include isometric core control to limit excessive lumbar flexion/extension and ankle/knee control to absorb impact.
primary_muscles: shoulder/forearm muscles (deltoids, rotator cuff, wrist flexors/extensors) - rhythm/rotation role

joint_actions.action: small rotational/abduction-adduction motions to turn rope
low-amplitude flexion/extension and pronation/supination for rope control

notes: Plyometric, high-repetition locomotor task. Variations (double-unders, single-leg jumps, high-knee) increase ankle/knee/hip power or unilateral stability demands. Emphasize ankle compliance, knee tracking, and trunk bracing to reduce impact risk.

reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder extension (humeral extension) in the sagittal plane as the straight/near-straight arms pull the rope from an overhead anchor down toward the thighs. Scapulothoracic depression and some retraction/downward rotation accompany the humeral motion to allow full lat engagement. Elbows remain near-extended and act isometrically to transmit force. The trunk and core act isometrically to prevent lumbar hyperextension and maintain a stable torso while the lats and associated scapular depressors produce the movement.
notes: Typically performed on a cable with a high anchor. Keep a slight bend in the elbows, avoid lumbar hyperextension, and cue scapular depression for optimal lat emphasis. Some variations that pull slightly posteriorly may add more horizontal/adduction components, but primary pattern remains a vertical pull.

reasoning: Rowing is a cyclic, compound posterior-chain dominant pull. The drive phase is initiated by powerful hip and knee extension (hip extension + knee extension in the sagittal plane) with the trunk moving from flexion to extension, followed by upper‑body pulling: scapular retraction and elbow flexion to bring the handle to the torso. Primary movers are the legs and posterior chain producing power (hinge-like hip extension) while the lats, rhomboids/traps and biceps execute the pulling action. Core and scapular stabilizers maintain trunk and shoulder position throughout the stroke.

joint_actions.action: extension / horizontal adduction (handle pull toward torso) with scapular retraction

notes: Technique sequencing (legs → hips/trunk → arms) matters: majority of power originates from leg drive and hip extension, with upper body finishing as a horizontal pull. On-water rowing and ergometer differ slightly in stabilization demands; no significant rotation or anti-rotation component in standard symmetric rowing.

reasoning: Rope pulley pulls are primarily a pulling movement where the lifter draws a rope handle toward the body against resistance from a pulley. The primary joint actions are shoulder extension/adduction (bringing the humerus down/back toward the torso) and elbow flexion to draw the hand inward; scapular retraction and (often) depression accompany the pull. These actions place the movement in a pull pattern. Depending on pulley height/setup the primary plane can be sagittal (high-to-low pulldown/vertical pull) or transverse (horizontal row), but the dominant mechanic remains a pull. Stabilization demands include isometric core control (anti-extension/anti-rotation), scapular stabilization by the mid/lower trapezius and rhomboids, and rotator cuff activity to maintain glenohumeral position.

joint_actions.action: extension/adduction (or horizontal extension depending on setup)

notes: Variation in pulley height/handle orientation changes the plane (vertical pulldown vs horizontal row vs face-pull) and secondary emphasis (lats vs posterior delts). Unilateral or offset pulls add notable anti-rotation demands and should be classified additionally as ANTI_ROTATION in those cases.

reasoning: This is a multi-planar glenohumeral circumduction drill: the primary joint action is shoulder (glenohumeral) circumduction, which is a coordinated sequence of flexion/abduction/external rotation followed by extension/adduction/internal rotation across the sagittal, frontal and transverse planes. Scapulothoracic motion (upward rotation/protraction/retraction) accompanies the humeral motion to preserve subacromial space. The elbows are typically extended and act as lever arms but have minimal active movement. Primary movers (deltoids, pecs, lats) produce the large arm arcs while the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids) control joint centration and smooth rotation. Core and thoracic mobility/stability may contribute if the torso moves slightly, but they are secondary.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: minor rotation/extension if torso assists movement

notes: Primarily a mobility/stretching drill for glenohumeral and scapulothoracic joints. Can be performed unilaterally or bilaterally, with a stick/band for guided motion, or with resistance for strengthening. Avoid large arcs if painful or with unstable shoulders; emphasize scapular control and rotator cuff activation.

reasoning: Rowing is a cyclic, multi-joint movement that begins with a powerful leg drive (knee extension) followed by hip extension (posterior chain/horizontal hip hinge) and finishes with trunk extension and an upper-body horizontal pull (scapular retraction and elbow flexion). Primary movers across the cycle are the quadriceps (knee extension) and glute/hamstring complex (hip extension/hinge) producing force into the footplate, and the latissimus dorsi/rhomboids/trapezius and biceps performing the final horizontal pull. Stabilization requirements include trunk/spinal extensors and abdominals to transfer force between lower and upper body (anti-flexion), scapular stabilizers to allow efficient retraction, and forearm/hand muscles for grip endurance.

joint_actions.action: extension (returning from flexed catch to neutral/extended finish)

notes: Cyclic endurance context emphasizes submaximal, repeated hinge + horizontal pull pattern (catch → drive → finish → recovery). Technique phases: leg drive (quadriceps), posterior chain hip extension, then upper-body pull; minimal rotation/anti-rotation unless performed asymmetrically or with technique faults. Foot strap/seat constraints reduce frontal-plane demand.

reasoning: Rowing on an ergometer is a compound, cyclical movement with primary upper-body pulling actions combined with a repeated leg drive. Primary joint actions: shoulder girdle/scapular retraction and shoulder horizontal extension with elbow flexion produce the handle pull (PULL pattern). Simultaneously, repeated knee extension and hip extension (leg drive) generate propulsion and transfer force through the chain, analogous to a loaded knee/hip extension pattern (SQUAT-like mechanics). The spine and core act isometrically to transfer force and maintain posture; shoulders and scapulae stabilize against the pull. Movement occurs primarily in the sagittal and transverse planes (hip/knee/ankle sagittal; shoulder horizontal/transverse; spine sagittal stabilization).
notes: As a warmup the intensity and range are reduced but the same joint actions apply. Emphasis can shift between leg drive (more 'squat-like') and upper-body pull depending on technique; seated constraint reduces pure hinge characteristics compared with deadlift.

reasoning: The rowing erg is primarily a horizontal pull: during the drive the shoulders/scapulae retract and the elbows flex to draw the handle toward the torso (transverse/sagittal planes) — this matches the PULL pattern. Secondary, the drive is initiated by leg extension with hip extension and knee extension producing force transfer through the trunk (hip-dominant component of the drive), which corresponds to a HINGE-like hip extension contribution. Stabilization demands include trunk/erector spinae and core isometric control to transfer leg force to the upper extremity and to maintain posture during the cyclical stroke.
notes: As a cool-down the intensity is low and relative contribution of legs vs. arms can vary (legs-first strokes vs. arms-only). If performed with emphasis on arms/back and minimal leg drive it becomes almost entirely a horizontal PULL. Technique variations (stronger hip drive or restricted knees) can change the balance between HINGE and PULL.

reasoning: Rowing is a coordinated drive and pull. The primary action felt at the handle is a horizontal pull driven by scapular retraction, shoulder extension and elbow flexion. The drive is initiated by the lower body with strong knee extension and concurrent hip extension (posterior chain) transferring force through the trunk to the handle. Movement occurs predominantly in the sagittal plane. Stabilization requires trunk/hip control (to transfer force and prevent excessive lumbar flexion/extension) and scapular stabilization during the pull phase.

joint_actions.action: trunk extension (from flexed catch to more extended finish)

notes: Primarily a horizontal PULL pattern for the upper body combined with lower‑body hip/knee drive (hip-dominant contribution justifies HINGE classification). Ergometer movement is fixed in the sagittal plane and requires isometric core stabilization and scapular control; variations (single-arm, sweep rowing, on-water technique) can add anti-rotation or transverse components.

reasoning: Rowing on an ergometer is primarily a horizontal pulling pattern: the handle is drawn toward the torso via scapular retraction and elbow flexion while seated. The power phase is initiated by forceful lower‑body extension (knee extension with concurrent hip extension) transferring through a relatively rigid trunk to the arms — thus significant hip extension (hinge-like action) and posterior chain contribution are present. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane for the lower body (knee, hip, ankle) and sagittal/transverse for the upper body (elbow flexion and shoulder horizontal extension/scapular retraction). Core and spinal erectors act isometrically to transfer force and stabilize the spine; scapular stabilizers maintain shoulder girdle position during the pull. Because the dominant action is pulling the handle horizontally, PULL is primary and HINGE is a major secondary/primary lower‑body contributor.
notes: Technique variants alter pattern weighting: a legs-only emphasis increases knee-dominant drive (more 'SQUAT'-like mechanics), a strong body swing increases hip extension (greater HINGE). As a conditioning interval, movement is repetitive with emphasis on coordinated lower-to-upper transfer; no significant rotational or carry/anti-rotation components unless performed asymmetrically.

reasoning: Rowing is a cyclic compound movement that combines a primary horizontal pull of the handle with a powerful hip-driven leg/torso extension. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane for the lower body (knee extension, hip extension) and trunk extension, while the upper body produces a horizontal pull via scapular retraction/shoulder extension and elbow flexion. Legs (quadriceps) initiate the drive, hips/glutes and hamstrings complete extension (hinge), and lats/rhomboids/traps and biceps perform the horizontal pull. Core and spinal erectors stabilize the trunk through the stroke and resist excessive flexion; scapular stabilizers control shoulder motion.

joint_actions.action: trunk extension (from flexed catch to open finish) with notable hip hinge

notes: If performed on an ergometer the stroke emphasizes leg drive then hip/torso swing into the pull; as a warmup cadence may prioritize leg/cardio work with lighter upper-body loading. Technique variations (e.g., single-arm cable row drills) may change emphasis toward anti-rotation or unilateral pull patterns.

reasoning: Rowing is a cyclic full-body drive where primary force transfer is a horizontal pull of the handle combined with lower‑body hip/knee extension. Primary joint actions: powerful knee extension (quadriceps) and hip extension (gluteus maximus/hamstrings) produce the initial drive (hinge/leg drive), followed by trunk extension and scapular retraction/shoulder extension with elbow flexion to bring the handle to the torso (horizontal PULL). The spine and core act isometrically to transfer force from legs through the trunk; the scapular muscles (rhomboids/traps) and lats produce the horizontal pull while biceps assist elbow flexion. Stabilization requirements include anti‑flexion/anti‑rotation of the trunk, scapular stabilization during the pull, and ankle/foot stability during leg drive.
notes: Rowing is cyclic and proportions of leg vs trunk vs arm contribution vary by technique (legs-first drive). Single‑arm or unilateral variations introduce anti‑rotation demands; arms‑only or legs‑only segments emphasize PULL or HINGE/SQUAT-like components respectively.

reasoning: The rowing erg is primarily a horizontal pulling action of the upper body (scapular retraction and elbow flexion) against the handle, classifying it as a PULL. The stroke is driven initially and largely by lower-limb extension — knee and hip extension with contribution from ankle plantarflexion — which is a hip-extension-dominant, hinge-like action of the posterior chain, so HINGE is a secondary pattern. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane for the lower limbs and spine (hip/knee/ankle extension) while the shoulder/scapula and elbows perform transverse/sagittal plane horizontal pull (scapular retraction, shoulder extension) and elbow flexion. Stabilization requires isometric trunk control (erector spinae, abdominals) to transfer leg drive to the handle and scapular stabilizers to control the pull.
notes: As a warm-up, resistance is typically low and cadence high. Technique is a coordinated sequence: legs (drive), body swing, then arms (finish). Movement emphasis may shift by coaching (more leg vs more arm); seated fixed position reduces rotational demands (minimal ANTI_ROTATION).

reasoning: Rowing is a cyclic, multi-joint movement where the primary organized action is a horizontal pull of the handle (scapular retraction/shoulder extension and elbow flexion) while the primary power source is a leg-driven extension sequence (knee and hip extension with ankle plantarflexion). Thus the movement combines a horizontal PULL (upper-body scapular/arm pulling) with a bilateral leg extension pattern functionally similar to a SQUAT-style drive. The trunk/spine extends from a flexed to a more upright position and core and spinal erectors act isometrically to transfer force from the legs to the handle; scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the shoulder during the pull.
notes: On an ergometer the timing is legs -> hips -> arms (leg-dominant drive). Technique variations (single-arm row, rib-cage emphasis, or very torso-dominant pulls) can shift relative pattern weighting toward more PULL or HINGE-like mechanics. Maintain neutral spine and scapular control during warm-up rowing.

reasoning: Rowing is a compound, seated horizontal pull where force is initiated through a leg-driven hip/knee extension (hinge-like hip extension and knee extension in the sagittal plane) and finished by trunk extension and a horizontal pulling action of the arms (scapular retraction/shoulder extension with elbow flexion).
