Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension producing drive, followed by spinal extension and shoulder/ elbow actions that complete the horizontal pull. Stabilization demands include trunk and pelvic control (anti-flexion) and scapular stability during the pull; grip and forearm isometric control are also required.

joint_actions.action: extension (trunk opening from flexed to neutral/extended)

notes: Technique emphasis: drive primarily with legs (hip and knee extension), then body swing (spine extension), then arms (horizontal pull). Variations (single-arm oar, rowing with trunk rotation) can add anti-rotation/rotation demands; stationary ergometer reduces frontal/transverse plane demands compared with on-water rowing.

reasoning: This warmup combines a rowing-style pull and shadowboxing punches. The rowing component is primarily a sagittal-plane leg drive (knee and hip extension) with a finishing upper-body pull (scapular retraction, elbow flexion) — a horizontal/near-sagittal pull pattern. Shadowboxing is dominated by repeated horizontal push actions (shoulder horizontal adduction/elbow extension) with transverse-plane trunk rotation to generate force. Primary movers (legs and lats/biceps for the row; pecs/delts/triceps and obliques for punches) produce the movement while the core and scapular stabilizers provide dynamic stabilization.
notes: This entry covers a mixed warmup; if performed separately, rowing maps primarily to PULL (+ lower-body drive/hinge-like actions) and shadowboxing maps primarily to PUSH + ROTATION. Intensity is typically low and core stability/scapular control are important for technique.

reasoning: Running is a cyclical gait task: primary joint actions are repetitive sagittal-plane hip flexion/extension, knee flexion/extension and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion producing forward propulsion and swing. Pelvis and trunk undergo transverse rotation and frontal-plane hip stabilization during single-leg stance, requiring isometric anti-rotation from the core and hip abductors to control rotation and frontal-plane collapse. Arm swing involves shoulder/elbow sagittal motion but is accessory to locomotion.

joint_actions.action: axial rotation (counter-rotation with limbs) and trunk control

notes: Variations (sprint vs jog, incline, barefoot, loaded) change emphasis (e.g., greater ankle plantarflexion and hip power in sprinting). Single-leg stance phases demand increased hip abductor and core anti-rotation control. If running is performed with an asymmetric load, ANTI_ROTATION demands increase further.

reasoning: Running is a cyclical locomotor pattern driven primarily by repeated sagittal-plane hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension (swing and push-off) with coupled transverse rotation of the pelvis and trunk. Primary joint actions: hip extension during stance/push-off and hip flexion during swing; knee extension during stance and knee flexion during swing; ankle plantarflexion for push-off and dorsiflexion for swing/foot clearance. Rotation of the pelvis and thorax in the transverse plane occurs to aid leg swing and arm counterbalance. Stabilization requirements: frontal-plane hip stability (gluteus medius) maintains pelvis level during single-leg stance; core (erector spinae/obliques) controls trunk posture and coordinates transverse rotation. Arm/shoulder movement is rhythmic and assists counter-rotation but is not primary for propulsive work.
notes: Variations (sprinting, incline, uneven terrain, added load) change muscle emphasis and stabilization demands. Loaded or asymmetric running would introduce CARRY and/or ANTI_ROTATION. Road/pavement running is primarily cyclical locomotion with pronounced transverse rotation and single‑leg stance stability requirements.

reasoning: This combined warmup includes two distinct movement emphases. Rowing is primarily a horizontal pull pattern: coordinated knee extension and hip drive (sagittal) transfer force to the handle while the shoulders retract and the elbows flex to pull (scapular retraction/shoulder horizontal extension and elbow flexion). Shadowboxing primarily produces horizontal pushing actions (rapid shoulder horizontal flexion/press and elbow extension) combined with transverse-plane trunk rotation to generate punch force. Stabilization demands include spinal control (isometric trunk bracing during the rowing stroke and dynamic rotational control during punching), scapular stability for force transfer, and lower-limb stabilization for the rowing drive.
notes: This entry covers two warmup modalities together; rowing is dominated by a horizontal PULL with significant lower-body drive (may also be classified as HINGE emphasis if focus is on hip drive), while shadowboxing emphasizes horizontal PUSH and transverse ROTATION. Specific pattern weighting depends on technique and emphasis (e.g., power-heavy rowing increases lower-body/hinge contribution; rotational punches increase ROTATION demand).

reasoning: This entry covers two light-cardio modalities. Rowing: primary action is a seated/compound horizontal pull — leg drive (knee extension → hip extension) initiates the stroke and is followed by trunk extension and a handle pull (scapular retraction and elbow flexion) to the torso. Primary movers are posterior chain and upper-back/arm muscles; core and lats/traps stabilize the spine and scapula. Shadowboxing (light intensity): primary actions are repetitive horizontal pushes (shoulder horizontal flexion/extension and elbow extension) with substantial transverse-plane trunk rotation and anti-rotation control to generate and transfer force; lower-body and footwork provide locomotor base and balance. Stabilization requirements for both include isometric core control (spine stability and intra-abdominal pressure), shoulder girdle stability (scapular control), and lower-limb balance during dynamic footwork or leg drive.
notes: This classification treats two separate light-cardio modalities together: rowing is primarily a PULL-dominant, lower-to-upper kinetic-chain stroke with secondary hip/knee drive; shadowboxing is PUSH-dominant with pronounced transverse rotation and dynamic balance/locomotor demands. Intensity and technique change the relative contribution of patterns (e.g., heavy rowing increases HINGE/leg-drive emphasis; advanced boxing increases rotation and anti-rotation demand).

reasoning: Running on a treadmill is a repetitive gait/locomotion task. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: cyclical hip extension (stance) and hip flexion (swing), knee extension (late swing/early stance) and knee flexion (swing), and ankle plantarflexion (push-off) and dorsiflexion (swing/landing). There is also transverse plane rotation of the pelvis/trunk and sagittal shoulder flexion/extension during arm swing as secondary motions. Stabilization demands include unilateral single-leg support phases requiring hip abductor (gluteus medius) and core isometric control to maintain pelvic and trunk alignment, plus ankle stabilizers for foot placement and balance.

joint_actions.action: extension/flexion (cyclical: extension in stance, flexion in swing)
extension/flexion (force absorption in early stance, flexion during swing)
axial rotation (contralateral trunk/pelvis rotation with gait)

notes: Treadmill running is classic locomotion. Variations (incline, speed, sprint vs jog) alter relative muscle demands (e.g., incline increases hip extensor demand, sprinting increases ankle plantarflexor and hip extensor power). Overground gait nuances (wind, terrain) differ but pattern remains LOCOMOTION.

reasoning: The runner's stretch is performed from a split-stance/half-kneeling lunge position. Primary joint positions mirror a lunge: the lead limb is in hip flexion and knee flexion (sagittal plane) while the trailing limb is placed into relative hip extension. The position is largely isometric (stretch) but the primary mechanical pattern is a lunge because the hip and knee angles and loading emulate a static lunge position. Muscles around the front hip/knee (gluteus maximus, quadriceps, hamstrings) act isometrically to support the position, while the iliopsoas/rectus femoris of the trailing side is being lengthened (hip flexor stretch). Core/erector spinae maintain upright torso and pelvic position for stability.
notes: Commonly called a runner's lunge; if performed as a standing hamstring reach variant (leg elevated on step) the primary pattern could be categorized as a hinge-like hamstring stretch. Watch front knee alignment over the ankle; variations include active/loaded versions that increase stabilization demands.

reasoning: Primary action is loaded locomotion — walking while holding a sandbag oriented anteriorly in a 'bear hug' position, so the dominant movement pattern is CARRY. During gait the hips, knees and ankles perform cyclical sagittal-plane extension/flexion to produce forward progression. The anterior load creates trunk and shoulder demand: the core must isometrically resist trunk flexion and rotational perturbations during single-leg stance phases, producing an ANTI_ROTATION/anti-flexion stabilization requirement. Upper body performs isometric shoulder flexion/adduction and elbow flexion to retain the load against the chest; scapular/pecal musculature and forearm grip maintain the hold while lower limbs drive locomotion.
notes: If performed asymmetrically (off-center bag or single-arm variation) the anti-rotation demand increases. Speed, load and surface (uneven terrain) will increase balance and single-leg stabilization requirements. If stationary (no walking) classify as anterior-loaded isometric carry with similar stabilization demands.

reasoning: Primary action is loaded walking (carry + locomotion): repeated single-leg stance and step initiation produce hip extension and hip flexion in the sagittal plane with knee and ankle flexion/extension. The sandbag held in a bilateral anterior 'bear hug' position creates an anterior flexion moment on the spine and variable transverse moments during single-leg phases, requiring isometric anti-rotation and anti-flexion from the core. Upper limb joints (shoulder horizontal adduction/neck of arms, elbow flexion) act isometrically to secure the load. Primary movers for propulsion are the gluteus maximus and hamstrings (hip extension) and the quadriceps (knee extension) while the core (rectus abdominis, obliques, erector spinae) and hip abductors stabilize the pelvis and resist rotation.
notes: Anterior loaded march increases spinal flexion moment; maintain upright torso. Single-leg phases increase pelvic/rotational stabilization demand—progress by adding distance, tempo, unilateral variations, or uneven surfaces. If load is highly asymmetric or held to one side, ANTI_ROTATION demand increases further.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal push from a supine or reclined position: shoulder horizontal adduction (bringing the load away from the chest) and elbow extension produce the pressing motion. The chest (pectoralis major), anterior deltoids and triceps generate the concentric force. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower/mid traps) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the shoulder girdle while the trunk and hips isometrically stabilize the torso against translational and rotational forces—instability of a sandbag increases demand on stabilizers but does not change the primary pattern.
notes: Typical classification is horizontal PUSH. Unstable or asymmetrically loaded sandbag variations increase demand on anti-rotation/anti-flexion stabilizers and, if performed single-arm or offset, should include ANTI_ROTATION in the movement list.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal pushing pattern: shoulder moves in horizontal adduction (transverse plane) while the elbow extends (sagittal plane) to press the load away from the chest. The lifter must also maintain scapulothoracic position (isometric scapular retraction/stabilization) and a neutral trunk (isometric core). With a sandbag, instability can increase demand on stabilizers but the primary movement pattern remains a horizontal PUSH.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / controlled protraction on press

notes: Pause on chest increases time under tension and reduces elastic rebound; a sandbag's shape/instability elevates demand on scapular stabilizers and core. If the load is asymmetric or single-arm, add ANTI_ROTATION. If performed standing or with leg drive variation, note additional pattern involvement.

reasoning: Primary demand is an anterior-loaded isometric hold: the shoulders/arms maintain a bear-hug (isometric shoulder flexion and horizontal adduction with elbow flexion) while the trunk resists forward flexion produced by the anterior load (isometric anti-flexion/extension). Hips, knees and ankles provide isometric lower-limb support to maintain upright posture. Although there is no locomotion, this is functionally a static carry pattern (anterior load hold) emphasizing load carriage and core anti-flexion/stabilization rather than concentric push/pull movement. Stabilization requirements include strong isometric activation of the anterior and posterior core (rectus abdominis, obliques, erector spinae) to prevent trunk collapse, scapulothoracic muscles and shoulder adductors to secure the load, and grip/forearm musculature.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion and horizontal adduction (holds bag against chest)
isometric extension / anti-flexion (resists trunk flexion from anterior load)

notes: This is a static anterior carry/hold. If performed while walking, add LOCOMOTION; if load is asymmetric or single-arm variation is used, include ANTI_ROTATION for lateral/rotational stabilization. Variation in bag position (higher/lower) will alter trunk moment and relative core demand.

reasoning: Primary movement is a sagittal-plane closed-chain squat: hip and knee flexion during descent and hip and knee extension during ascent while the lifter sits to/stands from a box. The posterior and anterior thigh musculature (gluteus maximus, hamstrings, quadriceps) produce the primary joint torques. The spine and core act isometrically to resist flexion and maintain torso position under the sandbag load; upper back/shoulder musculature may isometrically stabilize the load depending on sandbag placement (front bear-hug vs. back position). Ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion occurs to allow depth and push-off. Stabilization requirements include trunk anti-flexion, knee tracking, and balance/controlled descent to the box.
notes: Load placement changes secondary demands: front/bear-hug sandbag increases anterior trunk shear and requires greater core/upper-back isometric stabilization; back-positioned sandbag more closely mimics a barbell back squat. Box height alters depth and relative hip vs. knee contribution. Asymmetric or single-shoulder sandbag variations would add ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a bilateral sagittal-plane squat: hip and knee flexion to descend and hip and knee extension to stand. Ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion contributes to the rise. The sandbag is held in an anterior 'bearhug' position, creating an anterior load moment that the posterior chain and trunk must overcome; the shoulders and elbows act isometrically to secure the load. Primary movers are the quadriceps and gluteus maximus producing knee and hip extension respectively, with hamstrings assisting hip extension. The erector spinae and anterior core (rectus abdominis/obliques) act isometrically to resist trunk flexion from the anterior load, and the upper chest/shoulder girdle and forearms maintain the hold. Stabilization requirements include trunk anti-flexion (sagittal stability) and knee/ankle joint stability throughout the movement.
primary_muscles: shoulder girdle/pectoralis major and forearms (isometric load carry)

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion (holding sandbag close to chest)

notes: Functionally a loaded front/goblet-style squat. Anterior loading increases trunk flexion moment and core demand; individuals with limited shoulder mobility or poor anterior core endurance may alter posture. Variations: wider stance, deeper squat, or converting to a bearhug carry adds LOCOMOTION/CARRY elements.

reasoning: Primary movement is a sagittal-plane squat: hip and knee flexion on descent and extension on ascent against a centrally held anterior load (sandbag in bearhug). Quadriceps drive knee extension, gluteus maximus and hamstrings drive hip extension. The anterior bearhug load shifts the center of mass forward, increasing trunk flexor moment so the posterior chain and trunk extensors act to resist trunk collapse (isometric spinal stabilization). Upper body muscles (pecs, biceps, anterior deltoids, traps) act isometrically to secure the sandbag but do not change the primary pattern. Stabilization requirements include core/bracing to resist excessive spinal flexion and maintain upright torso, and ankle/foot control for balance onto the box.
notes: Anterior bearhug loading increases trunk and hip extensor demand versus a traditional back squat; box contact reduces hip/knee travel and can emphasize posterior chain or provide consistent depth. If performed as a walking or marching variant, add CARRY and possibly ANTI_ROTATION for asymmetry.

reasoning: Sandbag cleans are a compound explosive lift initiated from a hip-dominant hinge (deadlift/clean pull) producing triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) in the sagittal plane to project the load upward, followed by an upper-body pull (scapular elevation/shoulder flexion and elbow flexion) to receive the bag in a front/rack position. Primary movers are posterior chain muscles producing hip/knee extension (hinge) and scapulothoracic/shoulder musculature producing the vertical/high pull. The trunk and scapular stabilizers work isometrically to transfer force and control the unstable sandbag during the pull and catch. Depending on whether the lifter receives in a power or full squat, a deeper knee/hip flexion (SQUAT) can be a secondary component, but the dominant mechanics are hinge + pull.

joint_actions.action: extension (concentric during triple extension; flexion if receiving in squat)
flexion/abduction (to bring load to front rack/high pull)
flexion (to pull/catch the bag into rack)
elevation/retraction and upward rotation (during high pull and catch)

notes: Variation: power clean (no deep squat) emphasizes HINGE+PULL; full squat clean introduces SQUAT as a secondary pattern. Sandbag instability increases demand on grip, scapular stabilizers, and core (anti-flexion/anti-rotation). Single-arm or asymmetric sandbag variations would add ANTI_ROTATION and greater unilateral shoulder demand.

reasoning: The sandbag clean is initiated with a hip-dominant hinge to load the posterior chain followed by an explosive triple-extension (hip/knee/ankle) and an active vertical pull (shrug + upward force) to elevate the load. The finish/rack to chest requires rapid elbow flexion and shoulder positioning to receive the sandbag. Primary movement occurs in the sagittal plane (hip/knee/ankle extension, shoulder/ elbow flexion) with frontal/transverse demands for load stabilization due to the irregular/soft sandbag. The posterior chain (glutes/hamstrings/erector spinae) produces the hip extension; calves contribute plantarflexion; upper traps and scapulothoracic muscles drive the shrug/pull; elbow flexors and anterior deltoid position the load at the chest. Core and scapular stabilizers work isometrically to control trunk and shoulder position during the explosive phase and catch.
notes: If the clean is caught in a deep squat or with a pronounced dip under the load, a secondary SQUAT pattern may be present. Sandbag inconsistency/asymmetry increases anti-rotation and stabilization demands compared with a rigid barbell clean. Variations (hang clean vs. ground clean) change the relative contribution of hip hinge vs. initial pull.

reasoning: The sandbag get-up is a multi-phase, unilateral loaded transition from supine to standing. Primary joint actions begin with a hip bridge/hip extension (hinge) to create posterior chain drive, progress through hip and knee extension during the transition to kneeling/standing that uses lunge-like mechanics, and—when performed with a single-arm or offset load—require strong isometric anti-rotation of the trunk and shoulder to resist transverse-plane torque. The shoulders and scapular stabilizers provide isometric support of the load (often overhead or anterior) while the core/obliques resist rotation; glutes/hamstrings generate concentric hip extension; quadriceps provide knee extension during the stand. Secondary stabilization demands include ankle/foot stability and scapular/rotator cuff control.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (often flexion/abduction when held overhead)
joint_actions.plane: frontal/sagittal (primary vertical load), transverse for rotational control

joint_actions.action: isometric support (often partial flexion to lock load)

notes: Movement classification assumes common unilateral/offset sandbag get-up (similar to Turkish get-up). If the sandbag is centered on the chest and lifted bilaterally without unilateral load, ANTI_ROTATION contribution is reduced and classification could be HINGE + LUNGE mainly. If the exercise finishes with an active press, include PUSH for dynamic shoulder extension.

reasoning: The sandbag get-up is a multi-step movement that primarily uses hip extension/bridge mechanics (HINGE) to rise from supine and transition to standing, while the asymmetric, loaded position demands isometric anti-rotational core control (ANTI_ROTATION) to resist transverse-plane torque. The final transition to upright frequently resolves through a split-stance or stand-from-lunge pattern, involving knee extension and single-leg support (LUNGE). Primary joint actions are hip extension (bridge/drive), knee extension (stand/lunge), and sustained shoulder elevation/stabilization; the spine and obliques act isometrically to prevent rotation, and the shoulder girdle stabilizes the load overhead or anteriorly during the sequence.
notes: Aborted attempts may reduce expression of the lunge/stand phase but still require hip-driven bridging and strong anti-rotation stabilization. If the load is held overhead vs anterior/bear-hug, shoulder stabilization demand changes (more vertical PUSH/stability if overhead). Unilateral/asymmetric sandbags increase ANTI_ROTATION demand.

reasoning: The sandbag get-up is a multi-stage transitional movement whose primary mechanical demand is producing hip extension from a bridged/half-kneeling position into full standing (hinge-driven). Throughout the sequence the torso and shoulder complex must resist rotation and lateral flexion from an offset/load position (anti-rotation) as the load is transferred and the body moves under it. Secondary actions include knee extension to rise, occasional shoulder elevation/pressing or isometric overhead/loaded support depending on how the duffel is held, and transverse-plane rolling/torso control during the initial phases. Stabilization demands are high: obliques and deep core muscles prevent rotation, scapular stabilizers and deltoids stabilize the load, and lower-limb extensors produce the stand.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization and sometimes vertical/horizontal push depending on load position
variable (isometric support or extension if pressing the bag)

notes: Variation-dependent: single-arm or overhead variations increase anti-rotation and vertical-push demands (may add PUSH to classification). Bilateral anterior chest hold reduces transverse stress and shifts emphasis more to pure hinge/stand. The exercise is multi-planar and highly dependent on how the duffel is gripped/positioned during the sequence.

reasoning: The exercise is dominated by active transverse-plane rotation of the spine (thoracic principally, with some lumbar contribution) as the sandbag is moved around the torso. Secondary joint actions include shoulder girdle movement to transport/control the bag and lower‑limb adjustments to assist rolling. Primary movement is trunk axial rotation produced by the obliques and deep trunk rotators; shoulders and scapular stabilizers reposition the load while hips/knees provide bracing and positional changes. Stabilization demands include anti‑extension/anti‑shear of the lumbar spine and isometric scapular control.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction/abduction and repositioning of load

notes: Focus is on thoracic rotation and trunk control; unilateral or offset loading increases anti‑rotation demand and may warrant inclusion of ANTI_ROTATION for those variants. Caution with heavy loads and lumbar rotation — cue thoracic mobility and scapular control. Variations: single‑arm sandbag increases asymmetry (add ANTI_ROTATION), band resisted or bodyweight regressions increase/decrease intensity.

reasoning: Primary action is a hip hinge pattern: the hips flex as the torso tilts forward and then extend to return upright (sagittal plane). The lumbar/thoracic spine undergoes controlled flexion eccentrically and extension concentrically, with the erector spinae working to control trunk position. Knees remain in slight flexion but act mainly as a hinge/stabilizer rather than producing large sagittal motion. Holding the sandbag on the upper back/shoulders requires scapular/shoulder girdle and core isometric stabilization to maintain load position and a neutral spine.
notes: Variation in sandbag placement (high on traps vs. anterior bear-hug) alters trunk demand and may add anterior load tolerance; maintain neutral spine and hip-dominant movement to avoid excessive lumbar flexion. Sandbag shifts and instability increase core stabilization demand but do not change the primary pattern from HINGE.

reasoning: Primary phase begins with a hip hinge/hip extension (triple extension) to propel the sandbag off the ground (sagittal plane). The transition to the shoulder uses upward pull mechanics with elbow flexion and shoulder elevation/upper-flexion to bring the bag into the shoulder pocket (vertical/near-sagittal pull). If the bag is shouldered to one side (typical), the torso and obliques must resist rotation and lateral flexion during the receive and stabilization phase — producing an anti-rotation/isometric core demand. Secondary stabilizers include spinal extensors and scapular stabilizers.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (with transverse/rotation component if transferring to one side)

joint_actions.action: flexion (to pull and tuck into shoulder)

notes: If performed as a two-handed symmetrical cradle to center shoulder, anti-rotation demand is reduced and movement is primarily HINGE + PULL. Single-shoulder transfers increase rotational/isometric core demands. Tabata implementation increases metabolic/conditioning stress and may accentuate technique breakdown — cue trunk bracing and hip-drive to protect the lumbar spine.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal push: the shoulder performs horizontal adduction (transverse plane) while the elbow extends (sagittal plane) to drive the sandbag away from the torso. Pec major and anterior deltoid produce the horizontal pushing motion, triceps complete elbow extension, and scapular protractors (serratus anterior) assist the end range. The spine and core act isometrically to stabilize the torso against the anteriorly directed load and any translational/rotational tendency from the unstable sandbag. Grip/forearm muscles and rotator cuff work to stabilize the shoulder and load orientation.
notes: Shape/instability of cylindrical or duffel sandbags increases demand on scapular stabilizers, rotator cuff, and grip. Single‑arm or offset variants introduce significant anti-rotation/anti-lateral flexion demands (would add ANTI_ROTATION to movements in those cases). Lying (bench) vs standing changes core stabilization demands but remains a horizontal push pattern.

reasoning: Sandbag get-ups follow the Turkish‑get‑up style progression: initial bridge/hip drive (primary hip extension — hinge pattern) to create elevation, then transition into a half‑kneel and stand (primary knee extension/hip extension — lunge/stand pattern). The load is typically held off‑center or on one side/overhead which requires strong isometric trunk control to resist rotation and lateral flexion (anti‑rotation). The shoulders and upper limb act primarily as an isometric stabilizer of the load while the lower limb produces sagittal-plane extension to stand. Stabilization demands include single‑leg balance/anti‑abduction from the stance limb and transverse‑plane resistance to rotation from the obliques and rotator cuff.

joint_actions.action: isometric flexion/abduction (load stabilization, often overhead or front‑loaded)
isometric flexion/extension (depends on hold; supports and stabilizes load)

notes: If the sandbag is held centrally with both hands (bearhug) anti‑rotation demand is reduced; if held unilateral or overhead, anti‑rotation and shoulder stabilization demands increase. Variations emphasize different patterns (overhead get‑up increases shoulder/anti‑rotation; two‑handed chest get‑up increases primarily hinge/lunge). Strongman style awkward/offset load increases stabilization requirements compared with a kettlebell Turkish get‑up.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal pulling action: scapular retraction/adduction combined with elbow flexion to bring the sandbag toward the torso. The humerus undergoes shoulder extension/adduction components while the scapulae retract; the elbow flexors produce axial forearm movement. The torso/hips are typically held in a static bent-over or supine/inverted posture so the posterior chain and core act isometrically to maintain spine alignment. Therefore the dominant pattern is a PULL (horizontal pull) with spinal and hip stabilization.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (hinge/neutral position to maintain torso angle)

notes: If performed single-arm or with asymmetrical loading, ANTI_ROTATION should be added due to increased rotational/stability demand. Body angle (more horizontal = more bodyweight relative load) and grip/handle position modifies muscle emphasis. Bent-over variations increase hip/hamstring demand for stabilization.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip hinge: the torso pivots forward about the hips in the sagittal plane driving hip flexion on the descent and hip extension on the ascent. The knees remain in a slight, fixed flexion (minimal motion) while the lumbar/thoracic spine undergoes trunk flexion/extension to follow the hip hinge. The sandbag held in a front 'hug' position is an anterior load that increases the flexion moment at the hips and spine; the arms/shoulders hold the load isometrically. Primary movers producing the motion are the gluteus maximus and hamstrings generating hip extension and the erector spinae controlling trunk extension; the core (rectus abdominis/obliques) and thoracic extensors act isometrically to stabilize the spine, and the shoulders/arms act isometrically to retain the sandbag.

joint_actions.action: flexion on descent / extension on ascent (hip hinge)
trunk flexion on descent / extension on ascent (controlled)
flexion and horizontal adduction (isometric hold of sandbag)

notes: Variation of a standard Good Morning with anterior load. Emphasize neutral spine and hip hinge mechanics; anterior load increases low-back and hip extensor demands. If load is asymmetric or carried while walking, add ANTI_ROTATION and/or CARRY patterns. Regress by reducing range of motion or load; progress with heavier sandbag or increased ROM.

reasoning: This is a compound strongman lift: the movement begins with a hip-dominant hinge to lift the sandbag from the ground (triple extension: hip/knee/ankle) with a powerful pull to transition the load toward the torso/shoulder. The attempted finish is a vertical push (shoulder flexion/overhead press/jerk) to lock the bag overhead. Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension (hinge), scapulothoracic and gleno-humeral elevation and elbow extension (push/pull). The trunk and scapular stabilizers provide strong isometric anti-flexion and stabilization during the transfer and press.
notes: Failed attempts often indicate incomplete lockout at the PUSH phase; variations include clean-and-press, push-press, shouldering. Loading distribution of the sandbag (front vs. back vs. off-center) can increase anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demands and would modify classification to include ANTI_ROTATION or CARRY if walking or asymmetric loading is present.

reasoning: Primary movement begins with a hip-dominant lift from the ground (hip extension with knee extension component) — a hinge pattern driven by the posterior chain to initially lift the sandbag. The transition to shoulder involves unilateral shoulder elevation/arm flexion and a load transfer that requires active trunk rotation and rotational stabilization in the transverse plane as the bag is rolled/shouldered onto one side. Stabilization demands include anti-rotation and lateral-spine control by the obliques and quadratus lumborum, and scapular/rotator-cuff control while the shoulders and arms position the bag.

joint_actions.action: flexion/elevation and some horizontal adduction (load transfer)

notes: If the drill includes walking after shouldering, add CARRY. Asymmetric single-shoulder transfers increase anti-rotation demand. Variations (double-shoulder, clean-to-shoulder, or press finish) can shift emphasis toward more SQUAT-like or PUSH components.

reasoning: Sandbag March is loaded walking — the primary task is carrying a load while producing repeated gait cycles. Primary joint actions occur at the hip, knee and ankle (sagittal plane) as the lifter marches: hip extension during stance and hip flexion during swing, knee extension/flexion and ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion. The upper body typically holds the sandbag in an anterior or bear‑hug position, requiring isometric shoulder/elbow and scapular/torso stabilization to maintain load position. Core musculature (rectus abdominis, obliques, erector spinae) acts isometrically to resist spinal flexion and rotation while single‑leg stance phases demand gluteal and hip abductor control for frontal‑plane stability. Because the exercise is loaded walking, CARRY is primary and LOCOMOTION captures the repeated gait mechanics.
notes: If the sandbag is carried asymmetrically or shouldered, add ANTI_ROTATION for increased transverse-plane demand. Variation: heavy anterior/bear‑hug position emphasizes trunk anti‑flexion; single‑leg or long‑stride variations increase unilateral hip abductor and balance demands.

reasoning: Primary action is a ground-to-body lift initiated by hip hinge and knee extension to lift the sandbag off the ground (posterior chain concentric). Once the bag is off the ground the upper body performs pulling/cleaning actions (scapulothoracic elevation/depression, shoulder flexion/vertical transfer and elbow flexion) to bring the bag to the lap/chest/shoulder for loading. The trunk/obliques and erector spinae act isometrically to resist flexion and rotation during the transfer and while positioning the bag. Stabilization at the shoulders and grip (forearms, traps) is required to control the irregular load.

joint_actions.action: flexion/vertical transfer and adduction (to secure the bag to the body)

notes: If the event transitions to a loaded carry or running to a platform, add CARRY. Asymmetric or single-arm variations increase anti-rotation demand and may warrant adding ANTI_ROTATION. If the athlete finishes by pressing the bag overhead onto a platform, consider adding PUSH for the final phase.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: rapid lower-body dip and drive (triple extension) transfers force to an overhead shoulder press. Primary joint actions are shoulder flexion and elbow extension to drive the sandbag overhead in the sagittal plane. Hip, knee and ankle extension (sagittal) provide the leg drive that augments the press. The spine and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to transmit force and maintain a safe overhead path; rotator cuff and traps stabilize the glenohumeral joint and upwardly rotate the scapula. Because the core must resist extension and any load shift from the unconstrained sandbag, strong stabilization is required, but the primary pattern remains a vertical PUSH.
notes: Sandbag load is less stable than a barbell; asymmetric loading or shifting sand may add anti-rotation and increased core demand. If performed strictly as a press without leg drive (strict press), classification remains PUSH but with reduced contribution from lower-body joints.

reasoning: Primary movement is loaded locomotion (CARRY): repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane to walk while bearing a load overhead. The overhead position requires isometric shoulder and scapular control (glenohumeral elevation and scapular upward rotation) and strong core bracing to resist spinal flexion and rotation (ANTI_ROTATION). Primary joint actions are hip/knee/ankle producing gait, with the shoulder and elbow acting isometrically to maintain the load overhead; the spine performs isometric anti-flexion/anti-rotation to stabilize the trunk. Muscles producing gait (gluteus maximus, quads, hamstrings, calf complex) drive forward movement; deltoids, triceps, rotator cuff, serratus anterior and upper traps stabilize the overhead position; erector spinae, obliques and transverse abdominis resist spinal flexion and rotation.

joint_actions.action: isometric extension/anti-rotation (resist flexion and transverse plane rotation)

notes: If performed single-arm or with an imbalanced/unstable sandbag, anti-rotation and lateral stabilization demands increase. Variations: bilateral overhead carry (more pure axial load), single-arm overhead carry (higher anti-rotation), overhead farmer carry with rigid load (different shoulder/scapular demands). Ensure adequate shoulder stability and thoracic extension mobility before loading heavily.

reasoning: Primary joint action is shoulder elevation to an overhead position (isometric hold of shoulder flexion/abduction) with the elbows extended. This is functionally an isometric variant of a vertical push (overhead press family) and also a static overhead carry since a load is being held overhead. Shoulders (deltoids) and triceps produce/maintain the arm position; scapular stabilizers (upper traps, serratus anterior, rotator cuff) maintain glenohumeral/scapular positioning. The spine and core (erector spinae, obliques, rectus abdominis) act isometrically to resist trunk flexion/extension and lateral flexion (anti-extension/anti-lateral-flexion), while hips and knees provide a stable base (isometric stance).
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
notes: If the hold is performed while walking it becomes a dynamic overhead carry (still CARRY + PUSH). Asymmetric or single-arm overhead holds would add ANTI_ROTATION/ANTI-LATERAL-FLEXION emphasis. Shoulder mobility and rotator-cuff integrity are important safety considerations.

reasoning: Primary action is an isometric vertical push (shoulder elevation into an overhead position) held statically. The shoulders produce and maintain abduction/flexion in the sagittal/frontal plane to keep the load overhead while the elbows are locked isometrically. Scapular upward rotation and stabilization (serratus anterior, upper/lower trapezius) and rotator cuff activity resist dislocation and control humeral head position. The trunk (erector spinae, abs/obliques) resists spinal flexion/extension and potential rotation to maintain a neutral posture, and the hips/knees/ankles produce isometric postural support. If the sandbag is centrally held with two hands the primary pattern is a vertical PUSH (isometric); asymmetric or single-arm variations would additionally require ANTI_ROTATION and a CARRY pattern if walking.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (with elements of frontal for abduction depending on grip)

notes: Typical two‑handed static overhead hold = vertical PUSH (isometric). Single‑arm or offset sandbag creates pronounced ANTI_ROTATION demands; walking with the load converts or adds CARRY. Unstable/odd objects (sandbag) increase scapular, rotator cuff, and core stabilization demands and shoulder impingement risk in poorly positioned shoulders.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: the shoulder complex elevates the load overhead (shoulder flexion/elevation) while the elbow extends to lockout. Prime movers for the concentric action are the anterior and medial deltoids and triceps brachii, with upper trapezius and serratus anterior assisting scapular upward rotation. The rotator cuff and core (erector spinae, rectus abdominis, obliques) act isometrically to stabilize the glenohumeral joint and spine against extension and lateral flexion. Hips, knees and ankles typically provide isometric stabilization (unless the variation uses leg drive as in a push-press). If performed single-arm or with an asymmetric load, significant anti-rotation demands are added (see notes).
notes: Standard bilateral sandbag overhead press is a textbook vertical PUSH. Single-arm or offset sandbag variations add substantial ANTI_ROTATION demands. A push-press variation introduces hip/knee extension (leg drive) and becomes PUSH + HINGE/LEG DRIVE. Sandbag instability increases rotator cuff and core stabilization requirements compared with a rigid barbell.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: concentric shoulder elevation (flexion/vertical abduction depending on grip/arc) and elbow extension in the sagittal plane to move the sandbag overhead. Scapulothoracic upward rotation/protraction occurs to achieve full overhead position. Because a sandbag is an unstable, often shifting load, the trunk and anti-rotational core musculature work isometrically to resist rotation and lateral flexion, so anti-rotation is a relevant secondary pattern. Stabilizers include scapular stabilizers, rotator cuff, and isometric spinal/hip musculature to maintain posture and transfer force from torso to shoulder complex.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (primary) / frontal component possible depending on arc

joint_actions.action: isometric bracing (neutral) — minimal movement in strict press; extension if push-press variation

notes: Classified as vertical PUSH with secondary ANTI_ROTATION due to unstable sandbag load. If performed strictly two-handed and perfectly balanced, ANTI_ROTATION role is reduced; if single-arm/asymmetric or push-press variant with leg drive, include stronger anti-rotation and hip/knee extension involvement respectively.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical push: bilateral shoulder elevation (overhead shoulder flexion/abduction in the sagittal/scapular plane) with elbow extension to drive the load overhead. The glenohumeral joint produces the primary movement (anterior and middle deltoid, upper pecs), the elbow extends (triceps) to finish the press, and the scapulothoracic joint performs upward rotation (serratus anterior, upper/lower trapezius). The spine, hips and knees act isometrically to resist extension and rotation and to provide a stable base for force transfer. Sandbag loading increases demand on scapular stabilizers, rotator cuff and core due to instability and shifting mass.
primary_muscles: erector spinae / core stabilizers (rectus abdominis, obliques)
notes: If performed single-arm or asymmetrically loaded, include ANTI_ROTATION. Sandbag instability increases demand on scapular stabilizers and core compared with rigid-bar presses. Foot stance/trunk angle may shift plane slightly toward the scapular plane in practice.

reasoning: This is primarily an isometric vertical push pattern: the lifter holds a load locked out overhead, requiring the glenohumeral joint to be placed in elevation (shoulder flexion/abduction) and the elbow to be extended. Scapular upward rotation and elevation are required to maintain the overhead position. The core and posterior chain act isometrically to resist spinal extension, lateral flexion and any tendency to collapse (stabilization), and the lower limbs provide a stable base of support. Primary mechanical demand is maintaining an overhead lockout (vertical push), with substantial demand on shoulder stabilizers, scapular upward rotators and the trunk to maintain posture.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: flexion / elevation (also abduction component depending on hand position)

notes: If the sandbag is held asymmetrically (single-arm or off-center) or the athlete walks while holding it, include ANTI_ROTATION and/or CARRY. This static hold is an isometric variant of the vertical push (overhead press) and places high demand on rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers; ensure adequate shoulder mobility and trunk stability.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical PUSH: shoulder elevation (overhead press) with elbow extension in the sagittal plane. The exercise is assisted by a rapid dip-and-drive (partial squat) using hip and knee extension and ankle plantarflexion to transfer force into the bar/sandbag, so a SQUAT-like lower-body extension pattern is a secondary but important component. Muscles producing the press are primarily the anterior/mid deltoids and triceps; the dip-and-drive is produced by quadriceps and gluteus maximus with calf contribution. The spine and core act isometrically to transfer force and stabilize an unstable sandbag load; scapular stabilizers (traps/serratus) contribute to upward rotation and stability during the press.
notes: Typical sandbag push press is primarily a vertical push with a partial squat dip-and-drive. An unstable or asymmetric sandbag will increase core and anti-rotation demands; a push jerk variation introduces a larger lower-body repositioning (more 'dip/drive and catch' mechanics). If the load is shouldered asymmetrically, include ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical push: shoulder flexion and elbow extension to drive the sandbag overhead (sagittal plane). The movement is assisted by a rapid dip and drive (partial squat pattern) — hip, knee and ankle extension (triple extension) generate lower-body drive and transfer momentum to the upper body. Core and scapular stabilizers produce isometric stabilization against trunk flexion/extension and help control an unstable anterior load. Primary movers for the press are deltoids and triceps; primary lower-body movers for the drive are quadriceps and glutes. Stabilizers include rotator cuff, serratus anterior, traps and spinal erectors/abdominals.
notes: If performed strictly from the shoulders without leg drive, classification would be only PUSH (strict press). An offset or single-arm sandbag introduces significant anti-rotation demands and would add ANTI_ROTATION. Sandbag instability increases core and scapular stabilizer activation compared with a barbell push-press.

reasoning: Primary joint action is sustained shoulder elevation (overhead position) — an isometric vertical push pattern. Shoulders are held in flexion/abduction with elbows extended isometrically; the scapulae undergo upward rotation and the thoraco-lumbar spine must resist extension/flexion (anti-extension/bracing). Lower limbs provide isometric stance support. Primary movers are the deltoids and triceps producing/maintaining the overhead alignment while traps/serratus and rotator cuff stabilize the scapula and glenohumeral joint. The core (erector spinae, rectus abdominis/obliques) and hips/glutes act isometrically to maintain upright posture and resist spinal extension or collapse.

notes: If performed single-arm or with asymmetric loading, add ANTI_ROTATION (and if walking while holding, add CARRY). Emphasize scapular upward rotation and rotator cuff control; excessive lumbar extension can occur with heavy loads — cue core bracing and thoracic extension. Variations: double-arm stable overhead hold (standard PUSH pattern), single-arm overhead hold (PUSH + ANTI_ROTATION).

reasoning: Primary movement is dynamic axial (spinal) rotation in the transverse plane as the athlete rolls the sandbag across the body. Secondary primary actions include shoulder girdle movement (reaching/gripping, protraction/retraction) and hip-driven roll mechanics (hip flexion/extension) to generate and control the roll. The trunk must both produce rotation (obliques, contralateral erectors) and resist unwanted translational/rotational forces as the bag shifts, requiring strong isometric anti-rotation/stability from the obliques, transverse abdominis and hip stabilizers. Shoulders and scapulae stabilize and reposition the load during each roll, and the hips/glutes provide force to drive the body through the roll while the knees/feet often brace against the ground.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical push: shoulder elevation (flexion/vertical abduction depending on bar path) with elbow extension to drive the load overhead in the sagittal plane. Core and spinal musculature act isometrically to transfer force from the legs to the upper body and stabilize the torso; scapular stabilizers control the shoulder girdle during press and lockout.

reasoning: Sandbag rows are primarily a horizontal pulling movement. The main dynamic joint actions are shoulder extension (bringing the humerus posteriorly toward the torso) and elbow flexion to draw the sandbag toward the body, accompanied by scapular retraction (scapulothoracic adduction). The torso/hip are held in a hinged, flexed position isometrically to create a stable trunk and transfer force; the erector spinae and core resist spinal flexion. Grip/forearm musculature and scapular stabilizers also work to control the unstable sandbag. Because the primary movers are the posterior shoulder girdle and elbow flexors producing a horizontal pull, the movement is classified as PULL.
notes: Variations (single-arm, chest-supported, seated, standing bent-over) alter stabilization demands. Unilateral sandbag rows introduce anti-rotation demands and may be classified as ANTI_ROTATION + PULL in those cases. Unstable/awkward sandbag shapes increase core and grip stabilization requirements.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal/vertical pulling pattern: elbow flexion with scapular retraction and humeral extension to bring the sandbag toward the torso (PULL). The torso is held in a hip-hinged, flexed position to create a stable lever arm so the hips and posterior chain act isometrically to maintain posture (HINGE as a stabilization/secondary pattern). Muscles producing the pull are lats, middle traps/rhomboids and biceps; erector spinae, glutes and hamstrings stabilize the hip-hinge and neutral spine. Shoulders and scapulae perform retraction and the elbows flex in the sagittal/transverse planes while the spine resists flexion.
notes: If performed single-arm or with asymmetric loading, add ANTI_ROTATION for core stabilization. Chest-supported variations reduce HINGE/stabilization demand and isolate PULL. Grip variations (neutral/pronated) shift biceps vs brachialis contribution.

reasoning: The movement is a loaded sit-to-stand: primary motion is hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane as the lifter rises from a seated position. The sandbag is typically held in the lap or front-hugged so the load is fixed to the torso (no locomotion), making the pattern a loaded vertical rise consistent with a squat pattern. Trunk musculature (erector spinae, abdominals/obliques) and hip/knee extensors produce and control the upward force; shoulders and elbows act isometrically to secure the sandbag. Frontal/transverse plane stabilization is required to resist lateral collapse and any rotational tendency, but these are secondary to the sagittal-plane hip/knee extension.

joint_actions.action: isometric hold (flexion/adduction to hug the sandbag)

notes: If the sandbag is held asymmetrically or shifted to one side, ANTI_ROTATION should be added due to increased rotational/lateral stability demands. Progressions/variations (e.g., standing to shoulder, adding step) can introduce additional patterns (PUSH, HINGE, CARRY).

reasoning: Primary action is a pulling pattern: elbow flexion with scapular retraction and scapular elevation (the ‘shrug’ element) to draw the sandbag toward the torso/upper chest — this is a transverse/frontal-plane pulling motion at the shoulder girdle. Frequently performed with a forward-leaning torso, the exercise also uses a hip hinge to position the trunk and load the posterior chain; the hips/spine must isometrically stabilize against flexion while the upper limb performs the pull. Stabilization demands include thoracic extension control, lumbar/spinal anti-flexion from the erector spinae and core, and scapular control from the trap/rhomboid complex.

reasoning: Primary movement is a unilateral vertical push (push-press) where the legs/hips provide a dip-and-drive to help propel the sandbag from shoulder to overhead (vertical push). Primary joint actions are hip/knee/ankle extension (sagittal) for drive, followed by shoulder flexion/elevation and elbow extension (sagittal) to press the load overhead. Because the load is unilateral and offset, the core must produce strong isometric anti-rotation and resist lateral flexion (frontal/transverse) to maintain torso alignment and transfer force from the lower body to the arm. Secondary stabilization demands include scapular upward rotation/stability (serratus anterior, traps) and lumbar/spinal stabilization (erector spinae, obliques).

joint_actions.action: isometric anti-rotation / resist lateral flexion and rotation

exercise: Sandbag Shoulder Carry - Left (hill loop bottom)
reasoning: Primary action is loaded walking (CARRY) — repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane to produce locomotion while supporting a unilateral load on the left shoulder. The asymmetric, unilateral load creates a rotational and lateral bending moment on the trunk that must be resisted isometrically (ANTI_ROTATION / lateral stabilization) primarily in the frontal and transverse planes. The shoulder girdle on the loaded side acts isometrically to support the sandbag (scapular/shoulder stabilizers). Stabilization demands increase uphill and during single-leg support phases (increased glute medius/quadratus lumborum activity).

joint_actions.action: isometric elevation/abduction and scapular stabilization to support load
isometric flexion/holding (if hand/forearm assists in securing bag)

notes: Unilateral shoulder carry uphill increases demand on contralateral hip abductors (gluteus medius) and ipsilateral trunk lateral stabilizers (quadratus lumborum, obliques). Variations: switching shoulders, double-shoulder carry (reduces anti-rotation demand), front/bear-hug carry (shifts trunk flexion demand). Ensure trunk is braced to resist rotation and lateral flexion; progressive loading and uphill grade increase challenge.

reasoning: Sandbag shouldering is initiated with a posterior-chain driven lift from the floor or hips: primary hip extension (with concomitant knee extension in many variants) to generate vertical and upward trajectory of the bag (HINGE pattern, sagittal). As the load is brought up and across the body to one shoulder the torso and thorax rotate in the transverse plane to position the bag onto the shoulder (ROTATION pattern, transverse). The shoulders and elbows actively guide and receive the load (shoulder flexion/abduction and elbow flexion), while the core (obliques, erector spinae) produces controlled trunk rotation and resists unwanted lateral flexion. Stabilization demands are high due to asymmetry: contralateral anti-lateral-flexion and anti-extension efforts from the core and hip abductors are required during the lift and stabilization on the finishing shoulder.
notes: Asymmetric loading increases anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demands — if the drill includes loaded walking after shouldering, add CARRY. Technique variations (more knee bend vs hip hinge, clean-like vs scooping lift) alter relative contribution of knee extensor vs hip extensor but do not change primary HINGE + ROTATION classification.

exercise: Sandbag Shoulder Carry - Right (hill loop bottom)
reasoning: Primary action is loaded walking (CARRY): repeated hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane to produce gait and forward progression while bearing a unilateral load on the right shoulder. The asymmetric shoulder-loaded position creates a rotational and lateral-bending moment on the trunk that must be resisted isometrically (ANTI_ROTATION) by the obliques, quadratus lumborum and other core stabilizers. The right shoulder/scapula and ipsilateral grip act isometrically to stabilize the sandbag on the shoulder while contralateral hip abductors (gluteus medius) and ipsilateral spinal stabilizers counter pelvic drop and lateral flexion during single-leg stance phases. Uphill terrain increases hip extensor (glute/hamstring) demand.

joint_actions.action: isometric rotation control and resistance to lateral flexion

notes: Asymmetric, unilateral shoulder-loaded carry — expect strong demands on lateral core (anti-lateral-flexion and anti-rotation) and ipsilateral scapular stabilizers. Uphill increases posterior chain (hip extensor) demand. Variations (double-shoulder, front carry) change anti-rotation emphasis.

reasoning: The movement begins with a hip-dominant lift from the ground (hip and knee extension) — a hinge pattern driven by gluteus maximus and hamstrings with assistance from quadriceps and erector spinae. As the bag is brought to the chest and then transferred to one shoulder the torso actively rotates in the transverse plane (trunk/shoulder rotation) to clear and seat the load, recruiting obliques and ipsilateral/contralateral spinal rotators. Because the load ends up asymmetrically on one side and the lifter must resist unwanted torso collapse during the transfer and hold, substantial anti-rotation/isometric core stabilization is required (obliques, transverse abdominis, multifidus, glutes). Secondary upper‑limb actions include shoulder elevation/flexion and elbow flexion to maneuver the bag onto the shoulder, while the posterior chain provides the primary force to lift from the floor.

joint_actions.action: axial rotation (trunk rotation toward shoulder side)

notes: Variations include single-arm vs double-arm shouldering, finishing as a loaded carry if walking away (add CARRY). High asymmetric load increases anti-rotation demand — cue thoracic rotation and hip drive to protect lumbar spine. Technique differences (clean-style vs scoop-and-shoulder) alter the relative contribution of pull vs hinge but primary pattern is hip hinge with transverse rotation and core anti-rotation.

reasoning: The movement begins with a hip-dominant lift from the floor (hip hinge with knee extension) to raise the sandbag. As the bag is guided up and onto one shoulder the torso undergoes transverse-plane rotation and the shoulder/arm perform flexion/abduction and elbow flexion to position the load. Because the load is asymmetric and the trunk rotates against gravity, the obliques/TA and contralateral spinal stabilizers work isometrically to resist unwanted rotation and lateral collapse (anti-rotation). Primary movers for the lift phase are the posterior chain (glutes/hamstrings) and quads for knee extension; upper back, lats, deltoids and arms assist in pulling/controlling the bag while the core (obliques, erector spinae, TA) stabilizes and controls rotation.
notes: Variation: if the sandbag is carried/marched after shouldering, add CARRY. If the movement finishes with an overhead press/toss, add PUSH. High trunk rotation under load requires deliberate core bracing and progressive loading to reduce shear/rotational stress on the spine.

reasoning: Sandbag shouldering is initiated by a hip-dominant lift from the ground or lap (hip hinge with knee extension) to get the load moving upward. As the bag is brought up and across the torso onto one shoulder the trunk undergoes transverse rotation and the ipsilateral/contralateral obliques and erectors produce and control that rotation. The upper limb performs a pulling/hoisting action (elbow flexion and shoulder elevation/close-to-body assist) to guide the bag to the shoulder while the shoulder girdle and scapular stabilizers control the load. Stabilization demands include anti-rotation/isometric core control to resist unwanted lateral flexion, and scapular/rotator-cuff stability to receive the asymmetric load on the shoulder.

joint_actions.action: elevation/flexion and adduction across body (guiding load)

notes: Asymmetric loading creates significant anti-rotation/isometric demand even though movement includes active rotation. reasoning: Primary action initiates from a hip hinge: hip and knee extend to lift the sandbag from the ground (posterior chain drive). The lift is finished with a combined trunk rotation and shoulder elevation to bring the bag to one shoulder (active spinal rotation/transverse plane). Because the load is carried asymmetrically and moved across the body, the contralateral core and lumbopelvic musculature produce isometric anti-rotation forces to control the torso during the movement. Shouldering also requires elbow flexion and scapulothoracic stabilization but these are secondary to the hinge/rotation/anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary phase is a hip-dominant lift: the athlete deadlifts/hips-hinge the bag from the ground or lap using hip extension and knee extension in the sagittal plane (posterior chain). reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant lift from the ground or lap (hip extension with some knee extension) — a HINGE pattern driven by glutes/hamstrings/erector spinae. Secondary actions include shoulder elevation/holding and elbow flexion to secure the bag; scapular and trunk stabilizers work isometrically to control the load.

reasoning: Primary movement begins with a hip-dominant lift from the ground (hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane — a hinge-style lift) to elevate the bag. The finish requires strong trunk rotation and shoulder/upper-limb repositioning as the sandbag is swung/rotated up onto one shoulder (spine rotation and shoulder flexion/horizontal adduction in the transverse and sagittal/transverse planes). Primary movers are the posterior chain (glutes/hamstrings) producing hip extension, with knee extension assistance from quads; trunk rotators (obliques, transverse abdominis) and erector spinae control and produce rotation; shoulder complex (anterior deltoid, pec major, scapular stabilizers) and arm muscles position and secure the load. Stabilization requirements include anti-rotational/isometric core control on the loaded side, scapular stability from the rotator cuff and traps, and strong grip/forearm engagement. reasoning: Primary phase is a hip-dominant lift from the ground (hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane) to raise the bag—classical hinge mechanics driven by glutes/hamstrings and assisted by quads and erector spinae. The finish requires trunk and torso rotation in the transverse plane and dynamic shoulder elevation/flexion to move the bag onto one shoulder, so transverse plane rotation of the spine and scapulothoracic movement are primary for the carry-to-shoulder transfer. Stabilization demands unilateral core/oblique and contralateral hip/glute isometric activity to control the asymmetrical load during lift and shoulder receipt; grip/forearm muscles and scapular stabilizers control and position the load.
notes: Technique and movement emphasis vary by style: some athletes perform a more pronounced deadlift-to-shoulder (hinge + rotation), others add a short carry after shouldering. reasoning: The sandbag static hold is an isometric loaded hold—functionally a static carry. There is minimal concentric/ eccentric movement; the task mainly requires force production and endurance from the upper limb and core to resist collapse/translation of the load.
primary_muscles: anterior deltoid / pectoralis major (anterior load support)

reasoning: Primary demand is an isometric anterior load hold: shoulders are held in flexion (and slight adduction) with elbows flexed to secure the bag; the spine is held in isometric trunk extension/anti-flexion to resist collapse. Hips and knees maintain an upright isometric stance to support the load. Although there is no locomotion, the exercise is best classified as a carry-type load-bearing pattern because it primarily trains the ability to support and stabilize an external load on the body. Secondary requirements include upper limb grip/arm isometrics and core anti-flexion/anti-rotation stabilization depending on load symmetry.
notes: If the sandbag is carried asymmetrically (single-shoulder, suitcase position, or offset front carry) add ANTI_ROTATION. If held overhead, classify additionally as a VERTICAL PUSH (PUSH). Static hold emphasizes grip, upper-body isometrics and trunk anti-flexion rather than dynamic hip hinge or squat mechanics.

reasoning: Primary movement begins with a hip hinge (hip flexion to pick the bag, then powerful hip extension to lift). As the load is moved from the ground or lap to the shoulder the trunk and shoulders undergo transverse-plane rotation and diagonal elevation (active rotation to bring the bag onto one shoulder). reasoning: Scapular push-ups (push-up plus) are driven primarily by scapulothoracic protraction and retraction while the elbows and glenohumeral joints remain largely fixed in an extended, weight-bearing position.
