Repeated stepping, weight transfer and light footwork produce hip/knee/ankle flexion–extension and frontal plane weight shifts consistent with LOCOMOTION. Core musculature (obliques, rectus abdominis, erectors) and scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower traps) act to transmit force and stabilize the shoulder girdle and spine.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension and transverse rotation during weight transfer
flexion/extension for stepping and stance adjustments

notes: If performed stationary with no footwork, LOCOMOTION may be omitted and emphasis shifts to PUSH + ROTATION. For pure mobility-focused shadowboxing (slow, range-of-motion work) the movement is less forceful and more about joint dissociation and neuromuscular rehearsal rather than power production.

reasoning: Primary actions are transverse-plane trunk rotation and horizontal pushing at the shoulder during punches, plus dynamic lower‑limb/ankle/knee/hip actions for footwork and force generation. Shoulders perform horizontal adduction/protraction (transverse), elbows extend (sagittal) to deliver punches, the spine rotates (transverse) to transfer force from the hips; hips produce extension and transverse rotation to drive the strike and reposition during stepping (sagittal + transverse). Stabilization demands include rotator‑cuff and scapular stabilizers controlling the shoulder, and core obliques/erectors providing dynamic rotational control and resisting unwanted counter‑rotation during repeated strikes and footwork.
notes: Shadowboxing emphasizes lighter, higher‑velocity punches and footwork (more rotation and locomotion). Heavy bag work increases force transfer demands (greater hip extension and trunk rotation) and repetitive unilateral loading — monitor shoulder and lumbar rotational load and include bilateral/contralateral work or anti‑rotation drills to maintain balance.

reasoning: Primary actions are repeated punching gestures (shoulder horizontal adduction/shoulder flexion + elbow extension) producing a horizontal push-like action in the transverse/sagittal planes, combined with active trunk axial rotation in the transverse plane to generate force. Footwork consists of short steps, weight shifts and rhythmic raises/lowers of the hips/ankles that constitute locomotion mechanics. Stabilization demands include scapular control (serratus anterior, traps) for effective shoulder mechanics and dynamic core control (obliques, transverse abdominis, multifidus) to transfer rotational force and maintain balance during stepping.

joint_actions.action: rotation and weight shift (flexion/extension as stepping)

notes: Typically low-load, high-velocity horizontal pushing with integrated trunk rotation and light locomotion. Variations (longer footwork drills, emphasis on rotating body vs. arm-only punches, adding resistance or gloves) will shift emphasis between LOCOMOTION/ROTATION/PUSH and may increase demand on scapular stabilizers or anti-rotation control.

reasoning: Shadowboxing primarily produces repeated horizontal push actions (punches) via shoulder horizontal adduction/protraction and elbow extension in the transverse/sagittal planes. It also involves active axial rotation of the spine and hips (transverse plane) to generate torque and transfer force from the lower body into the upper body. Additionally, typical shadowboxing includes footwork (stepping, weight shifts) that constitute locomotion patterns (hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane) for balance, distance management and force generation. Stabilization requires isometric core control (obliques, rectus abdominis, erector spinae) to coordinate rotation and resist unwanted motion, and scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) to control protraction/retraction during repeated punches.
notes: Stationary shadowboxing reduces LOCOMOTION (can be classified as PUSH + ROTATION only). Level of rotational vs linear emphasis varies by punch type (jab = less hip rotation, cross/hook = greater rotation). Adding resistance or implements (weights, bands) may increase anti-rotation/stability demands.

reasoning: This is a gait-based locomotor task. Primary joint actions are cyclical hip flexion and extension, knee flexion and extension, and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion in the sagittal plane with accompanying transverse plane pelvic rotation and frontal plane balance corrections. Propulsion is generated by hip extensors and plantarflexors while knee extensors control stance; hip abductors and core musculature provide single-leg stability and trunk control. Upper limbs perform reciprocal shoulder flexion/extension as swing counterbalance but are secondary to lower-limb locomotor mechanics.
notes: Intensity, incline, speed, or holding an object (e.g., leash/child) can add carry or anti-rotation demands. Recovery walk implies low intensity and emphasis on gait mechanics and aerobic recovery.

reasoning: This conditioning activity combines repetitive upper-body pushing (shadowboxing punches) and pulling (rowing stroke) actions. Primary joint actions for shadowboxing are shoulder horizontal adduction/protraction and elbow extension in the transverse plane with transverse spine rotation for force/transfer. Primary joint actions for rowing are hip extension and knee extension (drive) in the sagittal plane plus shoulder horizontal abduction/scapular retraction and elbow flexion in the transverse/sagittal planes. Stabilization demands include isometric core control against rotation/forward flexion, scapular stabilizers controlling protraction/retraction, and lower-limb postural control during seated/standing variations.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction / protraction (punch) and horizontal abduction / retraction (row)
axial rotation (trunk rotation during punching) and anti-rotation/isometric control

notes: Shadowboxing emphasizes horizontal pushing and trunk rotation; rowing emphasizes horizontal pulling with lower‑body drive. As a light cardio/warmup these are low-force, high-repetition patterns — technique (scapular control, hip-hinge for rowing) influences which pattern predominates. If performed one-sided or with a strong rotational emphasis, include ROTATION or ANTI_ROTATION as secondary patterns.

reasoning: Primary actions are repeated unilateral/alternating shoulder horizontal flexion (punching) with elbow extension in the transverse plane — classified as PUSH (horizontal). Simultaneously the thorax and pelvis rotate axially to generate and transfer force, so ROTATION (transverse plane trunk rotation) is a primary pattern. Scapular protraction/retraction and rotator-cuff activity stabilize the shoulder; lower-limb stepping or weight-shift provides ground reaction force and balance but is secondary. Muscles producing the movement include pectoralis major/anterior deltoid/triceps for the punch, serratus anterior and scapular stabilizers for protraction and force transfer, and external obliques/other trunk rotators for axial rotation. Stabilization demands: rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control humeral position; core (obliques, TVA) resists unwanted flexion/anti-rotation and transmits force between lower and upper body; hips/ankles provide balance and push-off during footwork.

joint_actions.action: rotation and weight-shift (and occasional extension during push-off)
flexion/extension for stepping and stance adjustments

notes: If performed strictly stationary with no footwork, LOCOMOTION is minimal and classification remains PUSH + ROTATION. Intensity, hand position (guard) and stance influence relative loading on scapular stabilizers and lower-limb involvement. Shadowboxing includes significant shoulder and trunk stabilization—monitor shoulder mechanics in warm-ups.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip extension in the sagittal plane as the pelvis and lumbar spine lift off the mat. The action is driven by posterior chain hip extensors with the thoracolumbar spine extending to create a bridge; knees typically remain flexed and act as a stable base. Shoulders/scapulae provide a closed-chain support surface and require isometric stabilization. Therefore the dominant biomechanical pattern is a hip-dominant hinge movement emphasizing glute and hamstring-driven hip extension with trunk extension and core stabilization.
notes: Variations: single-leg bridge increases unilateral hip extension demand and introduces anti-rotation/stability requirements. Performed as a mobility/cool-down it also promotes lumbar and thoracic extension; in some advanced yoga variations (full wheel) the pattern includes greater shoulder/upper-extremity loading and additional joint actions.

reasoning: Primary motion is multi-planar circumduction of the glenohumeral joint (combination of shoulder flexion/extension, abduction/adduction and internal/external rotation) performed as continuous rotation of the humerus. The scapulothoracic joint also moves (upward/downward rotation, protraction/retraction) to preserve glenoid orientation. Primary movers producing the arc are the deltoid (segments) and rotator cuff muscles; scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) control scapular motion. Elbow remains largely stable/isometric. Movement is therefore best classified as ROTATION because the exercise emphasizes rotational/circumferential shoulder actions across transverse, frontal and sagittal planes with isometric stabilization of the elbow and core.
notes: Typically a mobility/stretching drill. Variations include small vs large circles, arms straight vs elbows bent, weighted implements (which increase load and add stabilization demand). Avoid aggressive circles if shoulder pain or instability; emphasize scapular control and rotator cuff engagement.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: bilateral overhead shoulder elevation (shoulder flexion/elevation into the scapular plane) with concurrent elbow extension to drive the load upward. The deltoids (primarily anterior and medial heads) produce the shoulder elevation while the triceps produce elbow extension. Scapulothoracic upward rotation and protraction (serratus anterior, upper trapezius) accompany humeral elevation to preserve subacromial space and efficiently orient the glenoid. The thorax and core act isometrically to resist spinal extension and maintain a stable base; rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control humeral head position throughout the range. Bands create variable resistance (increasing load near lockout) but do not change the fundamental joint actions.
notes: Banded version provides variable resistance but remains a vertical PUSH pattern. Single-arm or heavily offset band setups introduce an anti-rotation demand and would add ANTI_ROTATION to the classification. Emphasize scapular upward rotation and rotator-cuff stability for shoulder health.

reasoning: Primary movement is large-range humeral elevation (shoulder flexion/abduction) as the arms travel overhead and behind the torso — functionally similar to a vertical shoulder push pattern (humeral elevation/upward reach). The movement also includes significant glenohumeral transverse-plane rotation and circumduction (internal/external rotation and horizontal travel of the humerus) and scapulothoracic upward rotation, so a ROTATION pattern is included to reflect rotary components at the shoulder. The elbows are typically extended and act as passive levers; the scapulae and thoracic spine must actively upwardly rotate/extend and stabilize throughout the motion. Muscles producing the movement include the deltoids and supraspinatus for elevation, rotator cuff muscles (infraspinatus/teres minor/subscapularis) for controlled rotation and humeral head centration, and trapezius/serratus anterior for scapular upward rotation. Core and thoracic extensors provide postural stabilization.
notes: Primarily a mobility/warm-up drill rather than a loaded strength pattern. Can be performed with a dowel/band or with bent elbows (reduces glenohumeral rotation demand). If performed aggressively with load/resistance it more closely mimics a vertical PUSH pattern; bent-elbow variation reduces rotational demand and may shift emphasis to scapular mobility.

reasoning: This is a shoulder mobility/circumduction drill where the primary joint action is large-range glenohumeral motion: shoulder flexion to bring the arms overhead and shoulder extension/horizontal abduction to bring the arms behind the body. The humerus also undergoes internal/external rotation throughout the arc, and the scapulothoracic joint performs upward rotation and posterior tilt to allow full overhead/back position. Elbows remain largely extended and the thoracic spine and core provide isometric postural stabilization. Primary movers produce the arc (deltoids, lats, pec major for sagittal motion; rotator cuff muscles control rotation and joint centration; serratus anterior and trapezius produce scapular upward rotation), while rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers maintain joint centration and prevent impingement.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: extension / horizontal abduction (move arms behind body)
upward rotation and posterior tilt (scapular rotation to accommodate humeral motion)
isometric/postural stabilization (maintain upright posture, allow thoracic extension as needed)

notes: Mobility drill emphasizing glenohumeral and scapulothoracic kinematics. Use wider grip (or a band) to reduce impingement if shoulder ROM is limited. Progress by narrowing grip or adding tempo; regress by widening grip or performing single-arm pulldowns. Avoid forcing range if symptomatic -- focus on scapular control and rotator cuff activation.

reasoning: Primary movement is glenohumeral rotation and circumduction of the shoulder (transverse plane) with associated shoulder flexion/extension (sagittal plane) and scapulothoracic upward/downward rotation. The band provides longitudinal traction and bias for internal/external rotation while the rotator cuff and deltoids actively move the humerus; scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, traps, rhomboids) control scapulothoracic motion. The thoracic spine may extend/rotate to assist range. Elbow is typically held near extension and functions mainly as a positional joint/stabilizer. Overall this is a mobility/motor control pattern focused on rotation and scapular-thoracic coordination rather than a loaded push or pull.
notes: Primarily a mobility/motor-control drill emphasizing glenohumeral rotation and scapulothoracic coordination. Variations (arm bent vs. extended, band position) change demand on rotator cuff vs. scapular stabilizers. Avoid aggressive flossing with shoulder pain or acute labral/instability issues; progress gradually.

reasoning: Commonly performed as a front raise (shoulder flexion) or lateral raise (shoulder abduction) against gravity. The primary moving joint is the glenohumeral joint producing shoulder flexion (sagittal plane) or abduction (frontal plane). Scapulothoracic upward rotation accompanies large elevation ranges. The movement is primarily a single‑joint shoulder elevator (functionally similar to a vertical push of the hand/arm) with the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers acting isometrically to maintain joint centering; the core and thorax provide anti‑compensatory stabilization to prevent torso lean.
notes: Name is ambiguous — could be performed as front raise (shoulder flexion) or lateral raise (abduction). This is an upper‑body single‑joint shoulder elevation/isolation movement; classified as PUSH here because it functions as a vertical arm elevation against gravity rather than a multi‑joint push/pull compound. If performed as an overhead press (elbow extension under load) classification should be PUSH with higher confidence.

reasoning: Primarily a shoulder girdle posterior-opening mobility exercise: the glenohumeral joint moves into extension and often external rotation/horizontal abduction while the scapulothoracic joint retracts and the thoracic spine extends. Biomechanically this mimics a low-load horizontal pull pattern (scapular retraction and shoulder extension) though performed as a stretch/mobility drill rather than a loaded strengthening movement. Rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to control motion; thoracic erectors permit extension and the core provides trunk stability.
notes: This is primarily a mobility/stretch exercise rather than a loaded strength movement; classification as PULL reflects the posterior-opening/scapular retraction mechanics. Variations (doorway pec stretch, clasped-hands-behind-back lift, band-assisted shoulder opener) change emphasis on rotation vs pure extension and may add a mild loaded pull or rotational component. Use caution with glenohumeral instability or recent shoulder surgery.

reasoning: Primary movement is elevation of the scapula (scapulothoracic/shoulder-girdle elevation) in the frontal plane — an upward (vertical) pull of the shoulder girdle. The movement does not involve hip/knee/ankle motion and has minimal elbow motion; it is primarily a scapulothoracic/pull pattern with local scapular stabilizers engaged isometrically.
notes: Mobility version typically performed without load; emphasizes scapular upward translation/rotation. Stabilization demands include lower/middle trapezius and serratus anterior to control scapular motion and cervical stabilizers to prevent excessive neck elevation. Cue to avoid shrugging with pronounced neck extension.

reasoning: Primary movement is multi-planar glenohumeral rotation and large-range shoulder flexion/extension as the arms travel overhead and behind the torso. The humerus undergoes sagittal plane flexion/extension and transverse-plane internal/external rotation while the scapulothoracic joint performs upward/downward rotation and protraction/retraction to accommodate the arc. Stabilization demands come from rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (traps, serratus anterior, rhomboids) to control humeral head centration and scapular movement; thoracic extension mobility and core/bracing assist to prevent excessive trunk compensation.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor, supraspinatus, subscapularis)
notes: Primarily a shoulder mobility/rotation drill. Grip width and implement (band vs dowel) alter degree of glenohumeral rotation and thoracic compensation. Avoid if acute shoulder pain or instability; emphasize scapular control and thoracic extension to reduce compensatory lumbar movement.

reasoning: This is a dynamic shoulder mobility drill consisting of reciprocal shoulder flexion (forward swing) and extension (backward swing) in the sagittal plane. Primary joint action occurs at the glenohumeral joint (shoulder flexion/extension) with concurrent scapulothoracic protraction/retraction to accommodate the arm path. The movement alternates concentric action of anterior shoulder/pectoral musculature (forward swing, push-like) and posterior shoulder/latissimus/trapezius musculature (backward swing, pull-like); rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers act eccentrically and isometrically to control the swing. Trunk and hips remain largely static, requiring isometric core and postural muscle engagement to maintain upright posture and prevent compensatory spinal motion.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
notes: Common warm-up; may include variations (cross-body horizontal swings or arm circles) that add transverse-plane shoulder horizontal adduction/abduction or rotational components. Use controlled amplitude to avoid impingement in people with shoulder pathology; light band or resistance converts it toward more explicit push/pull loading.

reasoning: Primary demand is isometric anti-rotation of the trunk: while in a high plank the body must resist transverse-plane rotation as one hand leaves the ground to tap the opposite shoulder. Secondary primary action is unilateral upper‑body load bearing/shoulder stabilization (a horizontal push/anti‑collapse demand) through the supporting arm. Joints: the spine performs isometric anti-rotation (transverse plane) and anti‑extension (sagittal). Shoulders perform a small dynamic reach/tap (shoulder horizontal adduction/shoulder flexion in the transverse/sagittal planes) on the moving arm while the supporting shoulder maintains isometric scapulothoracic and glenohumeral stability (horizontal push/press-like demand). Elbow and wrist remain isometric in extension to transmit load. Hips, knees and ankles are isometric to maintain a straight plank (sagittal plane stability). Stabilization requires strong obliques/transverse abdominis and contralateral gluteal activation to prevent hip drop and rotation; serratus anterior, rotator cuff and triceps/SCT complex stabilize the shoulder girdle.

joint_actions.action: shoulder flexion / horizontal adduction (small dynamic reach)

notes: Primarily an anti-rotation core exercise with secondary unilateral shoulder stabilization (push-like) demand. Variations/progressions: slow controlled taps, add alternating leg lifts (increases anti-rotation demand), perform from knees (regression) or with elevated feet (progression). Watch for hip/shoulder drop and excessive torso rotation.

reasoning: The movement is primarily an overhead reach/arm elevation and lateral trunk side-bend. Primary joint actions are shoulder elevation (flexion/abduction) often with scapular upward rotation to allow arm overhead; the thoracic spine undergoes lateral flexion (frontal plane) for a lat-specific stretch. Although performed as a static mobility/stretch, the kinematics most closely map to vertical shoulder elevation mechanics (analogous to a vertical PUSH) with the scapula and thoracic spine acting as mobile segments. Stabilization requirements include isometric rotator-cuff and scapular stabilizer activity to position the humeral head and control scapular motion, plus core/hip stabilization to maintain pelvic position during the side bend.
notes: This is a mobility/stretch exercise rather than a resisted strength pattern. If performed as an active resisted reach (loaded overhead), classification would more strongly be VERTICAL PUSH; for a purely thoracic rotation-directed lat stretch, ROTATION could also be considered. Ensure scapular upward rotation and thoracic mobility when coaching the movement.

reasoning: Most common shoulder stretches (e.g., cross-body shoulder stretch where one arm is pulled across the chest) primarily involve glenohumeral horizontal adduction in the transverse plane produced by the assisting/active limb pulling the stretched arm across the body. The scapulothoracic joint typically protracts/rotates to accommodate the humeral position and the elbow may flex if the assisting arm grips behind the elbow. Primary movers that produce the movement (when active/assisted) are shoulder horizontal adductors; rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to stabilize the humeral head and scapula. Because this is a primarily isolated, assisted joint-range-of-motion action rather than a locomotor, loaded or multi-segment functional pattern, it best maps to a horizontal pull-type action for classification purposes.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (stabilizers: supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)

joint_actions.action: flexion (if assisting hand grips elbow or forearm)
neutral / slight ipsilateral rotation or sidebend depending on variation

notes: ‘Shoulder Stretch’ is a broad label — specific variants change classification. Cross‑body/horizontal adduction stretches map to a horizontal PULL pattern (assisted pull across chest). Sleeper/internal‑rotation stretches would incorporate ROTATION as primary. Doorway/pec stretches (horizontal abduction/external rotation) could be classified as a passive horizontal PUSH movement depending on intent. Because many stretches are passive/isometric and highly variant, review the exact technique for higher confidence.

reasoning: Primary movement is axial rotation of the thoracic spine in the transverse plane as the torso turns side-to-side while holding a stick across the posterior shoulders. The motion is produced primarily by the internal and external obliques and the intrinsic spinal rotators (multifidus/rotatores) with assistance from the erector spinae. The shoulders act as a loaded anchor requiring scapular stabilizers (middle trapezius/rhomboids) to hold the stick; the hips and pelvis typically act isometrically to limit lower‑body rotation if the intent is thoracic isolation. Core must eccentrically control and concentrically produce rotation, and anti‑extension/anti‑lateral‑flexion control from the transverse abdominis and obliques is required for stability.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / horizontal position while arms hold stick

notes: Usually used for thoracic mobility; cue to minimize lumbar rotation and keep hips stable to isolate thoracic work. Variations: seated/standing, added reach or loaded band for increased demand on scapular and core stabilizers.

reasoning: This is a plyometric locomotor task combining a lateral single- or double-leg hop (frontal-plane push-off/landing) immediately followed by forward sprinting (sagittal-plane propulsion). Primary joint actions are hip extension and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion for propulsion during both the lateral hop push-off and sprint acceleration; the lateral hop additionally requires hip abduction/adduction and frontal-plane control on landing. The movement’s primary purpose is locomotion/change-of-direction and forward sprint acceleration rather than a purely squatting, hinging, pushing, or pulling pattern. Significant single-leg and frontal-to-sagittal transition stability is required from the hip abductors/adductors and core to control landing and reorient force for sprinting.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization / slight rotation during reorientation

notes: Variation in execution (single-leg vs double-leg lateral hop, immediate sprint vs short acceleration) can change unilateral loading and frontal-plane demands. Emphasize soft, controlled landing and rapid reorientation to sagittal plane. Increased knee valgus risk on landing for athletes with poor hip abductor control.

reasoning: Primary movement is trunk lateral flexion (oblique-driven) combined with hip flexion to bring torso and lower limb toward each other. The spine undergoes lateral (frontal plane) flexion with a small transverse-plane oblique/rotational component depending on technique. The hip performs sagittal-plane flexion. Primary movers are the external and internal obliques and rectus abdominis producing trunk lateral flexion and flexion, with iliopsoas/hip flexors producing hip flexion. Stabilization demands include isometric activity from the contralateral obliques and transverse abdominis to control pelvic position, erector spinae to resist excessive spinal collapse, and hip abductors/glute medius to stabilize the pelvis in side-lying. If performed with a supporting arm/shoulder, the shoulder girdle also provides stabilization.

notes: Variations (knees bent vs. straight) change hip vs. spinal contribution; performing the movement from a side-plank base increases anti-rotation/stabilization demand and may add ANTI_ROTATION to the classification.

reasoning: This is an isolation/compound shoulder elevation sequence: first a shoulder abduction (lateral raise) in the frontal plane, then shoulder flexion (front raise) in the sagittal plane. Primary joint motion occurs at the glenohumeral joint producing arm elevation away from the torso; the elbow remains largely extended/isometric. Scapulothoracic upward rotation and stabilization are required to allow full range and protect the glenohumeral joint. Because the action is moving the load away from the body (vertical/lateral elevation) and not a pulling action, it best maps to the PUSH family (shoulder elevation/pushing movements). Stabilization demands include rotator cuff isometric control of the humeral head, and scapular stabilizers (trapezius, serratus anterior) for upward rotation; core and lower limb contributions are minimal and primarily isometric.
notes: Seated or supported variations reduce scapular contribution. Single-arm execution introduces an anti-rotation demand on the core (add ANTI_ROTATION if performed unilaterally). Grip/hand orientation (thumbs-up vs palms-down) shifts emphasis between anterior and lateral deltoid and alters supraspinatus involvement.

reasoning: Primary joint action is shoulder (glenohumeral) abduction in the frontal plane — the humerus is moved laterally away from the torso against gravity. The middle deltoid is the prime mover with supraspinatus assisting; scapular upward rotation/elevation (upper trapezius and serratus anterior) occurs as a linked scapulothoracic motion. The elbow remains slightly flexed/isometric and the spine/core provide postural stabilization. Because the action is moving the limb away from the body (a lateral/vertical push of the humerus), the best-fit movement pattern is PUSH. Rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to center the humeral head and control scapular motion.
notes: Common variations: seated reduces lower-body momentum; unilateral performance increases anti-rotation demand on the core. Cue slight external rotation to reduce subacromial impingement risk. Keep range and load controlled to emphasis deltoid isolation.

reasoning: The side bridge is primarily an isometric anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion trunk exercise. The spine is held in neutral against lateral flexion and rotation (frontal/transverse plane), producing no concentric movement but large isometric demand on the obliques, transverse abdominis and quadratus lumborum. The supporting hip must produce/isometrically hold hip abduction and slight extension to keep the pelvis elevated (frontal/sagittal planes). The shoulder complex (scapula and rotator cuff) and elbow/forearm provide isometric support and force transfer to the ground. Thus the primary pattern is anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion with multi-joint isometric stabilization across spine, hip and shoulder.

joint_actions.action: isometric abduction and slight extension to elevate pelvis
isometric scapular stabilization and load bearing

notes: Variation: performed on forearm (common) or hand; knees bent regress, elevated foot/weighted variations increase demand. More accurately described as anti-lateral-flexion (frontal plane) with anti-rotation components.

reasoning: Primary joint action is hip abduction in the frontal plane (lying or standing). The movement is dominated by lateral/horizontal displacement of the femur at the hip rather than sagittal hinge or knee-dominant actions. The gluteus medius and minimus (with assistance from TFL and upper gluteus maximus fibers) act concentrically to lift the leg; the contralateral hip abductors and ipsilateral trunk muscles (quadratus lumborum, obliques) isometrically stabilize the pelvis and spine to prevent lateral drop/rotation. Knee and ankle remain largely static (stabilizers) when the leg is kept extended. If performed standing, single-leg balance increases demand for ankle/hip stabilizers and small transverse-plane rotation control.
notes: Commonly performed lying (side-lying hip abduction) or standing (standing hip abduction); external resistance (band/ankle weight) increases load. Though not a perfect fit to the provided high-level pattern list, LOCOMOTION is chosen because hip abduction is a primary frontal-plane stabilizer/movement relevant to gait and lateral stepping. If a dedicated 'HIP ABDUCTION' pattern were available, that would be more precise.

reasoning: This is primarily a mobility/stretching exercise involving the cervical spine. The primary joint action is cervical lateral flexion (side bending) in the frontal plane. Movement is produced by ipsilateral upper trapezius/levator scapulae and contralateral sternocleidomastoid/scalenes adjustment; deep cervical extensors and rotators contribute to fine control. The thoracic spine and shoulder girdle act isometrically to stabilize the head and maintain posture during the stretch. Because this is an isolated cervical mobility action rather than a global movement pattern (push, pull, hinge, squat, lunge, carry, locomotion, rotation or anti-rotation), it does not map to the provided high-level movement pattern categories.
notes: Not a strength movement pattern — classified as cervical mobility/stretch. Use gentle, controlled technique; avoid forceful pulling on the head or stretching into pain. Modify or omit with cervical spine pathology. Variations include adding gentle contralateral rotation or performing seated versus supine for extra support.

reasoning: Primary joint action is at the hip: the loaded/positioned leg is placed into hip abduction with an external rotation bias to lengthen the medial thigh (adductor) tissues. Movement occurs primarily in the frontal plane (abduction) with a transverse plane component (external rotation). The action is typically passive/isometric (stretch) rather than a concentric/ballistic contraction. Pelvic and trunk stabilizers (obliques, quadratus lumborum, gluteus medius) isometrically control pelvic position to maintain the side-lying posture and prevent undesired lumbar lateral flexion or rotation.
notes: This is primarily a passive/adaptive stretch targeting the adductor bundle; some variations bias more abduction or external rotation. Avoid aggressive forcing in acute adductor strains. Trunk and pelvis must be stabilized to isolate the groin stretch; slight modifications (hip flexion/extension) change which adductor fibers are emphasized.

reasoning: Primary demand is isometric anti-rotation / anti-lateral-flexion of the spine while maintaining a laterally supported plank. The spine must resist lateral flexion and rotation (frontal/transverse planes) as the load (bag) is moved; hips are held in abduction to keep the pelvis elevated (frontal plane isometric). The top shoulder/arm produces a small transverse-plane horizontal slide of the bag (dynamic shoulder horizontal adduction/abduction) but this is secondary to the core anti-rotation demand. Stabilization requirements include isometric contraction of obliques, transverse abdominis and quadratus lumborum to prevent collapse/rotation, gluteus medius to maintain hip elevation, and scapular/rotator-cuff and serratus anterior activity to stabilize the shoulder during the slide.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction/abduction (sliding hand/arm movement) and isometric scapular stabilization

notes: Variant intensity depends on whether the top arm actively moves the bag (increases transverse challenge) or simply holds it (pure anti-rotation). Common progressions: longer lever (lower hip), added load, sliding faster or further. Watch for shoulder shrugging and hip sag (loss of anti-rotation/hip abduction).

reasoning: Primary motion is dynamic lateral trunk flexion/oblique-driven ‘crunch’ in a side plank position (frontal plane) often combined with hip adduction/abduction as the hips dip and lift. The supporting shoulder/arm and contralateral hip act isometrically to prevent rotation and maintain a stacked alignment (anti-rotation). Thus the exercise both produces trunk rotation/lateral flexion (ROTATION pattern) and demands isometric anti-rotational core/shoulder stability (ANTI_ROTATION).

joint_actions.action: lateral flexion (and some trunk rotation depending on variation)
isometric stabilization (scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff maintain position)

notes: Variations (hip dips vs bringing elbow to knee vs top-leg raises) shift emphasis between frontal-plane lateral flexion, transverse-plane rotation, and hip musculature. Ensure shoulder/elbow tolerance for loaded side support; emphasize anti-rotation control to protect lumbar spine.

exercise: Side Plank Reach Through (with Bulgarian bag)
reasoning: Primary movement is transverse-plane trunk rotation as the free/top arm reaches under the torso (dynamic rotation). The posture also requires isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion control from the core and hip complex to maintain a straight stacked-hip side plank while resisting the rotational/lateral torque — this demand is increased by the asymmetric Bulgarian bag load. Shouldering/upper‑limb joints provide load-bearing scapulothoracic and glenohumeral stability (isometric shoulder/rotator cuff/serratus work) while the hips and lower limb produce isometric abduction/extension to keep hips elevated. Thus the exercise simultaneously loads trunk rotation (movement) and heavy anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion stabilization.

joint_actions.action: isometric abduction and extension (hip elevation / stack control)

notes: The Bulgarian bag creates an asymmetric load that increases anti-rotation and lateral stability demands; exact shoulder/torque demands depend on how the bag is positioned (held overhead/on shoulder/drapped). reasoning: Primary movement is dynamic axial rotation of the thorax as the top arm threads under the torso (transverse plane). Simultaneously the core, hips and shoulder of the support side produce isometric anti-rotation and lateral stability to maintain the side-plank position (frontal and transverse plane stabilization). The obliques generate the rotational movement; the opposite-side obliques, transverse abdominis, quadratus lumborum and gluteus medius act isometrically to resist collapse/rotation. The supporting shoulder and scapula (deltoid, rotator cuff, serratus anterior) stabilize the upper limb and allow controlled reach-through of the moving arm.
notes: Common variations: forearm vs hand-supported side plank, bent-knee modification, elevated feet. Movement emphasizes trunk rotation and anti-rotational stability rather than vertical push/pull or lower-body hinging/squatting. Progressions can add load or slow eccentric control to increase rotational demand. Monitor shoulder stability and lumbar rotation tolerance.

reasoning: Primary movement is dynamic trunk lateral flexion (side-bending) produced by the obliques and quadratus lumborum in the frontal plane; there can be a small transverse component if the torso rotates toward the floor during the crunch. The supporting shoulder and elbow act isometrically to stabilize the upper body (scapular stabilizers, deltoid, rotator cuff) while the hips and glutes provide isometric lateral/hip stabilization. Because the exercise actively moves the trunk into lateral flexion/oblique-driven ‘crunch’ motion, it is best classified under the trunk rotation/lateral flexion core category (ROTATION).
notes: Variations (knee-to-elbow vs. hip-dip/lift) alter magnitude of lateral flexion and hip involvement. Performed on forearm vs. hand changes shoulder loading. Although the supporting side resists rotation (anti-rotation), the primary action during the crunch is dynamic lateral trunk flexion, so ROTATION is the primary pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is dynamic transverse-plane trunk rotation as the top arm reaches under the torso (ROTATION). The side plank position requires strong isometric resistance to spinal rotation and lateral collapse from the supporting shoulder/hip (ANTI_ROTATION). The reaching arm produces shoulder horizontal adduction/rotation in the transverse plane while the supporting shoulder and scapulothoracic muscles stabilize the shoulder girdle. Hips and glute medius/max maintain an elevated hip via isometric hip abduction/extension to keep a straight plank alignment. Overall the obliques drive the rotation and also act eccentrically/isometrically with the contralateral obliques/transverse abdominis to resist uncontrolled rotation and lateral flexion.

joint_actions.action: rotation (dynamic) and isometric control of lateral flexion
horizontal adduction / internal rotation (reaching under torso)
isometric abduction and sagittal-plane stabilization (maintain hip extension)

isometric stabilization for foot contact and balance

Regress with knees-down side plank; progress by adding load or increasing reach magnitude.

exercise: Side Plank Reach-Through with Bag Drag
reasoning: Primary movement is transverse-plane trunk rotation as the top arm reaches/threads under the torso (ROTATION). The side-plank base requires isometric resistance to rotation and lateral collapse of the trunk and hips (ANTI_ROTATION). The active dragging of a bag across the floor with the top hand is a horizontal pulling action at the shoulder (PULL). Primary joint actions are spinal axial rotation (dynamic), sustained lateral spinal stability (isometric), and shoulder horizontal/ transverse movement for the drag; hips and glute medius/QL act isometrically to maintain lateral pelvis alignment while scapular stabilizers support the loaded shoulder.
notes: Primary training effect is core (rotational and anti-rotational) with secondary upper‑limb horizontal pulling and heavy demand on scapular/shoulder stability. Progressions: add load or slow tempo. Modifications: knee-supported side plank reduces hip/torso demand; using no bag removes PULL, leaving ROTATION + ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: The movement's primary action is transverse-plane rotation of the thorax as the top arm reaches under the body (producing trunk rotation). joint_actions.action: abduction/adduction control (isometric) to maintain pelvis alignment

notes: Variations (forearm vs hand support) change shoulder loading; adding a leg lift increases hip abductor demand. Tempo alters emphasis: slow controlled reach emphasizes anti-rotation/stability, fast reach emphasizes dynamic rotation.

reasoning: Primary dynamic action is transverse-plane rotation of the thorax/shoulder as the top arm reaches under the body (reach-through) — this is a ROTATION pattern. joint_actions.action: isometric abduction/hip stability to maintain pelvis elevation

reasoning: Primary action is dynamic trunk rotation in the transverse plane as the upper arm/hand reaches under the torso (thoracic rotation relative to pelvis). The supporting side must resist unwanted rotation and lateral collapse (isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion) throughout the movement. joint_actions.action: isometric support (extension or flexion depending on forearm vs hand support)

reasoning: Primary movement is transverse-plane trunk rotation as the top arm reaches under the torso (dynamic rotation). The side plank base position requires isometric frontal-plane lateral stabilization of the spine and hips to resist collapse (anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion). The shoulder of the moving arm performs transverse/horizontal movement to drive the reach-through while the supporting shoulder and scapula provide isometric support. notes: Variation: performed on forearm or hand—hand version increases shoulder extension/press demands. Regression: knee-supported side plank reduces hip/knee stabilization demand. reasoning: Primary requirement is isometric lateral trunk stabilization (anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion) to hold the side plank: the obliques, transverse abdominis and quadratus lumborum produce/isometrically resist lateral collapse while the shoulder/scapular stabilizers hold load. joint_actions.action: rotation (dynamic during reach), anti-rotation/isometric to resist rotation
flexion/horizontal adduction during reach (dynamic) and isometric stabilization on support side

exercise: Side Plank Reach-Throughs (sliding Bulgarian Bag, 35 lb)
reasoning: Primary action is dynamic trunk axial rotation (transverse plane) as the top arm reaches under the torso and returns — produced primarily by the internal and external obliques and assisted by rectus abdominis and serratus anterior/shoulder musculature. The side-plank position requires strong isometric anti-rotation and lateral stabilization (frontal/transverse control) from the contralateral obliques, transverse abdominis, quadratus lumborum and gluteus medius to hold hip alignment and prevent collapse. The shoulder of the reaching arm performs transverse-plane movement (horizontal adduction/rotation) and the support arm/scapula must isometrically stabilize (rotator cuff, serratus anterior). Hips and knees are largely isometric (hip abduction/extension) to maintain a stacked side-plank alignment. Because the exercise intentionally creates and moves through rotation while simultaneously demanding resistance to collapse, both ROTATION and ANTI_ROTATION patterns apply.

joint_actions.action: isometric lateral stabilization / resist lateral flexion
isometric extension (if extended) or controlled flexion/extension if touching)

notes: Loaded sliding Bulgarian bag increases transverse shear and shoulder/rotator cuff demand and accentuates anti-rotation torque. Variations: knees-down reduces hip/oblique demand; slow controlled reaches emphasize anti-rotation stability, larger/forceful reaches emphasize rotational power.

reasoning: Primary movement is dynamic trunk rotation in the transverse plane as the upper limb reaches through/under the torso (ROTATION). Simultaneously the body must resist collapse into lateral flexion and control rotational torque — the side-plank base requires isometric anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion effort from the obliques, transverse abdominis, quadratus lumborum and hip abductors (ANTI_ROTATION). joint_actions.action: horizontal flexion/rotation and reaching (dynamic); scapular protraction/retraction control (isometric/dynamic)

reasoning: This is a lateral/diagonal explosive jump (plyometric) where the primary goal is horizontal/ lateral propulsion (locomotion). The movement is produced by rapid triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) initiated from a partial squat position (squat pattern influence) with significant frontal-plane demand at the hip for lateral transfer of force. Primary joint actions are hip extension and hip abduction to drive lateral displacement, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion for propulsion, with bilateral/unilateral core and hip stabilizers controlling frontal-plane balance. Arm swing (shoulder flexion/extension) assists momentum but is secondary.
notes: Lateral emphasis increases demand on hip abductors and frontal-plane stability (single-leg landing stress). Variations (single-leg lateral jump, added load) increase unilateral stabilization and may raise ROTATION/ANTI_ROTATION demands if asymmetric loading or rotational components are added.

reasoning: Primary action is axial (spinal) rotation in the transverse plane — the thoracic and to a lesser extent lumbar spine rotate as the torso twists side to side. Primary movers are the obliques producing rotational torque; erector spinae and multifidus assist/coordinate the movement. Stabilization requirements include isometric control from the deep core (transversus abdominis, multifidus) and hip/gluteal muscles to maintain pelvic position and prevent excessive lumbar shear or lateral flexion. If performed standing, lower-limb musculature provides a stable base; if seated, hips/pelvis are stabilized to isolate thoracic rotation.
notes: Typical cooldown/stretching movement focused on thoracic rotation. Variations (seated vs standing, arms extended vs hands on hips) change demand on pelvic stabilization and shoulder movement. Avoid forceful lumbar rotation in individuals with spine pathology.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pull (chin-up) driven by elbow flexion and shoulder extension/adduction. The lats, teres major and posterior shoulder complex produce shoulder extension/adduction while the biceps brachii and brachialis produce elbow flexion; scapular retractors (rhomboids, mid/lower traps) control scapulothoracic motion. The side-to-side displacement introduces asymmetric loading and lateral/transverse forces on the torso, requiring isometric core action (obliques, transverse abdominis, erector spinae) to resist rotation and control lateral translation. Grip/forearm musculature must also sustain the load. Primary movers are the vertical pull musculature; the anti-rotation demand is a secondary but consistent stabilization requirement during the lateral excursion.
notes: This is fundamentally a vertical PULL variation (underhand chin grip implied). The lateral movement increases unilateral/oblique demand; if the drill is performed as deliberate trunk rotation (torso twisting) include ROTATION as an additional pattern. Progression/variation: strict vertical chin-ups (remove lateral motion) = PULL only; exaggerated lateral excursions or moving hand positions along a bar increase anti-rotation and unilateral shoulder load.

reasoning: Primary action is a manual pulling of the hand/forearm across the body. The glenohumeral joint undergoes horizontal adduction in the transverse plane as the arm is drawn medially; the elbow typically flexes isotonically or is held slightly flexed while the contralateral hand applies the force. The wrist is taken into flexion/extension or ulnar/radial deviation depending on the specific stretch cue. Primary movers creating the movement are shoulder horizontal adductors and elbow flexors in the pulling limb; forearm muscles control wrist position. Stabilization demands include rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers to control the shoulder, and isometric core and trunk musculature to maintain upright posture during the pull.
primary_muscles: wrist extensors/wrist flexors (depending on stretch position)

reasoning: Primary visible actions are contralateral limb extension (hip extension of the lifted leg and shoulder flexion of the lifted arm) performed from a quadruped/side-quadruped position while the trunk resists rotation and excessive extension. The limbs produce small concentric hip and shoulder movements, but the primary training stimulus is isometric core stabilization to prevent rotation and collapse of the spine/pelvis. Stabilizers include spinal extensors and deep core (multifidus, transverse abdominis) along with glute medius for pelvic control and scapular stabilizers for the shoulder.

joint_actions.action: isometric extension (if leg straight) or flexion (if knee bent)

reasoning: This is a lateral locomotor plyometric drill: primary purpose is repeated lateral displacement (side-to-side stepping/hopping) driven by hip ab/adduction and single‑leg push-offs. Each step/hop also requires repeated knee and hip flexion/extension to absorb and generate force (squat-like loading and unloading). Stabilization demands include frontal‑plane pelvic control by the glute medius/minimus during single‑leg phases and trunk anti‑lateral‑flexion/anti‑rotation control from obliques/erector spinae. Ankles provide push-off (plantarflexion) and shock absorption (dorsiflexion).
notes: If performed predominantly as small lateral hops (single‑leg), classification leans further toward plyometric/LOCOMOTION with increased demand on hip abductors and ankle plantarflexors. If performed as low, repeated two‑foot lateral steps with deep knee bend, SQUAT characteristics increase. Surface/box height and step cadence change relative contribution of power vs. stability.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip external rotation of the top femur with a small component of hip abduction while lying on the side. The hip joint is the prime mover (transverse plane rotation and frontal plane abduction). The knee is typically held in flexion and does not contribute dynamic movement (acts as a lever), and the trunk/pelvis must isometrically stabilize to prevent pelvic roll/tilt. This is primarily an isolated hip rotator/abductor exercise that trains transverse-plane rotation of the femur relative to the pelvis.
notes: Commonly performed with a resistance band around the knees to increase hip abduction/external rotation demand. Knee angle and pelvic position alter moment arms and muscle emphasis; performing with poor pelvic control shifts load to lumbar stabilizers.

reasoning: The side plank is primarily an isometric core stability exercise that resists lateral trunk flexion and rotation. The primary joint demands are isometric control of the spine in the frontal plane (anti-lateral flexion) with anti-rotation components in the transverse plane. The supporting shoulder and elbow provide vertical load-bearing/stabilization of the upper limb, and the hips generate isometric abduction/extension to keep the pelvis elevated. Primary movers produce sustained tension (obliques, QL, glute medius) while scapular stabilizers and shoulder musculature stabilize the load-bearing arm.

joint_actions.action: isometric abduction (and slight extension) to maintain pelvic elevation

notes: Isometric anti-lateral flexion/anti-rotation is the defining pattern. Variations (forearm vs. hand, stacked vs. staggered feet, top-leg raise) alter shoulder and hip demands. Knee-supported side plank reduces hip/oblique load; added reach or weight can increase rotational demand.

reasoning: Primary joint action is humeral external rotation at the glenohumeral (shoulder) joint in the transverse plane. The movement is an isolated rotational action of the humerus while the elbow is held flexed (isometric) and the torso is stabilized in side-lying. notes: Commonly performed with light dumbbell or band. Key cues: keep elbow pinned to side (or supported), avoid shoulder elevation and trunk rotation. Variations include seated/standing external rotation (changes stabilization demands).

reasoning: Primary action is dynamic trunk rotation in the transverse plane as the top arm reaches under the torso (reach-through), driven by oblique musculature. reasoning: Primary joint action is rotation of the thoracic spine in the transverse plane (top arm/shoulder often moves to facilitate/guide the rotation). Primary movers/passive tissues being lengthened include the thoracic erector spinae, multifidus and the external/internal obliques; the shoulder movement engages the posterior deltoid/rotator cuff and scapular retractors/derotators. Stabilization is provided isometrically by the contralateral obliques, deep core (transverse abdominis), and hip abductors/gluteus medius to maintain pelvic alignment while the upper thorax rotates.
notes: Name is ambiguous — some side-lying stretches focus on the hip (side-lying quad/IT-band) or are primarily passive spinal rotations. reasoning: Primary action is a single‑leg plyometric hop/skip pattern: knee flexion to bring the heel toward the glute (active concentric knee flexion) combined with ankle plantarflexion and hip extension for push‑off in the sagittal plane. The movement is a unilateral locomotor task (single‑leg hopping/marching) requiring dynamic push‑off and rapid limb recovery. Stabilization demands include frontal‑plane pelvic stability via hip abductors and transverse/core control to maintain upright single‑leg posture during the hop and landing.

reasoning: Primarily an isolated shoulder elevation (either shoulder abduction for a lateral raise or shoulder flexion for a front raise) produced by the deltoid and supraspinatus. Because the load is unilateral, the trunk and hips must produce isometric anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion torque to keep the spine vertical and resist the asymmetric moment. Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles control shoulder joint position while the contralateral core and hip abductors stabilize the pelvis and trunk.

reasoning: Primary movement is unilateral shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) performed against a cable (a horizontal push/fly action). The pectoralis major and anterior deltoid produce the concentric horizontal adduction while the serratus anterior and pecs support scapular control. Because the load is unilateral and external, the trunk must resist rotation and lateral flexion, so the core (obliques and deep stabilizers) and contralateral hip/gluteal complex act isometrically to stabilize. primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
