reasoning: Primary joint actions are unilateral hip flexion and knee flexion in the sagittal plane — mechanically similar to the limb position in a unilateral closed-chain flexed posture. The movement is non‑weightbearing and performed as a mobility/stretch, but the dominant kinematic pattern is unilateral sagittal-plane hip/knee flexion (lunge-type pattern). Stabilization is low-load but requires ipsilateral and contralateral pelvic/spinal control (core and hip abductors) to prevent pelvic tilt and rotation while the limb is drawn to the chest.
primary_muscles: hip extensors (lengthened, e.g., gluteus maximus as antagonist)
notes: Non‑weightbearing mobility/stretch; primary goal is flexibility and neural/muscular relaxation rather than force production. If performed standing or as a loaded march variation, classification would shift toward LUNGE/LOCOMOTION or CARRY depending on context.

reasoning: Primary action is a single‑leg propulsive (plyometric) triple extension in the sagittal plane: hip extension, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion generate forward/upward impulse. Primary movers are the hip extensors and knee extensors working concentrically with plantarflexors. Single‑leg stance requires frontal and transverse plane stabilization (hip abductors/adductors, core) to control pelvis and prevent valgus/rotation during push‑off and subsequent flight/landing.
notes: This is a single‑leg locomotion/plyometric pattern (single‑leg hop/step push‑off). Emphasize eccentric control on landing, trunk stability and hip abductor strength to minimize knee valgus. Variations (forward hop, vertical hop, bounding) remain LOCOMOTION with similar joint mechanics.

reasoning: Primary movement is unilateral hip extension in the sagittal plane (a posterior-chain hinge) produced mainly by the gluteus maximus and hamstrings as the pelvis is driven upward. Because the load is unilateral, there is substantial frontal/transverse plane demand to keep the pelvis level and resist rotation — the gluteus medius/minimus and lateral core (obliques, T.A.) act isometrically to prevent hip drop and rotation. The working knee remains relatively flexed and stable while the non-working limb may be held extended; trunk/spine extends slightly to maintain a neutral stacked position. Foot/ankle provide a stable base and the contralateral hip/core provide anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion stabilization.

joint_actions.action: posterior pelvic tilt/controlled extension and isometric anti-rotation

notes: Primary classification is HINGE due to hip extension; include ANTI_ROTATION because unilateral loading demands pelvic/rotational stabilization. Variations (straight-leg, elevated foot, banded, weighted) alter hamstring vs glute emphasis and stabilization demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a unilateral pressing action: shoulder elevation/press with elbow extension (vertical/linear push in the sagittal plane). Because the load is single-arm and offset from the midline, the trunk (obliques, transverse abdominis, erector spinae) and contralateral hip/shoulder musculature produce isometric anti-rotation and lateral stabilization to resist torsion. Secondary scapular motion (upward rotation/protraction) and lower‑body bracing support the press.
notes: Similar to a single-arm landmine/one-arm press or jammer machine press. If performed on an angled/diagonal path or with a rotational finish, include ROTATION as a secondary pattern. Foot position and leg drive can increase lower-body contribution but do not change primary classification.

reasoning: Primary action is a horizontal push: the working arm produces elbow extension and shoulder horizontal adduction to raise/lower the torso relative to the hand (transverse and sagittal components). Because loading is unilateral, the trunk must produce isometric anti-rotation torque to resist collapse/rotation toward the unloaded side; hips and lower limb musculature also produce isometric extension to maintain a rigid plank. Scapular stabilizers control protraction/retraction and provide a stable base for the push. Primary movers for the push are pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps; serratus anterior and lower traps stabilize the scapula; obliques/transverse abdominis and gluteals provide anti-rotation and global trunk/hip stiffness.
notes: Single-arm variation substantially increases rotational demand and scapular/core stabilization compared with bilateral push-ups. Common regressions: elevated surface, knee-supported single-arm push-up. Progressions: decline single-arm push-up, weighted vest, slower eccentrics. Wrist position and scapular control are key to technique and shoulder health.

reasoning: Primary action is a plyometric single-leg propulsion and landing (locomotion). Takeoff requires concentric triple extension (hip and knee extension, ankle plantarflexion) in the sagittal plane to generate vertical/horizontal impulse; flight is ballistic; landing requires eccentric hip/knee/ankle flexion to absorb impact. Single-leg stance imposes substantial frontal-plane hip stabilization (gluteus medius) and ankle inversion/eversion control for balance. Core isometrically stabilizes the trunk to maintain alignment during flight and landing.
notes: Progression typically moves from double-leg to alternating hops to single-leg. Emphasize controlled eccentric landing to reduce injury risk; watch for knee valgus on landing. Variations include forward, lateral, and depth single-leg hops which add directional/rotational demand.

reasoning: Primary action is a unilateral explosive lateral displacement (plyometric locomotor task) driven by concentric hip and knee extension and ankle plantarflexion to produce lateral impulse and eccentric control on landing. Hip ab-/adduction and frontal-plane pelvic control by the gluteus medius and hip adductors contribute to mediolateral movement; gluteus maximus and quadriceps generate extension power. The trunk and contralateral musculature act isometrically to resist rotation and lateral collapse (anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion) during single-leg stance and flight-to-landing transitions. Stabilization demands at the hip and core are high to control frontal- and transverse-plane forces on takeoff and landing.

joint_actions.action: extension (concentric takeoff) and eccentric flexion on landing

notes: Primarily a frontal-plane locomotion/power task with high single-leg stability demands. Variations: medial hops, bounding, or adding reach tasks increase rotational/anti-rotation demands. Emphasize soft, controlled landings and hip abductor strengthening to reduce valgus collapse and injury risk.

reasoning: Primary objective is forward sprinting and change-of-direction around a cone — a locomotor task. Primary joint actions are repeated sagittal-plane hip, knee and ankle extension during push-off (propulsion) and hip/knee flexion during swing. Cutting or rounding the cone introduces transverse-plane trunk/hip rotation and frontal-plane hip ab/adduction for medial-lateral force production and balance, but these are secondary to the locomotion (propulsive) demands. Core and lower-limb musculature produce concentric propulsion and eccentric deceleration; trunk and hip abductors/adductors stabilize against lateral/rotational perturbation.

joint_actions.action: axial rotation and anti-rotation stabilization (during direction change)

notes: If the drill emphasizes straight-line sprint only, locomotion alone is sufficient. If the cone requires sharp cuts/turns, expect increased transverse-plane rotation and frontal-plane hip loading (may warrant adding ROTATION as a secondary pattern). Eccentric deceleration capacity (quadriceps/hamstrings) is important in stopping/changing direction variations.

reasoning: Primary action is a unilateral hip hinge in the sagittal plane: the stance-leg hip flexes as the torso leans forward to reach the toe, then extends to return upright. The spine flexes slightly during the reach and must be re-extended, and the stance-knee undergoes minimal change (small flexion to allow hip hinge). Because the exercise is single-leg, significant frontal-plane and transverse-plane stabilization is required from the hip abductors/adductors and the core to prevent pelvic drop/rotation, but these are stabilizing demands rather than primary movement patterns. Primary movers producing the hinge are the hamstrings and gluteus maximus, with spinal extensors eccentrically controlling forward flexion and concentrically assisting re-extension. Ankle dorsiflexors/plantarflexors and intrinsic foot muscles assist balance on the stance foot.
notes: Primarily a unilateral hinge and balance/mobility drill. Progresses to weighted single-leg RDLs when load is added. Common faults: excessive spinal flexion (rounding), knee collapse/valgus (insufficient hip abductor control), limited hip hinge (bending at knee instead).

reasoning: Primary movement is isolated knee extension in the sagittal plane performed on one leg. The knee joint performs concentric extension (quadriceps-driven) while the hip and trunk act primarily isometrically to stabilize single-leg posture. This is an open-chain, knee-dominant movement; because available movement pattern taxonomy groups knee-dominant, sagittal-plane lower-limb loading under SQUAT-like patterns, SQUAT is the closest match despite minimal hip extension compared with bilateral loaded squats.
notes: This is an open-chain, single-joint knee-extension exercise that primarily targets the quadriceps. It has limited hip extension and lower functional transfer compared with multi-joint SQUAT movements. If performed seated on a machine, stability demands are lower; if performed standing or with reach variations, frontal-plane hip abductors and core anti-rotation demands increase. Consider classifying as an isolation knee-extension movement when a taxonomy supports that distinction.

reasoning: Primary action is unilateral triple-extension to produce forward propulsion from a split-stance (hip and knee extension + ankle plantarflexion) characteristic of locomotion/bounding. The split stance and single-leg push-off share mechanics with a lunge pattern (powerful concentric from a split stance). Secondary demands include frontal-plane hip stabilization to control pelvic drop and sagittal-plane trunk stabilization on takeoff and landing. Takeoff: hip and knee extensors (glute max, quads, hamstrings) and plantarflexors generate force; landing requires eccentric control of the same musculature and increased glute med/abductor activity for frontal-plane control.
notes: Plyometric, unilateral, primarily sagittal-plane propulsion with important frontal-plane stabilization. Variations (forward bound vs vertical single-leg hop) may shift emphasis more toward LOCOMOTION or a unilateral SQUAT-like pattern. Watch for knee valgus on landing — increases demand on gluteus medius/hip external rotators.

reasoning: The sit-up primarily involves sagittal plane trunk flexion with a substantial contribution from hip flexion as the torso is brought upright. Primary joint actions are lumbar/thoracic spinal flexion (primary) and hip flexion (secondary/assist), with the knees typically held in a flexed, stabilized position. Muscles producing the movement include the rectus abdominis (spinal flexion) and the iliopsoas/hip flexors (hip flexion); external obliques assist and stabilize. Stabilization requirements include isometric control from the erector spinae during lowering, pelvic stabilization from the gluteal complex and hamstrings to limit posterior tilt, and shoulder/scapular stabilization if arms are used for assist or bracing.
notes: Variation-dependent: a strict crunch emphasizes spinal flexion (more abdominal dominant), while a full sit-up with feet anchored increases hip flexor contribution. Lumbar loading considerations for those with low-back issues.

reasoning: Skating is a lateral locomotion/plyometric movement performed as alternating single-leg push-offs and landings. Primary joint actions are hip abduction and hip extension on the push-off (frontal + sagittal planes), and eccentric hip adduction/hip flexion and knee flexion during landing/absorption (frontal + sagittal). The knee and ankle produce sagittal-plane propulsion/absorption via knee extension and plantarflexion. Core and hip stabilizers (glute medius/minimus, adductors, obliques) work isometrically to maintain frontal-plane balance and control pelvis alignment. Overall the movement is dominated by frontal-plane lateral transfer of bodyweight (locomotion) with significant single-leg stabilization demands.
notes: Typically performed as alternating lateral bounds or skating hops; can be low-impact (gliding) or plyometric. Emphasis on frontal-plane power and single-leg balance. Progressions add load or speed; regressions reduce amplitude or perform step transfers.

reasoning: Primary demand is an isometric loaded stance: the standing limb produces isometric hip and knee extension to support body/ load while the core and shoulder musculature hold the sandbag in a rack position. Hip abductors (gluteus medius) and gluteus maximus resist pelvic drop and provide frontal/sagittal plane support; the trunk (obliques, transverse abdominis, erector spinae) acts isometrically to prevent lateral flexion and rotation caused by single-leg support and any asymmetry of the load. Shoulders and elbows maintain an isometric front-rack hold (anterior deltoids, upper traps, biceps). Ankles perform continuous sagittal/frontal plane stabilization for balance.

joint_actions.action: isometric abduction to resist pelvic drop and isometric extension to maintain upright posture
continuous isometric plantarflexion/dorsiflexion and inversion/eversion control for balance
isometric anti-rotation and anti-lateral-flexion (bracing) to stabilize trunk against asymmetry and single-leg perturbation
isometric shoulder flexion/anti-depression in front-rack to hold sandbag
isometric flexion (holds sandbag close to torso)

notes: If performed as a stationary hold, it's classified as a carry-style loaded stance with strong anti-rotation and frontal-plane demands. Single-arm or offset rack variations increase anti-rotation demand. Dynamic marching transitions add LOCOMOTION; bilateral stance reduces ANTI_ROTATION and frontal-plane hip demand. Watch for knee/ankle stability and progressive load only after hip/core control is adequate.

reasoning: Primary demand is an isometric vertical pull: the shoulder and scapulothoracic complex support bodyweight through one arm (scapular depression/traction and glenohumeral overhead positioning) with the elbow held in extension. The unilateral load creates a rotational and lateral torque on the torso that the core must resist (anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion). Grip and forearm flexors produce the hand/finger force to maintain the hang, while scapular stabilizers and lats generate/isometrically sustain the vertical pull. Hips and lower limbs are passive.
primary_muscles: forearm flexors (flexor digitorum profundus/superficialis, flexor pollicis longus)
notes: Variation between passive and active hang (scapular depression engaged vs. relaxed) changes relative scapular muscle activation. Progressions include timed one-arm hangs, assisted single-arm holds, or eccentric negatives to concentric pull-ups. Caution with pre-existing shoulder or elbow pathology; ensure scapular control before prolonged single-arm loading.

reasoning: The harness sled drag is a loaded walk: primary movement is locomotion (repeated gait cycles) while carrying/resisting a load via the harness. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip extension, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion during push-off to propel the body and sled; hip/knee/ankle flexion occur during swing. The load through the harness means the posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings) and quads produce propulsion while the calves contribute to push-off. The trunk and pelvic stabilizers (erector spinae, obliques, transverse abdominis, glute medius) act isometrically to maintain posture, resist excessive thoracic/ pelvic rotation and transfer force to the sled. Because the task is loaded walking, the movement is best described as CARRY (loaded locomotion) with LOCOMOTION as the specific gait pattern.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (resist flexion/rotation) and small transverse pelvic rotation during gait

notes: Variations (forward vs. backward drag, incline, unilateral harness) modify joint emphasis (e.g., backward drag increases knee demand). Asymmetric or single‑side loading would add ANTI_ROTATION. Resistance level and gait speed change relative contribution of posterior vs. anterior chain.

reasoning: Slam ball slams are a compound, sagittal-plane power movement. The athlete typically initiates force with rapid hip and knee extension (hip hinge pattern) to generate proximal drive, then transfers that force through trunk flexion and powerful shoulder/arm movement to drive the ball downward (a vertical push action from overhead to forceful shoulder extension/elbow extension). Primary movers for force production are the posterior chain (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) and quadriceps for leg drive, with the rectus abdominis/obliques and thoracic flexors transferring/adding trunk flexion power, and shoulder/arm extensors (lats/posterior deltoid/triceps) accelerating the ball. Stabilization demands include core anti-extension/anti-rotation, scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff control, and lower-limb single-stance stabilization during explosive triple extension.
notes: If performed as a rotational slam (standing with trunk rotation or diagonal slams) include ROTATION in movements and increase oblique loading. A purely seated or strict-arm slam reduces hinge contribution and would increase relative PUSH/trunk-only classification.

reasoning: Primary task is a loaded overhead carry while performing backward gait. The load is held overhead isometrically at the shoulders (shoulder flexion/abduction and elbow extension to maintain the position) requiring scapular and rotator cuff stabilization. Locomotion backward primarily involves repeated sagittal-plane hip extension, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion to create step-to-step propulsion and deceleration. Core and spinal extensors act isometrically to maintain upright posture and resist trunk flexion/rotation under the overhead load.
notes: If the overhead load is asymmetric or one‑armed, add ANTI_ROTATION. Overhead position increases shoulder and thoracic mobility and requires good scapular upward rotation and rotator cuff strength. Backward gait alters joint loading (greater knee control) — cue controlled step length and stable trunk. Ensure progressive loading and attention to shoulder stability.

reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder horizontal abduction with concomitant scapular retraction in the transverse plane — the athlete moves the arms away from midline against resistance (sled) which is a horizontal pulling action. The shoulders (posterior deltoid and scapular retractors) produce the movement; the elbows remain slightly flexed as link joints. The thorax/spine acts isometrically to stabilize trunk position (anti-flexion/anti-rotation). If performed bent-over, the hips maintain a static hinge to create torso angle, but this is a stabilizing requirement rather than a primary pattern.
notes: Commonly classified as a horizontal pull variation. If the sled version requires walking while performing the pull (moving the sled), LOCOMOTION may be a secondary pattern; if performed prone on an incline, spinal loading and scapular stabilization demands increase. Equipment/setup (fixed handles vs. moving sled) can slightly alter stabilization demands but not the primary PULL classification.

reasoning: Primary action is propulsive locomotion produced by repeated hip, knee and ankle extension in the sagittal plane while the athlete applies a horizontal pushing force through the shoulders/hands against the sled. Lower body (glutes, quadriceps, plantarflexors) generates ground force to drive the sled; upper body (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, serratus anterior, triceps) produces a sustained horizontal push and scapular protraction. The trunk and hips act isometrically to transmit force and resist unwanted extension/rotation (core and gluteal stabilizers).

joint_actions.action: horizontal push / protraction (isotonic/isometric depending on load)

notes: Variations: low-handle sled push increases hip/knee demand; heavy/short pushes emphasize maximal force production, lighter/longer pushes emphasize power/endurance. Asymmetric hand placement or unilateral sled drags introduce anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demands and may add ANTI_ROTATION. Sled pull would shift pattern toward PULL + LOCOMOTION.

reasoning: The sledgehammer swing is a ballistic rotational chop: primary motion is trunk rotation in the transverse plane transferring force through the hips to the shoulder/arm to accelerate the hammer. The hips commonly perform a hinge-like extension to generate power (hip drive) while knees/ankles adjust for stance and force transfer. Shoulders and elbows produce the final acceleration and braking of the hammer. Stabilization demands include resisting excessive spinal flexion/extension and controlling transverse forces — the core (obliques/erector spinae) and hip/gluteal complex act isometrically/eccentrically to stabilize the torso and pelvis during the rotational swing.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension and horizontal adduction/abduction during swing
joint_actions.plane: sagittal and transverse (diagonal/oblique plane characteristic of chops)

notes: Alternating sides reduces continuous unilateral loading but remains an asymmetric rotational power task; exercise is ballistic—emphasize hip/leg drive and trunk rotation to protect the lumbar spine. If performed more as a slow controlled chop (no hip hinge), ROTATION still primary; if athlete uses pronounced deadlift-style hinge to lift/missile swing, HINGE contribution increases.

reasoning: Primary movement is a dynamic diagonal/rotational chop and slam: powerful transverse-plane trunk rotation (and anti-rotation control during deceleration) combined with sagittal-plane hip hinge and knee drive to generate force. Shoulders and elbows produce the acceleration and deceleration of the hammer (shoulder flexion/extension and horizontal adduction, elbow flexion/extension). Spine rotation and flexion transfer force from lower body to the implement. Stabilization demands include isometric control from the obliques/rectus and erector spinae to manage trunk rotation and deceleration, and lower-limb/gluteal control to stabilize the hip hinge and absorb ground reaction forces. ROTATION is primary because the exercise intentionally generates transverse-plane torque; HINGE is secondary as hip extension/drive is typically used to generate power and to decelerate.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension and horizontal adduction during swing
isometric stabilization and slight flexion/extension during impact

notes: High-repetition Tabata tempo emphasizes power endurance and trunk rotational capacity. Variation in technique can shift emphasis (more hip drive increases HINGE contribution; more isolated upper-body chops increase shoulder/rotational emphasis). Ensure core and shoulder stability to reduce low-back and shoulder injury risk.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow extension in the sagittal plane (triceps-driven) with the arms held overhead. The shoulder complex is held in an overhead/stabilized position (isometric shoulder flexion/abduction) while the scapulothoracic muscles produce upward rotation and protraction to allow the overhead position. The trunk and hips act isometrically to stabilize the torso against extension and maintain a stable base while force is produced at the elbows. Because the primary moving joint is the elbow producing an extending (pushing) action overhead, this classifies as a vertical PUSH pattern.
notes: If performed single-arm or asymmetrically loaded, include ANTI_ROTATION due to lateral/rotational stabilization demand. Sled resistance path (linear cable/sled) can alter torque curve compared with free-weight overhead triceps work; monitor shoulder position to avoid impingement. Variations (lying/kneeling) change scapular/trunk stabilization demands but do not change primary PUSH classification.

reasoning: Primary action is powerful trunk rotation (transverse plane) to accelerate the hammer through a diagonal/arc. Secondary primary contributor is a hip hinge pattern that generates force transfer from the posterior chain into the trunk (sagittal plane hip extension). Shoulders and elbows act to steer and accelerate the implement (shoulder horizontal/diagonal flexion/extension and elbow extension/flexion) while the thoracic spine provides large rotational ROM. Stabilization demands include isometric/anti-extension control of the lumbar spine and anti-rotation control from the obliques and deep core as the arms and hammer create large rotational and shear loads.
notes: Variations (overhead start, two-handed vs alternating) change shoulder/elbow emphasis and increase asymmetry (adding anti-rotation demand). High-impact/rotational stress — emphasize hip hinge mechanics, thoracic mobility, and progressive loading to protect lumbar spine and shoulder. When performed as alternating single-arm swings, consider including ANTI_ROTATION as a secondary pattern for unilateral stabilization.

reasoning: The slide-bag side-plank is primarily an isometric lateral/postural stability task: the spine must resist lateral flexion and rotational torque while the shoulder and hip provide isometric support. Primary joint actions are isometric stabilization of the spine against lateral flexion and rotation (frontal/transverse plane), isometric shoulder support/scapular stabilization (frontal/scapular plane), and isometric hip abduction/pelvic stabilization (frontal plane). The slide-bag element can add a transverse (rotational) perturbation, increasing anti-rotation demand. Stabilization requires coordinated activation of trunk rotators/anti-rotators, scapular stabilizers, and hip abductors to maintain a straight plank alignment.

joint_actions.action: resists lateral flexion and rotation (isometric anti-lateral-flexion and anti-rotation)
isometric support / scapular stabilization (vertical load bearing, resists collapse)
isometric abduction and pelvic stabilization (prevents hip drop)

notes: Variation: if the slide-bag is actively moved (dragging/reaching) the exercise introduces dynamic transverse rotation and may be classified additionally as ROTATION; forearm vs. hand support changes shoulder/elbow loading. Emphasize scapular control and pelvic alignment to prevent substitution (hip drop, thoracic rotation).

reasoning: Primary demand is isometric anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion of the trunk: the obliques and quadratus lumborum resist spinal rotation and lateral collapse while the pelvis is held aloft in the frontal plane. The supporting shoulder complex (deltoid, rotator cuff, serratus anterior, scapular stabilizers) and triceps provide isometric support at the shoulder/elbow to keep the torso elevated. The hip musculature (gluteus medius/minimus and gluteus maximus) isometrically controls pelvic alignment; if the slide-bag element introduces movement of the free leg, there is additional dynamic hip adduction/abduction in the frontal plane which increases transverse/frontal plane control requirements. Stabilization requirements include scapular stability, shoulder/elbow load bearing, and isometric hip and core control to prevent spinal rotation and lateral flexion.

joint_actions.action: resists lateral flexion (isometric) and resists rotation (anti-rotation, isometric)
hip abduction / pelvic elevation (isometric); may include dynamic hip adduction/abduction if sliding leg moves
scapulothoracic and glenohumeral stabilization (isometric), supporting weight through the shoulder
near-full extension (isometric) providing a column of support

notes: Performed as a static side plank with a sliding element under the moving leg; if the free leg is actively slid in/out, add emphasis on dynamic hip adduction/abduction and increased transverse-plane control. Variations: forearm vs. hand support alters shoulder load; elevated/loaded variations change intensity. Primary classification remains ANTI_ROTATION due to spine stabilization demand.

exercise: Smith Machine Behind the Back Shrug
reasoning: Primary movement is scapulothoracic elevation (vertical uplift of the shoulder girdle) produced by the upper trapezius and levator scapulae. The bar positioned behind the body places the humerus in slight extension/retroversion but the primary moving segment is the scapulae elevating in the frontal plane. Elbows and hands maintain an isometric grip on the bar; the thoracic/lumbar spine and erector spinae act isometrically to stabilize trunk and preserve posture while the scapular elevators generate the movement.
notes: Functionally a variation of the barbell shrug — primarily a PULL pattern (scapular elevation). Behind-the-back setup alters shoulder/humeral position and can increase shoulder/wrist ROM demands; cue scapular motion rather than excessive cervical elevation. Avoid with limited shoulder mobility or prior posterior shoulder pathology.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal/decline press: shoulder horizontal adduction (transverse plane) with concurrent elbow extension (sagittal plane) producing a pushing action. The decline angle shifts emphasis to the inferior/sternal fibers of the pectoralis major. The Smith machine fixed path reduces demand on dynamic shoulder/scapular stabilizers but scapular protraction/retraction and rotator cuff activity remain important for joint control. The trunk and pelvis are isometrically stabilized on the bench.
notes: Decline angle biases lower/steral pec fibers. Using a Smith machine reduces requirement for transverse-plane stabilization and may alter bar path mechanics compared with free-bar decline bench press. Ensure scapular control and rotator-cuff activation for shoulder health.

reasoning: Primary motion is shoulder horizontal abduction / posterior elevation (reverse/incline rear-delt raise) while lying on an incline; the movement draws the arms back/out laterally against resistance — functionally a horizontal pull of the upper limb. The glenohumeral joint performs horizontal abduction (transverse plane) with accompanying scapular retraction/packing; the elbow remains relatively extended and the spine/core act isometrically to stabilize the torso on the bench. Primary movers (posterior deltoid, middle trapezius, rhomboids) produce the joint movement while rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control humeral head and scapular position.
notes: Assumes the incline shoulder raise refers to a prone/incline rear-delt (reverse) raise. If the exercise is an incline front raise (shoulder flexion) or an incline press variant, primary pattern would change (PUSH for press, isolated shoulder flexion not well-captured by the provided pattern set). Scapular control and rotator cuff integrity are important to avoid impingement during this transverse-plane shoulder work.

reasoning: Primary movement is ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane producing a vertical displacement of the body/loaded bar (a vertical push against the ground). The Smith machine places a vertical load across the shoulders so the lower limb performs concentric plantarflexion to raise the heels. Secondary requirements include isometric stabilization at the knee and hip to maintain upright posture and resist forward/backward translation (Smith frame reduces need for lateral stabilization).
notes: If performed with fully locked knees (standing), gastrocnemius contribution is greater; with bent knees (seated variation) soleus is emphasized. Smith machine limits transverse/frontal plane instability; if performed as single-leg or with asymmetric load, ANTI_ROTATION/CARRY considerations would apply.

reasoning: Primary movement is closed-chain lower‑body sagittal plane knee and hip extension against a fixed vertical/resisted track, functionally equivalent to a squat/leg press pattern. The knees extend (quadriceps drive) and the hips extend (gluteus maximus and hamstrings assist) to push the load; ankles contribute with plantarflexion through the push phase. The machine/back support reduces demand on spinal stabilizers and frontal/transverse plane control compared with free‑weight squat, but the core and hips still provide isometric stabilization.
notes: Variation of leg press/squat using Smith machine; foot placement (high vs low, narrow vs wide) shifts emphasis between glutes/hamstrings and quadriceps. Machine reduces requirement for balance and transverse/frontal plane stabilization compared with free‑weight squats.

reasoning: Primary action is hip extension in the sagittal plane (hip rises toward full extension). The movement is a posterior-chain dominant hinge: gluteus maximus produces the bulk of the extension, hamstrings assist, and spinal extensors (erector spinae) help extend/stabilize the trunk. Knees are generally held in a flexed/isometric position (fixed foot placement) so knee motion is minimal; the lumbar spine must be stabilized to prevent excessive hyperextension. Using a Smith machine changes balance/stabilization demands (fixed bar path) but does not alter the primary hip-extension hinge pattern.
notes: Often performed as a glute bridge or hip thrust with bar across hips/shoulders; Smith machine reduces transverse/frontal plane stabilization demands compared with free-bar variants. Knee angle and bench height alter hamstring vs. glute emphasis. Watch for excessive lumbar extension.

reasoning: Primary action is an explosive hip hinge from the hang (power phase) producing hip extension with secondary knee and ankle extension (triple extension) to generate upward bar momentum — this is a HINGE-dominant power action. Immediately followed by an active vertical/high pull (scapular elevation/shoulder upward movement and rapid elbow flexion to pull the bar and then pull-under into the catch) which is a PULL pattern. The catch phase involves rapid knee/hip flexion into a partial squat but is secondary to the explosive hinge and pull. Stabilization requires trunk extension control (erector spinae, abdominals) and scapular stability; using a Smith machine enforces a fixed vertical bar path which reduces transverse/frontal plane stabilization demands compared with a free barbell clean.

joint_actions.action: extension (during triple extension) and rapid flexion for catch
elevation/shrug and some shoulder flexion/abduction during high pull
joint_actions.plane: primarily frontal for scapular elevation, sagittal for shoulder flexion

joint_actions.action: rapid flexion to pull the body under the bar (and some extension on catch)

notes: Smith machine constrains bar path (vertical), reducing need for transverse/frontal stabilization and slightly altering technique compared with a free-weight hang power clean. Catch is typically a partial/quarter squat (power catch) — if performed into a deep full squat, consider adding SQUAT as a secondary pattern.

reasoning: This is a vertical push. Primary joint actions are shoulder elevation (primarily shoulder flexion in the sagittal/scapular plane with abduction components) and elbow extension (sagittal) to drive the bar upward. Scapular upward rotation and elevation (trapezius, serratus anterior) enable full overhead range. Core and spinal extensors act isometrically to prevent excessive lumbar extension and provide a stable trunk; lower limb joints provide isometric support when standing. The Smith machine constrains bar path vertically, reducing the need for transverse/frontal plane stabilization but preserving the vertical push mechanics.
notes: Classic vertical pushing pattern. Can be performed seated or standing; grip width and bar path alter deltoid emphasis. If performed with leg drive (push press) it becomes a compound push+hip drive variation.

reasoning: The snatch is a compound Olympic lift that begins with a hip-dominant hinge (deep hip flexion then explosive hip extension) and a powerful triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to drive the bar upward (PRIMARY: HINGE + PULL). The second pull/shrug and arm positioning are a vertical/upper-body pull pattern (PULL) that accelerates the bar. Most snatches are finished by dropping under the bar into a deep overhead catch, which is a full-depth overhead squat pattern (SQUAT) requiring knee/hip flexion while stabilizing the load overhead. Spine and shoulder girdle provide substantial isometric stabilization throughout (anti-flexion/anti-rotation) to control the bar path and receive the load.

joint_actions.action: elevation/abduction into locked overhead position (receive) with scapular upward rotation during pull/shrug

notes: Variation between power snatch and squat snatch changes emphasis on the SQUAT component; the lift has high technical and mobility demands (thoracic extension, hip/ankle mobility). Although the shoulders/elbows stabilize overhead rather than perform a pressing action, they are essential for receiving and holding the load.

reasoning: This is an isolated ankle-joint exercise whose primary movement is ankle dorsiflexion (lifting the toes toward the shin) in the sagittal plane. The Smith machine provides a fixed bar across the upper back/shoulders (or front of shoulders depending on setup), so the exercise requires minimal multi-joint action beyond isometric stabilization of the hips, knees and spine. Primary movement is produced by dorsiflexors of the foot (concentric dorsiflexion), with plantarflexors controlling the lowering eccentrically. Stabilization demands include isometric trunk and hip control to maintain upright posture under the bar and balance of the foot on the platform; the Smith machine reduces medio-lateral balance requirements compared with free-weight variations.
notes: This exercise is primarily an isolated ankle dorsiflexion movement and does not map cleanly to the typical gross movement patterns (SQUAT, HINGE, PUSH, PULL, LUNGE, CARRY, ROTATION, ANTI_ROTATION, LOCOMOTION). If performed with toes rising (reverse calf raise), tibialis anterior is emphasized; if performed as a traditional calf raise (heels up) the gastrocnemius/soleus would be primary instead. Smith machine setup reduces balance demands but requires trunk/shoulder contact with the bar for stabilization.

reasoning: The Snatch Balance is primarily a squat-pattern movement: the lifter performs a short dip/drive then rapidly drops into and receives a low squat under an overhead load, then stands up. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion to receive (and subsequent extension to stand) with ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion. The arms/shoulders and elbow remain locked overhead isometrically to stabilize the bar, and the thoracic/ lumbar spine and scapular stabilizers resist collapse. Muscles producing the vertical displacement are principally the quadriceps and gluteus maximus (with hamstrings and calves contributing), while deltoids, triceps and rotator-cuff/scapular muscles provide isometric overhead stability and the core/erector spinae maintain trunk posture.
notes: Considered an overhead squat variant with dynamic drop-under. Primary training effect is squat mechanics (receiving and standing from a low squat) while demanding high shoulder/upper-back isometric stability and thoracic mobility. Variations (split snatch balance) add unilateral/lunge elements.

reasoning: The snatch shrug is primarily a vertical pulling action of the shoulder girdle: an explosive scapulothoracic elevation/upward rotation to drive the barbell higher during the second pull. The primary joint action is scapular elevation/upward rotation at the shoulder complex (frontal/transverse emphasis). Elbows remain extended (isometric) and the lower limbs often produce a secondary plantarflexion (ankle) and slight hip/knee extension to augment upward momentum. Stabilization demands include isometric elbow and thoracic control (triceps, lats) to maintain a straight arm and neutral spine while the upper traps and levator scapulae elevate the scapulae.
notes: If performed strictly as an isolated shrug (standing with bar in hands), classification as PULL is high confidence. When performed as part of a full snatch pull sequence, there are temporally earlier hip/knee hinge and extension contributions — but the isolated 'snatch shrug' movement is primarily scapular elevation. Variations (dumbbell vs barbell, shrug on toes) change ankle involvement and stabilization demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge with powerful hip and knee extension (triple extension at ankle/knee/hip) to drive the load upward, combined with an explosive vertical pull (shrug/upper trap driven scapular elevation and upward acceleration of the bar) while elbows remain extended. The hip hinge (sagittal plane) and trunk/erector control produce force transfer, while the shoulder girdle (scapular elevation/upward rotation in frontal/transverse components) produces the vertical pull. Core and spinal erectors provide anti-flexion stabilization; lats/rhomboids and rotator cuff stabilize the shoulder girdle during the pull.

joint_actions.action: maintained in extension (isometric; no primary flexion)

notes: Typical snatch pull performed with barbell is a textbook example of a hinge-dominant movement combined with a vertical pull (no catch). Variations (high pull, power snatch pull, using trap bar) may alter emphasis slightly but retain HINGE+PULL pattern. If performed without external load (bodyweight/unknown), pattern still emphasizes hip hinge and scapular elevation mechanics.

reasoning: Primary action is a forceful triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) to accelerate the bar vertically (hip extension = hinge dominant) followed by a high vertical pull/extension of the torso and rapid elevation of the bar while the lifter pulls themselves under the bar. Joints: hips and knees extend in the sagittal plane producing the primary propulsive force (glutes, hamstrings, quads), ankles plantarflex to add final drive (gastrocnemius/soleus). The upper body executes a vertical pull and rapidly receives/stabilizes the bar overhead — traps, lats and posterior deltoids produce/assist the pull and rotator cuff/deltoids stabilize the overhead catch. The spine resists flexion (isometric extension) to transmit force. If the bar is received in a deep squat the exercise adds a pronounced eccentric/sagittal knee and hip control component (SQUAT-like), but the core mechanics from blocks are dominated by hinge-driven pull mechanics.
notes: Block height and intent (power vs. squat snatch) can change the degree to which a SQUAT pattern is involved on the catch. Overhead stability requires strong rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers; timing (second pull + pull-under) is critical. Primarily trained as a pull/hinge variation in Olympic weightlifting progressions.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow extension in the sagittal plane against band resistance — a single-joint pushing action (triceps-driven). The shoulder is positioned overhead (shoulder flexion) and functions largely as an isometric stabilizer; scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles maintain glenohumeral and scapulothoracic position. The core and lumbar extensors act isometrically to prevent excessive spinal extension while resisting the band pull. Thus the dominant pattern is a vertical push (elbow extension) with substantial upper‑quarter and core stabilization demands.
notes: Band placement (behind head vs. overhead anchor) and single‑arm vs double‑arm variation can alter shoulder torque and anti‑rotation demands; unilateral versions introduce anti-rotation/carry-like stabilization considerations. This is primarily an isolation vertical push (elbow extension) rather than a multi-joint press.

reasoning: Snow Clearing is a shoveling-style warmup that primarily uses a hip hinge (sagittal plane) to lower the torso and a thoracic/trunk rotational component (transverse plane) to sweep the arms from one side to the other. The hip hinge loads the posterior chain (glutes/hamstrings) while the thoracic spine, obliques and intercostals drive and control rotation. Shoulders perform a transverse-plane sweep (horizontal adduction/extension) to mimic the shovel arc. Core musculature (obliques, transverse abdominis) and erector spinae stabilize the spine against flexion and uncontrolled rotation; lower-limb muscles provide a stable base and small knee/ankle adjustments for balance.
notes: Commonly bodyweight/mobility drill. If performed with an asymmetric load (single-arm shovel or weight), ANTI_ROTATION should be added due to asymmetric torque. If stepping/lunging while sweeping, LUNGE or LOCOMOTION elements may be present.

reasoning: The exercise name 'Spell Caster' is ambiguous and used for multiple different drills (standing single‑leg/anti‑rotation reach, supine/bridging letter‑tracing, mobility reach drills, etc.). Without a movement description or video, primary joint actions cannot be determined reliably. Because movement patterns describe joint actions and planes, assigning a pattern requires knowing whether the drill is primarily anti‑rotational/isometric core work, single‑leg balance with hip/knee movement, a reaching/pressing action, or a sagittal plane hinge/squat. I cannot prioritize primary movers over stabilizers without that detail.
notes: Provide one of the following to allow a definitive classification: a short description of start and end positions, which limbs move (arms/legs), whether the spine rotates or resists rotation, whether weight is loaded or bodyweight only, and the primary plane of motion. Example mappings of common variants: (A) Standing anti‑rotation 'spell caster' (arms reach across while standing in split stance) -> movements: ["ANTI_ROTATION", "LUNGE" or "SQUAT" (if significant knee/hip flexion)] and primary actions: torso anti‑rotation, single‑leg support.
