reasoning: Primary action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane (curling the forearm toward the humerus) performed from a prone/incline position. The biceps brachii, brachialis and brachioradialis produce the concentric elbow flexion. The shoulder is held in a fixed position on the bench (isometric stabilization), and the scapula/rotator cuff and upper back act isometrically to stabilize the shoulder girdle while the elbow moves. Spine and hips remain neutral/controlled on the bench with no primary sagittal-plane hip or knee movement.
notes: Isolation elbow-flexion variation performed prone on an incline bench. Variations (standing curls, preacher curls) maintain the same primary PULL pattern. No rotational or carry components; shoulder/scapular stability is important to isolate the elbow flexors.

reasoning: Spider Crawl is a quadrupedal crawling locomotion pattern performed in a plank/half-plank posture with alternating limb advancement. Primary joint actions are hip flexion (bringing knee toward hand) often combined with transverse plane rotation of the thorax/hip, and shoulder flexion/protraction on the supporting side as the body moves forward. The spine undergoes dynamic thoracic rotation and the core produces both rotary movement and anti-rotational stabilization. Shoulders and scapulae provide weight-bearing stability through protraction/retraction and isometric elbow extension. Therefore the dominant pattern is LOCOMOTION with a clear ROTATION component (dynamic spinal/hip rotation and rotational core control).

joint_actions.action: external rotation / transverse rotation with contralateral patterning

notes: Commonly called Spiderman/Spider Crawl; primary purpose is loaded quadrupedal locomotion with thoracic/hip rotation and high core demand. Variations (slower controlled vs fast crawling) shift emphasis between rotational mobility and conditioning. Regressions remove range of hip/torso rotation; progressions add load or unilateral arm/leg reach to increase anti-rotation demand.

reasoning: Spiderman lunges are primarily a lunge pattern performed from a plank/stride where the lead hip and knee move through sagittal-plane flexion while the hip also undergoes frontal-plane abduction and transverse-plane external rotation as the foot is placed outside the hand. Many warmup variants include an active thoracic rotation/opening of the upper torso (transverse plane) when the trail arm reaches up. The movement is produced by hip flexors and quadriceps driving the front-leg flexion, gluteal musculature controlling hip position and external rotation, and the core/obliques and thoracic extensors producing/allowing thoracic rotation. Shoulders and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to support the upper body on the hands. Stabilization demands include core bracing to resist unwanted lumbar rotation, scapular/shoulder stability to support bodyweight, and hip stability on the stepping limb.
notes: Commonly performed as a mobility drill from plank; progression includes adding thoracic reach (increasing rotational demand). Emphasize controlled hip/knee position and scapular stability. If performed without thoracic reach (pure step-in), ROTATION component is reduced; confidence would remain high for LUNGE but ROTATION could be optional.

reasoning: Primary action is a lunge pattern: stepping/positioning produces hip and knee flexion of the lead limb (sagittal) with concomitant hip extension of the trailing limb. The mobility variant commonly includes thoracic spine rotation (transverse) as the upper body opens — often accompanied by shoulder flexion/abduction as the arm reaches upward. Primary movers for the lower body are quadriceps and gluteal complex producing knee extension and hip extension/offer control; hip abductors/external rotators control frontal/transverse positioning. Thoracic rotation is produced by the obliques and spinal rotators with erector spinae assisting; core musculature must isometrically stabilize the pelvis and lumbar spine against excessive rotation/extension. Additional stabilization demands include single‑leg/contralateral hip stability (glute med/min), ankle dorsiflexion control on the lead side, and scapular/trunk stability if performed from a plank start.
notes: Common mobility/warmup variant often performed from plank (emphasizes thoracic rotation) or from standing/lunge position. Emphasize controlled thoracic rotation and hip stability; regress by reducing reach or depth, progress by adding ankle dorsiflexion restriction or loaded variations.

reasoning: Primary pattern is a LUNGE: stepping or lowering into a deep front-leg lunge produces sagittal-plane hip flexion and knee flexion of the lead limb with concurrent hip extension of the trailing limb and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion. Many common Spiderman-lunge variations add a transverse-plane thoracic rotation (reaching up or opening the chest toward the lead leg), so a ROTATION component is often present. Movement is produced primarily by the quadriceps and gluteal complex for the lunge portion, with hip flexors controlling front-leg hip position; the obliques and thoracic extensors drive or permit the rotational/opening motion. Stabilization demands include single-leg balance on the lead limb, frontal-plane hip control by the gluteus medius and adductors, and core anti-flexion/anti-rotation isometric work to maintain trunk posture while rotating.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (if hands on ground or reaching)

notes: Many instructors perform a pure sagittal lunge variation (no rotation) — in that case classification would be solely LUNGE with slightly higher confidence. Variants from plank (bringing foot to hand) emphasize hip mobility and may increase spinal rotation and scapular/shoulder stabilization demands. Cue knee tracking, maintain neutral spine during rotation, and emphasize glute medius engagement to control pelvic drop.

reasoning: Primary action is a deep step/lunge pattern: the lead hip and knee move into deep flexion while the trail hip is relatively extended, loading the front leg in a sagittal-plane lunge. Many Spiderman Lunge variations add thoracic rotation (bringing the elbow or hand toward the instep), producing transverse-plane spinal rotation and hip transverse/frontal plane motion (abduction/external rotation) of the lead limb. Quadriceps and gluteus maximus generate/sustain the lunge mechanics while hip abductors/external rotators and thoracic rotators (obliques/erector spinae) produce/allow the rotational component. Core musculature and scapular stabilizers work isometrically to stabilize the spine and shoulder while the dynamic lunge and rotation occur.
notes: Common mobility/warm-up variation can be performed from plank (dynamic step in) or from standing. Emphasizes hip flexion ROM and thoracic rotation; maintain knee tracking and avoid forcing rotation if painful. Progressions add reach/loaded variations; regress by reducing depth or removing rotation.

reasoning: Spinal Rolls are a mobility/articulation exercise characterized by sequential, segmental movement of the vertebral column (rolling through flexion into extension and back) primarily in the sagittal plane. The primary joint action is spinal flexion followed by spinal extension (segmental vertebral motion). Secondary joint actions commonly include small amounts of hip flexion/extension and knee flexion to accommodate the roll, and isometric stabilization of the pelvis and hips to control the articulation. Although the dominant motion is sagittal spinal flexion/extension (not a classic transverse rotation), the exercise is best categorized under a spinal/segmental mobility/rotation-type pattern from the available options because it emphasizes controlled multi-segment spinal movement rather than a hip-dominant hinge, carry, push or pull pattern. Stabilization requirements include pelvic neutral control, gluteal and hamstring length/tension management, and deep core (multifidus/TA) control to sequence vertebral motion smoothly.
notes: Performed standing or supine depending on variation. Emphasize segmental control from pelvis to thoracic spine. If substantial transverse rotation is added (spinal rolls with twist), include ROTATION more explicitly and increase confidence. This classification is for spinal/segmental mobility rather than a hip-dominant hinge or locomotion pattern.

reasoning: The primary joint complex involved is the spine. A spinal stretch typically involves sagittal-plane flexion/extension and often transverse-plane rotation (depending on the variation — e.g., seated forward bend vs. supine twist). The dominant mechanical action for many 'spinal stretch' variations is controlled spinal flexion or rotation rather than limb-driven push/pull or hip-dominant hinge/squat patterns. Muscles that lengthen during the stretch (and/or eccentrically control the motion) include the erector spinae, multifidus and deep rotators; active rotation is produced by the external and internal obliques. Stabilization typically requires isometric control of the pelvis and hips (glutes/hip extensors) and deep core activation to protect the lumbar segments during the motion.
notes: Exercise name is ambiguous — variations include forward spinal flexion (seated/standing forward bend), spinal extension (cobra/lying backbend), or transverse spinal twist (supine/seated twist). If you can specify the exact variation, pattern classification and confidence can be refined.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical push (overhead drive and lockout) produced by rapid lower-body triple extension to drive the bar and active shoulder/elbow extension to receive it overhead. The lower limbs perform an explosive sagittal-plane hip/knee/ankle extension (drive) followed by a split-stance catch that resembles a unilateral lunge pattern (front limb more flexed, rear limb more extended) to stabilize the load. Stabilization demands include strong core and scapular control to transfer force from the legs to the arms, and single-leg stability in the catch to absorb and balance the load.

joint_actions.action: flexion/vertical abduction to position bar overhead (pressing action)

notes: Variations (power jerk, push jerk) change the degree of dip/drive and split depth. The catch is asymmetrical (split stance) requiring single-leg stability but does not inherently create anti-rotation demands unless load or technique is asymmetric. Requires good ankle/hip mobility and thoracic extension to receive the bar safely overhead.

reasoning: The split clean is an Olympic-style lift that primarily uses a powerful vertical pull driven by lower-body triple extension. Primary joint actions: an initial hip hinge (first pull) followed by explosive hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion (triple extension) to generate upward momentum (PULL + HINGE). The bar is then received in a split stance where one hip and knee flex while the opposite hip/knee are in partial extension to stabilize the catch—biomechanically similar to a lunge pattern (LUNGE). Upper-body actions include scapular elevation/trap-driven shrug and rapid elbow flexion/shoulder rotation to rack the bar. Throughout, the spine and core act isometrically to transmit force and maintain posture.

joint_actions.action: scapular elevation (shrug) and rapid shoulder/upper-arm rotation for turnover

notes: Split clean is a compound, multi-phase lift: hinge-dominant first pull, explosive triple extension (power/pull), and an asymmetric split catch resembling a lunge. Requires coordinated timing, good thoracic mobility and single-leg stability; not an anti-rotation or carry pattern since load is symmetrical.

reasoning: The split jump is a unilateral plyometric lunge variation: primary movement is hip and knee extension (takeoff) and ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane on the drive leg, with the opposite leg extending/descending in a lunge pattern during the cycle. It is an alternating, propulsive locomotor action (repeated single-leg push-offs and landings) so LUNGE is the primary pattern and LOCOMOTION is a secondary pattern. Muscles produce concentric extension for propulsion (quads, glutes, calves) and eccentrically absorb landing (quads, glutes, hamstrings). Frontal and transverse plane musculature (gluteus medius/minimus, adductors, core) work isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and trunk during single-leg flight/landing.
primary_muscles: core (obliques/rectus abdominis/erector spinae for trunk stability)
notes: Plyometric loading increases eccentric demand on landing—progress gradually. Single-leg imbalance and frontal/transverse stability demands are high; cue soft, controlled landings. Variations (weighted, alternating step-ups) may shift emphasis but remain LUNGE + LOCOMOTION dominant.

reasoning: The split snatch is initiated by powerful triple extension (hip, knee, ankle) — a hinge-dominant explosive extension — combined with an aggressive upward pull (shrug and arm pull) to accelerate the load. The catch is performed in a bilateral asymmetrical split stance, functionally equivalent to a lunge pattern for receiving and stabilizing the load overhead. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane (hip/knee/ankle extension, shoulder elevation) with frontal/sagittal stabilization in the split catch. Core and shoulder girdle must isometrically stabilize the bar overhead during the lunge-style catch.

joint_actions.action: plantarflexion (triple extension) and then dorsiflexion on front leg in catch
flexion/abduction to receive and stabilize the load overhead
elevation (shrug) during pull and isometric stabilization overhead

notes: No true pressing phase — the lift uses a powerful pull and turnover then an overhead catch. Split catch imposes unilateral stability and mobility demands (hip flexor length on rear leg, ankle dorsiflexion on front leg). If performed as a full squat snatch, replace LUNGE with SQUAT. Ensure shoulder mobility and overhead stability are sufficient before loading.

reasoning: Primary movement is a bilateral squat: coordinated hip and knee flexion on descent and hip and knee extension on ascent in the sagittal plane. Ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion accompany the squat to maintain balance. The Bulgarian bag commonly sits across the upper back/shoulders or is cradled anteriorly; either way the movement pattern remains a squat with load altering trunk angle slightly. Prime movers producing the movement are the quadriceps (knee extension) and gluteus maximus (hip extension), with hamstrings and adductors assisting. The spine and trunk musculature (erector spinae, deep core) act isometrically to maintain neutral torso and resist excessive flexion. Secondary shoulder/upper-back activation occurs to position/stabilize the bag if present.
notes: Bag placement changes trunk angle and moment arm (upper-back placement ≈ back squat mechanics; anterior/cradle placement ≈ front/goblet squat mechanics). As a warm-up, load is typically light and emphasis is on mobility, neuromuscular activation, and technique rather than maximal loading.

reasoning: Stairmaster is a repetitive stepping/step-up action — a locomotor task. Primary joint actions are cyclical sagittal-plane hip and knee flexion (pulling the foot up) followed by hip and knee extension (driving the body upward), with ankle dorsiflexion on foot placement and plantarflexion on push-off. Single‑leg support phases require frontal‑plane stabilization at the hip and isometric core engagement. Shoulders and elbows are passive/stabilizing when holding rails but are not primary movers.
notes: Variations: higher step height or added resistance increases hip extensor demand; holding rails reduces balance and hip abductor/core demands; stepping backward shifts muscle emphasis slightly. Primarily a locomotion/gait pattern rather than a SQUAT or LUNGE despite similar hip/knee actions.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are vertical shoulder press movements (shoulder elevation/ flexion with accompanying elbow extension) performed unilaterally in an alternating fashion. The deltoids and triceps produce the concentric pressing action (vertical PUSH). Because the load is applied to one side at a time, the core (especially obliques and deep trunk stabilizers) must produce isometric anti-rotation torque to resist spinal rotation and lateral flexion, so ANTI_ROTATION is a secondary but important pattern. Feet/hips/knees act isometrically to provide a stable base; scapular upward rotation (serratus anterior, upper trapezius) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint throughout the motion.
notes: If performed seated or with both arms simultaneously, the anti-rotation demand is reduced; neutral-grip variations alter deltoid emphasis. Heavy unilateral loading increases lateral/rotational trunk demand and potential for compensatory lumbar extension if core control is insufficient.

exercise: Sprawl to jump knee / sprint reset
reasoning: This is a dynamic, multi-phase bodyweight drill. The session transitions from a sprawl (bodyweight supine/plank-like position and rapid return to standing), into an explosive knee drive/jump and immediate sprint/reset. The primary mechanical demands are sagittal-plane lower-body triple-extension (hip, knee, ankle) during the jump and sprint (classic SQUAT-like/vertical propulsion pattern) and short-distance human gait/sprint mechanics (LOCOMOTION) on the sprint-reset. The sprawl phase requires shoulder and scapular stability and core control but is primarily a preparatory/transition movement; the jump/sprint phases are the main movers. Stabilization demands include isometric trunk control (preventing excessive lumbar extension/flexion) and scapulothoracic stabilization during the plank/sprawl transition.
notes: Movement is a compound conditioning drill — movement pattern emphasis shifts through the sequence. Coach cue: emphasize rapid triple extension for power and quick transition to sprint mechanics. Watch trunk posture during sprawl to avoid lumbar collapse. Variations: add hands/press-up (increases upper-body push demand) or perform as repeated shuttle sprints (increases LOCOMOTION emphasis).

reasoning: The movement is a compound lift with an initial hinge-based pull (hip hinge into triple extension: hip, knee, ankle) that generates vertical momentum, a powerful upper posterior chain and scapular shrug (pull) to transfer force to the hands, then a rapid pull-under and catch into a front-loaded squat. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: hip/knee extension and ankle plantarflexion for the drive, followed by knee/hip flexion to receive the load and then extension to stand. The shoulder and elbow perform flexion/elbow flexion and scapular elevation during the rack and pull-under, and the spine functions in anti-flexion (isometric extension) to stabilize. Stabilization demands include trunk anti-flexion/anti-rotation to control the anterior/unstable sandbag, scapular/shoulder stability in the front rack/catch, and grip/forearm endurance to control the sandbag through the pull and catch.

joint_actions.action: flexion (pull-under and rack) / extension to stabilize

notes: Sandbag load is anterior and shifting; increases demand on trunk stability and grip compared with barbell. Variations: power clean (less squat depth) emphasizes HINGE+PULL more; full squat clean emphasizes the SQUAT catch and recovery. Sandbag may require higher scapular/upper-arm stabilization during rack.

reasoning: Primary movement is spinal extension combined with axial rotation (thoracic and to a lesser extent lumbar). The movement produces sagittal-plane extension of the spine (back-bend) and transverse-plane rotation. Primary movers are spinal extensors producing extension and oblique/spinal rotators producing rotation. Secondary contributions: hips may extend slightly to allow trunk backward lean and shoulders may flex/abduct if the arms move overhead, requiring scapular and shoulder stabilization. Core stabilizers (transverse abdominis, multifidus, QL) and lower‑limb isometrics maintain upright stance and control excess lumbar shear.
notes: Mobility/stretch exercise emphasizing thoracic extension/rotation. Cue to emphasize thoracic motion rather than excessive lumbar extension. Progression/variation: perform with arms overhead or hands on hips to modify shoulder involvement; regress by reducing range or performing seated thoracic rotations. Avoid aggressive lumbar extension in individuals with low‑back pathology.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: shoulder elevation (mainly abduction/elevation in the frontal/scapular plane with scapulothoracic upward rotation) combined with elbow extension to press the bar overhead. Deltoids and triceps generate the concentric movement while scapular stabilizers (upper trapezius, serratus anterior) produce upward rotation and the rotator cuff stabilizes the glenohumeral joint. The thoracic spine and core act isometrically to maintain an upright trunk and transfer force from the lower body; hips and knees are also isometrically stable to provide a stable base. Because the action is an overhead vertical press rather than a horizontal push, the correct movement pattern classification is PUSH.

joint_actions.action: abduction/elevation (overhead elevation) with external rotation component

notes: Behind-the-neck press emphasizes lateral deltoid and upper trap and places greater demand on shoulder external rotation and thoracic mobility. Higher risk of subacromial impingement for those with limited shoulder/torso mobility; many coaches prefer the front (military) press for joint-friendly mechanics. Grip width and torso lean alter muscle emphasis.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane produced by concentric action of the elbow flexors. The shoulder and trunk act primarily as isometric stabilizers to maintain arm position and posture while the cable provides constant external tension. No intentional rotational or carry elements are present in a standard bilateral standing cable curl.
notes: If performed unilaterally or with an offset foot stance, include ANTI_ROTATION due to asymmetric load requiring lateral/trunk stabilization. Cable line of pull can alter shoulder orientation but primary pattern remains elbow flexion (PULL).

reasoning: Primary joint action is ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane producing an upward push of the body against gravity. Hip and knee remain largely stationary and act isometrically to support posture; the spine and upper body stabilize a loaded barbell. The movement is an isolated lower-leg concentric action (plantarflexion) rather than a hip or knee-dominant pattern, so it is best described as a vertical push from the ankle plantarflexors.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (bar support across upper back/traps)

notes: Standing vs seated changes muscle emphasis (standing emphasizes gastrocnemius; seated favors soleus). Performed on a step increases ROM and dorsiflexion demand. Balance and ankle mobility are important; heavy bar across upper back increases spinal loading and requires scapular/shoulder stabilization.

reasoning: This is a static stretch that places the humerus into extension (arm behind the body) with the elbow extended and often some external rotation of the humerus. The primary joint actions are shoulder (humeral) extension in the sagittal plane and elbow extension in the sagittal plane, with a transverse-plane component of shoulder external rotation in many variations. These joint positions correspond mechanically to the end range of typical 'pull' actions (shoulder extension/lat-dominant pulls). Muscles that would produce this positioning (if actively held) are posterior deltoid, latissimus dorsi and teres major for shoulder extension and triceps brachii for elbow extension; scapular stabilizers (rhomboids/middle trapezius/serratus anterior) work isometrically to position the scapula. Because this is a stretch, the biceps brachii and anterior shoulder musculature are the primary tissues being elongated rather than concentrically producing movement. Core and thoracic posture require isometric stabilization to maintain an upright torso during the stretch.
notes: Primarily a mobility/stretch exercise; classified as PULL because the dominant joint position is shoulder extension (the action typical of pull patterns). Variations (hand on wall, palm up/down) change degree of external rotation and wrist position; excessive force may place stretch on brachial plexus or anterior capsule — cue to avoid pain and maintain thoracic extension.

exercise: Standing Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
reasoning: Primary movement is elbow extension in the sagittal plane (triceps-driven), which is an upper-body pushing action (an isolation push for the elbow joint). The lifter is hinged at the hips into a bent-over position, which is held isometrically to provide a stable base; the spine and core act isometrically to resist flexion and maintain torso angle. Scapular stabilizers and posterior shoulder musculature stabilize the upper arm so the triceps can extend the elbow against resistance. There is no asymmetric load or intentional rotation, so ANTI_ROTATION is not required and the hip hinge is a positioning/stabilization demand rather than a primary HINGE movement.
notes: Commonly performed as a triceps 'kickback' variation — primary emphasis on elbow extension (triceps). Keep torso braced and elbow anchored near torso to avoid shoulder substitution and low-back strain. Symmetric two-arm loading minimizes anti-rotation demands.

exercise: Standing Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow extension (sagittal plane) produced by the triceps brachii — this is an isolated pushing action at the elbow. The person is held in a bent-over hip-hinge position with the torso flexed, so the posterior chain and spinal extensors act isometrically to maintain trunk position. Because the load is unilateral, the core (obliques, transverse abdominis) must resist rotation, so anti-rotation stabilization is required. The shoulder is largely a stabilizer (isometric) to maintain upper-arm position while the elbow extends.
notes: If performed with the upper arm elevated overhead instead of aligned with the torso, shoulder involvement increases (long head of triceps and shoulder stabilizers). Emphasize keeping elbow stationary and torso braced to isolate triceps. Unilateral load introduces rotational torque — cue core bracing.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are horizontal shoulder adduction (transverse plane) and elbow extension (sagittal plane) producing a horizontal pushing action away from the body. The shoulder horizontal adduction is driven mainly by the pectoralis major and anterior deltoid, with elbow extension produced by the triceps brachii. Scapular protraction (serratus anterior) and scapular stabilizers control scapular motion. When performed standing, the trunk, hips and lower limbs provide an isometric base to resist rotation and maintain posture; if performed single‑arm or unilaterally, the core must provide additional anti‑rotation/isometric stabilization. Primary movement pattern classification is horizontal PUSH because the dominant mechanical action is pressing the load away from the chest.
notes: Standard classification is horizontal PUSH. If executed single‑arm or with an offset cable path, add ANTI_ROTATION due to asymmetric loading. Cues: maintain neutral spine, drive from chest/shoulder, scapula control by serratus anterior. Cable provides continuous tension and may introduce slight sagittal or transverse components depending on pulley height and stance.

reasoning: The Bradford press is a vertical overhead press variation where the implement is pressed from the front of the shoulders overhead and then rotated around the head to the back and returned forward. The primary joint actions are bilateral shoulder flexion (pressing overhead) and shoulder extension/horizontal motion as the bar is moved behind the head; elbow extension produces the press. These are primarily vertical/sagittal-plane pushing actions with a transverse-plane component as the load travels behind the head. Scapular upward rotation and protraction occur during the press. Core, gluteal and lower-limb muscles act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and pelvis while rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control the glenohumeral joint throughout the arcing path. Because the movement is fundamentally an overhead press pattern, it is classified as PUSH.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (primary) with transverse component during rearward arc

notes: Behind-the-neck path increases shoulder impingement risk for some athletes; dumbbells or avoiding extreme rearward range can reduce risk. Primary classification remains a vertical PUSH despite the arcing/transverse component.

reasoning: The standing cable lift is primarily a transverse-plane rotational movement of the trunk (woodchop/lift pattern). The primary joint action is thoracic and lumbar spine rotation, produced by the obliques and transversus abdominis, with contribution from rectus abdominis and erector spinae for control. The shoulder performs a diagonal/upper-lift action (shoulder flexion/diagonal elevation and scapulothoracic protraction/retraction) to guide the cable path. Hips and lower limb joints act mainly as stabilizers and may produce small amounts of hip rotation and weight-shift. Core and lower-limb stabilizers (glute med/min, quadriceps, ankle stabilizers) isometrically resist unwanted frontal/sagittal plane motion and provide a stable base for the rotational drive. If performed single-arm or with an off-center load, additional anti-rotational demand increases to prevent contralateral collapse.

joint_actions.action: diagonal elevation / flexion with scapulothoracic protraction

notes: Variation: low-to-high cable lift (woodchop) emphasizes trunk rotation and shoulder diagonal lift; high-to-low reverses emphases. Single-arm or staggered stance increases anti-rotation and single-leg stabilization demands. If performed as a resisted hold against rotation (not actively rotating), classify additionally as ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: Primary joint action is ankle plantarflexion in the sagittal plane producing a vertical rise of the body or heel (a concentric 'push' at the ankle). The gastrocnemius and soleus generate the plantarflexion torque; the tibialis anterior acts eccentrically on descent. Knees and hips remain relatively static and act isometrically to stabilize the limb and maintain posture. Balance requires intrinsic foot muscles, peroneals, and hip abductors/adductors to provide frontal/transverse plane stability.
notes: Seated calf raises shift emphasis to the soleus (knee flexed reduces gastrocnemius contribution). Single-leg variations increase balance/stabilizer demand. If classified taxonomy requires ankle-specific pattern, consider adding a dedicated 'ANKLE' or 'ISOLATION' category; here 'PUSH' is used as the closest analogue (vertical push at the ankle).

reasoning: Primary movement is transverse-plane trunk rotation driven by the obliques and aided by other core and shoulder muscles. The exercise requires the torso to rotate around the spine while the arm drives a diagonal pull with the cable; the shoulder and scapulothoracic region produce the arm path but are secondary to spinal rotation. Lower-limb joints (ankle/knee/hip) act mainly isometrically to provide a stable base and allow force transfer from the legs/hips through the trunk to the handle. Because the exercise produces active rotation (not primarily an anti-rotation hold), it is classified as ROTATION.

joint_actions.action: isometric to slight extension/flexion depending on arm path

notes: Variations (high-to-low vs low-to-high) change shoulder muscle emphasis (deltoid/lat activation) but remain primarily rotational. Single-arm, asymmetrical loading increases anti-rotational demand on the contralateral core for stabilization. Proper foot stance and bracing are important to avoid excessive lumbar shear; some individuals may perform a slight hip hinge or rotation of the pelvis, but trunk rotation remains primary.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane producing concentric shortening of the elbow flexors (a pulling action). The forearm typically supinates (transverse plane) during the curl. The shoulder and scapula act isometrically to stabilize the humerus while the trunk/obliques produce anti-rotation torque to resist unilateral loading. Therefore the movement is primarily a single-joint PULL (elbow flexion) with a secondary ANTI_ROTATION stabilization demand from the unilateral load.
notes: If performed braced against the thigh or seated (classic concentration curl) the trunk anti-rotation demand is reduced. Cable or band variations may introduce a slight horizontal pull component but the primary pattern remains elbow flexion (PULL).

reasoning: This static stretch is typically performed in a split-stance (one foot forward, one back) where the front ankle is dorsiflexed to stretch the plantarflexors. The primary joint action is ankle dorsiflexion in the sagittal plane with the knee and hip of the front leg held in a partially flexed/extended, load-bearing position (static). The movement pattern aligns best with a LUNGE position because the exercise places the legs in a unilateral, staggered stance with emphasis on sagittal-plane loading of the front ankle/knee. Stabilization demands include unilateral lower-limb balance (ankle/foot intrinsic muscles, peroneals), and isometric core/hip stabilization to maintain posture.
notes: If performed with both feet parallel and no split stance (bilateral heel-down stretch), classification as LUNGE is less appropriate — in that case the exercise is primarily an ankle mobility/stretch with minimal pattern classification. primary_muscles: quadriceps (rectus femoris, vasti) — target tissue being stretched
gluteus maximus — hip extensor (assist if active)
notes: This is a static assisted stretch rather than a strength or locomotor pattern; it does not map cleanly to the provided movement pattern categories. Common variations: lying prone quad stretch (removes balance requirement), standing with strap (assisted), or dynamic walking quad stretch. If classifying into movement patterns for programming, treat as a mobility/stretching accessory rather than a primary movement pattern.

reasoning: Primary joint action is spinal flexion in the sagittal plane (thoracic and lumbar spine flex). The exercise is performed against a high cable/rope so the hands/forearms pull the rope downward to drive the trunk into flexion; the upper limb action (isotonic downward pull at the shoulder/elbow complex) serves to apply resistance but the visible motion is trunk flexion. Primary movers producing the visible movement are the rectus abdominis and obliques producing spinal flexion; hip flexors may contribute minimally. Stabilization demands include isometric control from the erector spinae and thoracic extensors on the descent/return, and scapular/shoulder stabilizers (lats, traps, rhomboids) to control the cable path and shoulder girdle position.
notes: This exercise is primarily a trunk-flexion (crunch) movement. Because available pattern categories lack a dedicated 'trunk flexion/abdominal' pattern, it is classified as PULL due to the resisted downward pulling action on the rope/cable. Variations (kneeling cable crunch, rotating cable crunch) can add different stabilization or ROTATION components.

reasoning: Primary movement is multisegmental shoulder/glenohumeral motion moving the stick in an arc from front to back and back to front, which combines shoulder flexion/extension (overhead arc) and humeral internal/external rotation predominantly in the sagittal and transverse planes. Thoracic spine extension (and some rotation/segmental mobility) and scapulothoracic upward rotation/retraction/protraction accompany the humeral motion to allow the path of the stick. Elbows remain mostly extended and act as a kinematic link. Stabilization demands include scapular control (trapezius/serratus/rhomboids) and standing postural stability through the core and lower limbs to maintain upright posture while the shoulder complex moves.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis, supraspinatus)
notes: Primarily a shoulder/thoracic mobility drill emphasizing rotational and sagittal-plane shoulder travel. Grip width, stick vs band, and shoulder ROM limitations alter movement demands. Avoid depth/width that produces pain in those with impingement or severe glenohumeral restrictions.

reasoning: The movement is primarily a sagittal-plane rotation of the pelvis relative to the spine (posterior and anterior pelvic tilt), driven by lumbar spine flexion/extension and pelvic rotation rather than gross hip or knee travel. Primary joint action is lumbar spine flexion (posterior pelvic tilt) when curling the pelvis under and lumbar extension/anterior tilt on the return. Hips and knees remain largely isometric to maintain standing posture; deep core and hip extensors act to control and stabilize the pelvis. This is primarily a spinal/pelvic mobility and motor-control exercise, not a loaded limb-based push/pull/hinge/squat pattern.

joint_actions.action: flexion (posterior pelvic tilt) / extension (anterior pelvic tilt)
minimal posterior rotation / isometric control (relative extension tendency)

notes: This is primarily a pelvic/spinal mobility and motor-control drill. If performed dynamically with added limb movement or asymmetric loading it may also require ANTI_ROTATION or be incorporated into other patterns (e.g., single-leg stance adds anti-rotation demands).

reasoning: Standing toe touches are a sagittal-plane forward-bending movement characterized by hip flexion combined with substantial lumbar spine flexion. The primary joint actions are hip flexion (bringing the pelvis/trunk toward the thighs) and spinal (lumbar) flexion; the knees are typically held near full extension and the ankles remain in neutral/slight dorsiflexion. Muscle action is dominated by trunk flexors and hip flexors producing the flexion while posterior chain tissues (hamstrings, gluteals, erector spinae) lengthen and provide tension/limit range; core and hip musculature stabilize the pelvis and control the descent. Because the pattern centers on sagittal hip/trunk flexion (similar to a forward hinge), it is categorized as HINGE, acknowledging that this particular movement involves more spinal flexion than a textbook hip-dominant hinge.
notes: This is classified as HINGE for pattern alignment because the dominant movement is sagittal-plane forward bending at the hip/pelvis. However, standing toe touches include pronounced lumbar flexion (spinal movement) and are often performed as a flexibility/stretch rather than a pure hip-dominant hinge. If evaluating for strict hip-dominant training (neutral spine hinge), treat toe touches as a mobility/stretch rather than a loading hinge variation.

reasoning: Primary joint action is hip flexion in the sagittal plane with concurrent spinal (lumbar) flexion. The movement lengthens the posterior chain (hamstrings, glutes) and spinal extensors; when performed actively the hip extensors eccentrically control descent and the core/hip complex stabilizes the pelvis. Knees typically have minimal change (may be straight or slightly flexed) and ankle dorsiflexion is minimal. This pattern is best classified as a hip-dominant hinge movement (performed as a passive stretch in a cooldown).

joint_actions.action: minimal movement (often slight flexion depending on technique)

notes: Often performed as a passive stretch rather than a strength exercise. Variations: knees bent reduces hamstring strain and lumbar rounding; maintain hip-dominant hinge (less lumbar flexion) if goal is posterior-chain loading/control. Caution with acute low-back disc pathology—avoid excessive lumbar flexion.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow extension in the sagittal plane against resistance (triceps-driven push). Shoulders and scapulae act largely isometrically to position and stabilize the humerus (often in an overhead or behind-the-head position). The core and thoracic musculature provide anti-extension and postural stabilization to keep the torso upright while the elbows extend. There is no primary horizontal/vertical shoulder translation or lower-limb locomotion, so the dominant pattern is a pushing action at the elbow.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (set/retraction or upward rotation depending on arm position)

notes: If performed single-arm or asymmetrically (one-hand on towel), include ANTI_ROTATION due to lateral/core stabilization demands. Overhead variants increase lumbar extension risk—emphasize core bracing. Anchoring the towel overhead vs. bilateral hand-held changes shoulder demand but does not alter primary PUSH classification.

reasoning: The combined exercise contains two mobility components: the pigeon portion is primarily a hip transverse-plane movement (hip external rotation with accompanying sagittal hip flexion on the front leg and hip extension on the rear leg) — the rotational element of the hip is the dominant, distinctive action. The standing calf stretch primarily loads the ankle in dorsiflexion/plantarflexion (sagittal plane) but is a mobility/passive stretch rather than a primary movement pattern in the provided list. Primary joint actions are hip external rotation and hip flexion/extension (transverse + sagittal) for pigeon, and ankle dorsiflexion (sagittal) for the calf stretch. Stabilization requires pelvic and core isometric control, weight-bearing foot/ankle stability, and support of the contralateral hip during the hold.
notes: This is a mobility/cooldown combination; pigeon is best categorized under ROTATION due to prominent hip external rotation. The standing calf component does not map cleanly onto the provided foundational movement patterns (it is isolated ankle sagittal mobility). Watch for knee discomfort in pigeon variations and maintain neutral spine; variations include elevated pigeon, reclined figure-4 (less hip compression), or wall-supported calf stretch.

reasoning: Star jump is a plyometric vertical jump driven primarily by triple extension of the hip, knee and ankle (a squat-type concentric action) in the sagittal plane to create vertical impulse. The exercise also includes frontal-plane hip abduction (legs splay outward) and shoulder abduction/flexion to bring the arms overhead; these are secondary for movement/momentum. Muscles producing the primary movement are the gluteus maximus and quadriceps (hip and knee extension) and the plantarflexors (gastrocnemius/soleus) for ankle propulsion. Landing requires eccentric control (hip/knee/ankle flexion) and trunk/hip abductors (gluteus medius) for frontal-plane control. Core and spinal extensors act isometrically to stabilize the torso during takeoff and landing.
notes: Plyometric emphasis: concentric triple extension for takeoff and eccentric absorption on landing. Frontal-plane hip abduction and arm swing are secondary and assist momentum; coach landing mechanics to reduce injury risk. Variations (tuck jump, jumping jack without arm swing) may alter shoulder/hip abduction involvement.

reasoning: Primary joint demands replicate a squat pattern: the hips and knees are held in flexion (isometric) in the sagittal plane, requiring the lower-extremity extensors to produce/maintain the vertical support moment. The anterior goblet load introduces an anterior trunk flexion moment so the spinal extensors and abdominal wall act isometrically to maintain an upright torso. Shoulder and elbow are isometrically flexed to cradle the load and serve a stabilizing role.
notes: If performed seated on a chair (supported), joint moments and muscular demand are reduced compared with an unsupported goblet squat but the primary pattern remains SQUAT. Asymmetric or single-arm variations would introduce ANTI_ROTATION demands. This is an isometric variation (hold) emphasizing endurance/stability rather than concentric/eccentric movement.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are hip and knee flexion held isometrically in the sagittal plane (bottom/mid-squat position). Ankle dorsiflexion is also maintained. The anterior kettlebell load requires isometric shoulder/elbow activity to hold the implement and increased trunk bracing to resist forward collapse. Primary movement pattern is a squat because the exercise loads/maintains vertical displacement demands at the hips and knees in the sagittal plane. Stabilization requirements include strong isometric trunk extensors/abdominals to resist trunk flexion and lower-leg musculature to control ankle dorsiflexion.

joint_actions.action: flexion/neutral (isometric to hold kettlebell at chest)

notes: Isometric variant of the goblet squat. Depth and anterior load increase trunk flexion moment — maintain 'chest up' and core bracing. If performed single-arm or asymmetrically, include ANTI_ROTATION. Dynamic ascent/descent converts it to a conventional SQUAT movement with concentric/eccentric actions.

reasoning: This is an isometric squat position with primary joint demands at the hip and knee in the sagittal plane. The hips and knees are held in flexion while the hip and knee extensors (gluteus maximus, quadriceps, hamstrings) produce isometric extension torque to prevent descent. The trunk/erector spinae and abdominal musculature act isometrically to maintain an upright/neutral spine against the anterior load (goblet), and the forearms/shoulder/elbow stabilize the load at the chest. Ankles are dorsiflexed and the plantarflexors co-contract for stability.

joint_actions.action: flexion (isometric hold of flexed position with extensors producing torque)
flexion (isometric hold with quadriceps producing extension torque)
dorsiflexion (isometric stabilization of tibia over foot)
neutral/extension (isometric stabilization against trunk flexion from anterior load)

notes: Static, isometric variant of the goblet squat — primary pattern is SQUAT. Load position (anterior chest) increases trunk extension demand but does not create significant anti-rotation unless asymmetric. Depth, load magnitude, and torso angle influence relative quad vs. hip-dominance; breath/brace technique (avoid uncontrolled Valsalva) recommended.

reasoning: Primary joint action is an isometric vertical push position: shoulders are held in end-range flexion/overhead elevation (sagittal plane) with elbows extended to maintain the load overhead. Scapulothoracic upward rotation and stabilization (serratus anterior, upper trapezius) and rotator cuff activity stabilize the glenohumeral joint. The trunk (erector spinae, rectus abdominis and obliques) works isometrically to resist spinal extension and maintain a neutral/extended thoracic posture. Lower limbs provide an isometric base of support (hips/knees/ankles) but do not produce primary movement. Because the exercise is a static overhead push position rather than a walking or dynamic carry, the dominant pattern is a vertical PUSH (isometric overhead hold).
notes: If the sandbag is held asymmetrically or the load shifts, ANTI_ROTATION becomes relevant (lateral/rotational core stabilization). Variations (single-arm overhead hold, walking while holding overhead) would add ANTI_ROTATION or CARRY. Caution for shoulder mobility and thoracic extension limits; emphasize scapular stability and bracing.

reasoning: Although no locomotion occurs, the static sandbag hold functions as an isometric loaded carry (holding a load against the body) and therefore primarily resembles a carry pattern with strong core stabilization demands. Primary joint actions are isometric/anti-gravity shoulder flexion and horizontal adduction to cradle the bag, elbow flexion to maintain grip, and isometric trunk extension/anti-flexion to resist forward collapse. The core (rectus abdominis, obliques, erector spinae) and hip extensors maintain upright posture; scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, traps, rhomboids) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the shoulders. If the load is asymmetric or the hold is off-center, significant anti-rotation torque is resisted by the obliques and contralateral lumbar stabilizers, justifying the ANTI_ROTATION classification.

joint_actions.action: isometric trunk extension / anti-flexion (and anti-rotation if asymmetric)

notes: If the sandbag is carried while walking, classification weight toward CARRY increases. If held perfectly centered (bear-hug) the primary demand is anti-flexion/postural stabilization; if held off-center or one‑arm, anti-rotation demands increase. Some programs may label pure static holds as 'isometric carry'—interpretation varies.

reasoning: Step-ups are primarily a unilateral sagittal-plane hip and knee extension task performed by the stance (leading) leg to raise the body's center of mass onto an elevated surface. The primary joint actions are hip extension and knee extension with contribution from ankle plantarflexion during the push. Because the movement is performed from a split-stance/step pattern (single-leg drive onto a higher surface) it aligns with the LUNGE movement pattern. Stabilization demands include frontal-plane hip stabilization (gluteus medius/minimus) to control pelvic drop and core/trunk musculature to maintain upright posture and balance during single-leg support.

joint_actions.action: flexion (to clear and place on step)

notes: Step height (16 in) increases hip flexion demand and single-leg strength requirement. Emphasize controlled eccentric descent for added quadriceps/glute work. Variations (weighted step-ups, box height, tempo, alternating vs. unilateral) alter load distribution and stability demands; asymmetric loads would add ANTI_ROTATION components.

reasoning: Primarily an isometric vertical push: the shoulders and elbows generate/maintain upward force to keep the sandbag overhead (shoulder flexion/abduction and elbow extension in the vertical plane). Because the load is carried overhead (even when stationary) the task shares mechanics with overhead carry patterns — the entire kinetic chain (hips/legs/feet) and the core act to support and transfer the load. The shoulder girdle (traps, serratus) provides upward rotation and scapular stability while the core (erector spinae, obliques, rectus abdominis) resists spinal flexion and rotation. Lower-limb extensors produce isometric support for posture and balance.
notes: If the hold is performed while walking it becomes more clearly a CARRY (overhead carry). Asymmetric or single-arm variations add ANTI_ROTATION demands and would warrant adding ANTI_ROTATION to the movement list. Wrist/grip and scapular upward-rotation capacity are common limiting factors.

reasoning: Step Mill is a cyclical stair-climbing/stepping locomotion pattern. Primary joint actions are repeated hip and knee flexion during the swing phase and hip and knee extension (with ankle plantarflexion) during the push-off/stance phase in the sagittal plane. Movement is produced primarily by the gluteus maximus and quadriceps during extension, with hamstrings and plantarflexors contributing to hip/knee control and push-off. Single-leg stance phases require hip abductors (gluteus medius) and core musculature to stabilize the pelvis and trunk; upper body may isometrically stabilize if holding rails.
notes: Variants: holding rails reduces core/hip stabilizer demand; higher resistance or stepping at a higher incline increases strength demand (greater hip/knee extensor load). Reverse stepping or single-step emphasis increases posterior chain or unilateral balance demands respectively. If performed as loaded stepping (weighted vest, carrying), CARRY/ANTI_ROTATION considerations may apply.

reasoning: Primary action is a unilateral vertical rise onto an elevated surface produced by stance-leg hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane (classic squat-type movement). The added knee raise is concentric hip flexion of the non-stance limb but does not change the primary pattern. Major movers producing the lift are the quadriceps and gluteus maximus (knee and hip extension), with hamstrings as assistants and gastrocnemius contributing to plantarflexion if present. Single-leg support demands frontal-plane/pelvic stability from the gluteus medius/minimus and isometric core stabilization to maintain upright spine and prevent frontal/transverse plane collapse.
notes: Step height, load, and tempo alter emphasis (higher step increases hip involvement). Single-leg support increases frontal-plane demand (glute medius) and core stabilization; adding asymmetrical load could introduce ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pull: the shoulders move from flexion/overhead into extension/adduction while the elbows flex to bring the sternum to the bar (sagittal plane). Scapular retraction and depression occur (transverse/sagittal components) and the thoracic spine extends to allow sternum-to-bar contact. Hips and knees remain relatively static and act as isometric stabilizers. Muscles producing the movement are the prime movers (lats, teres major, posterior deltoid) and elbow flexors (biceps, brachialis), with scapular retractors/depressors (middle/lower traps, rhomboids) and core/erector spinae providing stabilization.
notes: Sternum pull-up is a vertical pulling variant emphasizing greater thoracic extension and scapular retraction than a standard chin-up; grip width and torso lean alter lat vs. biceps emphasis. Core must isometrically resist undue swing; if performed with twist/asymmetry, include ROTATION or ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: This is a vertical pulling exercise: primary joint actions are shoulder extension/adduction (bringing the upper arm down and back toward the torso) and elbow flexion in the sagittal plane, combined with pronounced scapular retraction and depression and thoracic extension as the sternum is brought to the bar. The latissimus dorsi, teres major and posterior deltoid generate shoulder extension/adduction while the biceps brachii, brachialis and brachioradialis produce elbow flexion. Scapular retractors/depressors (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids) and core/spinal extensors stabilize the thoracic spine and allow the pronounced chest-to-bar path. Hips, knees and ankles are typically isometrically stabilized during the movement.
notes: Sternum/Chest-to-bar variation increases thoracic extension and scapular depression demands versus standard pull-up; requires adequate shoulder extension ROM and thoracic mobility. Grip width and pronation/supination will alter biceps vs lat emphasis.

reasoning: A vertical pulling exercise where the primary movement is pulling the torso upward to contact the sternum with the bar. Primary joint actions are shoulder extension/adduction and elbow flexion in the sagittal plane, augmented by marked scapular retraction/depression (transverse/frontal) and thoracic/spinal extension to achieve a high chest/sternum position. Scapular retractors and depressors control the scapulothoracic motion while core/spinal extensors maintain a rigid body line. Grip/forearm muscles produce isometric stabilization on the bar.
notes: Variation emphasizes greater scapular depression/retraction and thoracic extension than a standard chin/pull-up. Requires good shoulder mobility and thoracic extension. Kipping or momentum reduces pure pull pattern and increases demand on timing and hip drive.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pull: the humerus moves from an overhead/flexed position into extension (and slight adduction) while the elbow undergoes concentric flexion to bring the sternum toward the bar. The scapulae actively depress and retract during the pull and the thoracic spine extends to increase chest-to-bar contact. Core and scapular stabilizers work isometrically to control torso position and limit swing. Because the dominant joint actions are shoulder extension and elbow flexion in a vertical pulling trajectory, this classifies as a PULL pattern.
notes: Sternum pull-up emphasizes greater thoracic extension and scapular depression/retraction than a standard chin-up; requires good shoulder mobility and scapular control. If performed with swing/kip or with pronounced horizontal reach, additional patterns (e.g., ROTATION or ANTI_ROTATION) could be relevant.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical pulling movement: shoulder moves from overhead into relative extension/adduction while the elbow flexes, with pronounced scapular retraction/depression and thoracic extension to bring the sternum to the bar. Movement is produced mainly by the lats/teres major (shoulder extension/adduction) and elbow flexors (biceps/brachialis) while scapular retractors (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids) and thoracic extensors control thoracic extension. Core and shoulder girdle muscles act isometrically to stabilize the spine and scapulae during the pull.
notes: Sternum pull-ups emphasize greater scapular retraction and thoracic extension than standard pull-ups; requires good thoracic mobility and scapular control. Performed as bodyweight volume/technique work, tempo and scapular positioning are key cues. Variations (wide grip, kipping) change muscle emphasis and stability demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pull: the humerus moves from an overhead position into shoulder extension/adduction while the forearm flexes at the elbow to bring the sternum to the bar. Scapulothoracic retraction and depression occur to position the sternum to the bar and create thoracic extension. The shoulders and elbows are the prime movers; the core, scapular stabilizers and lower body act isometrically to stabilize the torso and pelvis during the pull.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (primary) with transverse component for scapular positioning

notes: Sternum pull-ups are a vertical pulling variation emphasizing greater scapular retraction and thoracic extension than a standard chin-over-bar pull-up; requires good shoulder and thoracic mobility. As a finisher, form may degrade so scapular control and elbow-dominant substitutions should be monitored.

reasoning: This is an isometric top-position pull-up variant. The primary joint actions are shoulder extension/adduction and sustained elbow flexion (isometric) as the sternum is held to the bar, with coordinated scapular retraction and depression to maintain the high chest position. The spine and core perform isometric stabilization (anti-extension) to keep a rigid torso. Muscles producing the pull are the lats, teres major, posterior deltoid and elbow flexors (biceps, brachialis); scapular retractors (rhomboids, middle/lower traps) maintain shoulder girdle position. Grip/forearm flexors maintain handhold, and the core and erector spinae stabilize the trunk.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (primarily) with transverse component for scapular retraction

notes: A strict bilateral vertical pulling isometric — classify as PULL. Emphasizes scapular control and upper-body pulling strength; progressive regressions include band-assisted holds or holds to chin level; watch for shoulder impingement in those with limited thoracic extension or poor scapular mobility.

reasoning: Stick dislocates are a shoulder mobility/circumduction pattern that requires significant transverse-plane rotation of the humerus combined with sagittal-plane shoulder flexion and extension. The primary joint action is at the glenohumeral joint (shoulder) — moving the straight arms from front to overhead to behind the body — which involves shoulder flexion to overhead, then extension/horizontal abduction behind the body and internal/external rotation of the humerus. Scapulothoracic motion (upward rotation, protraction/retraction) is required to allow full range. The elbows remain extended (isometric) and the thoracic spine extends modestly to permit the path. Stabilization demands come from rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers to control humeral head positioning and from thoracic extensors/core to maintain posture.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
notes: Primarily a shoulder mobility/rotation exercise rather than a push or pull. Requires adequate thoracic extension and scapular mobility; grip width and arm straightness change emphasis. Avoid if symptomatic shoulder impingement or acute rotator cuff pathology. Variations include wider/narrower grip or using a band for assisted range.

reasoning: The stomach vacuum is an isometric deep-core 'hollowing' maneuver that primarily recruits the transverse abdominis and internal obliques to draw the abdominal wall inward, producing spinal flattening/posterior pelvic tilt in the sagittal plane. There is no substantive dynamic movement at the hips, knees, shoulders or elbows—the exercise's purpose is core stabilization and resistance to spinal extension rather than producing joint angular displacement or rotation. Stabilization requires coordinated diaphragm and pelvic floor activity and engagement of multifidus and other local stabilizers to maintain neutral spine while the abdomen is drawn in.

joint_actions.action: lumbar posterior tilt / isometric spinal flattening

notes: This exercise is primarily an isometric anti-extension/core-bracing drill. The available movement-pattern set does not include a dedicated 'ANTI-EXTENSION' label; ANTI_ROTATION is used as the closest 'anti' core category. Common variations: standing, seated, quadruped; practiced with exhalation or breath-hold to emphasize transverse abdominis recruitment.

reasoning: Performed prone on an incline bench with the arms kept straight and lifted away from the body, the exercise primarily produces shoulder horizontal abduction (and some shoulder extension depending on bench angle) in the transverse/sagittal planes. The movement is a posterior shoulder/scapular pulling action — the posterior deltoid generates the bulk of the torque at the glenohumeral joint while scapular retractors (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids) control scapulothoracic motion. Elbows remain extended isometrically and the trunk/bench provide stabilization. Because the primary joint actions are pulling the humerus posteriorly (horizontal pull), this maps to a PULL pattern (horizontal pull emphasis).

joint_actions.action: horizontal abduction (and slight extension depending on path)

notes: If performed with arms moving in the sagittal plane (straight-arm rear raise from overhead toward hips) emphasis shifts slightly toward shoulder extension but remains a horizontal/posterior pull pattern. Bench angle and hand/thumb orientation will alter relative deltoid vs. scapular muscle contribution. If performed as a front raise variant (arms lift forward), classification would change to PUSH (shoulder flexion/front raise) — confirm exact arm path if ambiguous.

reasoning: Primary movement is humeral (shoulder) extension/flexion in the sagittal plane with the arms held near full extension. The latissimus dorsi and teres major (with assistance from posterior deltoid and the sternal head of pec major) drive the humerus posteriorly (pullover motion). Elbows remain nearly locked and act isometrically to transmit load; the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control glenohumeral and scapulothoracic position. The trunk (especially thoracic posture) and core act isometrically to stabilize the spine and allow pure shoulder motion. No significant hip/knee/ankle movement—this is primarily an upper‑body pulling pattern of the humerus rather than a row-style scapular retraction movement.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (possible thoracic extension depending on setup)

notes: Bilateral straight-arm pullover is a sagittal-plane humeral pull. Single-arm variations introduce anti-rotation demands. Bent-arm pullovers shift more load to pecs/triceps. Performing on a bench with chest arch increases thoracic extension and shoulder range of motion; poor technique can stress the shoulder joint.

reasoning: Primary movement is shoulder extension (humeral movement downward/back toward the body) in the sagittal plane performed as a vertical pulling action with the elbows kept extended. The latissimus dorsi and teres major drive humeral extension/adduction while lower trapezius and scapular stabilizers control scapular depression and retraction. Elbows remain isometrically extended (no concentric elbow flexion). The spine and core act isometrically to maintain neutral posture and resist flexion or rotation.
notes: Typically a cable/functional trainer exercise; emphasizes lats by minimizing elbow flexion. Variations (bent-arm pulldown, single-arm) change loading and may add greater elbow flexion or anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary mechanical demand is an isometric horizontal push position: the shoulders are loaded with the arms extended, producing compressive/axial force through the shoulder girdle while the trunk and hips resist sagittal collapse. Primary joint actions are isometric shoulder flexion and elbow extension with isometric hip and knee extension and trunk anti-extension (spinal stabilization). Muscles of the anterior shoulder and scapular stabilizers (anterior deltoid, pectoralis minor/major to a lesser extent, serratus anterior), and triceps hold the upper-body 'push' position while core muscles (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, obliques) and glutes maintain a rigid plank line and prevent pelvic sag or spinal extension.
notes: Symmetric straight-arm plank is best classified as an isometric horizontal PUSH pattern due to weight-bearing on extended arms. Variations (single-arm plank, side plank) introduce anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion demands and should include ANTI_ROTATION. Watch shoulder stability and scapular control; regress with elevated hands or progress with loaded variations or instability.

reasoning: The straight-arm plank is an isometric, weight-bearing hold on the hands that biomechanically matches the top position of a horizontal push. Primary joint demands are isometric shoulder flexion and elbow extension to support bodyweight, with the trunk, hips and lower limbs isometrically resisting sagging (anti-extension) in the sagittal plane. Shoulders and scapulae produce/maintain the vertical reaction force through the hands (horizontal push context), while the anterior and deep core musculature resist spinal motion and maintain a rigid torso. Secondary stabilization demands occur at the hips, knees and ankles to maintain a straight line.
notes: Symmetrical straight-arm plank is best classified as a horizontal PUSH (isometric). Variations (single-arm plank, offset hand placement) introduce significant anti-rotation and lateral stabilization demands and would warrant adding ANTI_ROTATION. This classification focuses on primary weight-bearing shoulder mechanics and trunk anti-extension.

reasoning: The straight-arm plank is an isometric core stabilization task in which the trunk resists sagittal plane collapse (anti-flexion/anti-extension) and also requires resistance to rotational perturbation; the shoulders and elbows provide a static weight-bearing support. Primary joint action is isometric stabilization of the spine to maintain a neutral alignment (prevent lumbar flexion/extension) in the sagittal plane. Secondary isometric actions occur at the shoulders (supporting the torso in ~90° flexion), elbows (extension), hips and knees (maintain straight line). The exercise recruits the deep and superficial core musculature to prevent spinal movement and resist rotation while the shoulder complex provides static load-bearing and scapular control.
notes: Although the arms are in a push-like bearing position, the plank is primarily an isometric core (anti-extension/anti-rotation) exercise. Variations (forearm plank, single-arm/leg plank) increase emphasis on anti-rotation and unilateral shoulder/hip stabilization. If classifying by anti-extension specifically, a dedicated ANTI_EXTENSION category would be more precise.

reasoning: Primary actions are trunk (lumbar) flexion and hip flexion to lift the straight legs and torso into a V-up, combined with deliberate transverse-plane movement as the legs/weight travel across the midline to pass the kettlebell. The obliques and transverse-plane hip/torso muscles actively produce the crossover (rotation), while rectus abdominis and hip flexors drive sagittal flexion. Shoulders and scapular stabilizers hold and guide the kettlebell across the midline and act isometrically for control. Stabilization demands include anti-extension/anti-shear from the deep core and isometric shoulder/elbow control to safely transfer the load.

joint_actions.action: flexion with movement across midline (adduction/hip rotation component)
flexion and horizontal adduction (guiding/passing the weight across midline)

notes: Primary classification is ROTATION due to the transverse-plane crossover of legs/weight combined with dynamic trunk flexion. Modify by bending knees to reduce lower-back shear or use lighter/no load. Emphasize controlled spinal rounding and oblique activation; avoid aggressive end-range lumbar rotation with high load for those with spine issues.

reasoning: Stretching is a mobility/warmup category activity rather than a single loaded movement pattern. reasoning: Primary action is loaded locomotion — repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension during walking while holding a unilateral load at the side. notes: Commonly performed supine, seated or quadruped; emphasize thoracic mobility and minimize lumbar compensation. Variations include adding extension (thoracic extension + rotation) or using a foam roller to increase range. Caution with acute spinal pain or instability.

reasoning: Primary movement is thoracic spine rotation (transverse plane) often paired with thoracic extension (sagittal plane) while the ipsilateral shoulder moves into flexion to reach. The spine's segmental extensors and rotators create thoracic extension/rotation; the anterior deltoid elevates the arm and scapular upward rotators (serratus anterior, upper/lower trapezius) control scapulothoracic motion. The lumbar spine and pelvis act as isometric stabilizers (multifidus, transverse abdominis, gluteal complex) to prevent compensation and isolate the thoracic region. Shoulder/elbow position is primarily movement-producing (reach) while the core and scapular stabilizers provide essential stabilization.
primary_muscles: upper and lower trapezius (scapular upward rotation/stability)
notes: Commonly performed in quadruped, half-kneeling or standing. Emphasize thoracic segmental motion and prevent lumbar compensation. Variations: add progression with reach-plus-rotation or combine with scapular mobility drills. Regress by reducing range or performing thoracic extension only.

reasoning: Primary joint action is thoracic (spinal) extension in the sagittal plane as the thoracic vertebrae extend over the foam roller. Secondary action is scapular retraction/horizontal adduction of the shoulder girdle (a posterior/‘pull’-type shoulder girdle action) as the chest opens and shoulders retract to allow extension. The movement is mobility-focused (large spinal segmental motion) rather than a loaded push or hinge; however, the dominant visible movement pattern at the shoulder/scapula resembles a horizontal pull, so PULL is the closest movement-pattern classification. Stabilization requires isometric control from the deep core (multifidus, transversus abdominis), lats and thoracic extensors to control segmental motion, and hip/gluteal control to maintain pelvic position.
primary_muscles: posterior deltoid (as a scapular/shoulder girdle facilitator)
notes: Mobility exercise with minimal external load; primarily targets thoracic extension and scapular mobility. Can be performed with arms folded, hands behind head, or with thoracic rotation pulses — if significant transverse rotation is introduced, include ROTATION as an additional movement. Low loading, high emphasis on segmental control rather than force production.

reasoning: Primary action is thoracic spinal rotation in the transverse plane as one arm threads under the torso; concurrently the ipsilateral shoulder moves into horizontal adduction/internal rotation (transverse plane) and the scapula undergoes protraction/retraction around the ribcage. Hips and knees remain in quadruped flexion and act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis while core musculature controls and guides the rotation. The movement is a mobility/rotational pattern rather than a push/pull or load-bearing pattern.
notes: Common variations include reaching further for a deeper thoracic rotation or returning to neutral for dynamic thread-and-return. Can be progressed to weighted or standing rotational mobility drills, but as performed in quadruped it is primarily a thoracic rotation mobility exercise. Minimal load—no carry/anti-rotation requirement.

reasoning: Primary movement is thoracic spinal rotation (transverse plane) as the torso rotates to allow the arm to thread under the contralateral side. The glenohumeral joint performs horizontal/diagonal movement (reaching across/under) with internal/external rotation components depending on hand orientation. Scapular stabilizers control scapulothoracic motion while hips and knees remain in a stable, flexed quadruped position providing an isometric base. Thus the dominant pattern is rotational spinal mobility with secondary shoulder transverse-plane motion; core and scapular muscles act isometrically to stabilize.
notes: Commonly performed from quadruped. Variations (palm up vs palm down) change shoulder rotation demands. Emphasizes thoracic mobility and scapular movement; avoid aggressive threading if symptomatic in shoulder or low back.

reasoning: Primary movement is thoracic spine rotation in the transverse plane as one arm threads under the torso and then the opposite arm opens toward the ceiling. The glenohumeral joint undergoes horizontal adduction/internal rotation during the thread-under and shoulder abduction/external rotation during the open-up; the scapula protracts/retracts to allow the arm paths. The lumbar spine and hips act as stabilizers (control of pelvic position and anti-extension/anti-lateral-flexion) while the shoulder girdle provides mobility and stability. This is primarily a rotational mobility exercise targeting transverse-plane spinal motion rather than a load-bearing push/pull or locomotion pattern.
notes: Commonly performed from quadruped. Emphasize thoracic rotation with a stable pelvis and neutral lumbar spine. Variations include standing or half-kneeling versions; avoid if acute shoulder or thoracic pain. Focus is mobility/rotation, not anti-rotation.

reasoning: Thread-the-needle is a thoracic-spine rotation mobility drill performed from quadruped (or kneeling) that drives axial rotation of the trunk through the transverse plane while the reaching shoulder moves across and under the body. Primary joint action is thoracic spinal rotation (transverse plane). The glenohumeral joint performs transverse-plane movement (reaching under = horizontal adduction/internal rotation; returning/upward rotation = horizontal abduction/external rotation) with the elbow moving only minimally. Hips and knees remain weight-bearing and act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and lower body. Scapulothoracic stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) control scapular motion during the reach. Core rotators (internal/external obliques, multifidus) and thoracic extensors produce the rotation; glutes and hip stabilizers provide pelvic stability.
primary_muscles: posterior deltoid / pectoralis major (depending on phase)

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction and internal rotation (reach under) / horizontal abduction and external rotation (return)

notes: Primarily a thoracic rotation mobility pattern. Variations include seated/standing/lying versions; can be progressed with loaded reaches or combined with quadruped scapular protraction drills. Caution with acute lumbar spine pain — emphasize thoracic movement and avoid forcing rotation through low back.

reasoning: Thread-the-Needle is primarily a thoracic spine rotation mobility exercise. The primary joint action is transverse-plane rotation of the thoracic spine as one arm threads beneath the torso. The glenohumeral joint undergoes horizontal adduction and internal rotation during the thread; the elbow flexes briefly to allow passage of the arm. Movement is generated largely by spinal rotators and oblique activity while the shoulder girdle moves to allow the thread; simultaneous core and scapular stabilization is required to keep the lumbar spine and pelvis neutral and control the scapula during reach.
notes: Primarily a thoracic-rotation mobility drill. Requires isometric stabilization of the lumbar spine and pelvis to avoid lumbar rotation (co-contraction of core). Scapular stabilizers control shoulder position. Variations include lifting the top arm to emphasize thoracic extension/rotation or performing from supine/standing for different loading and stability demands.

reasoning: Tire flip is a compound movement that begins with a hip-dominant hinge to lift the near edge of the tire (deadlift-like) and transitions into a pushing action to roll/drive the tire over. Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension (sagittal) producing the initial lift through the posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, erector spinae) with substantial contribution from the quadriceps. As the tire is elevated, the lifter drives with the upper limbs — shoulder-driven push (horizontal/forward drive) and elbow extension — to complete the flip. The spine must resist flexion (isometric extension) and the scapulothoracic region and forearms provide stabilization and force transfer. Depending on technique, there may also be a brief pulling/gripping phase (lats/arms) but the dominant, defining actions are hinge (hip/knee extension) and push (shoulder/elbow extension).
notes: Technique-dependent: some athletes use a more squat-like or more hinge-dominant setup; finish can be more horizontal shove or a vertical press depending on tire size and hand placement. High demand on core and low-back stability; poor technique (spinal flexion) increases injury risk. Variations/loads alter relative contribution of pushing vs pulling/hinge components.

reasoning: The tire flip is primarily a bilateral lower-body hip-dominant lift that begins with a hip/knee hinge (triple extension) to lift the tire, then transitions to a forward/upward pushing action to drive the tire over. Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension (sagittal) producing the initial lift (hinge). Once the tire clears the edge, the arms/shoulders perform a horizontal push (shoulder horizontal adduction/protraction and elbow extension, transverse/sagittal) to flip the tire. The spine must resist flexion and transfer force (erector spinae and core isometric stabilization), while the scapulae and lats stabilize the shoulder girdle during the push. Sequence and force transfer make HINGE the primary pattern with a secondary PUSH finish.
notes: Technique and mechanics vary: two-person flips or very large tires may alter loading (more horizontal pull components or greater trunk involvement).
