A single-person flip with a lift-and-drive style emphasizes HINGE then horizontal PUSH. Asymmetric or one-arm variations introduce anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary action is repeated bilateral jump propulsion and landing: concentric hip and knee extension with ankle plantarflexion to propel the body (sagittal plane) and eccentric hip/knee/ankle flexion on landing. Because the drill moves feet in and out of a target laterally, there is additional frontal-plane hip abduction/adduction control to position the feet. Primary movers are lower-extremity extensors for propulsion (glutes/quads/plantarflexors) with hip abductors/adductors and core engaged to control lateral placement and frontal-plane stability. Stabilization demands include trunk isometric control to resist flexion/rotation and frontal-plane control at the hips to limit knee valgus during rapid landings.

joint_actions.action: extension (concentric during takeoff) / flexion (eccentric during landing)
extension (concentric during takeoff) / flexion (eccentric during landing)
abduction/adduction (frontal-plane foot placement and lateral control)

notes: Commonly coached as a plyometric/conditioning drill emphasizing quick ground contact, hip/knee extension power and frontal-plane control. Variations: single-leg in/out, lateral-only, or higher box/tire heights. Watch for excessive knee valgus on landing; emphasize soft, hip-dominant landings and trunk bracing.

reasoning: Tire flips begin with a hip-dominant lift pattern: hip and knee extension with spinal extension to break the tire from the ground (classic hinge/deadlift mechanics). After initial lift the movement transitions to a push/drive phase where the athlete pushes/upwards and forwards on the tire with shoulder and elbow extension to rotate/roll it (horizontal/diagonal push). Primary movers are posterior chain muscles producing hip extension in the first phase and anterior shoulder/elbow extensors producing the push in the second phase. Core and scapular stabilizers work isometrically to transfer force and maintain a neutral spine throughout.
notes: Movement varies with tire size/height and individual technique (more knee-dominant or more squat-like starts possible). Emphasize neutral spine, leg-driven lift, and finishing push through shoulders/elbows. Not typically classified as a pure pull despite initial lift because the finish is a pushing/rolling action.

reasoning: The exercise is a primary axial (spinal) rotation in the transverse plane. The dominant joint action is rotation of the spine (thoracic and to a lesser extent lumbar segments) produced by bilateral/contralateral activation of the internal and external obliques and assisted by multifidus and erector spinae. The hips/pelvis and shoulder girdle act mainly as stabilizers or transmit forces depending on arm position. Core stabilization (transversus abdominis, pelvic floor, multifidus) is required to control segmental motion and protect the lumbar spine during rotation.
notes: Variations include seated thoracic rotations, standing trunk twists, or supine knee-drop rotations. If performed isometrically against a rotational load it would additionally be classified as ANTI_ROTATION. Arm/shoulder movement can alter stabilization demands but does not change the primary ROTATION pattern.

reasoning: Toe touchers primarily produce sagittal-plane flexion at the trunk and hip as the torso and/or leg move toward one another. The movement typically involves spinal (lumbar) flexion and hip flexion with the knees often extended (if performed with straight legs). Because the exercise is a forward-fold/abdominal reach rather than a loaded hip-extension task, it does not cleanly map to a dedicated 'core-flexion' category in the available list; HINGE is the closest sagittal hip-dominant label available. Stabilization requires isometric control of the pelvis and deep trunk stabilizers to coordinate lumbar spine flexion and limit unwanted rotation or excessive posterior pelvic drop.
primary_muscles: erector spinae (eccentrically controlled or lengthened depending on variation)
notes: Variation matters: standing forward fold (hamstring stretch) vs. supine toe-touch crunch (trunk flexion). Neither maps perfectly to available patterns; flag for manual review if a distinct 'core flexion' or 'forward fold' category is required. If the exercise is a supine crunch-type toe toucher, primary pattern would be core/trunk flexion rather than a traditional hip HINGE.

reasoning: Trail running is primarily a locomotion pattern: repeated single‑leg stance and swing phases with cyclic hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane producing forward progression. Primary propulsion comes from hip extension and ankle plantarflexion with knee extension contributing to support and push‑off. Because running on uneven trail surfaces and the reciprocal arm swing create rotational forces on the trunk, the core must resist rotation and stabilize the spine and pelvis (isometric anti‑rotation), and the hips must control frontal plane deviations during single‑leg support.
notes: Variations: uphill increases hip/knee extension demand; downhill increases eccentric knee control. Uneven terrain increases frontal plane and proprioceptive/stabilization demands. Unloaded locomotion — no carry pattern unless external load is added.

reasoning: Trail running/walking is a gait-based locomotor activity. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: cyclic hip extension (push-off) and hip flexion (swing), knee extension (stance/push-off) and knee flexion (swing), and ankle plantarflexion (push-off) and dorsiflexion (landing/swing). Secondary requirements include frontal-plane hip abductor activity to stabilize the pelvis during single-leg stance and transverse-plane trunk rotation control to coordinate arm swing and absorb perturbations on uneven terrain. Muscles producing the movement are concentric/eccentric across these joints (gluteus maximus and hamstrings for hip extension; iliopsoas and rectus femoris for hip flexion; quadriceps for knee extension; gastrocnemius/soleus and tibialis anterior for ankle plantarflexion/dorsiflexion). Core and hip abductors act isometrically/eccentrically to stabilize the trunk and pelvis against rotational and frontal-plane perturbations, especially on uneven trail surfaces.

joint_actions.action: abduction/adduction for pelvic stabilization during single-leg stance
axial rotation control and anti-rotation stabilization

notes: Uneven trail surfaces increase demands on proprioception, single-leg balance, and frontal/transverse stabilization. Uphill increases hip/knee/ankle extensor demand; downhill increases eccentric knee/hip control. Carrying a pack would add CARRY and possibly ANTI_ROTATION if asymmetric; use of poles alters upper-limb loading and stabilization.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip extension (hip hinge) combined with knee extension in the sagittal plane to lift the load from the ground — this classifies as a HINGE movement with a pulling action at the torso/upper extremity to overcome load (PULL). Gluteus maximus and hamstrings generate hip extension while quadriceps contribute to knee extension; the erector spinae and other trunk stabilizers maintain a neutral/extended spine. Upper-back muscles (lats/traps) and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to keep the shoulder girdle stable while the hands/arms transmit force to the bar. The trap bar’s neutral handles and more upright torso typically increase knee contribution (more quad involvement) relative to a conventional deadlift but the primary hip-hinge/pull mechanics remain dominant.

joint_actions.action: plantarflexion/extension (final phase) with dorsiflexion at setup

notes: Trap bar deadlift is a textbook deadlift variant — primary patterns are HINGE and PULL. Compared with conventional deadlift it often produces a more upright torso and greater knee (quad) contribution. High-handle or elevated trap bar reduces ROM; unilateral or offset-handle variants would introduce ANTI_ROTATION/CARRY considerations. Focus on maintaining neutral spine and scapular stability.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane hip extension with concurrent knee extension to lift the load from the floor (hinge-dominant deadlift variant). The bar is vertically displaced by pulling force from the lower body and posterior chain, and the lift requires upper-back and grip stabilization (classified as a pull). The trunk (spine) works isometrically to resist flexion while scapular/shoulder girdle muscles stabilize the load. Trap-bar geometry and more upright torso can increase knee contribution relative to a conventional deadlift, but hip extension of glutes/hamstrings remains primary.
notes: Trap-bar handle height and individual stance/torso angle alter knee vs hip emphasis (high handles or more upright torso shift toward greater knee/quadriceps contribution). Pyramid indicates progressive loading/volume but does not change primary movement pattern. Should be treated as a hinge-dominant pull with notable quadriceps assistance compared to a conventional deadlift.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip-dominant extension (hip hinge) with concurrent knee extension to raise the load from the floor—this is a sagittal-plane hip/knee extension pattern. The lift is also a pulling action: the lifter exerts force on the bar to overcome gravity, with posterior chain and scapular/upper-back musculature stabilizing and controlling the bar path (characteristic of a pull). Gluteus maximus and hamstrings produce hip extension; quadriceps assist knee extension; erector spinae maintains spinal extension; lats and trapezius stabilize the shoulder girdle and keep the bar close; forearm flexors/grip maintain hold. Stabilization demands include isometric spinal extension (core/erectors) to resist flexion, scapular/upper-back isometric control to maintain bar position, and lower-limb joint stability during force transfer. Compared with a conventional deadlift, trap-bar use often allows a more upright torso and more knee contribution but does not change the primary hinge + pull pattern.
notes: Trap-bar setup places hands at the sides in a neutral grip and typically produces a more upright torso and greater knee contribution than a conventional barbell deadlift; very high handle heights or marked squat-style technique can shift demand toward SQUAT mechanics. Use of straps or lifting with higher handles reduces grip/ ROM demands but does not change hinge + pull classification. If performed with a pronounced vertical torso and deeper knee bend, some coaches may describe it as a hybrid hinge-squat, but primary pattern remains HINGE + PULL.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge with concurrent knee extension to lift the load from the floor — the pelvis and femur extend in the sagittal plane producing the majority of work (glutes and hamstrings). Knee extensors (quadriceps) contribute to knee extension, especially in the trap-bar variation due to a more upright torso and more knee travel. The lift is also a vertical pull of a loaded implement, requiring upper-back/lat/trap activity to maintain scapular position and grip muscles to hold the handles. The spine is held in a near-neutral/isometrically braced position to transfer force and resist flexion. Stabilization demands include thoracic and lumbar erector isometric control, scapular stabilization from the lats/traps, and grip/forearm isometric force.
notes: Trap-bar shifts the load closer to the center of mass and uses a neutral grip, often producing a slightly more upright torso and increased knee contribution compared with a conventional deadlift. Pyramid refers to loading scheme and does not change primary movement pattern. Variations (high handles, deficit, trap-bar jump) can alter knee vs hip emphasis.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip hinge: the hips flex eccentrically as the torso moves forward and then extend concentrically to return upright (sagittal plane). The lumbar/thoracic spine is held in a neutral/extended position under load (isometric trunk stability). Knees remain slightly flexed and relatively static (secondary), and the shoulder girdle and arms act isometrically to hold the handles while the posterior chain produces the lift. Muscles producing the movement are primarily the gluteus maximus and hamstrings for hip extension, with the erector spinae and other spinal stabilizers maintaining trunk posture. The lift also involves pulling the load vertically upward, so scapular and upper-back muscles (lats/traps) contribute to load transfer and stabilization.

joint_actions.action: trunk stabilization (controls flexion / returns to extension)

notes: Trap bar shifts the load closer to the body compared to a straight bar deadlift; RDL variation emphasizes the hinge with reduced knee travel. High-handle or more upright trunk positions can increase knee/quad contribution (slightly more 'squat-like'); maintain hip-dominant hinge cues and neutral spine for intended pattern.

reasoning: This is an isometric variation of a trap-bar deadlift position: the primary joint demand is maintaining hip hinge alignment while producing/isometrically resisting hip extension torque (sagittal plane). Knees are held in slight flexion with isometric knee-extension torque to support the posture. The spine is held neutral with isometric trunk extension/anti-flexion from the erector spinae and core. Shoulders and elbows are fixed with isometric shoulder-girdle and elbow extension to hold the handles; scapular stabilizers and lats provide shoulder girdle stability and the forearm flexors maintain grip. Because there is no locomotion or rotational demand and the primary load-bearing/resisting action is at the hip (posterior chain), the HINGE pattern is the appropriate classification.

joint_actions.action: isometric extension torque (support partial knee flexion)
isometric trunk stabilization / resist flexion (neutral extension)

notes: Handles-up trap bar places the load close to the center of mass and emphasizes posterior-chain isometric strength (similar to a held deadlift). Not classified as CARRY because there is no locomotion; not ANTI_ROTATION unless performed asymmetrically. Lower handles or added walking would change classification (lower handles increases knee demand; walking converts to CARRY). Ensure core/bracing to protect lumbar spine and maintain neutral alignment.

reasoning: The trap bar static hold is an isometric lockout of a hip-dominant position. Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension held isometrically in the sagittal plane, producing an extended hip posture similar to the top of a deadlift/hinge. The posterior chain (gluteus maximus and hamstrings) provides the primary hip extension torque; quadriceps contribute to knee extension/bracing. The erector spinae and deep spinal stabilizers maintain trunk extension/isometric spinal stability. Upper limb musculature (forearm flexors/grip, traps, scapular stabilizers) act isometrically to maintain the bar position and transmit load to the body. Shoulders and elbows are statically extended/neutral to support the handle, but are not undergoing primary concentric movement. Overall the movement pattern is hip-dominant/isometric hinge rather than a carry, push, or pull.
notes: This is an isometric hinge/lockout. If performed from floor-to-stand repeatedly it combines dynamic HINGE with a PULL-like grip demand; adjusted to ~80% indicates submaximal load and may reduce grip failure risk. Not classified as CARRY because no locomotion and not ANTI_ROTATION unless load is asymmetric.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge: the hips flex to lower the torso and the hips extend to return to standing. Knees remain slightly flexed and move minimally (not a primary knee-dominant squat pattern). The spine resists excessive flexion and maintains a neutral/extended posture (isometric control). Upper back and shoulder girdle act isometrically to hold the trap bar and maintain scapular position. The trap bar places the load more in-line with the center of mass than a straight bar, allowing a more upright torso but the dominant joint action remains hip extension (posterior chain).
notes: Trap bar RDL is a textbook hip-hinge variation; compared with straight-bar RDL it often permits a more upright torso and slightly greater knee contribution but remains hinge-dominant. Emphasize hip travel, neutral spine, and loaded scapular/Grip stability. Variations (sumo trap bar, elevated handles) alter torso angle and ROM but not primary pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge: powerful hip extension drives the load from the floor. Knee extension contributes to lift (combined hip-knee extension in sagittal plane) but the pattern remains hinge-dominant with a vertical pull of the load. Spine is maintained in neutral/near-extension by erector spinae and core to transmit force. The shoulder girdle and lats/traps act isometrically to stabilize the bar and control scapular position while the hands/grip maintain connection to the load. With low handles the torso is more inclined (classic deadlift mechanics); trap-bar shape and neutral grips reduce shear and can slightly alter knee contribution versus a conventional deadlift, but primary pattern is HINGE with a PULL component.
notes: Low handles emphasize hinge mechanics; higher trap-bar handles or very upright torso shift more load to knee (more squat-like). Neutral grip reduces shoulder stress and shear compared with conventional barbell deadlift. Maintain crank/core bracing to protect lumbar spine; grip strength can be a limiting factor.

reasoning: Primary movement is hip-dominant extension (hip hinge) with concurrent knee extension to lift the load from the floor — both occur in the sagittal plane. The lift is also a pulling action: the lifter produces extension force through the hips and knees while the posterior chain and scapular stabilizers control the bar path (vertical pull). Spine and core act isometrically to maintain neutral alignment; shoulders and lats/traps provide scapular stability and prevent rounding.
notes: Trap-bar deadlift is a variant of the conventional deadlift; the neutral handle and centered load often allow a more upright torso and relatively greater knee contribution, but the dominant pattern remains a hip hinge combined with a vertical pull. If performed with a very upright torso and excessive knee bend it may take on more SQUAT-like characteristics, but classification above reflects the common execution.

reasoning: The trap bar RDL is primarily a hip-hinge movement. The dominant joint action is hip extension in the sagittal plane (return from hip flexion to extension) produced mainly by the gluteus maximus and hamstrings. The knees remain slightly flexed and undergo minimal flexion/extension (secondary), while the lumbar spine/trunk resists flexion and is controlled by the erector spinae (eccentric on descent, concentric on ascent). Upper limb musculature (grip/forearm) and scapular stabilizers (lats/traps) act isometrically to hold the handles. Trap-bar geometry often allows a more upright torso and slightly greater knee involvement than a straight-bar RDL, but the primary mechanical pattern remains a hinge.
notes: Trap-bar handle height and stance can shift torso angle and knee contribution (higher handles or more knee bend increases quad involvement). Use neutral spine and maintain a hinge at the hips to preserve hinge-dominant mechanics. Equipment listed as bodyweight/unknown is likely incorrect for this exercise (typically performed with a trap bar and load).

reasoning: Primary action is a hip-dominant hinge (hip extension) with concurrent knee extension in the sagittal plane while holding the load isometrically. The lift/pull component (vertical lift from the ground) requires spinal/pelvic control and upper-back fixation to transmit force from lower to load. During isometric holds the posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, erector spinae) and quadriceps generate/maintain extension torque while scapular and arm musculature (traps/lats/forearms) produce isometric stabilization of the bar/handles. Core (abdominals/obliques) and erector spinae provide isometric spinal stabilization to resist flexion and rotation.
notes: Trap-bar variant typically places load more centrally, reducing shear and often increasing knee contribution relative to conventional barbell deadlift. 'Iso ladder' holds emphasize isometric strength/endurance of posterior chain, grip and core rather than dynamic concentric/eccentric work. Watch for trunk bracing and neutral spine during holds.

reasoning: Primary movement is a loaded hip-dominant lift with concurrent knee extension performed in the sagittal plane. The trap-bar high-handle reduces required torso flexion compared with a conventional deadlift (more upright torso), but the movement still relies on hip extension (posterior chain) while the knees extend to complete the lift. The action is a vertical lift of the load (a pulling action) with the upper limb maintaining a neutral grip and providing load transfer — thus the exercise functions biomechanically as a hinge-based lift with a pulling demand. The spine and scapular musculature act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and transfer force; forearm/grip muscles maintain hold of the handles.
notes: High-handle trap-bar shifts some load to the quadriceps (more knee contribution) and produces a more upright torso than a conventional deadlift; if performed with very upright stance or deep knee bend it can trend toward SQUAT mechanics, while lower handles/greater hip hinge increase HINGE dominance. Ladder (10 s) denotes timed sets but does not change primary pattern classification.

reasoning: This is a loaded walking/marching task with a trap-bar held at the lifter's sides/neutral grip. Primary movement is locomotion under load (CARRY) — repeated hip/knee/ankle flexion-extension in the sagittal plane to produce step-to-step progression while maintaining an upright torso. Shoulders and elbows primarily provide isometric support of the load (neutral grip) and the spine and core provide isometric trunk stabilization (resisting flexion, lateral flexion and rotation). The gait cycle (stance push-off and swing) is produced by concentric hip and knee extension and ankle plantarflexion, with eccentric control during landing and swing-phase hip/knee flexion.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (neutral grip, minimal dynamic motion)
isometric extension / resists flexion, lateral flexion and rotation

notes: Symmetric, centered trap-bar load reduces anti-rotation demand compared with unilateral carries. Primary training effect: loaded gait and lower-extremity force production/endurance; secondary demands: grip and trunk isometric stability. Variations (single-arm trap-bar hold or offset loading) would add ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: The trap-bar iso hold is a static (isometric) locked position equivalent to the top of a deadlift: the hips and knees are held in near-extension to support a loaded vertical force. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip and knee extension held isometrically, with the posterior chain (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) bearing the load and the spinal erectors providing isometric trunk extension. Upper-body musculature (traps, lats, scapular stabilizers, forearms) act isometrically to maintain the grip and shoulder girdle position. Core and spinal extensors resist trunk flexion/forward collapse, requiring substantial isometric stabilization.
notes: Typical symmetrical trap-bar iso hold is primarily an isometric hinge pattern (deadlock). If performed while walking it becomes a CARRY; asymmetric loading or single-arm holds introduce significant ANTI_ROTATION demand. Handle height and starting posture can shift emphasis slightly toward more knee-dominant (quadriceps) or hip-dominant (posterior chain) mechanics.

reasoning: This exercise is an isometric variant of the deadlift/hex-bar hold so the primary joint action is hip extension torque held isometrically with secondary knee extension torque. The hips and posterior chain (gluteus maximus, hamstrings, erector spinae) produce and resist hip extension moments while the quads contribute to knee extension/stability. The spine is held in near-neutral/extended alignment by the erector spinae and deep core musculature to resist flexion. Shoulders and elbows act isometrically to hold the handles (scapular stabilization and elbow extension), and the forearms/grip musculature maintain handle contact. Overall this is a HINGE-dominant isometric hold; if performed while walking or carried, CARRY should be added, and if the load is asymmetrical an ANTI_ROTATION component would be present.
notes: If performed as a standing static lockout/mid-shin hold this remains HINGE-dominant. If the trap bar is marched/walked with the load, add CARRY. If the load/hold is asymmetric (one-sided hold or offset load), include ANTI_ROTATION for lateral/core stabilization. Handle height (mid-shin vs. lockout) shifts emphasis between hamstrings/posterior chain and glutes/quads.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge performed eccentrically (negatives). The hips move through sagittal-plane flexion as the torso travels forward while the knees maintain slight flexion; the lifter controls hip flexion/extension eccentrically to lower the load. The spine resists flexion (isometric/eccentric control of extension) to maintain neutral alignment. Shoulders and elbows act isometrically to hold the trap bar; scapular stabilizers maintain shoulder girdle position. Because the load is centered (trap bar), there is less vertical pulling emphasis and the dominant pattern is the posterior-chain hinge rather than a primary pull.

joint_actions.action: controlled flexion (eccentric)/isometric extension to resist flexion

notes: Negatives emphasis increases eccentric load on glutes/hamstrings and erector spinae; maintain neutral spine and hinge from hips. Trap-bar central load reduces shear and minimizes a pronounced upper-back pull compared with conventional deadlifts. If performed from the floor with a concentric phase, a small PULL component could be argued, but primary pattern remains HINGE for RDL-focused negatives.

reasoning: With the trap-bar at the high handle position and performed isometrically, the lower-limb joints are held in mid/near-extended positions resisting hip and knee flexion. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip extension and knee extension (isometric), producing a mixed hinge/squat demand. The elevated handles produce a more upright torso than a conventional barbell deadlift, increasing knee-extensor contribution (quadriceps) while still loading the posterior chain (glutes/hamstrings) and requiring lumbar/hip stabilization (erector spinae, abdominals). Upper traps/shoulder girdle and forearms provide isometric grip and scapular stability, but are secondary to the lower-limb joint actions.
notes: High handles shift load toward knee extensors vs conventional low-handle trap-bar or barbell deadlift, producing a hybrid hinge–squat pattern. Being isometric (ladder of holds) reduces concentric/eccentric travel but preserves joint loading pattern. If performed as a carry or single-leg variant, include CARRY or LUNGE/ANTI_ROTATION accordingly.

reasoning: Primary action is a hip hinge: the hips move through flexion/extension in the sagittal plane while the knees remain in a slight, quasi-isometric flexion. Hip extension (concentric) is driven by gluteus maximus and hamstrings; the erector spinae and intrinsic spinal stabilizers control spinal position through the range. Hands/forearms hold the trap bar but do not perform a vertical/horizontal pull as the primary driver. Core and lumbar extensors act isometrically to maintain a neutral spine; knees and ankles provide secondary sagittal-plane stability.
notes: ‘Ladder’ refers to rep/set scheme and does not change movement pattern. Trap-bar handle height and stance width can shift load slightly toward more knee involvement (more quad contribution) or more hip-dominant hinge; neutral grip and center-of-mass position typically reduce shear compared with a straight-bar deadlift. Maintain neutral spine and hinge at hips to preserve HINGE pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal/near-sagittal pull: elbow flexion with concomitant scapular retraction and shoulder extension as the hands are drawn toward the torso. The trunk/hips are held in a hinged position isometrically to provide a stable base, so the dynamic action is at the elbow and shoulder girdle (pull). Stabilization demands: thoracic and lumbar erector spinae maintain neutral spine against flexion, glutes/hamstrings maintain hip position, and scapular stabilizers control the retraction rhythm.
notes: Handles-down trap-bar row is primarily a horizontal pull. If the lifter uses substantial hip drive or performs a more upright, dynamic torso extension, classify additionally as HINGE. Neutral-grip (handles at sides) increases biceps/forearm involvement relative to pronated-bar rows.

reasoning: Primary demand is holding a bilateral load at the sides in a standing posture. The task is isometric: hips and knees produce/isometrically maintain extension to support the load; ankles provide stance stability; shoulders and elbows maintain a neutral/extended position to transfer load to the hands; the grip/forearm muscles produce sustained finger flexion. The spine and trunk act isometrically to resist flexion and maintain neutral alignment (anti-flexion/anti-rotation stabilization). Scapular stabilizers (traps, lats, rhomboids) provide shoulder girdle stability. Although there is no locomotion, this is biomechanically a loaded hold/stand — classified as a CARRY pattern (static variant of a farmer's hold).

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization with finger flexion for grip

notes: This is the static/hold variant of a farmer's carry. If the exercise includes walking/marching it remains CARRY but would increase dynamic stabilization demands; an asymmetric or single-arm hold would add ANTI_ROTATION. High handles reduce hip hinge compared with conventional deadlift mechanics.

reasoning: This is an isometric posterior-chain hold in the deadlift/hinge position. The primary demand is to maintain hip extension with static knee position while resisting spinal flexion; the hips and posterior chain produce isometric hip-extension torque. Shoulders and elbows are held in neutral/extended positions to support the load and the grip forearm muscles maintain bar contact. Stabilization requires isometric spinal erectors and core to resist flexion, and scapular/shoulder girdle musculature to maintain carrier position of the bar.
notes: Ladder refers to progressive duration or load of isometric holds. Not classified as CARRY because there's no locomotion; if used while walking, add CARRY. Asymmetric loading would add ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: Primary demand is an isometric loaded hold: lower limbs and posterior chain maintain an extended (lockout) posture while the hands/grip support the load inside the trap bar. Primary joint actions are isometric hip extension and knee extension to maintain upright posture (hinge/lockout), with isometric shoulder girdle and elbow extension to support the load (carry-type load carriage). The spine and core act isometrically to resist flexion and maintain neutral alignment. Stabilization requirements include grip/forearm endurance, scapular stability (retraction/depression), and anti-flexion trunk activation (erector spinae, deep abdominals).
notes: Although no locomotion occurs, the exercise functions similarly to a static carry (loaded grip and axial load) and holds the hinge/lockout position; if performed while walking, classification would remain CARRY but with increased dynamic demand. Asymmetric loading or single-arm variations would add strong ANTI_ROTATION requirements.

reasoning: The exercise is an isometric loaded upright hold taken from a hip-hinge position. Primary joint action is maintaining hip extension (posterior chain isometrically) with knees near full extension — mechanics align with a hinge pattern. Because the load is held in the hands in a loaded standing position (static loaded carry), it also functions as a carry variant (isometric carry). Upper limb actions are isometric grip and scapular/shoulder-girdle stabilization; the spine and core act isometrically to resist flexion. There is no primary horizontal/vertical push or active elbow flexion, and no rotation component in the symmetric trap-bar hold.
notes: Trap-bar centers load around the body reducing shear compared with barbell deadlift. 'Ladder' implies progressive hold durations. If performed unilaterally or with offset load, add ANTI_ROTATION. If used while walking, classify as CARRY primary.

reasoning: This is an isometric loaded hold in the trap bar (handles low) with the lifter standing upright holding the load at the sides. Primary joint demands are maintaining hip and knee in near-full extension (sagittal plane) and resisting trunk flexion — the movement is not dynamic but matches the biomechanical intent of a loaded carry/hold. Grip and forearm muscles produce the force to retain the implement, scapular stabilizers (traps, lats) and elbow extensors maintain shoulder/elbow posture isometrically, and the posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, erectors) and quads sustain hip/knee extension. Stabilization requires substantial anti-flexion core activity and scapular/shoulder stability; because the load is symmetric and there is no walking, no anti-rotation or locomotion pattern is required.
notes: Classified as CARRY because it is a loaded standing hold (carry family). Handles-low increases posterior-chain demand compared with raised handles. If the lifter walks while holding it, add LOCOMOTION. Asymmetric or single-arm variations would add ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip-dominant hinge with simultaneous knee extension in the sagittal plane producing vertical displacement of a loaded implement. The concentric phase is generated largely by hip extension (gluteus maximus) and hamstring activity with substantial knee extensor contribution (quadriceps) depending on handle height and stance. The lift also functions as a bilateral vertical pull pattern: the load is pulled from the floor against gravity with isometric scapular and spinal control (lats, traps, erector spinae) to maintain torso position and transfer force. The pyramid sets increase volume while the hold emphasizes isometric lockout of the hips/spine and grip endurance. Stabilization demands include anti-flexion of the spine (isometric spinal extension), scapular stabilization to prevent protraction, and grip/forearm isometrics to maintain hold.
notes: Trap-bar variation yields a more upright torso than conventional deadlift and can increase knee extensor contribution; using higher handles or a narrow stance further shifts demand toward quadriceps (squat-like). The 'hold' emphasizes isometric hip/spine lockout and grip endurance. No significant rotational or carry demands in the standard bilateral trap-bar deadlift.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane producing a vertical displacement of the load (hip-dominant hinge pattern with significant knee extension). The lifter initiates force via hip extension (glutes/hamstrings) while extending the knees (quads) to stand. The lift is also a pulling action of a loaded implement from the ground — scapular and upper-back musculature (lats, traps) and grip produce/isometrically control the pull. The trap-bar often produces a more vertical torso and greater knee contribution than a conventional deadlift, but the dominant mechanical pattern remains a hip hinge with a pulling intent. Stabilization demands include isometric spinal extension from the erector spinae and core to resist flexion, and scapular/shoulder stabilization by lats/traps; elbows remain largely extended/isometric.
notes: Trap-bar configuration shifts load path compared with conventional deadlift — more upright torso and increased knee contribution can make it slightly more 'squat-like' depending on handle height and stance, but primary mechanics remain hinge + pull. Pyramid set scheme affects fatigue and neuromuscular demand but not fundamental pattern. Elevated handles, sumo stance, or very wide/narrow foot positions can alter joint contribution and should be considered when classifying.

reasoning: This movement is essentially a trap-bar deadlift variant performed from the elevated/high handles and held isometrically (max-hold ladder). Primary joint actions are hip extension and knee extension in the sagittal plane (partial-range deadlift/lockout). The spine functions in isometric extension to resist flexion (anti-flexion), and the shoulders/scapulae and elbows act isometrically to maintain grip and bar position (scapular stabilization/retraction). Because the action is lifting and holding a load by extending the hips/knees against gravity, it matches the HINGE pattern (posterior chain hip-dominant extension) with a secondary PULL pattern (vertical/lifting grip action with scapular stabilization).
notes: High handles reduce hip ROM and can increase knee contribution (slightly more quad demand) compared with conventional deadlift; performed as an isometric hold (ladder) emphasizes posterior chain and grip endurance. If performed as loaded walking, add CARRY; asymmetric loading would add ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: Primary action is a hip-dominant hinge: the hips flex as the torso moves forward and the hips extend to return to upright, all in the sagittal plane. Knees remain slightly flexed with minimal change in ROM (not a primary knee-dominant squat pattern). The lumbar/thoracic spine is held in near-neutral and resists excessive flexion (isometric spinal extension). Upper limbs hold the trap bar statically to transmit load; there is minimal scapular retraction or elbow flexion production. Therefore the movement is best classified as a HINGE emphasizing posterior chain hip extension (glutes/hamstrings) with spinal stabilization by the erector spinae and core.
notes: Trap-bar RDL is a textbook hinge variant—trap bar shifts load closer to the centerline and often allows a more upright torso than straight-bar RDL, slightly reducing shear and increasing comfort. Progressions/variations: heavier loading approaches a conventional deadlift pattern (may add PULL characteristics), single-leg trap-bar RDL introduces greater stability/anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a deadlift-style hip hinge: the lifter produces hip extension (with concomitant knee extension) in the sagittal plane to lift the load and then holds it isometrically. Secondary pulling demands (grip, scapular/shoulder stabilization) classify it as a PULL pattern. The hold phase requires isometric spinal extension and core stabilization to maintain neutral torso; forearm flexors maintain grip and traps/lats maintain scapular position.
notes: Trap-bar shifts the load closer to the body and permits a more upright torso and greater knee contribution than a conventional barbell deadlift, but primary mechanics remain hip-dominant hinge with pulling/grip stabilization. If the exercise transitions to walking while holding, add CARRY. Asymmetric variations would add ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: The primary movement is a hip-dominant lift from the floor into standing (hip extension with secondary knee extension) — a hinge pattern. While the upper limb does not perform concentric elbow flexion, the back and shoulder girdle perform isometric/anti-gravity pulling actions (scapular and lat stabilization) to keep the trunk neutral and the bar close to the body, so the exercise also fits the PULL pattern. The hold phase is an isometric continuation of these demands, with substantial grip/forearm work and spinal stabilization.
notes: Trap-bar setup often yields a more upright torso and greater knee contribution than a conventional deadlift, but primary pattern remains a hinge. The hold phase increases isometric grip and spinal stabilization demands. Asymmetric or single-handle variations would add ANTI_ROTATION/CARRY elements.

reasoning: Primary movement when picking and holding a trap-bar from the floor is hip-dominant extension (hinge pattern) with concurrent knee extension; this produces vertical displacement of the load. The lift also requires strong spinal extension/isometric trunk stabilization and scapular/upper-back stabilization to maintain a locked-out hold (pull pattern as in deadlift where the posterior chain and lats/traps assist and stabilize the load). Grip/forearm muscles maintain the hold. The primary joint actions are hip and knee extension in the sagittal plane; the spine is held in isometric extension to resist flexion; shoulders and elbows act isometrically to stabilize the bar in a neutral handle position.
notes: Trap-bar shifts load closer to center of mass and typically allows a more upright torso and greater quadriceps contribution versus a conventional deadlift, but primary pattern remains hip-hinge with posterior chain dominance and pull-style upper-back stabilization. If the hold is followed by walking, add CARRY; if load is asymmetric, add ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: This is an isometric loaded standing hold: primary requirement is to support a load at the hands while maintaining upright posture. Primary joint actions are isometric hip and knee extension to keep the torso elevated, isometric spinal extension to resist trunk flexion, and isometric elbow extension/forearm grip to support the load. Scapular depression/retraction and shoulder girdle stabilization are required to position the load. Muscles generating/supporting these actions are the posterior chain and core to maintain posture and the forearm/hand muscles for grip.
notes: Classified as CARRY because it is a loaded hold (static carry). If performed as a walk, it remains CARRY; if load is offset/unilateral, add ANTI_ROTATION for asymmetric loading. Fatigue is often grip-limited; trunk and scapular endurance are key stabilizers.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow extension in the sagittal plane driven concentrically by the triceps. The glenohumeral joint and scapulothoracic complex remain relatively isometric to stabilize the upper arm at the side; the forearm/wrist maintain a neutral grip under tension. Movement is a unilateral/bilateral upper-body pressing action about the elbow (push pattern) with cable resistance providing constant tension.
notes: V-bar provides a neutral/semi-pronated grip which can alter wrist/forearm loading. Variations (rope, straight bar, overhead triceps extensions) change shoulder involvement; cable provides continuous tension throughout range.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow extension in the sagittal plane produced by the triceps. The shoulder girdle remains relatively fixed (isometric scapular/rotator cuff stabilization) while the elbow extends against resistance. This is an upper-body pushing action focused at the elbow joint rather than a multi-joint shoulder push.
primary_muscles: triceps brachii (long head, lateral head, medial head)

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (neutral or slight extension depending on grip)

notes: Variation by attachment/grip: rope, bar, or V-handle changes wrist/elbow flare and long-head emphasis. Single-arm or highly offset loads introduce anti-rotation/stability demands. Overhead triceps extensions move the shoulder and would add a SHOULDER extension/flexion component.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow extension in the sagittal plane produced by the triceps brachii (especially the long head when arm is overhead) and anconeus. The shoulder is held in an overhead position (shoulder flexion/abduction) and functions largely as an isometric/stabilizing joint, with rotator cuff and deltoid activity to stabilize the glenohumeral joint. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius, rhomboids) and core musculature provide trunk and shoulder girdle stability to resist unwanted lumbar extension or scapular motion. Because the primary movement is an elbow extension (a pushing action of the upper limb) the most appropriate movement pattern is PUSH.
notes: Rope attachment can increase end-range triceps stretch and allow some external rotation of the forearm at lockout. Cue scapular control and neutral spine; single-arm or asymmetrical variations would introduce anti-rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary visible movement is repositioning of the arm overhead (shoulder flexion/abduction) with the elbow flexed to place the hand behind/near the head and an accompanying lateral trunk side-bend (spinal lateral flexion) to accentuate the stretch. The shoulder/arm movement is analogous to an unloaded vertical arm raise (vertical push pattern) while the trunk movement is a frontal-plane spinal movement often categorized with rotational/lateral trunk patterns. Stabilization demands include scapular control (serratus anterior/traps) and contralateral core engagement to control the lateral bend and maintain balance.

joint_actions.action: upward rotation / elevation (to allow overhead arm position)

notes: This is a static stretching/mobility exercise rather than a force-producing pattern. 'PUSH' denotes the unloaded overhead arm position mechanics; 'ROTATION' selected to reflect trunk frontal-plane side-bend (closest available category). Variations: performed with arm held by opposite hand for increased lateral trunk stretch; can be done seated or standing.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow extension in the sagittal plane produced by the triceps. The shoulder and scapula remain relatively fixed and act isometrically to stabilize the upper arm; the spine and core provide trunk stabilization. The rope allows slight transverse/outward movement of the hands at terminal extension but does not introduce a primary rotational or anti-rotation pattern. Primary mover is the triceps brachii (all heads) with anconeus assisting; forearm musculature provides grip/stabilization and rotator cuff/delts stabilize the shoulder girdle.
notes: Rope attachment permits independent hand movement and slight external hand flare at end range; changing torso angle or using different bar attachments slightly alters shoulder involvement. Emphasize controlled eccentric and full elbow extension without excessive shoulder motion.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow extension in the sagittal plane produced by the triceps brachii (terminal elbow extension). The upper arm is held relatively stationary (shoulder isometrically held in slight flexion/neutral) and the torso/hips maintain a hinged, braced position to allow isolation of the elbow. Scapular stabilizers and rotator cuff muscles isometrically control the shoulder position while the triceps create the concentric elbow extension. If performed unilaterally without support, the exercise also imposes anti-rotational/core stabilization demands to resist torso rotation, but that is a secondary requirement and depends on the variation.
notes: Typically a single-joint elbow extension exercise mapped to the PUSH pattern (elbow extension = push). Unilateral/unsupported variations add ANTI_ROTATION demands; supported/bent-over bench variations reduce core anti-rotation load. Watch for excessive shoulder movement—if the shoulder moves substantially the pattern shifts toward combined shoulder extension/horizontal abduction.

reasoning: This is a static stretching exercise rather than a dynamic functional movement pattern. The primary joint positions are elbow flexion (bringing the forearm toward the upper arm) and shoulder flexion/overhead positioning (arm lifted overhead) in the sagittal plane; some variations introduce horizontal adduction when the elbow is pulled across the head/chest (frontal/transverse components). The intent is passive lengthening of the triceps (especially the long head which crosses the shoulder) rather than concentric/functional movement, so it does not map cleanly to PUSH/PULL/HINGE/SQUAT/LUNGE/LOCOMOTION/CARRY/ROTATION or ANTI_ROTATION patterns. Stabilization is provided isometrically by the rotator cuff and periscapular muscles to maintain glenohumeral/scapular position and by the contralateral arm if used to assist the stretch.
notes: Categorized as a stretch — not a primary functional movement pattern. Variations: cross-body triceps stretch adds shoulder horizontal adduction (frontal/transverse). Caution with shoulder impingement or recent elbow/shoulder injury; ensure scapular stabilization and avoid forced range of motion.

reasoning: The tuck crunch is primarily a sagittal-plane trunk-flexion movement with a secondary hip-flexion component when knees are drawn toward the chest. The primary joint motion is lumbar/thoracic spine flexion produced by concentric shortening of the rectus abdominis and assisted by the internal/external obliques; the hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) act as secondary movers to bring the femur toward the torso. The hips and knees flex in the sagittal plane to enable the tuck, and the pelvis posteriorly tilts. Stabilization demands include isometric control from the deep core (transversus abdominis) and the erector spinae eccentrically on descent, plus pelvic/hip stabilizers to control pelvis position. Given the available pattern set, HINGE is selected to represent the pronounced sagittal hip flexion component, though the dominant technical action is spinal flexion (trunk curl).
notes: Classification constrained by available pattern list; exercise is fundamentally trunk-flexion (core) rather than a classic hip-hinge. If a 'TRUNK FLEXION' or 'CORE' pattern were available it would be more accurate. Variations (leg straight, bicycle crunch) change hip vs. spinal contribution.

reasoning: The Turkish Get-Up is a multi-step, unilateral overhead-to-standing sequence. Primary demands are: 1) isometric anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion of the trunk and shoulder to stabilize a unilateral overhead load (transverse/frontal plane), 2) hip-dominant bridging/hip extension and posterior chain work when rising from supine/hip bridge phases (sagittal hinge), and 3) a transition to and drive from a half-kneeling/standing position that functions biomechanically as a lunge/stand (sagittal plane knee and hip extension). Secondary requirements include scapular and rotator cuff stability to maintain the overhead position, thoracic mobility/controlled rotation during the roll-to-elbow and sweep phases, and single-leg stability through the lunge/stand finish.

joint_actions.action: extension (bridge and drive) and flexion/transition during sweep
flexion/extension (knee support in half-kneel and lunge-to-stand)

notes: Typically performed with a unilateral overhead load (kettlebell/DB) which increases anti-rotation demand; can be done unloaded (lower anti-rotation load). Movement contains transient thoracic rotation during transitions but primary core demand is anti-rotation. Progressions emphasize controlled hinge and single-leg/lunge strength and overhead stability.

reasoning: Primary action is an isometric vertical pull/hang from an overhead implement: shoulders are held in overhead position with the scapulothoracic muscles controlling scapular depression/retraction while the forearms maintain grip. Hips and knees are held in sustained flexion to keep the tuck position, requiring isometric hip flexor and abdominal engagement. The trunk must isometrically resist lumbar extension (anti-extension) while the shoulders and forearms provide the vertical support. Primary movers are therefore the lats and scapular stabilizers for the hang, forearm finger flexors for grip, and hip flexors/abdominals to maintain the tucked posture; stabilization demands include scapular control and core anti-extension.
primary_muscles: lower trapezius / scapular stabilizers (rhomboids, serratus anterior)

joint_actions.action: elevation/overhead hold with scapular depression control (isometric)

notes: Two main emphases: vertical pull/grip and core/hip-flexor isometric hold. Variations/progressions include active scapular depression (compression tuck), L-hang progressions (extend hips), single-leg tucks, or adding scapular retraction focus. Monitor shoulder integrity and grip endurance.

reasoning: The Turkish get-up is a multi-segment transitional movement. Primary actions: unilateral hip extension/bridge to rise from supine (HINGE), then progression to a split/kneeling-to-standing pattern that ends in a single-leg/step-up–like rise (LUNGE). The load is typically held overhead on one side (or simulated), producing strong isometric demand to resist rotation and lateral flexion of the torso and shoulder complex (ANTI_ROTATION). Shoulders and elbows act primarily as isometric stabilizers while the hips and knees produce concentric extension in the sagittal plane; the trunk undergoes/transfers transverse rotation during the roll-to-knee and turn-to-stand phases that must be resisted when loaded unilaterally.

joint_actions.action: transverse rotation and isometric anti-rotation stabilization

notes: If performed with an overhead weight (kettlebell/dumbbell), ANTI_ROTATION demand increases markedly. Without external load the movement still contains transverse rotation and unilateral stability demands. The exercise is commonly taught as segmented progressions (roll to elbow → bridge → sit → kneel → stand). Mobility (shoulder, thoracic, hip) and scapular/rotator cuff stability are important considerations.

exercise: Turban Stretch (pull leg in, push knee while pulling ankle) - hips/glutes
reasoning: Primary joint actions are hip flexion (bringing the thigh toward the torso) and hip external rotation/abduction (creating the figure‑4 orientation that stretches the piriformis/gluteal region) with concurrent knee flexion as the ankle is drawn toward the body. The transverse plane hip external rotation is the key mechanical feature (hence ROTATION). The hands actively pull the ankle/foot toward the chest, so a secondary pulling action occurs (PULL) to produce/assist the hip flexion and knee flexion. Stabilization requires an isometric neutral spine and contralateral hip stability; the core and contralateral hip musculature act to prevent pelvic rotation or tilt while the stretched side undergoes rotation and flexion.
notes: Commonly performed supine as a figure‑4/piriformis stretch. If the movement is purely passive (no active pull) PULL may be omitted; if performed seated/standing with active limb manipulation, PULL is appropriate. Avoid forcing range if there is radiating sciatic pain; use a strap if ankle reach is limited.

reasoning: The Turkish Get-Up is a complex, multi-segment movement that primarily requires isometric anti-rotation of the trunk/shoulder complex (to stabilize an elevated arm and resist torso rotation) while producing sequential hip hinge and single-leg hip/knee extension transitions that finish as a split-stance stand (lunge pattern). Primary joint actions: shoulder stabilization in an overhead position (scapular stability, rotator cuff activation) and spinal anti-rotation in the transverse/frontal planes; hip extension via a single-leg bridge/hinge to lift the pelvis; then progressive knee and hip extension in sagittal plane to stand from a half-kneeling/split-stance (lunge) position. Throughout, the obliques/transverse abdominis and glute medius/glute maximus act isometrically to control rotation and frontal-plane pelvic position. Secondary requirements include scapular and rotator-cuff stability, ankle mobility/stability on the stance leg, and eccentric control during controlled descent.

joint_actions.action: isometric elevation/stabilization (overhead hold) with scapular upward rotation
anti-rotation/isometric stabilization with controlled axial rotation during the roll-to-elbow
plantarflexion/dorsiflexion for stance control and balance
controlled flexion/extension in transition to split-stance and stand

notes: Classification assumes a typical single-arm overhead or unloaded bodyweight technique. With a loaded single-arm version, ANTI_ROTATION importance increases; with no overhead load the anti-rotation demand is reduced but transverse-plane control and hinge/lunge sequencing remain. Progressions emphasize slow, controlled tempo to improve shoulder stability, hip hinge mechanics, and single-leg strength/balance.

reasoning: This is primarily an isolated elbow flexion exercise performed in the sagittal plane. The primary joint action is elbow flexion against resistance produced by the biceps brachii, brachialis and brachioradialis. The preacher pad stabilizes the upper arm and reduces shoulder and torso contribution, so the shoulder and spine act largely isometrically to maintain position and resist unwanted movement. Scapular and rotator cuff muscles provide stabilization of the shoulder girdle while the forearm may perform concurrent supination depending on grip.
notes: Preacher bench increases isolation of elbow flexors by limiting shoulder motion. Grip (supinated vs neutral/hammer) changes relative emphasis between biceps brachii and brachioradialis. Performed seated with pad reduces momentum and trunk involvement.

reasoning: The movement is initiated as a hip-dominant hinge: hip flexion to start and explosive hip extension in the sagittal plane to generate upward momentum. Secondary actions include knee extension and ankle plantarflexion (triple extension) contributing to force production, followed by a rapid arm/upper-body pull (elbow flexion with forearm supination and scapulothoracic control) to guide the kettlebells into the front-rack position. Primary movers are the posterior chain (glutes/hamstrings/erector spinae) producing hip extension, while upper limb pullers (biceps, forearm supinators, traps/latissimus for scapular control) decelerate and rack the load. The trunk and scapular stabilizers (erector spinae, obliques, deep core, serratus anterior) act isometrically to transfer force and maintain a neutral spine during the turnover. Because the load is bilateral and symmetric, anti-rotation is minimal.

joint_actions.action: flexion/vertical displacement and stabilization into rack (minor)

notes: Bilateral symmetric load—no significant anti-rotation. Variations: single-arm clean introduces ANTI_ROTATION demands; squat-clean variations add SQUAT pattern. Kettlebell handle orientation requires forearm supination during turnover.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical push: the weights are driven from the front-rack to locked overhead via shoulder elevation and elbow extension. The movement is powered by a rapid dip and drive (short hip/knee/ankle flexion followed by explosive extension—triple extension) in the sagittal plane, which classifies the lower-body contribution as a shallow/ballistic squat-type drive. Stabilization demands include scapular upward rotation and rotator-cuff control at the shoulder, and strong anti-flexion/anti-rotation core activity to transfer force from the legs to the upper extremities and to receive the load overhead.
notes: Variation: push jerk (split or squat receiving) vs strict push press; split or squat receiving changes lower-limb stabilization demands. Bilateral, symmetric loading—no ANTI_ROTATION. Emphasis on timing of dip-drive and strong scapular/rotator cuff stability for safe overhead lockout.

reasoning: Underhand (supinated) cable pulldowns are a vertical pulling movement. Primary joint actions are humeral (shoulder) extension and adduction as the bar is pulled from overhead toward the torso, with concurrent elbow flexion. The scapulothoracic joint undergoes retraction and slight depression/downward rotation to support the humeral movement. The trunk and pelvis are held isometrically to stabilize the torso while the shoulder girdle and elbow perform the concentric pull. Because the movement is driven by pulling the load toward the body (vertical plane), it classifies as a PULL pattern.
notes: Underhand (supinated) grip increases biceps contribution and can alter shoulder mechanics vs. pronated lat pulldown. Excessive torso lean shifts pattern toward a horizontal pull/row. Ensure scapular depression/retraction control to avoid shoulder impingement.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical push: bilateral shoulder elevation into overhead (primarily shoulder flexion/abduction in the sagittal/scapular plane) with elbow extension to lock out. The scapulothoracic joints perform upward rotation (scapular stabilizers active). The thoracic/lumbar spine and hips act isometrically to resist trunk flexion/extension and maintain an upright posture. Kettlebell grip demands forearm/wrist stabilization. Because the load is symmetric and the action is an overhead press, the dominant pattern is PUSH; there is no primary pulling, hinging, squatting, carrying, or anti-rotation requirement beyond general core stabilization.
notes: Kettlebell-specific considerations: two-arm symmetric loading reduces anti-rotation demands compared with unilateral presses; grip and wrist position may alter forearm/triceps loading. Strict military press variation emphasizes minimal lower-body drive and greater shoulder/core isometric control.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are shoulder flexion (raising the arms overhead) and thoracic/lumbar spinal extension in the sagittal plane. Biomechanically this is the same primary joint action as a vertical push (overhead reach/vertical shoulder flexion) even though it is usually performed without external load. Shoulders produce the large arc of motion while scapular upward rotation (trapezius/serratus) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint. Spinal erectors produce the extension/anti-gravity control of the trunk; core musculature (abdominals, obliques) and hip extensors act isometrically to limit excessive lumbar hyperextension and maintain pelvic position.

joint_actions.action: neutral to slight extension (posterior chain support)

notes: Often performed as a mobility/stretch exercise (e.g., 'upward salute' / Urdhva Hastasana). If performed dynamically with load or forceful press, classification would include PUSH + possible ANTI-ROTATION for asymmetry. Scapulothoracic upward rotation is a key component but scapula is not listed as a joint in the schema.

reasoning: Primary motion is thoracic spine rotation in the transverse plane (typical upper-back stretches such as "thread-the-needle" or seated thoracic rotations). The thoracic vertebrae rotate relative to the lumbar/cervical spine; scapulothoracic movement (protraction/retraction and slight shoulder movement) is commonly present as a secondary action to increase thoracic ROM. Stabilization is provided isometrically by deep spinal stabilizers (multifidus/rotatores) and scapular stabilizers (rhomboids, serratus anterior) to control the thoracic motion and protect lower spine.
notes: This classification assumes a thoracic rotation-style upper-back stretch (e.g., thread-the-needle or seated thoracic rotations). If the intended stretch is strictly thoracic extension (foam-roller extension or pec/lat stretch) the primary joint action would be sagittal-plane extension and classification could differ; stretching exercises are primarily mobility-focused rather than force-based movement patterns.

reasoning: Primary action is combined spinal flexion and transverse-plane rotation performed dynamically while the hips flex to bring legs toward the torso and the arms reach around the kettlebell. The movement is a core-dominant trunk flexion with an intentional rotation component (alternating side-to-side) — obliques generate rotation while rectus abdominis and hip flexors drive the sagittal flexion; shoulders/arms perform a reaching motion. Stabilization requires isometric control of the lumbar spine and pelvic position, and the shoulder girdle/base of support must stabilize during the reach.
notes: If the kettlebell is being reached around asymmetrically or held, there may be added anti-rotation/isometric stabilization demands; variations (single-leg, weighted reach) increase transverse-plane/oblique loading. Progress/regress by limiting range (toe touches) or removing rotation (straight V-up).

reasoning: The V-Bar Pulldown is a vertical pulling exercise. Primary joint actions occur at the glenohumeral joint (downward/back humeral movement — shoulder extension with an adduction component) and the elbow (flexion) in the sagittal plane. The scapulothoracic region performs concentric depression/retraction to assist the downward pull (lower trap/rhomboid activity). Trunk/spine functions isometrically to maintain a stable torso. Primary movers (latissimus dorsi, teres major) drive the shoulder extension/adduction while elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis) contribute to elbow flexion; scapular retractors/depressors (middle/lower traps, rhomboids) stabilize and guide the scapula.

joint_actions.action: extension with adduction component (downward/back pull), concentric

notes: V-bar (neutral, close) grip emphasizes elbow flexors and a more vertical/close-path lat line compared with wide pronated pulldowns; scapular depression/retraction quality and trunk stability influence technique and muscle emphasis.

reasoning: The V-Up is primarily a sagittal-plane core/hip flexion movement: the hips actively flex to bring the legs upward while the lumbar spine flexes to bring the torso toward the legs. Primary joint actions are hip flexion and spinal (lumbar) flexion; the knees are typically held in near-extension and the shoulders/arms reach overhead (shoulder flexion is a small assisting action to maintain arm position). Movement is driven by concentric hip flexors and spinal flexors with the abdominals producing trunk flexion; hip extensors and posterior chain act largely isometrically for stabilization. Core stabilizers (transverse abdominis, multifidus) control pelvic position and limit excessive lumbar shear during the combined hip+spine flexion.
notes: V-Up combines hip flexion and trunk flexion; classified here as HINGE due to dominant sagittal-plane hip movement when selecting from the provided pattern set. Variations (bent-knee V-up, weighted V-up, decline V-up) change loading and lumbar shear. Caution with lumbar disc history because of repeated/loaded spinal flexion.

reasoning: Primary joint action is hip flexion in the sagittal plane as the thigh is drawn toward the torso by the hands. The movement is non–weightbearing (commonly supine) or can be performed in standing; in both cases the hip flexors produce the primary motion while the upper limb (shoulder/elbow flexors) actively pulls the limb. Stabilization requirements depend on variation: supine version requires pelvic/core stabilization to prevent posterior tilt; standing single‑leg versions require ipsilateral ankle stability and contralateral hip abductor/isometric core activity.
notes: Variation exists: some perform this as a supine hamstring/hip stretch (knee may be extended or slightly flexed), others perform a standing quad/heel‑to‑glute grab. If standing, include increased demand on single‑leg balance and hip abductors. Avoid aggressive pulling if low back or recent hamstring injury is present.

reasoning: The Viking Press is a vertical pressing movement where the lifter drives handles upward from shoulder height. Primary joint actions are shoulder elevation/flexion (lifting the arm overhead) and elbow extension in the sagittal plane. The scapulothoracic complex produces upward rotation to allow full overhead range. The spine and core act isometrically to resist trunk extension and maintain a stable torso while force is transferred from the legs/hips through the torso to the shoulders. Prime movers are the deltoids and triceps with assistance from upper pecs and scapular upward rotators; the core/erector system stabilizes the spine.
notes: Machine/stance and handle path variations change exact shoulder plane (slight scapular plane/scaption), but the primary pattern remains a vertical PUSH. Seated versions reduce lower‑body involvement; single‑arm or asymmetric setups increase anti‑rotation demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical press: bilateral/semi-unilateral shoulder elevation to overhead with elbow extension (vertical PUSH). Because the variation alternates arms (neutral-grip alternations), there is transient unilateral loading that creates rotational and lateral torque on the torso, requiring isometric anti-rotation/anti-lateral-flexion bracing. Shoulders (glenohumeral) perform flexion/upper elevation (with scapular upward rotation) and the elbows extend to complete the press. The trunk (obliques, rectus, erector spinae) and contralateral hip/gluteal complex work isometrically to resist rotation and maintain a stable base. Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, upper trapezius, rotator cuff) control the shoulder blade throughout the overhead path.
notes: If performed strictly bilateral (both arms simultaneously on symmetrical handles) the ANTI_ROTATION component is reduced and classification would be primarily PUSH. Seated/leaning variations change lower-body stabilization demands. Neutral grip emphasizes rotator cuff and scapular control and may shift loading slightly toward the deltoids and triceps compared with a pronated grip.

reasoning: Primary movement is axial rotation of the spine in the transverse plane (thoracic and to a lesser extent lumbar). The movement is produced by bilateral/unilateral contraction of the obliques and spinal rotators to rotate the torso; hips may allow or limit rotation depending on foot/pelvic positioning but are not the primary drivers. Stabilization demands include isometric activity of the deep abdominals (transverse abdominis) and spinal extensors (multifidus/erector spinae) to control segmental motion and protect the lumbar spine during rotation.
notes: Commonly performed standing or seated. Emphasize thoracic rotation with a stable pelvis to reduce lumbar shear. Variations: seated/anchored pelvis to isolate thoracic rotation, or added load/medicine ball toss to increase rotational demand. Avoid large lumbar rotation in clients with acute low-back pain.

exercise: Viking Press (Landmine, U-clip setup at waist height, 45 lb plate)
reasoning: Primary joint actions are shoulder flexion/diagonal upward press and elbow extension as the bar is driven in an upward-forward arc off the landmine (primarily a vertical/oblique push). The off-center load and arc produce a transverse-plane rotational moment about the spine that the core (obliques, transverse abdominis) must resist isometrically, so anti-rotation stabilization is a secondary but important component. Scapular upward rotation and protraction occur to allow full overhead/arc movement (serratus anterior, upper trapezius). Lower limbs provide bilateral stance stabilization with isometric hip/knee/ankle control.

joint_actions.action: flexion with oblique/upward arc (horizontal adduction component)

notes: If performed single-arm or unilateral on the bar, anti-rotation demand increases substantially; two-handed/symmetric grips reduce but do not eliminate transverse torque because of the offset landmine pivot. Bar height and grip position alter the arc (more horizontal vs more vertical emphasis).

reasoning: As a plyometric, bodyweight Vertical Swing is primarily an explosive triple-extension movement (hip, knee, ankle) to generate vertical displacement — classification as SQUAT pattern. Many vertical swings also begin with a pronounced hip hinge and powerful hip extension to load and 'snap' the hips (hinge pattern). The arms actively swing in the sagittal plane to contribute to vertical momentum (shoulder flexion/extension) and timing. Primary joint actions are sagittal-plane hip extension, knee extension and ankle plantarflexion; shoulder sagittal motion is secondary. Core and lumbar extensors provide trunk stabilization during the explosive phase and landing.
notes: If the Vertical Swing refers specifically to a kettlebell-style swing (ballistic hip hinge with limited knee flexion), HINGE would be primary and confidence should be increased. If it's a countermovement/squat jump with arm swing, SQUAT is the dominant pattern. Pay attention to technique: more knee bend shifts emphasis toward SQUAT; more hip snap shifts emphasis toward HINGE.

reasoning: Walking is a cyclical locomotor pattern characterized by alternating lower-limb movements producing forward progression. Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: hip extension during stance and hip flexion during swing, knee extension during weight acceptance/stance and knee flexion during swing, and ankle plantarflexion at push-off with dorsiflexion at foot strike. There is also transverse-plane pelvic/trunk rotation and frontal-plane hip abductor activity to maintain pelvis level during single-leg stance. Primary movers (gluteals, hamstrings, quadriceps, calf complex, tibialis anterior, iliopsoas) drive the motion while core and hip stabilizers (gluteus medius, obliques, erector spinae) provide postural and single-leg stabilization; reciprocal arm swing involves small shoulder flexion/extension to assist balance.
notes: Cool-down walking is unweighted locomotion; if external load is carried add CARRY, and if load is asymmetric also include ANTI_ROTATION. Pace, incline, or arm carriage will alter muscle emphasis and stabilization demands.

reasoning: This is a gait pattern (walking) driven primarily by cyclical hip flexion/extension, knee flexion/extension and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion in the sagittal plane. Pelvic and thoracic segments undergo low-amplitude transverse rotation with contralateral arm swing. Single‑leg phases require frontal‑plane hip stabilization to control pelvic drop. Primary movers (gluteus maximus, hamstrings, quadriceps, calf complex, tibialis anterior) produce propulsion and limb advancement while hip abductors and core musculature act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and trunk.
notes: Cool‑down walking is low intensity locomotion; variations (speed, incline, carrying load) could add CARRY or greater stabilization demands. Arm swing contributes to transverse plane counter-rotation but is not primary for classification.

reasoning: Walking is a locomotor pattern driven by cyclical hip/knee/ankle actions in the sagittal plane with transverse pelvic rotation and frontal-plane hip control for balance. Primary joint actions are hip flexion/extension, knee flexion/extension and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion producing forward progression; trunk and pelvis rotate in the transverse plane and hip abductors act isometrically to stabilize during single-leg stance. Arm swing produces reciprocal shoulder flexion/extension but is secondary to lower‑limb locomotion.
notes: Assumed unloaded, steady-state walking. If walking is loaded or asymmetrically loaded (e.g., carrying an object or partner), add CARRY and/or ANTI_ROTATION as appropriate. Pace, incline, or assisted/resisted variations modify muscle emphasis and stabilization demands.

reasoning: This is a walking-based cardio movement (bodyweight). Primary joint actions are repeated hip flexion/extension, knee flexion/extension and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion in the sagittal plane to produce step-to-step progression. Each step requires single-leg support so frontal-plane hip abduction and transverse-plane trunk/hip control act as stabilizers. Movement is driven by concentric/eccentric action of hip extensors and knee/ankle muscles for push-off and swing, with isometric core and hip abductors maintaining pelvis/trunk alignment.
notes: Assumed bodyweight walking/cardio. If the exercise includes a load (e.g., farmer's carry, single-arm load) add CARRY and potentially ANTI_ROTATION for asymmetric loading; uphill or resisted variations increase hip extensor demand.

reasoning: Treadmill walking is a cyclical locomotor pattern driven primarily by repeated sagittal-plane hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension to produce forward progression. Each step includes a stance phase (single-leg support) and a swing phase; propulsion is produced by plantarflexion and hip extension while hip flexion and dorsiflexion advance the limb. Balance during single-leg stance requires frontal-plane stabilization from the hip abductors and core, and there is low-amplitude transverse rotation of the pelvis/trunk that contributes to gait mechanics.
notes: Unloaded treadmill walking is a canonical LOCOMOTION pattern. Variations: incline increases hip extensor demand, faster speed increases concentric power and impact; carrying load converts to CARRY and may add ANTI_ROTATION if asymmetric; arm swing is secondary and not primary for classification.

reasoning: This exercise is a walking-based cooldown focused on forward progression. Primary joint actions are alternating hip flexion and extension, knee flexion and extension, and ankle dorsiflexion/plantarflexion in the sagittal plane to create step-to-step movement. There is commonly low-amplitude transverse rotation of the spine and reciprocal shoulder flexion/extension with arm swing as secondary motions. Propulsion is produced by concentric action of hip extensors and plantarflexors and eccentric control by dorsiflexors and knee extensors; the trunk and pelvic stabilizers (core, glutes) control posture and limb alignment during single-leg support.
notes: Listed as a bodyweight cooldown walk. If the drill emphasizes trunk rotation or added rotational mobility cues, add ROTATION as a secondary pattern. If performed while holding a load, add CARRY and potentially ANTI_ROTATION for asymmetric loads.

reasoning: Wall Angels are primarily a scapulothoracic and glenohumeral mobility/control drill. The primary joint action at the shoulder is humeral elevation (flexion/abduction) in the sagittal/frontal planes as the arms slide overhead (kinematically similar to an unloaded vertical push). Concurrently the scapulae undergo upward rotation and retraction (scapular posterior tilt/retraction) — actions that are mechanically analogous to a low-load pull of the scapula. The thoracic spine extends to allow the arms to pass overhead while maintaining contact with the wall. Stabilization requires isometric control of the scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, lower/middle trapezius, rhomboids) and tonic thoracic/spinal extensors to maintain wall contact and prevent compensatory lumbar extension or scapular winging.
notes: Mobility/control exercise with minimal external load. Variations include sliding with forearms vs. full-hand contact, adding band resistance, or performing seated. Common faults: loss of wall contact (lumbar overextension), scapular winging, and excessive cervical extension. Classifying as PUSH+PULL reflects the overhead arm elevation (push-like kinematics) plus active scapular retraction/upward rotation (pull-like scapular control).

reasoning: Primary joint demands match a squat pattern: fixed closed-chain hips and knees held in approximately 90° of flexion against gravity (isometric). The quadriceps generate the primary knee-extension torque to resist collapse, gluteus maximus provides hip-extension torque isometrically, and hamstrings co-contract for joint integrity.
