Ankles are held in slight dorsiflexion with plantarflexors stabilizing the foot. The trunk/spine must be isometrically stabilized to maintain an upright torso against the wall. There is no translational locomotion, hinge, push, pull, or rotational component, so SQUAT is the dominant movement pattern.
notes: Isometric variation of the squat pattern. Emphasizes quadriceps endurance and knee joint compressive load; caution for individuals with anterior knee pain. Variations: single-leg wall sit (increases unilateral demand/anti-rotation), weighted wall sit (adds load but remains SQUAT pattern), shallower/deeper angles change muscle emphasis.

reasoning: Primary motion is overhead shoulder elevation (glenohumeral flexion/abduction in the sagittal/scapular plane) combined with scapulothoracic upward rotation and posterior tilt; elbows remain near extension. This mimics the kinematic pattern of a vertical push (overhead reach/press) but performed as a mobility/activation exercise without external load. Primary movers producing the upward/overhead motion are the anterior/middle deltoid and rotator cuff for glenohumeral control, with serratus anterior and upper/lower trapezius driving scapular upward rotation; thoracic extensors and core act to extend and stabilize the spine and maintain upright posture. Scapular and rotator-cuff stabilization requirements are high to maintain glenohumeral centering and smooth scapulothoracic rhythm.

joint_actions.action: flexion/abduction with scapular upward rotation and posterior tilt (scapulothoracic contribution)

notes: Primarily a mobility/activation drill replicating unloaded vertical push mechanics; emphasizes scapular upward rotation and rotator-cuff control. Variations include band-assisted wall slides, thumbs-up/thumbs-down (affects external rotation demand), and wall slides with anterior pelvic tilt or seated position for reduced thoracic demand.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane trunk and hip extension against gravity with the torso moving from flexion into extension while the pelvis/hips act as the axis. The weighted ball increases the moment about the hips and lumbar spine, loading the posterior chain. The erector spinae produce spinal extension; gluteus maximus and hamstrings contribute to hip extension. Shoulders/arms hold the load isometrically (stabilization). The pelvic pad/hips often act as a stabilizing pivot, and the core and hip extensors eccentrically control descent and concentrically extend the trunk/hips.

joint_actions.action: isometric hold (flexion/adduction depending on ball position)

notes: If performed with emphasis on lumbar spinal movement (minimal hip motion) the exercise is more trunk-dominant; if performed with larger hip travel it behaves more like a hip-hinge. Asymmetric or overhead loading would introduce anti-rotation/lateral stabilization demands. Caution with lumbar pathology due to compressive/shear forces during loaded trunk extension.

reasoning: Wall slides are an unweighted overhead reaching / upward-moving shoulder pattern. The primary joint action is shoulder elevation (flexion/abduction in the scapular plane) combined with scapulothoracic upward rotation; the elbows may extend as the arms reach overhead. These actions mimic a vertical push/reach pattern (similar kinematically to an unloaded overhead press) with emphasis on scapular mobility and control rather than producing external force. Stabilization requirements include rotator cuff activation to centralize the humeral head, serratus anterior and trapezius coordination to produce smooth upward rotation, and thoracic-extension/postural control to allow full overhead range.
primary_muscles: rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
notes: Considered an unloaded vertical PUSH/reach mobility drill. Common variations: banded wall slides, wall slides with broomstick, or wall slides in internal/external rotation. Watch for compensations: excessive cervical elevation, scapular hiking, or lumbar overextension. Useful as scapular motor control and thoracic mobility exercise; may be modified or avoided in acute painful shoulder conditions.

reasoning: Primary motion is lateral flexion of the lumbar/thoracic spine in the frontal plane (side bend) while holding an asymmetric external load. Although not a transverse-plane rotation, this is a core/torso movement commonly grouped with trunk rotational/oblique patterns. The movement is produced concentrically/ eccentrically by the ipsilateral obliques and quadratus lumborum with contralateral obliques and deep stabilizers controlling descent and decelerating return. The shoulder and elbow hold the weight isometrically and scapular stabilizers resist displacement; hips and knees remain statically loaded. There is also an anti-rotational/stabilizing demand to prevent unwanted axial rotation, especially under heavier or offset loads.
notes: Commonly performed standing with a single dumbbell/medicine ball at the side or overhead. If performed with marching/step, add CARRY; if the exercise emphasizes resisting rotation rather than producing side flexion (static hold), include ANTI_ROTATION. Avoid excessive loading to reduce compressive shear on the lumbar spine; maintain trunk neutral rotation and controlled ROM.

reasoning: The weighted dead hang is an isometric vertical-load hold with the hands gripping an overhead bar. Primary joint positions are the shoulder in overhead flexion (holding position) and the elbow in full/near-full extension; there is no concentric movement but the muscles of the pulling chain and grip act isometrically to resist gravity. The forearm/finger flexors maintain grip, the latissimus dorsi and scapular stabilizers (lower trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint in the overhead position. The core and spinal extensors maintain neutral spine under traction. Because the exercise is a static hang rather than a concentric pull, it is best classified under the PULL pattern (vertical upper-body loading of the pulling chain).
primary_muscles: forearm/finger flexors (flexor digitorum profundus/superficialis, flexor pollicis longus)
rotator cuff (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis)
scapular stabilizers (lower trapezius, serratus anterior, rhomboids)
notes: Variants include passive 'dead' hang (relaxed scapula) versus active/depressed-scapula hang (scapular depression/packing). Weighted hangs increase traction and grip demand; ensure proper shoulder health and progressive loading to reduce impingement risk. If the athlete actively pulls to create scapular retraction/elevation, consider adding a PULL + HINGE? No hinge here.

reasoning: The exercise is an isometric vertical pulling hold. Primary joint actions occur at the shoulder complex (scapulothoracic depression and retraction to actively engage the shoulder girdle) while the glenohumeral joint is held in overhead flexion; the elbows are extended and held isometrically; the forearm/wrist/fingers produce sustained grip force. The action is not a concentric pulling repetition but it is a vertical pull pattern because the shoulder/scapular musculature is actively creating downward force/torque and resisting upward traction. Core and spinal erectors act isometrically to maintain neutral spine; rotator cuff muscles stabilize the humeral head. Grip musculature (finger flexors, forearm) are primary for load transfer. Stabilization requirements include scapular control, glenohumeral stability, and core/postural control to prevent excessive lumbar extension or scapular elevation.
notes: Active dead hang is best classified as a vertical PULL isometric exercise. Useful for scapular depression/retraction training and grip strength. Caution with shoulder impingement or acute pathology; emphasize scapular control and avoid excessive anterior shoulder migration. Weighted variation increases axial traction and grip demand.

reasoning: Primary movement is sagittal-plane trunk (spinal) flexion — the rib cage moves toward the pelvis via concentric shortening of the anterior trunk musculature. Because the available movement-pattern set does not include a dedicated 'trunk flexion/core flexion' category, the exercise is mapped to HINGE (interpreted here as sagittal flexion of the trunk/spine). Primary joint action is spinal flexion; the hips remain relatively fixed (pelvis may posteriorly tilt slightly) and act more as a stabilizing pivot. Stabilization demands include isometric control of the pelvis/hip complex to prevent excessive hip flexion, and neck musculature if the head/weight is supported.

joint_actions.action: isometric/stabilization (minimal movement, slight posterior pelvic tilt)

notes: If the exercise is performed with added transverse-plane rotation (twisting crunches), include ROTATION; if the load is held asymmetrically or causes torque, consider ANTI_ROTATION. If the weight is pressed overhead during the movement (uncommon), secondary shoulder stabilization occurs. Mapping to HINGE is an accommodation because the provided pattern list lacks a dedicated 'spinal/trunk flexion' pattern.

reasoning: Primary requirement is an isometric vertical pull: the shoulders are held in humeral elevation with active scapular depression and retraction while the elbows remain extended and the hands maintain a forceful grip on the bar. The exercise does not produce concentric elbow flexion but loads the vertical pulling system (scapulothoracic and latissimus-dorsi complex) and the forearm flexors for grip. Stabilization demands include rotator cuff control of the glenohumeral joint and core/shoulder girdle isometric control to prevent excessive spinal extension or scapular winging.

joint_actions.action: humeral elevation held (isometric; no concentric flexion/extension)
finger flexion for grip (isometric); wrist neutral/stabilized
neutral trunk posture with isometric stabilization

notes: This is an isometric/loaded vertical pull variation emphasizing scapular depression and grip. Variations (passive hang vs active hang) change scapular muscle emphasis. Watch for shoulder impingement in forced depressed hangs; progressive loading increases demand on grip and scapular stabilizers.

reasoning: This is an isometric vertical pull position (dead-hang). The primary joint positions are the shoulder held in overhead flexion (arms overhead) and the elbow held in near-extension; the action is primarily isometric rather than dynamic. Forearm/finger flexors maintain grip on the bar while scapular depressors (lower trapezius, latissimus) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint and scapula to support the load. The core and spinal extensors act isometrically to limit trunk swing and maintain a neutral spine. Hips and knees are passive. With a weighted vest the demand on grip and scapular/shoulder stabilizers increases, but the movement pattern remains a vertical pull (isometric).

joint_actions.action: isometric neutral stabilization (resists trunk swing and excessive flexion/extension)

notes: Tabata format emphasizes grip and muscular endurance. Weighted vest increases axial load and grip/scapular demand. Watch for shoulder impingement history; ensure active scapular depression and controlled scapular positioning. If the hang includes active scapular retraction/depressing motion (scapular pull-ups) classification remains PULL but may include a brief dynamic scapular depression component.

reasoning: The exercise is an isometric overhead hang under axial load — the body is passively/actively suspended from the hands. Primary joint demand is at the shoulder (arms overhead in flexion/vertical loading) with the elbows maintained in extension and heavy demand on finger/forearm flexors for grip. The movement pattern aligns with a vertical PULL (the hanging position is the end-range of a vertical pulling action and primarily trains pull-related tissues isometrically). Stabilization requires scapular control (depression and slight retraction), rotator cuff activity to maintain glenohumeral integrity, and core/hip stiffness to prevent excessive swinging.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (resist flexion/rotation and control swing)

notes: Weighted vest increases vertical traction and grip demand. If performed with active scapular depression (active hang) there is additional concentric/eccentric scapular control; if passive, greater passive stretch to shoulder structures. Avoid excessive swinging — dynamic swinging introduces additional transverse-plane demands not typical of a pure dead-hang.

reasoning: The weighted dead-hang is primarily an isometric vertical pull: the hands maintain traction on an overhead bar while the shoulder complex and scapular musculature bear the load. Primary joint actions are isometric shoulder elevation/overhead positioning with active scapular depression/stability and isometric elbow extension while the spine is under axial traction. Muscles producing the load-bearing action include the latissimus dorsi, teres major, and scapular stabilizers (lower/middle trapezius, rhomboids, serratus anterior) working to maintain scapular position, while forearm and finger flexors produce grip force. The rotator cuff contributes to glenohumeral stability. Core and thoracic extensors isometrically stabilize the spine against stretch/traction. There is minimal concentric/eccentric movement — primary demand is isometric pulling and grip endurance.

joint_actions.action: isometric elevation/overhead support with scapular depression/stability

notes: Variation: adding external load increases vertical pull/grip demand. Differentiate passive hang (relaxed scapula) from active hang (scapular engagement); active hang increases scapular stabilizer activation. Avoid with acute shoulder impingement or instability; progress to active scapular pulls or weighted pull-ups as strength permits.

reasoning: Weighted plank is primarily an isometric core stabilization exercise resisting spinal flexion (anti-extension) and resisting rotational perturbation. The spine is held in a neutral position isometrically in the sagittal plane while the hips and knees maintain a rigid, extended position. The shoulders and elbows/forearms provide isometric support and scapular stabilization to transfer load from the trunk to the ground. Because the movement is an isometric core brace that also resists rotation and transverse-plane moments (especially if the load is off-center), it best fits the ANTI_ROTATION/core-stability category within the provided pattern set.
notes: Plank is fundamentally an anti-extension/core stability exercise; the provided movement list lacks an explicit ANTI-EXTENSION category so ANTI_ROTATION is used to represent isometric core stabilization against transverse-plane and rotational moments. If weight is placed asymmetrically, include stronger anti-rotation emphasis. Monitor spinal neutrality and shoulder/neck loading when adding external load; hand-plank vs elbow-plank changes shoulder/elbow demand.

reasoning: This is a unilateral, sagittal-plane lunge. Primary joint actions are hip and knee flexion during descent and hip and knee extension during ascent, with ankle dorsiflexion on the front limb in the lowering phase and plantarflexion during push-off. The concentric phase is driven mainly by hip extension and knee extension (gluteus maximus and quadriceps), with hamstrings and calves assisting. The trunk and shoulder girdle perform isometric stabilization to maintain a neutral spine and to stabilize the bag; frontal-plane hip stabilizers (gluteus medius) control pelvic drop. If the bag is held asymmetrically, additional anti-rotation core demand is present.
primary_muscles: trapezius/upper back (if bag rests on shoulders)
notes: Placement of the Bulgarian Bag (across upper back, front rack, or asymmetric hold) alters upper-body stabilization and can add anti-rotation demands. Variations include walking lunge, reverse lunge, and Bulgarian split squat (rear foot elevated).

reasoning: Primary action is an isometric vertical pull on a single upper limb: the shoulder and elbow are held in an overhead, extended position against gravity requiring the latissimus, biceps/forearm flexors and scapular stabilizers to produce/maintain tension (PULL). Because loading is unilateral, there is a strong demand for the trunk and contralateral shoulder girdle to resist rotation and lateral collapse, so ANTI_ROTATION is a primary stabilization pattern. The shoulder and elbow produce the load-bearing isometric actions while the core/contralateral side provides anti-rotational/isometric stabilization.
notes: Grip strength and scapular depression capacity often limit performance. Progressions include two-arm hang → one-arm assisted hang → weighted one-arm hang. Pay attention to shoulder health (rotator cuff/scapular control) and avoid excessive swinging; bracing of the trunk increases anti-rotation demand.

reasoning: The weighted pull-up is a vertical pulling movement. Primary joint actions are shoulder extension (bringing the humerus down from overhead toward the torso) and elbow flexion to raise the body toward the bar, performed primarily in the sagittal plane with a substantial scapulothoracic component (scapular retraction/depression). The latissimus dorsi and teres major drive shoulder extension/adduction, the biceps brachii, brachialis and brachioradialis produce elbow flexion, and the rhomboids/middle-lower trapezius assist scapular retraction. The spine and core act isometrically to prevent excessive torso swing and maintain a stable torso; hips/legs are typically neutral but can contribute if kipping is used. Because the exercise is a vertical pull with primarily concentric/ eccentric pulling actions at the shoulder and elbow, it is classified as PULL.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (resists sagittal flexion/extension and limits transverse rotation/swing)
neutral / isometric stabilization (can contribute if kipping)

notes: Variations affect emphasis: supinated (chin-up) increases biceps involvement; wide grip shifts shoulder mechanics but remains a vertical pull. Kipping or leg drive introduces hip/joint motion and reduces pure pull emphasis. Strict weighted pull-ups are a textbook vertical PULL pattern.

reasoning: A weighted pull-up is primarily a vertical pulling movement. The primary joint actions are shoulder extension/adduction (bringing the humerus down from an overhead position) and elbow flexion (controlled eccentric elbow extension during the descending phase). The scapulothoracic joints perform retraction and depression to stabilize and position the shoulder girdle. The trunk/spine acts isometrically to prevent excessive swing and maintain body alignment during the descent. Primary movers (lats, teres major, biceps) produce the movement while scapular retractors and core musculature stabilize.

joint_actions.action: extension and adduction (bringing humerus down from overhead toward torso)
flexion (concentric) — controlled eccentric extension during descending phase
isometric stabilization to prevent excessive sagittal plane flexion/extension and minimize swing

notes: Descending (eccentric) emphasis increases demand on latissimus and eccentric control of elbow extensors. Weighted variation increases axial load through the shoulder/upper limb and grip. Grip width and hand orientation affect relative contributions of lats vs. biceps; kipping or leg drive would introduce additional hip/torso movement (not included here). Ensure scapular control (retraction/depression) to protect shoulder complex.

reasoning: The weighted pull-up is a vertical pulling movement. Primary joint actions are shoulder extension/adduction (bringing the humerus from overhead toward the torso) and elbow flexion to raise the body toward the bar. Scapular retraction and depression accompany the motion to orient the glenoid and increase thoracic extension. The spine, hips and core act isometrically to prevent excessive swing and maintain a stable torso. Grip/forearm muscles provide isometric stabilization of the wrist and hand on the bar.

joint_actions.plane: sagittal (vertical pull) / frontal component for adduction

notes: Strict weighted pull-up is a textbook vertical pull. Variation in grip (pronated, supinated, neutral) shifts emphasis among biceps/forearms and lats. Kipping or leg drive introduces dynamic hip/torso contributions and reduces pure vertical pull demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pulling action: shoulder (glenohumeral) moves from flexion/overhead toward extension/adduction while the elbow flexes to bring the body toward the bar. Scapulothoracic retraction and depression occur to initiate and complete the pull. The spine remains isometrically stabilized to prevent excessive trunk extension or swinging. The weight vest increases axial load and intensifies the demand on the prime pulling muscles and grip. Primary joint actions are shoulder extension/adduction (sagittal/frontal) and elbow flexion (sagittal), with scapular retraction/depression and core isometric stabilization as key stabilizing actions.
notes: Strict weighted pull-up is a textbook vertical pull. Variations: kipping or butterfly pull-ups add hip drive/pendulum (introducing LOCOMOTION/plyometric elements); neutral/chin grips alter biceps vs lat emphasis. Weight vest increases axial load and grip demand; asymmetric loading would introduce ANTI_ROTATION.

reasoning: Primary movement is an upper-body vertical/horizontal pull: concentric shoulder extension/adduction with simultaneous elbow flexion to elevate the torso toward the bar. The scapulothoracic joint performs retraction and slight depression to position the shoulder girdle. The spine and core act isometrically to maintain torso alignment; hips/knees are typically held static. Weighted loading increases demand on prime movers (lats, biceps) and scapular stabilizers during both concentric and eccentric phases.
notes: Variation in grip (pronated, supinated, neutral) shifts emphasis between biceps and lats. Kipping or butterfly pull-ups add hip drive and dynamic trunk motion (introducing more sagittal/hip contribution), but strict weighted pull-ups remain a PULL-dominant vertical pulling pattern. Asymmetric loading would add ANTI_ROTATION demands.

reasoning: Weighted pull-ups are primarily a vertical pulling pattern. The primary joint actions are elbow flexion (sagittal) and shoulder extension/adduction as the body is pulled toward the bar, with concomitant scapular retraction and slight depression (transverse/frontal). Scapular retractors (rhomboids, middle/lower traps) and rotator cuff act to position the shoulder girdle. The spine acts isometrically to maintain a neutral torso and resist excessive hip drive or swing. Grip/forearm muscles provide force transmission and fatigue can limit performance. The weighted variation increases axial load but does not change the fundamental pull movement pattern.

joint_actions.action: extension and adduction (humeral extension toward torso)
isometric stabilization (maintain neutral or slight extension)

notes: Weighted variation increases external load but remains a vertical pull. Grip width and supinated (chin-up) vs pronated (pull-up) grip alter emphasis toward biceps or lats. Kipping/strict technique changes momentum and stabilization demands — strict weighted pull-ups are textbook PULL. Poor scapular control or excessive leg drive introduces other pattern elements (anti-rotation or hip drive) but are technique deviations.

reasoning: Weighted pull-ups are a vertical pulling exercise. The primary joint actions are shoulder extension (bringing the humerus from an elevated/overhead position down toward the torso) and elbow flexion (closing the angle at the elbow) occurring primarily in the sagittal plane. The scapulothoracic joints perform retraction and depression to position the shoulder girdle, and the spine and core act isometrically to stabilize the torso. Prime movers (latissimus dorsi, teres major) produce shoulder extension/adduction while elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis) produce elbow flexion. Scapular retractors/depressors (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids) and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint; the core and lower back resist excessive hip/back motion, and the forearm musculature maintains grip on the bar.
notes: Weighted variation simply increases load on the vertical pull pattern. Grip width and hand position (pronated vs supinated/neutral) change emphasis between lats and biceps. Kipping or momentum-based pull-ups introduce dynamic/hip drive elements and reduce strict vertical-pull specificity. Requires substantial grip strength and scapular control; partial ROM or assisted variations alter muscle recruitment patterns.

reasoning: Primary movement is a vertical pulling action: shoulder extension/adduction with simultaneous elbow flexion. The latissimus dorsi, teres major and posterior deltoid drive humeral extension/adduction while the biceps brachii and brachialis provide elbow flexion. Scapular depression and retraction (lower/mid traps, rhomboids) initiate and stabilize the shoulder girdle. The spine and core act isometrically to prevent excessive torso swing (anti-extension/anti-rotation) and the hips/knees typically hold a fixed position to maintain body alignment. Plane: primarily sagittal for elbow flexion and shoulder extension, frontal component for shoulder adduction, and transverse component for scapular retraction.

joint_actions.action: isometric stabilization (often slight flexion to hold legs)

notes: Variations: chin-up (supinated grip) increases biceps contribution; kipping or butterfly pull-ups add hip drive/plyometric components (introducing HINGE/LOCOMOTION elements). Weighted variations increase core demand to prevent swinging but do not change primary pattern. Grip width alters degree of shoulder adduction vs. extension emphasis.

reasoning: Primary movement is a horizontal push: the elbows extend to press the body away from the floor while the humerus moves into horizontal adduction (transverse plane). Pectoralis major, anterior deltoid and triceps produce the concentric push. The scapulothoracic region actively protracts/retracts for shoulder girdle control (serratus anterior, mid/lower trapezius), and the trunk/hips must isometrically resist spinal extension (anti-extension) to maintain a rigid plank line under load. Added weight increases axial/compressive load and the demand on prime movers and stabilizers but does not change the primary horizontal push pattern.

joint_actions.action: extension (concentric on press, eccentric on descent)

notes: Weighted variation is a loaded horizontal push. Ensure load is centered (weighted vest preferred to plates on upper back) to avoid excessive shear or cervical strain. Scapular control and core rigidity become more important as external load increases.

reasoning: Primary dynamic action is transverse-plane trunk rotation as the top arm reaches under the torso (reach-through). The side plank base requires isometric anti-lateral-flexion/anti-rotation of the spine and isometric hip abduction to keep hips elevated. Shoulders perform transverse-plane movement of the reaching arm (horizontal adduction/rotation) while the supporting shoulder/scapula and elbow act isometrically to transmit load. Thus the movement combines active rotation of the trunk/shoulder with strong anti-rotation/isometric stabilization demands of the core and hip.
notes: Weighted variant increases rotational torque and anti-rotation demand. Performed on elbow vs hand changes shoulder/elbow joint action emphasis. Hip drop indicates insufficient hip abductor/core endurance and shifts load to obliques and QL.

reasoning: A weighted dead-hang is an isometric vertical pull: the hands/arms support a loaded body while the shoulder girdle and elbows hold the position. Primary joint actions are isometric shoulder (glenohumeral) position in overhead flexion/extension tension and elbow extension while the scapulothoracic joint actively depresses and retracts to maintain a stable hang. The latissimus dorsi/teres major produce the primary pulling/tension at the shoulder, scapular stabilizers (lower trapezius, rhomboids) maintain scapular depression/retraction, and forearm/finger flexors maintain grip. The spine and rotator cuff act isometrically to stabilize posture and glenohumeral joint under load.

joint_actions.action: isometric overhead tension (positioned in flexion/vertical overhead hold)

notes: Weighted dead-hang is an isometric vertical PULL. Variations (single-arm hangs, asymmetric loading) introduce significant anti-rotation and lateral stabilization demands and would add ANTI_ROTATION/CARRY as patterns. Common coaching cues: engage scapular depressors (active hang) to protect the shoulder and avoid passive impingement; progress load carefully due to grip limitation and shoulder stress.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip hinge: the torso pivots at the hips with minimal knee bend (stiff legs) through the sagittal plane. The lowering phase involves hip flexion with near-isometric/slight knee flexion; the return is hip extension. The wide stance shifts some demand to the adductors and places the hips in a more externally rotated position, increasing adductor and gluteal contribution and requiring lateral hip stabilization. The trunk/erector spinae act isometrically to maintain a neutral spine and resist excessive spinal flexion; core muscles stabilize against sagittal and rotational perturbations. No primary vertical/horizontal push or carry component is present unless external load/grip changes the pattern.

joint_actions.action: flexion (lowering) / extension (rising) with isometric stabilization to maintain neutral posture
external rotation / increased adductor engagement (postural/position effect)

notes: If performed with a barbell or heavy load and significant upper-extremity pulling/gripping, PULL could be a secondary pattern; if knees are driven deeper the movement shifts toward SQUAT. Wide stance increases adductor and external rotator contribution compared with narrow stiff-leg variants.

reasoning: Primary joint action is trunk (spine) flexion in the sagittal plane with secondary hip flexion when the pelvis rotates anteriorly — the torso is being brought toward the thighs. The movement is produced primarily by concentric spinal flexors (rectus abdominis) with substantial contribution from hip flexors (iliopsoas, rectus femoris) depending on technique. Bands provide variable resistance in the sagittal plane but do not introduce a primary rotational or carry pattern. Stabilization demands include isometric control from the obliques for lateral stability, erector spinae eccentrically on descent, and hip extensors/glutes act to stabilize the pelvis if the movement emphasizes lumbar flexion versus pure hip flexion.
notes: Band attachment and placement affect emphasis: anchored behind the torso or chest keeps resistance in the sagittal plane; anchor offset or single‑side banding can introduce anti-rotation demands. If the exercise is performed with strong hip drive (full sit-up), hip flexors contribute more; if performed as a curl-up, spinal flexors dominate.

reasoning: Primary action is a vertical pulling movement: the humerus moves from an elevated/abducted position down and slightly posterior (shoulder adduction and extension) while the elbow flexes to bring the bar behind the head. Scapular depression and retraction accompany the descent to position the shoulder girdle. Primary movers generate shoulder extension/adduction (lats, teres major, posterior deltoid) and elbow flexion (biceps); scapular stabilizers (middle/lower trapezius, rhomboids) control scapular motion and rotator cuff muscles stabilize the glenohumeral joint. The trunk and thoracic spine act isometrically to stabilize posture. Because the dominant mechanical action is pulling the load down toward the torso/neck, this is classified as a PULL pattern.

joint_actions.action: adduction and extension (humeral depression toward torso/posterior)
joint_actions.plane: frontal and sagittal (with scapular plane components)

notes: Behind-the-neck pulldowns place the shoulder in a vulnerable position (requires thoracic extension and shoulder external rotation); higher impingement and cervical stress risk compared with front pulldowns. Movement remains a vertical pull; front/lat pulldown is a safer variation targeting the same PULL pattern.

reasoning: Primary movement is glenohumeral movement where the arms travel in an arc from over the chest toward/behind the head — functionally shoulder extension (and an element of horizontal abduction depending on arm path) in the sagittal/transverse planes. This is a pulling action of the upper limb dominated by latissimus dorsi/teres major/pectoralis major producing shoulder extension/adduction. The elbows remain relatively fixed (isometric or mild flexion), and the scapulothoracic region must stabilize/allow controlled scapular upward/downward rotation and posterior tilt. Core and thoracic musculature provide isometric stabilization on the decline bench. Therefore the primary pattern is PULL (shoulder extension-based pull), with scapular stabilizers acting isometrically.

joint_actions.action: extension (primary) with element of horizontal abduction
stabilization with controlled upward/downward rotation and posterior tilt

notes: Wide grip and decline bench angle can shift emphasis between lats and pecs; greater range of motion behind the head increases shoulder extension demand. Elbow flexion/extension should be minimized to keep emphasis on shoulder movement. Ensure thoracic mobility and scapular control to avoid excessive strain on the glenohumeral joint.

reasoning: Primary action is an upper-body vertical pulling movement: the humerus moves from overhead toward the torso (shoulder extension/adduction) while the elbow flexes to bring the body up to the bar. Scapular depression and retraction accompany/precede humeral motion to orient the glenoid. Prime movers (latissimus dorsi, teres major, posterior deltoid) produce shoulder extension/adduction; elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis) produce elbow flexion; scapular retractors (rhomboids, middle/lower trapezius) stabilize and control scapular motion. The core and spinal extensors act isometrically to maintain torso alignment; rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers control joint centration. Hips and knees are generally static in a hanging position and serve only as passive attachments.
notes: Behind-the-neck / rear pull-up variations and very wide grips increase shoulder impingement and glenohumeral stress; consider front-facing (chin-over-bar) pull-ups or narrower grips for individuals with limited shoulder mobility. Scapular control and rotator cuff health are important for safe execution.

reasoning: Primary joint action is elbow flexion in the sagittal plane producing upward forearm movement toward the humerus. The exercise is an upper-body pulling pattern because the elbow joint is the prime mover rather than hip/knee/ankle or a pushing action. Primary muscles producing the movement are the biceps brachii, brachialis and brachioradialis. The shoulders and scapulae act primarily as stabilizers (isometric) to maintain elbow and torso position; the spine and hips provide anti-extension/isometric core stabilization during standing. Wrists/forearms stabilize the barbell grip during the curl.
notes: Wide grip changes forearm and biceps line of pull and can alter short vs long head emphasis and ROM. Standing execution requires core bracing to prevent torso swinging; strict form keeps the pattern a pure elbow-dominant pull. Momentum or excessive shoulder movement shifts pattern toward compound upper-body involvement.

reasoning: Wind sprints are high-velocity, repeated single-leg propulsion and swing cycles (running). Primary joint actions occur in the sagittal plane: hip extension during push-off and hip flexion during swing, knee extension for support/push-off and knee flexion during swing, and ankle plantarflexion for toe-off with dorsiflexion during swing. Upper-extremity shoulder flexion/extension provides counterbalance but is secondary. Core and spinal musculature act isometrically to stabilize the trunk and transfer force between lower and upper body. The dominant mechanical goal is locomotion (accelerating/maintaining high forward velocity) rather than isolated pushing, pulling, hinging or carrying.
notes: Predominantly sagittal-plane locomotion; acceleration phase emphasizes greater hip extension torque, max-velocity includes shorter ground contact and higher elastic contribution from calves. Surface, stride mechanics, and starting position can alter relative joint contributions.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip hinge (sagittal plane) as the torso folds at the hips toward the planted foot while maintaining a long spine. Simultaneously the trunk undergoes controlled lateral flexion and transverse rotation as the torso reaches down and the torso rotates/slides around the hip (dynamic rotation/mobility). The shoulder of the raised arm is held overhead and acts isometrically to stabilize the load/arm, imposing anti-rotational demand on the shoulder girdle and core. Stabilization requirements include scapular and rotator cuff stability at the overhead shoulder, unilateral hip/ankle stability for balance, and eccentric/isometric control of the obliques, quadratus lumborum and erector spinae to control lateral flexion and rotation.
notes: If performed with an external load overhead (kettlebell/dumbbell) the anti-rotation/isometric core demand and shoulder stability increase; as a mobility/stretch variation (bodyweight) the exercise emphasizes spinal lateral flexion and hip hinge mobility more than heavy loading. Balance and unilateral hip abductor strength are often limiting factors.

reasoning: The movement is a chopping/diagonal swing pattern driven primarily by trunk rotation in the transverse plane. The spine (thoracic rotation) creates the primary directional torque while the shoulders and arms transfer the force to the implement (or imaginary axe). Hips and lower limbs produce and transfer force through transverse rotation and provide sagittal-plane stability/weight shift. Stabilization demands include resisting unwanted spinal flexion/lateral flexion and maintaining lower-limb stance stability (hip abductor control) during the rotational transfer of force.

joint_actions.action: rotation and slight flexion/extension for weight shift and power transfer

notes: Variation: high-to-low or low-to-high chops, single-leg or stepping versions. With external load (sledgehammer, med ball) movement remains ROTATION-dominant; asymmetric loading may add ANTI_ROTATION elements for stabilizers. For strict isometric anti-rotation training, this would be a different drill.

reasoning: A wood-splitting/chopping movement is driven primarily by trunk rotation in the transverse plane (diagonal/rotary chop) combined with force generation from the hips via a hip hinge pattern. The primary joint action is spinal rotation (transverse) producing the chopping torque, and the hip extensors produce power through a hinged hip extension (sagittal) often accompanied by knee extension for drive and transfer of force. The shoulders and scapula move the implement in a diagonal plane (shoulder horizontal adduction/extension) and require rotator-cuff/scapular stabilization. The core (obliques, transverse abdominis) and contralateral hip/glute medius act to stabilize the torso and pelvis during the rotational drive.
notes: Variations include single-arm or overhead-to-hip chops, which increase rotational demand and anti-rotation stabilization on the opposite side. Performing on a split-stance or adding a step introduces more unilateral hip/knee drive and balance demands.

reasoning: The movement is dominated by transverse-plane rotation of the pelvis and lumbar spine as the legs sweep side-to-side. Primary joint actions are axial rotation of the spine and rotation/hip adduction-abduction at the hips as the legs move laterally. The obliques create/guide the rotation concentrically on one side and eccentrically on the other while deep core stabilizers (transverse abdominis, multifidus) and rectus abdominis control motion and maintain spinal position. Shoulders and scapulae remain in contact with the ground and act isometrically to stabilize the upper torso against rotation.
notes: Variations: performed with knees bent (shorter lever, easier) or legs extended (longer lever, more load on obliques). Primarily a mobility/core-rotation exercise rather than a loaded strength pattern. Keep shoulders pinned to the floor to isolate trunk rotation; avoid if acute low-back pain unless prescribed by a clinician.

reasoning: The movement is a dynamic chopping motion that primarily produces axial (thoracic/pelvic) rotation in the transverse plane. The arms/shoulders move on a diagonal/transverse path (shoulder horizontal adduction/extension) to simulate an axe swing, and the hips shift/rotate to allow weight transfer. Primary joint action is spinal rotation driven by the obliques and assisted by lats/glutes; shoulders transfer force to the implement or hands. Stabilization demands include isometric control of the lumbar spine and scapular stabilizers to decelerate and control the swing.

joint_actions.action: horizontal adduction / transverse extension (diagonal chop path)
weight shift with slight rotation and transverse plane pivot
slight flexion/extension for shock absorption and weight transfer

notes: Common warm-up variation (high-to-low or low-to-high woodchop). Emphasize thoracic rotation rather than excessive lumbar rotation. If performed with a heavy or asymmetric load, consider adding ANTI_ROTATION to account for increased stabilizing demand.

reasoning: Primary action is repeated punching: shoulder horizontal adduction/forward reach with elbow extension (a horizontal push action) combined with transverse-plane trunk and pelvis rotation to generate force. Shoulders and elbows produce the push (pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, triceps) while the core and hips produce and transmit rotational force (external/internal obliques, rectus abdominis, contralateral/ipsilateral hip rotators, glutes). Stabilization demands include anti-rotation/isometric core control to resist unwanted spinal shear and scapular/stabilizer activity (serratus anterior, lower/ middle trapezius) to allow safe shoulder protraction and punch follow-through. If weight shifting/stepping is included, lower-limb stabilizers (glutes, adductors, quadriceps) contribute to force transfer.
notes: If performed with stepping/marching include LOCOMOTION; single-arm or offset-loaded variations increase anti-rotation demand. Emphasize scapular control and progressive range of motion in warm-up context. Avoid excessive uncontrolled trunk rotation to protect lumbar spine.

reasoning: Primary actions are a dynamic forward lunge (hip and knee sagittal motion) combined with thoracic spine rotation and shoulder reach (transverse plane). The lunge element is produced by hip flexion of the lead leg and hip extension of the trailing leg with knee flexion/extension; this loads and lengthens the hip flexors/glutes/quadriceps/hamstrings. The rotation element is produced by thoracic spinal rotation and shoulder flexion/rotation as the lead arm reaches upward, engaging thoracic extensors, obliques and scapular stabilizers. Core musculature (rectus abdominis, obliques, multifidus) and the contralateral hip/glute complex act isometrically to stabilize the pelvis and spine during the combined movement.
notes: Primarily a mobility/active-stretch pattern combining a lunge with thoracic rotation. Variations (kneeling, deeper rotation, reach-under vs reach-up) shift emphasis between hip mobility and thoracic rotation. Not typically an anti-rotation/isometric loading exercise unless held statically or loaded asymmetrically.

reasoning: Primary movement is axial rotation of the forearm/wrist — pronation and supination of the radioulnar joints (transverse plane). The distal forearm muscles (pronator teres, pronator quadratus, supinator, biceps brachii when elbow is flexed) generate the rotational torque. The wrist/hand muscles (wrist flexors and extensors, brachioradialis) act to position and stabilize the bar/grip and control radial/ulnar deviation. The elbow and shoulder remain largely isometric to maintain limb position; scapular and core musculature provide proximal stabilization to prevent unwanted shoulder or trunk motion. Because the primary joint action is rotation (forearm), the correct movement pattern classification is ROTATION.
notes: Ensure motion originates at the radioulnar joints (avoid compensatory shoulder or trunk rotation). Keep elbow angle consistent to target pronators/supinators; heavier resistance or long lever arms increase torque at the shoulder and could shift pattern toward combined shoulder stabilization demands. Avoid with acute wrist/forearm pathology.

reasoning: Wrist circles are primarily a joint-specific circumduction/rotational mobility movement at the radiocarpal and distal radioulnar joints. The primary joint action is wrist circumduction, which is a compound movement combining wrist flexion/extension (sagittal) with radial/ulnar deviation (frontal), producing a circular motion; the distal radioulnar joint contributes pronation/supination (transverse). Forearm pronator/supinator and wrist flexor/extensor muscles actively produce the motion while the elbow and shoulder and core act isometrically to stabilize the limb and torso against unwanted movement.

joint_actions.action: circumduction (combination of flexion/extension and radial/ulnar deviation)
isometric stabilization (typically slight flexion to hold position)

notes: Primarily a mobility/warm-up exercise for the wrist/forearm rather than a strength or locomotor pattern. Perform slowly in both directions, vary radius and speed. Avoid large ROM or pain with known wrist pathology; can be progressed with light load (e.g., small weight, band) for conditioning but remains joint-specific.

reasoning: Primary movement is forearm rotation (pronation/supination) and wrist flexion/extension while winding/unwinding the load — a transverse-plane rotational action at the radioulnar joint with sagittal-plane wrist motion. The exercise functions as a distal forearm/hand pulling action to raise the load, so it can be secondarily classified as a PULL pattern. Shoulder and elbow act primarily as isometric stabilizers (elbow often held slightly flexed) and the trunk/scapular muscles stabilize posture. Muscles producing the winding motion are the forearm pronators/supinators and wrist/finger flexors/extensors; shoulder and scapular stabilizers resist movement of the proximal limb.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension (concentric to wind, eccentric to lower)
isometric stabilization (often held in slight flexion)

notes: Primary emphasis is distal forearm/wrist rotation and grip; direction of winding determines whether pronators or supinators are emphasized. Can be performed single- or two-handed; load mass and cadence change emphasis on concentric vs eccentric control. Not a primary shoulder/elbow pull in the traditional sense, hence ROTATION is primary and PULL is secondary.

reasoning: Primary motion is shoulder elevation/abduction in the scapular plane (an oblique plane ~30° anterior to frontal) with concomitant scapulothoracic upward rotation and posterior tilt. The glenohumeral joint produces the arm lift (deltoids/supraspinatus) while scapular upward rotators and retractors (lower/middle trapezius, serratus anterior) control scapular motion — mechanically similar to a scapular-focused pull pattern. Elbow remains extended/isometric; thoracic/spinal extensors and core provide postural stabilization. Because the exercise emphasizes scapular control and upward rotation rather than a horizontal or vertical pressing action, it fits the PULL pattern (scapular pulling/upward-rotation emphasis).

joint_actions.plane: scapular plane (oblique between sagittal and frontal)

notes: Commonly performed prone or standing with a slight hinge; primary goal is scapular mobility and posterior shoulder activation. With load or resisted band the movement remains scapular-elevation dominant (still best classified as PULL).

reasoning: Primary movement is open‑chain shoulder elevation in the scapular plane (a combined shoulder flexion/abduction) producing an overhead/upward motion of the humerus — biomechanically analogous to a vertical shoulder push. The glenohumeral joint undergoes flexion/abduction in the scapular plane while the scapulothoracic articulation produces upward rotation. Elbow remains largely extended/isometric; the thoracic spine and scapular stabilizers act isometrically to maintain posture. Primary movers (lower/mid trapezius, posterior deltoid, supraspinatus/rotator cuff) drive the elevation while serratus anterior and scapular retractors/upward rotators stabilize the scapula.

joint_actions.action: upward rotation and posterior tilt (scapular motion)
isometric stabilization / slight extension when prone

notes: Typically performed prone or standing on an incline; primary emphasis is scapular upward rotation and lower trap activation. Variation with external load (dumbbells, bands) does not change primary pattern (vertical shoulder elevation). Avoid excessive shoulder internal rotation; perform in scapular plane to reduce impingement risk. If performed with heavy resisted horizontal pushing (rare), consider adding PUSH+ANTI_ROTATION for asymmetric loading.

reasoning: Yard cleanup commonly requires repeated hip-dominant bending to pick up debris (hip hinge) and frequent transport of loads (carrying/walking with loads). Tasks such as raking, throwing debris, or twisting to reach create active trunk rotation through the transverse plane; asymmetric carrying or stabilizing loads while walking also imposes rotational/anti-rotational demand. Primary joint actions are hip extension to stand from a bent position, knee/ankle actions for stooping and gait, shoulder/elbow actions for manipulating tools and loads, and trunk rotation/flexion for reach and toss. Stabilization demands include isometric core control (anti-rotation) to protect the spine and scapular/shoulder stability during tool use and load carriage.
notes: Highly variable activity—specific pattern emphasis changes by task (e.g., wheelbarrow work increases PUSH/PULL, repeated deep lifts may involve more SQUAT). Asymmetric loads or one-handed carrying introduce strong anti-rotation stabilization demands; frequent heavy lifts warrant coaching on hinge vs squat strategies to protect the lumbar spine.

reasoning: A yoga medley typically combines spinal mobility (twists and rotational transitions) and hip-dominant mobility/positioning such as lunging variations (warrior, crescent, pigeon) that involve hip and knee flexion/extension in the sagittal plane. Primary joint actions observed across common poses are transverse-plane spinal rotation and sagittal-plane hip/knee flexion-extension. Muscle action is primarily mobility and low-force control rather than high-load concentric work; the obliques and multifidus drive/permit rotation, while gluteals, hamstrings, quadriceps and iliopsoas control hip/knee positions. Stabilization requirements include isometric core control (anti-rotation/anti-flexion) and single-leg balance demand in many transitions.

joint_actions.action: flexion/extension (and scapular upward rotation in overhead poses)

notes: High variability—exact patterning depends on the specific sequence of poses. Many poses also include isometric anti-rotation/stabilization and single-leg balance demands; if the medley emphasizes standing balance or twists, ROTATION and single-leg LUNGE/STANCE variations become primary. This classification assumes a general mixed yoga flow with lunging and twisting elements.

reasoning: Primary action is loaded locomotion (carrying) with repeated hip/knee/ankle sagittal-plane flexion-extension producing forward progression. The load is held in the crook of the elbows (anterior, bilateral), creating an anterior flexion moment at the trunk that the lumbar and abdominal musculature resist isometrically. Shoulders/elbows maintain a flexed, isometric hold to support the load. Primary movers for movement are the lower-extremity extensors during stance; trunk and shoulder/elbow muscles act primarily as stabilizers to maintain posture and hold the load.

joint_actions.action: isometric extension / anti-flexion (resist trunk flexion from anterior load)
flexion / isometric stabilization (holding load close to torso)

notes: Zercher carry is a bilateral anterior-loaded carry — primary classification is CARRY. Although the trunk works isometrically to resist flexion, the load is symmetric so ANTI_ROTATION is not required unless an asymmetric variation is used. High anterior moment increases demand on spinal stabilizers and may bias more upright posture; hold position (low vs high in crook) and load magnitude alter torso demands.

reasoning: Primary movement is a hip hinge: the athlete pivots at the hips with a relatively fixed knee angle, producing hip flexion during the descent and hip extension during the return in the sagittal plane. The torso undergoes trunk flexion/extension with strong isometric trunk extension demand to resist forward collapse because the load is front-loaded in the Zercher position. Shoulders and elbows remain in flexion isometrically to cradle the sandbag. Stabilization requirements include high lumbar/erector spinae and anterior core (anti-flexion) activation and scapular/upper-arm isometric stability to hold the load. Because the dominant joint action is hip hinge and posterior chain contraction, this classifies primarily as HINGE.

joint_actions.action: slight flexion (mostly stable/isometric; minor flexion/extension adjustments)
trunk flexion (descent) / extension (ascent) with strong isometric anti-flexion demand
flexion (isometric to hold sandbag in Zercher position)

notes: Front-loaded Zercher position increases anterior moment arm, raising trunk-extensor and anterior core demand compared with a conventional RDL. Tabata (high-intensity interval) increases fatigue risk and can degrade hinge mechanics — emphasize neutral spine and hip-dominant movement. Watch for excessive lumbar flexion; adjust knee bend or load as needed.

reasoning: Primary movement is elbow flexion/extension (sagittal plane) against resistance — an upper-body pulling/isolation pattern. The exercise uniquely combines forearm rotation: typically a supinated curl concentrically (supination) and a pronated/neutral lowering (pronation) — transverse plane rotation at the radioulnar joint. Shoulders and scapulae act isometrically to stabilize the arm and maintain joint position; the wrist also requires stabilization. Muscles producing the elbow flexion are primary (biceps brachii, brachialis, brachioradialis) while supinator and pronator muscles control the forearm rotation. Rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (traps, rhomboids, serratus) provide isometric stabilization of the shoulder girdle.
notes: Typically performed with dumbbells (concentric supination, eccentric pronation). Classify as an isolation PULL with a distinct forearm rotation component; unilateral variations increase anti-rotation demands on the trunk/shoulder stabilizers.

reasoning: The Yoke Walk is a loaded walking task: the primary action is gait (repetitive hip, knee and ankle flexion/extension in the sagittal plane) while supporting a large axial load across the shoulder complex. Hip extensors (gluteus maximus, hamstrings) and knee extensors (quadriceps) generate propulsive force; plantarflexors (gastrocnemius/soleus) assist push-off. The spine and core act isometrically to resist flexion and maintain an upright trunk under compressive load, while the shoulder girdle (traps/scapular stabilizers) provides isometric support of the yoke. Stabilization demands are high (intra-abdominal pressure, erector spinae), but the primary pattern is loaded carry with locomotion mechanics.

joint_actions.action: isometric extension/stabilization (resists flexion and axial compression)
isometric support/scapular stabilization (load bearing, slight depression)

notes: Symmetric axial load across the shoulders makes this primarily a CARRY + LOCOMOTION pattern rather than anti-rotation. High compressive and shear forces on the spine require strong core bracing and often shorter stride/rigid posture. If load becomes asymmetric or unilateral yoke variations are used, include ANTI_ROTATION. Variants: heavy/short-distance focus maximal loading; longer walks emphasize gait economy and endurance.

reasoning: Primary joint actions are spinal axial rotation (twists) in the transverse plane and multi-joint hip motion (abduction and external rotation for hip-openers) primarily in the frontal/transverse planes. Downward dog and similar weight-bearing hand positions impose shoulder flexion/weight-bearing with scapulothoracic upward rotation and protraction/retraction demand — functionally a vertical push/stabilization pattern. Movement is primarily mobility-driven (dynamic rotation and hip opening) with secondary requirement for shoulder vertical load-bearing and scapular/axial stabilization. Muscles producing rotation include the external/internal obliques and paraspinals; hip abductors and external rotators produce hip opening; shoulder deltoids, serratus anterior and rotator cuff muscles produce/maintain the weight-bearing/pressing position. The core (multifidus, transverse abdominis, obliques) provides stabilizing/isometric control of the spine and pelvis during transitions.
primary_muscles: hip external rotators (piriformis, obturator internus, gemelli)
notes: Flow variability matters: some poses add single-leg work or isometric anti-rotation demands (would add ANTI_ROTATION). Loading is bodyweight and mobility-focused; patterns are dominated by spinal rotation and shoulder vertical load-bearing rather than classical strength patterns.

reasoning: Primary action is elbow flexion (sagittal plane) during the concentric curl and controlled elbow extension during the eccentric. The Zottman variation adds forearm rotation: concentric usually performed with supination (increasing biceps brachii contribution) and the eccentric performed with pronation (shifting load to brachialis/brachioradialis and forearm extensors). The preacher bench arm support minimizes shoulder/grip cheat and converts the movement into an isolated elbow/forearm pull. Shoulder and trunk act isometrically to stabilize the limb and bench position.
notes: Preacher bench support reduces involvement of shoulder girdle and torso, making this an isolation pulling pattern for elbow flexors. Variations: performed single-arm or with different grips; tempo and whether rotation occurs concentrically or eccentrically will shift relative muscle emphasis.
